BCS. Book Week was marked with a parade of students in Market Square, dressed as storybook characters.

Issue 176, 31 August 1994, page 9

Variety Club Bash. This year’s event raised $835,000 for charity. Local entry, Car 144, a 1960 Falcon, completed the course. The road north to Innamincka proved challenging. Penguin Books sponsored a vehicle driven by Richard Nitschke, formerly of Willogoleche.

Issue 176, 31 August 1994, page 11

Obituary. Gloria Dawn Read died on 29 August at Dawes Road Hospital. She was the wife of Brian Read and mother of Garry, Sue, John, Robert & Leanne.

Issue 177, 7 September 1994, page 1

The Burra-Morgan Road will have another 3 km of sealing completed at the Morgan end. Money has also been allocated for planning for the sealing of the rest and exploring for road-making materials. Funding has been approved for sealing the Spalding-Booborowie Road.

Burra Hospital Board is concerned that by mid-August they had no indication of the basis for deciding what the 1994-95 budget would be, let alone how much. The Board is reviewing the administration of the hospital following the resignation of John Chilton as CEO. In the interim Mrs Lesley Phillips, Director of Nursing will be the acting CEO.

Weather. Useful rain fell to the east over the weekend. Typical falls ranged from 18 mm at Redcliffe, Poonunda and Oakvale to 35 mm at Kia Ora. Burra recorded 10.4 mm.

Issue 177, 7 September 1994, page 2

Letter. Bob Skinner writes to thank the Arts Council for organising the concert by the New England Duo at the Old Courthouse. The lack of patronage for such well organised and high class events must be disappointing.

Letter. Maureen Wright responds to M. Campbell re Burra Passport costs.

At $30 for four people the passport costs $7.50 per person and includes a book that sells separately for $5. For an extra $3 per person entry to Morphett’s Enginehouse and the Bon Accord Museum can be obtained – representing a saving of 50%. Entrance to Sovereign Hill, Ballarat cost $15.50 per adult and to the Swan Hill Pioneer Settlement $10 per adult.

Issue 177, 7 September 1994, page 3

Editorial. The editor urges people to shop locally and to support local businesses.

Issue 177, 7 September 1994, page 6

Burra High School students and teachers from c. 1944 will hold a reunion at Westlakes Shore on Saturday 22 September at 7.30 p.m. – organisers Brian O’Reilly and Kaye Boulger.

Issue 177, 7 September 1994, page 8

CWA Warnes Group held its Group Exhibition Day at the Burra Town Hall on Monday. The Spalding Branch had the best display table. About 80 women attended.

Advt. Polly’s Tea Rooms

Mike & Leonie thank customers and suppliers for their patronage over the last two years and wish the new owner, Grace Delaney, every success.

Issue 178, 14 September 1994, page 1

Burra Hospital

Mrs Lesley Phillips has been appointed acting CEO with help from Clare Hospital on an ‘as needed’ basis, for an interim period of six months.

Mrs Cathy McPherson will take over as Director of Nursing. In the longer term consideration is being given to combining both roles with a consultant CEO from Clare Hospital as support.

The AGM on 30 August was well attended.

Mr John Brak, Mrs Judy Kellock and Mr Ron Thamm were elected as community consumer members. Mr Gordon Wooton was thanked for his five years of valued service to the board. Mr Brak was re-elected Chairman, with Mrs Colleen Woodgate as Vice-Chair.

Accident. An elderly woman was evacuated to Adelaide by helicopter on Saturday evening after a vehicle rollover on the Morgan Road some 30 km east of Burra.

Issue 178, 14 September 1994, page 3

Royal Adelaide Show

Rob Ashby of ‘Old Ashrose’ won Supreme Champion Merino or Poll Merino Exhibit.

Andrew McInnes of ‘Springbank’ won the state final of the Sheep Counting Competition and will represent SA in the national finals to be contested at Warren in NSW.

Kevin Schwartz of ‘Pindar’ won Reserve Champion Merino Ewe.

Issue 178, 14 September 1994, page 4

Burra Hospital. Some points from Chairman John Brak’s Annual Report:

The Health Towards 2000 Survey showed unanimous support for the retention of existing services.

The need to upgrade the Casualty & Theatre areas of the hospital was reinforced.

Increases were urged in Women’s Health Services and GP services – the need for a female GP to complement Dr Oswald’s service in Burra.

The development of a walk-in freezer/coolroom and a dry food storage area has been urged by senior staff.

The upgrading of the Casualty & Theatre areas has been helped by the bequest from the estate of the late Miss Agnes Seigert.

The Student Boarding Facility in the former Nurses’ Home has been an enormous success.

Issue 178, 14 September 1994, page 5

A Kapunda-Burra Wheelbarrow Push will be a feature of Burra’s J150 celebrations. It will take place over 21-22 January. The route will be via Tarlee and Riverton to Saddleworth on day 1 and then to Burra via Manoora on day 2. First prize is to be $1,000 and 2nd $500. There will be a maximum of 20 teams with six runners per team.

Burra’s J150 Souvenir Program & Calendar will be launched on Wednesday 21 September at the Burra Civic Centre by Mr Keith Johns, former Director of the Department of Mines & Energy and a descendent of the first mining captain Thomas Roberts. Copies will be available for $8.50 each.

Issue 178, 14 September 1994, page 6

The Veteran Car Club’s Diamond Jubilee Veteran Tour will meet in Burra on Sunday 18 September and will hold a series of runs based in Burra until 24 September, when many of the vehicles will then go on to take part in the Bay to Birdwood run on 25 September.

19 September Visits to historic Burra sites

20 September Saddleworth, Auburn, Martindale Hall and Sevenhill.

21 September A free day with lunch at Princess Royal

22 September Display of the vehicles on the Clare Oval and a run to Geralka Farm

23 September Run to Hallett, Cappeedee & Ulooloo with dinner in the Burra Town Hall.

Three of the participating cars were once owned by the Warnes Family of Woolgangi, including the oldest; a 1904 Wolseley.

[Photo of 1906 showing cars lined up in Burra for the run to Morgan. Pictured are: Mr Charles Warnes & Mr Woodfield (1904 Wolseley); Dr J. Sangster Jnr, Mrs Sangster with maid (De Dion); W.J. Richards (organiser) on his Richards motorcycle; L.W. Gebhardt with Mr & Mrs A. Gebhardt (Talbot) and then the motorcyclists: J. Richards, H. Scott, G.E. Dane, Mr Dearlove, S. Torr, G. Bartholomaeus and Mr Pearce.]

Issue 178, 14 September 1994, page 7

Heysen Trail Trek

About 40 women are walking the length of the trail. They travelled the last section into Burra by horse and wagon and stayed at Redruth Camp Centre over the weekend. Half of the group planted a total of 700 trees around Burra on Saturday and Sunday – 250 at the old charcoal pits as a woodlot for Paxton Cottages and 450 at the Showgrounds. The other half toured Burra sites. [In view of the Burra Burra DC report Issue 179, 21 September 1994, page 2 below the ‘charcoal pits’ would seem to refer to the slag paddock.]

Issue 179, 21 September 1994, page 1

‘Caroona’ owned by James Hawker, was sold by auction on Friday for $693,000. About 140 attended the sale at the Burra Civic Centre. The 12,945 ha property has frontages to Newikie and Witto Creeks and is largely rising hills with saltbush and mallee and is Perpetual Leasehold. The new owner is Geoff Davis.

The 1994 Veteran Car Club Rally saw more than 130 veteran cars in Burra last weekend.

Issue 179, 21 September 1994, page 2

The Young Trust – part of the National Trust SA, sent 12 members to Burra for the weekend of 9-11 September. They did volunteer work on some of the Burra Branch’s historic sites.

The MFS has been asked by Council to restrict its activities to the occupied area of the Burra Township, rather than the old Burra Corporation boundary. This includes the Princess Royal and some adjoining farmland.

[This is an odd statement as while the Princess Royal may have been within the area being served by the MFS in 1994, it was not within the old Burra Corporation boundary.]

Burra Burra DC has approved the planting of trees on the travelling stock route above the town oval and in the slag paddock and reserve adjacent to Burra Oval. Part of these plantings will be a woodlot for firewood for Paxton Square Cottages.

Issue 179, 21 September 1994, page 4

BCS. This week Year 10 students are looking at employment avenues on a visit to Adelaide.

Year 3 students went to Pt Augusta on a camp.

Natasha Burton has taken Libby Robinson’s place at Burra Stationers.

Jacobi Brenton is going to Alice Springs and her place will be taken by Rachael O’Connor of Burra.

Beth & Ralph Oakley have moved to Adelaide from Mt Bryan.

Birth. To Bev & Jim Low (former teachers at BCS), a son, Jack Angus.

Birth. To Peter & Heather Watkins (nee Alderson of Burra) at Katherine, a son.

Marriage. At Burra last Saturday

Anne-Marie Baldock of Booborowie married Jason Waldon of Blyth.

They will live in Sydney, where Jason is in the army.

Obituary. George Clark died 27 August and was buried at Hallett.

Obituary. Arthur Lewis of Hallett died at Burra on 9 September.

Obituary. Dorothy Reed, formerly of Burra, died in Adelaide 16 September.

Issue 179, 21 September 1994, page 5

The Old Swimming Pool Area

Burra Lions Club has presented the Burra Burra DC with a plan to redevelop this site as a picnic and barbecue area, with the work to be done in four stages. Council has accepted the plan.

Plant a lawn in the pool area, remove the chain wire fence on Market Street and provide ramp access for wheelchairs and pushers.

Open landscaped picnic area on the old buildings site.

Landscape the area between the pool and the motel.

Remove the eastern perimeter fence and landscape down to the Burra Creek.

Issue 179, 21 September 1994, page 9

Birth. To Philip & Anne Stolte (nee Jenkins) formerly of Mt Bryan on 15 September, a son, Sean.

Issue 180, 28 September 1994, MISSING from Burra Community Library hard copy files.

Issue 181, 6 October 1994, page 1

Burra Housing Development

The Kooringa CoHousing Co-operative plans to build 23 homes and a community centre on five acres of vacant land an Allen Street on the southern edge of Burra. The density will be c. 4 per acre, but instead of each being on a quarter acre block, they will cluster around a central building that will provide a community kitchen, laundry, lounge and playroom, leaving the rest of the site available for orchards, windbreaks, gardens and play space. This style of development has become popular in Scandinavia and the USA, but is the first of its kind in SA. It is funded mainly by the SA Government. The design includes solar heating. Co-op members do not own the houses, but have a lifetime security of tenure. The secretary of the Kooringa CoHousing is Colin Endean. Tree planting has begun on the site and funding for the first seven houses has been approved by the SA Co-operative Housing Authority.

Issue 181, 6 October 1994, page 2

Birth. To Maryann & Stephen Angel on Sunday 2 October, a daughter, Isabel Rose.

‘Scat’ an eleven piece jazz vocal ensemble from Queensland performed at the Burra Hotel. Their three 45-minute sessions gained rousing ovations. Their act included jazz, fusion, pop and swing offerings.

Lower North Community Health is sponsoring MOVE (Men Overcoming Violent Emotions) – a ten week course designed to encourage men who have difficulty with violence to move towards a more responsible and appropriate way of behaving.

Issue 183, 19 October 1994, page 1

Burra Hospital

Acting Hospital Board Chairperson Colleen Woodgate said a Service agreement between the Hospital and the Health Commission , due to be signed on 14 October, has not been signed and many letters seeking clarification have not been answered. The Hospital is seeking clarification on the allocated bed numbers and the ratio of private and public bed numbers.

The 1990 agreement allocated the 30 beds as 10 acute and 20 long stay nursing home type. At present there are 17 long stays in residence.

Funding has been allocated for 9 long stays and the resulting shortfall in funds would make running the Hospital quite difficult. Advice on Friday was that sections of the agreement were being redrafted. Mr Kerin MP has been advised that nursing home bed days have been marginally reduced as more nursing homes were being built. Burra’s doubling of long term patients in recent months has gone against this trend.

Ram Sales

East Bungaree has moved its sale site to be close to Collinsville’s, to the advantage of both studs. Bidding was strong, with buyers from across SA and interstate. 88 of 90 rams on offer were sold for an average of $641 and a top of $2,000. Seventy stud Merino ewes sold at an average $26.

Issue 183, 19 October 1994, page 2

Jean Kleinig has been canteen manager at BCS for many years, but has now left to work at Water’s Bakery, from which Ally Ashenden has moved to a part-time position at the National Australia Bank.

Sheep Counting Competitions

Rosemary Seaford won the sheep celebrity counting competition at the Burra Show.

Andrew McInnes won the sheep counting at the Royal Adelaide Show and has gone on to be placed second in the national finals at Warren in NSW.

Irene & Paddy Lonergan have moved from Burra to Adelaide after some years here.

Bishop David McCall conducted a confirmation service for three young people at St Catherine’s, Hallett, last Sunday.

Obituary. Helen Scott (formerly Jones), who ran the Kooringa Hotel for many years, has died in WA.

Issue 183, 19 October 1994, page 3

Burra Regional Art Gallery

A provisional Board of Management has been formed to establish the Burra Gallery at the Old Telegraph Station and Post Office building in Burra. Chairman is Judge Andrew Wilson. The Burra Burra DC has been asked to approve proposals outlined by the Board: to refurbish the building and to convert its use as a gallery and art museum. On the board are:

Tony Barker – farmer and Burra Burra DC member

Vincent Burke – former Marketing Manager of the Adelaide Festival Centre

Jan Davis – proprietor of Miss Mabel’s Cottage

Jojo Gebhardt – representative of the rural community

Andrew Gebhardt – former Burra Burra DC member and former Chairman of the Lewis Board (Paxton Square Cottages)

Susan Roche – Convenor of the Gallery Board and Committee.

Issue 183, 19 October 1994, page 5

Accident. A single vehicle rollover on the Black Springs-Robertstown Road on 12 October resulted in injuries to two people who were conveyed to Robertstown Hospital.

Issue 183, 19 October 1994, page 8

Collinsville Ram Sale

96 Merino rams were sold for an average $865.

24 Poll Merino rams averaged $1117.

One ram reached $4,500 and a poll ram reached $4,200.

There was a large crowd and of a total of 932 ewes sold the average price was $60.

Issue 183, 19 October 1994, page 9

Remnant Vegetation in the Burra Hills region will be the subject of a survey 23-30 October. The survey will cover remnant vegetation on private bushland outside national parks. This information is needed in determining which plant species are best suited for revegetation work and will be useful to Landcare and Greening Australia and will also aid in assessing fire hazards and fuel loads for bushfire management. Owners of land will receive a letter seeking permission for survey teams (a botanist and assistant) to enter land to collect data. The area to be surveyed ranges from Saddleworth to Booborowie in the east, the plains in the west, Eudunda in the south and Peterborough in the north. [East & west would seem to be the wrong way round.]

Issue 183, 19 October 1994, page 11

Birth. A Thank You Notice suggests: To Sally Murphy & Paul Fritz at Burra Hospital, a daughter, Ashleigh Jane.

Issue 184, 26 October 1994, page 1

AdChem

There is presently a glut of copper oxide on the world market and as a result the Burra operation will shed about eight jobs. The board has asked for charges to effect a saving of $1 million. The idea is to ensure the long term viability of the Burra plant. Cuts will affect both award based and staff positions. Production for the year will be around 15% below the previous year’s output. Since the suspension of concentrate treatment the company’s priority has been to obtain a lower cost source of raw materials. This has proved difficult and so other costs must be cut. From next month the operation of the cupric oxide plant will return to a 19 day shift cycle, reducing the shift teams from four to three. One person will also be cut from each shift team. A further cut of one person from the day shift relief team and from maintenance will also be needed.

Issue 184, 26 October 1994, page 2

A Disturbance at Terowie on Thursday last has resulted in a male person being charged with two counts of attempted murder.

Burra High School students who attended up to 1965 had a successful reunion at West Lakes last Saturday night.

Issue 184, 26 October 1994, page 3

Box Thorn eradication is a current priority around older homes and on pastoral properties. The most cost effective means of destruction would appear to be mechanical removal.

Redbanks Reserve

Redbanks has been a popular community recreation area for many years. After it became popular with motorbike riders and off road recreation vehicle users, a number of accidents led to the Government closing it in December 1992. It was then declared a Conservation, Recreation and Education Reserve under the control of the Burra Burra DC on 26 November 1993. The reserve was closed to the public pending a draft plan. Off road recreational vehicles will not be allowed back. The draft plan suggests:

The removal of feral animals

The prohibition of dogs and cats on the reserve

That horses be restricted to defined areas on a trial basis

The continuation of the ban on off road vehicles

The plan also addresses maintenance, visitor access and future management. The draft is available at the Council Office and public comment is invited.

Issue 184, 26 October 1994, page 5

Travis Thamm is captain of the SA team for the 5th National Prince Philip Mounted Games to be held at the Royal Melbourne Showgrounds on Sunday 30 October.

Mr V. Haddow & Ms M. Florence have been appointed Paxton Square Cottages managers from 28 November.

Issue 184, 26 October 1994, page 6

J150 Copper Trail Commemorative Walk

Groups of students from Mid North schools will walk the old Gulf road in May 1995 as they re-enact journeys made by miners from Burra to Kadina last century. The Copper Trail Commemorative Walk is planned to end at Kadina on the weekend of the Kernewek Lowender celebrations.

Issue 184, 26 October 1994, page 7

Swimming 1994-95

Booborowie swimmers will only be able to use the pool when a supervisor is present. Changes are in line with Education Department guidelines.

Hallett. The pool will be cleaned and the surrounds tidied on 6 November for an opening ‘splash’ on 13 November.

Burra. The Education Department and SACON have ordered an additional tank to correct the water balance problem and this should allow the plumbing to operate well. Rob Kerin MP will officially open the pool on 2 December.

BCS. The school production of Joseph and the Amazing Technicolour Dreamcoat was performed to packed houses at Burra Town Hall on Friday and Saturday. More than 180 people were in the choir and cast.

Louise Button played Joseph

John Cunningham was Jacob (Joseph’s father)

Luke Frahn was Potiphar

Geoff Schell was Pharaoh

The show was deemed a huge success. [Photo.]

Issue 185, 2 November 1994, page 2

Accident. A vehicle rolled over some 9 km south of Burra on the Barrier Highway on Saturday afternoon. A female from Mt Bryan was the sole occupant and was conveyed to the Burra Hospital with minor injuries.

The Baulderstone Family has taken over the Market Square Snack Bar.

Marriage. Burra Uniting Church next Saturday

Judy Stockman will marry Adrian Bruce. They will live at Hanson.

Obituary. Dorothy McMahon of Booborowie, wife of Jack McMahon, died recently.

Issue 185, 2 November 1994, page 4

Child, Adolescent & Family Health Service (CAFHS)

A group of parents and babies meet regularly to discuss mutual problems and issues. As a result they have resolved to form a Friends of CAFHS Group – an informal gathering of mums, dads and children to exchange ideas and experiences. The first meeting will be on 9 November at noon.

Harry Dighton will run a Cob b & Co. style stage coach from Market Square with routes varying from ten to fifty minutes. The first day of operations was yesterday, with a journey from Market Square to the Bon Accord Hotel. The coach was recently built in Melbourne by Cobb & Co. Horse Drawn Carriages, run by Ben Hall – a great grandson of the infamous bushranger.

Issue 185, 2 November 1994, page 5

Burra Community Library’s contribution to Burra’s J150 celebrations will be a research award of up to $1,000 for any [unpublished] research with a focus on Burra. Interests should be registered by the end of June 1995.

Burra Kindergarten will celebrate the International Year of the Family with a Family Fun Fair on Sunday 13 November, as its main fundraising event for 1994.

The Area Health Association publishes a questionnaire on the need for a hydrotherapy pool in the district.

Issue 186, 9 November 1994, pages 1 & 3

Eastern Districts Soil Conservation Board met for the first time in Burra on Friday. The aim of the Board is ‘to make landholders, the general public and Government aware of the nature and extent of land degradation, methods for its prevention and control, and their responsibilities in the use and management of the land.’

[Photo on page 1: Sonya Irwin (Balah), Dudley Cockington (Redcliffe), Bruce Lambie (Calpernum), Chris Reed (Bendigo & Council’s Representative), Vic Breeding (Braemar), David Lindner (Wonga) & Paul Williams (Sturtvale). Page 3 – a.]

Issue 186, 9 November 1994, page 2

Letter. Anthony Thorogood writes in response to a report of yellow orchids by the mine entrance. They are in fact Native Primroses – Goudenia. There are also white ones nearby. Another native in the district that looks like an orchid is the Native Leek with a long stem of yellow flowers. Other local native flowers include Billy Buttons, a Blue Bell, Poached Egg Daisies, Lambs Tails and Purple Calostemma – also Spear grass, Lomandra and native peas. (Not to mention flowering weeds.)

Issue 186, 9 November 1994, page 3

Regional Art Society Awards from the Jamestown Art Exhibition:

Moona Nookemba of Robertstown won 2nd prize, following a win at the Balaklava Art Exhibition

Glenys Christopher received a commendation.

Polly’s Café has a new courtyard dining area at the rear of the premises.

Gem & Mineral Fair. Andrew Overton has organised a gem and mineral fair in the Burra Show Hall for 3 & 4 December. As well as minerals and gems, machinery and metal detectors will be on show and the Burra Pistol Club will provide a barbecue.

12 in administration

7 in maintenance

Total 32

The Cottage Corner Store at Hallett is one year old. It sells arts and crafts and much more from places between Adelaide and Broken Hill.

Issue 188, 23 November 1994, page 2

Letter. Avian Pink writes on behalf of Mrs Stella Lihou seeking information about a 19th century ginger beer and cordial factory in Queen Street. It was opened in 1876 by Thomas Jones Monro, with Stephen Lihou as manager. Miss Stella Lihou is writing the family history and is seeking any information about the location of the factory – perhaps from land titles in Queen Street.

Issue 188, 23 November 1994, page 4

Burra Arts Council held its AGM recently and elected: President, Nicci Bernhard; Vice-President, Geoff Jenkins; Secretary, Georgia Hyde; Treasurer, Tony Statton and Publicity Officer, Rod Smith.

The new executive will aim for a more mainstream approach, hoping for a broader base of support from the Burra community.

Issue 188, 23 November 1994, page 5

Burra Hospital Auxiliary raised $2,368 from its Melbourne Cup Luncheon at the Burra Town Hall. The Day Care Trading Table raised $1,303. The Timestep Tappers entertainment group was well received. Proceeds will go towards the Cloud Comfort Mobile Chair.

Burra National Trust Branch held its AGM recently.

The Chair, Elizabeth Robertson said the year had been one of strategic planning and budgeting and redefining of the relationship with the Burra Burra DC. The year’s projects had included:

Painting Redruth Gaol

Preservation of historic garments by Artlab

Preliminary conservation work on Kotz Cottage following a conservation study of the site.

Installation of motion detectors and alarms at its properties

Freda and Avian Pink were thanked for their many years of service to the Clare and Burra branches of the National Trust, after the announcement that they would not stand for positions this year.

This year saw the introduction of individual site budgets, a capital budget and forward planning.

The plans for 1995 include:

Interpretation for Redruth Gaol

A Victoriana Picnic

Selected displays of the branch’s extraordinary wealth of archival artefacts

Elected were: Chair, Elizabeth Robertson; Vice-Chair, Maureen Wright; Secretary, Tim Horsnell; Assistant Secretary, Jenny Field and Treasurer, Joan de Metris.

Issue 188, 23 November 1994, page 8

Booborowie Primary School.

Eugene Madigan (Podge) has retired as groundsperson after years of service. Falling numbers using the school bus will see that service withdrawn in 1995. Enrolments in 1995 will however, be the highest for some years, with twelve coming into Reception. Enrolments should stay c. 33 for the next three years.

[Photo of Eugene Madigan with 27 students.]

Issue 189, 30 November 1994, page 1

BCS. Goyder House boarding facility. Mrs Rhonda Cooper, the inaugural supervisor of Goyder House has resigned after nearly two years in the position and will return to Adelaide to live. The new supervisors will be Peter and Maureen Heinrich, formerly from Karoonda, who took over on 25 November. Maureen is a former teacher and Peter a farmer. Currently there are nine students at Goyder House and a further six have been accepted for 1995. They come from isolated areas of SA and western NSW.

Burra Swimming Pool

The new Burra Community Pool will be officially opened next Friday at 2.30 p.m. by Rob Kerin MP. There will then be free swimming for all. The Lions Club will have their donut machine operating and canteen facilities will be available. Visitors can bring a barbecue and BYO (but NO glass). Early morning swimming will commence on 1 December.

Issue 189, 30 November 1994, page 2

The National Bank in Burra has extensions and renovations underway.

Burra Uniting Church Parish. After several months ministering here Rev. Jim Peacock has left to take up work in Adelaide. The Benns, Rev. Kel & Lorna, have been on long service leave overseas, but now return to resume work here.

The Kakoschke Family of Burra will soon move to the Sultanate of Oman, where Bart will be an air traffic controller. The two younger girls will go with their parents and the older children will continue their schooling in Alice Springs next year.

Marriage. Burra Uniting Church last Saturday

Amanda Nicholls married Darren Taylor.

Marriage. Recently

Chantelle Simpson, formerly of Mt Bryan, married Darren Hunt of Adelaide.

Issue 189, 30 November 1994, page 3

Sandra Kolar of Hove, SA, writes as a visitor, saying Burra was a lovely town, but wondering how the sickening smell of creosote soaked logs is permitted in the centre of town.

Issue 189, 30 November 1994, page 4

Burra Burra DC. A pop-up sprinkler system will soon be installed for the creek bank gardens.

Burra Cemetery. Restoration work on old headstones has been continued, with some returned to the old section of the cemetery. The old gazebo [Mortuary Chapel] has been painted.

Issue 190, 7 December 1994, MISSING from Burra Community Library hard copy files.

Issue 191, 14 December 1994, page 1

Burra Hospital

The Health Commission has approved funding for only 9 of the 20 long stay beds and a hospital delegation met with the Minister of health Michael Armitage last week to try to solve this anomaly. There are currently 17 long term patients. Dr Armitage refused to budge until being embarrassed by the Health Department’s own apparent preparedness to fund up to 20. He then conceded to increase the funding from 9 to 11.9 patients, but refused to give any advice on the funding of the other 5.1 patients. Written confirmation is now awaited.

Craig Wissell of Burra has been announced as ICI Cropcare’s SA Dealer of the Year. The prize is an expense paid overseas study tour of 7-10 days. [Photo.]

Issue 191, 14 December 1994, page 2

BCS. Reception to Year 2 students spent a day in Adelaide a couple of weeks ago.

Birth. To Alby & Rosemary Graham (nee Hogan) recently, a daughter, Alice.

Obituary. Mavis Wall died suddenly on 3 December.

[Born Mavis Webb and married John Malcolm Wall in 1945. Buried at Burra 7 December 1994 aged 68.]

Obituary. Ross Irlam died at North Adelaide on 30 November aged 67.

[Ross Stuart Irlam, born 11 September 1927 at Robertstown.]

Issue 191, 14 December 1994, page 4

Burra Regional Art Gallery has been awarded a grant of $36,490 for refurbishment of the former Post & Telegraph Office.

Vandalism at Burra Cemetery saw about $2,000 damage to headstones over the weekend of 3-4 December.

Break-ins in the last week were reported from Burra Silos where two shovels and a wheelbarrow were taken and from Leighton Cricket Club rooms. Here c. 60 cans of soft drink were stolen and damage worth c. $100 was done to the locked fridge.

World Geo Science Corporation of WA had a light aircraft flying low over Burra on Friday whilst carrying out a geophysical survey.

Issue 191, 14 December 1994, page 5

Burra Hospital Auxiliary has recently provided more than $8,000 for two Recovery Trolleys for the new Casualty area and a Cloud Comfort Chair.

Issue 191, 14 December 1994, page 6

Sue & Peter Ryan, Kirsty & Matthew are leaving Burra for Lameroo in 1995 after a number of years in this district.

The Frahn Family: Roger, Sabina, Luke, Danika and Tahnee are moving to Eudunda.

BCS. Staff moves:

Helen Mysior goes to Paringa Park P.S.

Karl Pope moves to Flaxmill in the Morphett vale area.

Kathy Misso looks likely to be at Booborowie next year.

The locations for Helen Wurst, Wendy Richards and Geoff Woolford are as yet uncertain.

Birth. To Richard & Sharon Irlam at Clare on 26 November, a son, Tyson Richard.

Marriage. At Mt Barker on Saturday

Karl Pope (of BCS) will marry Rachel Lovegrove.

Marriage. Beechwood Garden in the Adelaide Hills on 14 January 1995

Paul Elsegood will marry Gavin Turner. [Sic: for Paula Elsegood.]

Issue 191, 14 December 1994, page 7

Marriage. Burra Uniting Church, 26 November

Amanda Jane Nicholls married Darren James Taylor, both of Burra.

Wedding photos at Hampton ruins were followed by a reception at Burra Town Hall. The couple will live at Burra. [Photo.]

Issue 191, 14 December 1994, pages 8-12

A Review of the Year 1994

Burra’s Main Street Program was outlined to a meeting of c. 40 people. A survey was undertaken to obtain suggestions. A grant of $20,000 was received from the State Government for the employment of a co-ordinator. The Burra Burra DC released a draft street tree policy.

New Swimming Pool. Progress continued on the replacement pool, with the official handover to the District Council from the contractor on 1 March. The usual school swimming carnival had to be abandoned.

The Season. The first four months yielded only 19.8 mm with no rain at all in March or April. Good rains in June enable seeding to be completed. (119 mm in Burra) August had a cold snap with snow at Mt Bryan, Hallett and Whyte Yarcowie, but more rain fell in early September.

Burra Jubilee 150 plans are well in hand for 1995.

Leonie Fretwell is co-ordinator.

A calendar to publicise the year has turned out very well.

Burra sticker sheets and a special Burra postmark have become reality.

Burra Community Print will publish souvenir issues of the old Burra Record.

Merino Field Days

54 studs took part in March.

Close to 700 people went to Burra Oval for the judging of the Merino Capital Champion Ram and Champion Pair awards.

Koomooloo Field Day attracted 35 suppliers and 200 spectators.

At Collinsville sales a Merino ram sold for $4,500 and a Poll Merino ram for $4,200.

96 rams brought an average of $865 and 24 Poll Merino rams averaged $1,117.

The East Bungaree sale averaged $641 for 88 rams with a top price of $2,000.

Tourism Restructuring

Burra’s management of tourism resources has seen changes in 1994.

Council has taken over direct responsibility for the Tourist Office, Paxton square Cottages, the Mine Museum and the Caravan Park from committees.

A committee of seven councillors will act as the Council Tourism Resource Committee to promote Burra as a tourist destination, in conjunction with the National Trust, the Regional Tourist Association and Burra Traders’ Association.

A Burra Tourism Executive Officer has been appointed to oversee this work.

Riley Rally. More than 100 Riley cars came to Burra for the club’s annual Riley Rally.

Burra Hospital

In April there was a 48% response to a survey of the Hospital’s needs. It identified the top four needs as:

A female GP to complement the services of the town’s male GP

A women’s health clinic

An additional male GP

An up-grade of the accident and emergency department

Problems were compounded with the introduction pf the Casemix system of funding in July.

When CEO John Chilton resigned the Board employed a consultant firm to undertake a review and in the interim Mrs Lesley Phillips was made acting CEO.

Schools

The Northeast Combined School Sports Days was hosted in April by Hallett. C. 140 children from Mt Bryan, Booborowie, Spalding and Hallett Primary Schools took part.

BCS staged the musical Joseph and the Amazing Technicolour Dreamcoat by Andrew Lloyd Webber in October.

The old Mt Bryan East school building was renovated for walkers on the Heysen and Mawson Trails.

New Housing. Kooringa CoHousing Co-operative intends to build 23 homes and a community centre in Burra over the next few years.

Radio 5BCS. Thursday 5 May was test broadcast day for BCS’s own radio station, 5BCS.

Cricket. Burra were premiers for the third year in succession in the Belalie-Mokota Cricket Association.

Darren James’s 105 n.o. was a highlight and he featured in the new season in October as well with a quick 110 followed by 115, this season playing for the rejuvenated Leighton Cricket Club.

Mid North Games.

As part of the Games, Burra hosted the Little Athletics in April, when 200 children attended from 21 clubs, including 13 Adelaide clubs, 2 from Sale, Victoria and others from many SA Towns. The Chess Tournament was held in the Burra Civic Centre 16-17 April and was the first time for many years that an SA Chess title event has been held outside Adelaide.

Local Exhibitions.

The Annual Antique & Decorating Fair was held at Burra Town Hall.

Burra Arts Council’s 2nd Art Exhibition had works from 18 artists, including 10 from Burra and drew more than 600 visitors in the first weekend in May.

Burra Arts Council and the Burra Burra DC put in a submission for funding to refurbish the former Post & Telegraph Office as a Regional Art Gallery.

Terowie established a Pioneer Gallery with more than 1,000 photographs.

The Burra Show Society is trying to boost the number of exhibitors.

New Businesses.

Peter & Jane Strawbridge – Doll Display & Blacksmithing in May.

Glenis Carpenter – lingerie shop G.J. Creations in April.

Burra Supermarket – Tom & Kaye Boulger returned in November to manage it again after having run it from 1973 to 1988.

Grace Delaney is the new owner of Polly’s Tea Rooms.

Royal Adelaide Show.

Local Merino breeder Rob Ashby of ‘Old Ashrose’ won Supreme Champion Exhibit for Merino or Poll Merino.

Andrew McInnes won the final of the sheep counting competition.

Adchem. An announcement in February foreshadowed the loss of 46 jobs. Staff at Burra is now down to 32. General Manager Mark Woodford says the changes were made in the interests of ‘long term viability’.

CWA. 80 women from 11 CWA Branches from Spalding to Riverton gathered in Burra for the Warnes Group Exhibition Day. Hallett CWA held a September fashion parade with an attendance of 50.

Special Interest groups in Burra include Burra Arts Council, Heartbeat (a support group for those with heart conditions), Dog Obedience Club, Pony Club, Gardening Group, Young Trust, Day Care, Senior Citizens and a hundred more in the district.

Burra was the venue for the Sporting Car Club’s Diamond Jubilee, when more than 130 cars visited.

Travis Thamm was chosen captain of the SA Team for the 5th National Prince Philip Mounted Games in Melbourne in October.

Issue 191, 14 December 1994, page 12

Hallett Dc farewelled Clarrie Martin, who has been employed as plant operator since 13 January 1964.

Issue 192, 21 December 1994, page 1

Maureen Bevan was accorded a Civic Function on 8 December to honour her contribution and commitment to the management of Paxton Square Cottages over the past decade. She and her late husband Bryan, were appointed as managers soon after the Bridge Terrace row was restored in 1983. They saw the complete square restored and made available for holiday accommodation.

Andrew Gebhardt, who was a former Chairman of the Lewis Board, commended Maureen and Bryan for their work. When work started it was thought a 40% occupancy rate was needed to service the loan. A staggering 80% rate was achieved and that paved the way to proceed with restoration.

Robyn Page, immediate past Chairman of the Lewis Board, endorsed Andrew’s remarks and described the Bevans as hard working, caring and kind and they achieved a State Tourism Award, which gave Paxton Square national exposure. Maureen had continued alone after the death of her husband – with the help of her family.

Council Chairman Graham Kellock presented Maureen with a plaque, a certificate and a basket of flowers.

Maureen responded. [Photo.]

Issue 192, 21 December 1994, page 2

The Gem & Mineral Fair drew a crowd of some 400 over the weekend. Organiser Andrew Overton was pleased with the result, but thought more would have attended had it not been so hot.

Accident. A single vehicle rollover on the Burra-Morgan Road on Saturday saw no serious injuries, but the vehicle, a Ford Festiva, was written off.

Issue 192, 21 December 1994, pages 3 & 15

BCS Speech Night was held last Thursday. Guest speakers were Mr Steve Ramsey from the Department of the Family and Mrs Sue Twelftree from Urania.

Alf Puckridge Science Award Adam Lomman

Sports Award Sheridan Coad

Ron Thamm School & Community Award Sheree Jones

All Rounders Award Alan Pearce

BCS High Achievers Award Karen Jennings

[Other awards are listed.]

Issue 192, 21 December 1994, page 4

The Burra Bash Boys will enter a car for the 3rd year running in the Variety Club Bash for 1995. The crew will comprise Peter Nesbitt, Andrew Nourse, Richard Dollman and Rob Blott of Gawler. There will be a ‘new’ car for 1995 – a 1964 EH Holden Stationwagon.

Burra Market on 14 December saw a yarding of 17,000 sheep.

Issue 192, 21 December 1994, page 5

The Kooringa Hotel has been given a State Heritage Fund grant to help with conservation work including painting, upgrading of stonework and repairs to the top balcony.

[Photo of Warwick Digby of Kooringa Hotel and Douglas Alexander, Heritage advisor.]

Issue 192, 21 December 1994, page 6

Birth. To Jim & Kathy Nunn at Burra on 2 December, a son, Daniel James.

Birth. To Mark Turner & Carla Edwards at Burra Hospital last Friday, a daughter.

Issue 192, 21 December 1994, page 7

KESAB has recognised the Senior Citizens for their work in maintaining garden areas along the creek.

[Photo of Len Hentschke, Shirley Broad, Sue Hentschke and Laurel Neill.]

Issue 192, 21 December 1994, page 8

Rick Williams, works manager for Burra National Trust, was digging a post hole at the Bon accord Mine site when the shovel disappeared down the hole. He discovered some stone foundations and a twenty foot deep shaft, which was partly undermining a section of Linkson Street. It will be further investigated, but is thought to be Dickson’s Shaft. A number of shafts are believed to exist on the site, though none of them bore copper ore.

Issue 192, 21 December 1994, page 12

Burra Red Cross ended the year’s fundraising with a Luncheon Trading Table and Christmas Tree Gifts. They raised $480.85. The branch has given $361.21 to the local St John’s Ambulance Service, which will put it towards a Heart Start 3000 defibrillator.

Issue 192, 21 December 1994, page 15

Obituary. Dudley O’Brien died last week. He was born in Burra in 1923 and lived here all his life. He was sent to Largs Bay Orphanage after his mother died when he was only young. He worked for Wally Webb at Willalo, served in New Guinea in WWII and then worked for the District Council and the Burra Corporation for many years. [Dudley Bruce O’Brien, born 14 July 1923 at Kooringa. Died at Burra 13 December 1994.]

Issue 193, 11 January 1995, page 1

J150 Update

The Kapunda-Burra Wheelbarrow Push has been cancelled.

Expressions of interest are sought from those interested in being part of the first Art & Craft Exhibition 19-20 August.

The first activity is underway – a photographic exhibition ‘Four Way Focus’ at Kookaburra Woolshed – featuring Car Art.

An exhibition of landscapes by local photographer Dick Cleland runs till 26 January.

Beginning 12 January Burra’s own commemorative postmark is available.

Issue 193, 11 January 1995, pages 1 & 2

Accident. A semi-trailer loaded with groceries overturned on 19 December 1994 and ended up in Richard Rigg’s paddock. The manager of Hi-Speed Transport has since sent cheques totalling $1,000 to the local volunteer organisations that helped with the clean-up. The rollover occurred 10 km north of Burra on the Barrier Highway. The driver escaped with a broken hand. [Photo.]

Issue 193, 11 January 1995, page 2

Vandalism. A female juvenile has been reported for damage to headstones at Burra Cemetery.

Accident. A rollover occurred on the Farrell Flat-Mintaro Road on the night of 6 January.

Issue 193, 11 January 1995, page 4

Jodi Lomman, formerly of Mt Bryan has a job with Unley Council after a successful traineeship there.

Vandalism. The Council is concerned about a rash of vandalism to roadside signs, guide posts, toilets, barbecues, headstones and the theft of hazard lights and star droppers from road construction sites – all are a cost to the community.

Birth. To Jill & Terry Wilson at Pinnaroo on 2 January, a son, Harley Robert. [Photo page 6.]

Birth. To Paula & Garry Illicevs, ‘just in time for Christmas’ a daughter, Paige Lee.

Birth. To Lisa & Mark Brooks of Hallett on 31 December, a son, William Robert Tiver.

[Photo Issue 194, 18 January 1995, page 5.]

Obituary. Di Day’s father died just before Christmas.

Obituary. Ros Drew’s mother died 31 December after a short illness.

Issue 193, 11 January 1995, page 6

Birth. To Patricia & David Croucher of Hallett on 20 December, a daughter, Deanne Alyce. [Photo.]

Birth. To Andrew & Christine Robinson on 18 December, a daughter, Stephanie Lee.

Issue 193, 11 January 1995, page 8

Weather. Burra’s rainfall for 1994 totalled 271 mm, which was well short of the average of 450 mm.

Issue 194, 18 January 1995, page 1

Weather. Last Saturday Burra and Districts were deluged with more than 100 mm of rain. Leighton and Gum Creek areas reported falls of more than 150 mm. Stock had to be rescued from floodwaters.

In Burra more than 25 mm fell in a 15 minute period and the creek past the Burra Hospital flooded down Commercial Street, where water entered premises along the south side from Dollman’s Garage to Elders. Other shops and houses on Commercial, Thames and Chapel Streets also sustained water damage.

At various times the Burra-Morgan and the Burra-Robertstown roads were closed and the Barrier Highway was cut at Burra, Mt Bryan floodway and south of Hallett. The SES and DRT workers made a great effort. [Photos pages 1 & 8.]

Issue 194, 18 January 1995, page 2

The Potts Family is moving to Gladstone soon, where Jim will be in BankSA there.

Birth. To Julie & Alexander MacLachlan on 12 January, a son, Alexander Patterson John.

Obituary. Molly Baird, well known in Burra many years ago as Molly Walker, died recently in Pt Lincoln.

Issue 194, 18 January 1995, page 3

Letter. Dick Cleland write re the refurbishment of the Mt Bryan East School. He is glad to have taken before and after photos – though wishes that the render had been preserved, rather than removed.

[The context seems to imply that the render should have been preserved as an original feature of the building. In fact the school was not originally rendered and presumably the render was added when the school was repaired at some point. Its removal and repointing of the stone work would thus have been restoring the original nature of the exterior.]

SES honoured Des James recently for his 14 years of service – 12 of them as Group Controller.

Burra Railway Turntable. There have been whispers that Peterborough was eying off the Burra Turntable. State Heritage Branch has indicated opposition to the removal of any of Burra’s railway infrastructure.

Issue 194, 18 January 1995, page 4

Burra Motor Inn. Bob & Lorraine Howell took over the reins of the motel last week. Bob has previously been an ANZ Bank manager, working at Bordertown, Clare and Manoora.

Issue 194, 18 January 1995, page 5

Burra J150 Postmark. Photo of Brian Hastelow, manager of Burra Post Office and Leonie Fretwell, J150 co-ordinator, with a souvenir envelope.

Australia Day Breakfast. Burra Burra DC has provided $2,000 towards the event, which will again be organised by the Burra Traders’ Association. Local Federal MP Barry Wakelin will present the Australia Day awards.

Issue 194, 18 January 1995, page 6

Burra Rainfall Records from 1930 to 1994 are printed, showing monthly and annual totals.

Issue 194, 18 January 1995, page 7

Learn to Swim Campaign has been run last week and this at Burra Pool.

Issue 195, 25 January 1995, page 1

Hallett’s Citizen of the Year is Mrs June Honan.

She was born in Peterborough about 60 years ago and married John Honan in 1956, and has been a productive and dedicated member of the community. She was a founding member of the Hallett CWA, in which she has held many executive positions as well as being President of the Branch and Group and has currently been nominated for Divisional President. She has just been granted life membership of the CWA. June has also been a hard working member of the Hallett Red Cross for many years and an active member of the Hallett Hall Committee. She has a tremendous capacity for fundraising. In the early years of her marriage she was very active on committees serving the Whyte-Yarcowie and Jamestown schools. June is an Elder of the Uniting Church and President of the Hallett & Jamestown Fellowship and a founding member of the Hallett & District Historical Society.

Issue 195, 25 January 1995, pages 1 & 3

J150 Events

The National Trust has the first of its J150 displays on show in BankSA, based on ‘Sport & Recreation.

Street banners produced for Burra’s J150 will adorn the town for 1995.

Burra Tennis Club will hold its ‘In Cellar Cool’ event on 18 February, featuring a jazz band and mini disco in the Unicorn Brewery Cellars.

St Mary’s Church will stage a Flower Festival 24 & 25 February.

The great, great, great, great, granddaughter of Richard Trevithick, inventor of the Cornish beam Engine visited Burra on Monday.

On the same day a great nephew of Sir Frederick Holder visited Burra.

Issue 195, 25 January 1995, page 3

Burra Burra DC

Council has refused the J150 Committee’s request to place a sign on the railway bridge on Watt Road on the advice of the Heritage Advisor.

Council will repair two vandalised headstones at the cemetery.

Council will fence a stand of the rare Acacia glandulicarpa in the Gum Creek area.

John Cole of Outdoor Adventure Skills was given approval for abseiling on Wednesday 8 February in the Aberdeen Ballast Quarry.

Council has no objections to Clare Taxi Service operating a taxi in Burra.

Issue 195, 25 January 1995, page 7

Graham Kellock is Burra’s Citizen of the Year

He was born in Burra in 1942 and is a fourth generation Burra resident. Graham was educated by correspondence and at Burra Primary and High Schools. He is a farmer with interests in the Kelvale Poll Merino Stud. He has been involved in many of the districts organisations including:

Rural Youth – member, President 1960-61 & adviser

Burra Community & Sports Club – foundation member & President for four years

Burra School Councillor and Chairman of the Agriculture Committee

Burra Show Society – member for 36 years and President for two.

Burra Football Club – a past player, Captain of the ‘B’ Grade and one-time President

Farrell Flat Football Club – past player and President 1964

Burra Picnic Races – supporter since inception

Old Burra Swimming Pool – helped with construction

Burra Burra DC – Councillor since 1985, Deputy Chairman 3 years and Chairman 5 years

Mid North Regional Development Board – member and Chairman

Mid North Local Government Association Executive Committee Member

Burra Bowling Club – member and on committee

Member of the Redbanks Committee

Member of the Merino Capital Committee

Member of the Committee for Back to Burra schools for J150

Issue 195, 25 January 1995, page 8

Burra Burra DC is seeking $105,000 from the Open Space Program and Greening Urban SA Project. Council is proposing to contribute $77,000. The money would upgrade the creek area opposite Paxton Cottages with lawns, car parking, shelters and barbecues.

Burra Event of the Year 1994 is the catering for the Riley Motor Club of Australia’s National Rally over Easter.

Issue 195, 25 January 1995, page 9

Les Smale has been appointed Controller of Burra SES following the resignation of Des James.

Burra Arts Council’s ‘Four Way Focus’ Exhibition at Kookaburra concludes on Australia Day:

George Vrastaminos – series of classic cars in acrylic

Stephen Richardson – silver gelatine prints on abstract themes

Dieter Hauptmann – scientific microscape of crystals in polarised light

Dick Cleland – local and Australian landscapes in black and white.

Issue 195, 25 January 1995, page 11

Notice. The Minister for Health, Hon Dr Michael Armitage will open the upgraded casualty facilities at Burra Burra Hospital on Sunday 12 February at 10 a.m.

Issue 196, 1 February 1995, page 1

J150 Update

ETSA has sponsored the illumination of the creek area for the rest of 1995.

The J150 medallion is available for $15.50 from the Council Office.

The Flower festival at St Mary’s Church 24 & 25 February will also feature a display of tapestry kneelers and organ music by Jan Cockington, Judith Neale and David Gallasch.

Issue 196, 1 February 1995, pages 1, 4 & 7

Australia Day Breakfast

The J150 Chair, Mrs Robyn Page launched the Jubilee 150 year.

The breakfast was sponsored by the Burra Burra DC and organised by members of the Burra Traders’ Association. Council Deputy Chairman Mr John Quinn introduced special guests and welcomed the crowd of about 350. Mr Barry Wakelin Federal MP for Grey presented the Citizen of the Year Award to Graham Kellock and Daphne Lines accepted the Certificate for Event of the Year on behalf of the cratering group for the Riley Car Club Visit. Mr Wakelin also cut the Australia Day Cake prepared by Colleen Spackman. Members of the bush band, the Wild Matildas who were staying at Paxton Cottages, supplied music for the breakfast.

[Page 7 photo: caterers group; Wild Matildas; Bob & Joanne Simpson with Jane Strawbridge; and Graham Kellock & Mrs Daphne Lines with Mr Barry Wakelin MP.]

Issue 196, 1 February 1995, page 2

Theft. The coke machine at BCS was ripped open on 25 January and drinks were stolen. The wall clock at the Burra Pool was stolen on the same night.

Accident. A car rollover on the Burra-Morgan Road on 29 January resulted in two people being taken to the Burra Hospital with minor injuries.

BCS. New staff for 1995:

John Agnew (Agriculture)

Naomi Clare (French)

John Phillips (Technology)

Sarah Rainbow (Primary)

[A photo on page 3 adds Helen Wurst (Years 5/6).]

Geraldine Smedley has the position of Itinerant Teacher this term, to visit isolated children regularly.

Scott Scholz, son of Sue & Michael, has been accepted into a Mining Engineering course. His brother Michael qualified in the same area and is working with Western Mining in WA.

Issue 196, 1 February 1995, page 5

Les Smale & Ric Williams were accredited in the Land search Operations Course recently held at Melrose. Burra currently has members accredited in vertical rescue, road accident rescue, light rescue, air search, heavy rescue and land search.

Residents of Burra will be offered a free passport for J150. As part of the offer visitors, friends, guests and relatives of residents can get a passport for $5 each for the duration of 1995.

Issue 196, 1 February 1995, page 6

Burra National Trust has agreed to spend $12,000 on improving Trust heritage sites in Burra:

$3,000 painting the outside of the Market Square Museum.

$4,000 maintenance and repainting of the Courthouse.

$5,000 on signage and interpretive displays.

Issue 197, 8 February 1995, page 1

BCS. Year 12 results were good with most Year 12 students gaining entry to a University, a Business College Course or TAFE. Natalie Jennings and Sheree Jones gained perfect scores in Typing.

Natalie Jennings – University of SA

Sheree Jones – a career in Office Administration

Sheridan Coad – A Banking & Finance Course

Karen Jennings – a Physical Education Teaching Course

Allan Pearce – a BA at Magill Campus

Daniel Neill & Adam Lomman – Agricultural Production at Roseworthy Campus

Donna Clapp – B. Ed. At Flinders University

Belinda Sichler – Tourist & Hospitality at TAFE

Matthew Opperman, Rob Gill, Christie McCann, Christian White and Bianca Dunstan have all gained employment.

Issue 197, 8 February 1995, page 3

Burra Yacht Club is planning a regatta for 5 March. There will be a procession from Barkers Homes at 10 a.m. to the lawns by the creek, followed by a full day of racing. Regulations are strict: the yachts must have a maximum size of 2 m x 2 m, a minimum crew of 2 and the yacht must carry at least 1 m2 of sail and be powered by the crew. [There will also be dragon boat races.]

There will also be on shore activities, stalls and activities for children.

Burra Community Library is offering a prize of up to $1,000 for previously unpublished research into the History of the Burra area. The publication should be between 3,000 and 12,000 words. Registrations of interest by 28 February.

Issue 197, 8 February 1995, page 9

Burra Girl Guides, Kylie Kaiser & Carly Phillips attended ‘Making Waves’, an international Girl Guide camp in Tasmania 30 December 1994 to 7 January 1995, with about 1,000 Guides from 20 Asia-Pacific countries. It was held at Roches Beach some 25 km south of Hobart.

Issue 197, 8 February 1995, page 11

Timothy Horsnell of Leighton Management Consultants, has been appointed ‘Main Street’ Co-ordinator.

Issue 198, 15 February 1995, page 1

Burra Hospital

The Minister for Health, Michael Armitage opened the upgraded casualty area on Sunday morning at 10 a.m. He said the upgrade would help the hospital gain accreditation. The upgrade was completed on time and under the $24,000 budget. The project was helped by a bequest of $58,000 from the estate of the late Agnes Seigert. [Photo.]

Issue 198, 15 February 1995, page 2

The Rotunda in Market Square is getting a new coat of paint. ́

Nic Lamont, formerly of Burra has finished his studies at Teachers College and is teaching Technical Studies at Pulteney Grammar School.

Greg Secomb has completed his degree course at Roseworthy and is job hunting.

The North Eastern Division SES Unit Controllers’ Conference was conducted at the Burra Community Centre on Sunday 12 February.

‘Sugar ’n’ Spice – formerly Price’s Bakery, is being redecorated. They have added goods from Balfours, Villis and Linkes in the Barossa to the Price’s Bakery lines.

‘Picketts’ – formerly Polly’s Café, is being redecorated and has had a successful launch night.

Issue 198, 15 February 1995, page 3

Burra Art Gallery

Burra Burra DC bought the old Post & Telegraph Office building last year for $130,000. The State Government has helped launch stage 1 of the redevelopment with a cheque of $36,490 that was handed over by Rob Kerin MP recently.

Thefts. Four persons have been arrested by Riverton Police following a series of break-ins in Burra:

Vehicles in St Just Street

Baulderstone’s Fruit & Vegetable Store

Off Beat Art & Craft shop

The shed at the rear of Peter’s Meat Service

Issue 198, 15 February 1995, page 4

Bob Heath’s insurance property management service has been bought by Neil Page & David Evans. Sally Richardson, who has been clerk for R.A. Heath Agencies, will move across the road with the business. The other half of the business – D & M Real Estate – has been bought by Knappsteins of Clare.

Bob will continue in real estate with D & M Real Estate’s Rural Property Division, based in Gawler.

[2 photos.]

Issue 198, 15 February 1995, page 5

ANZ Burra has won the quarterly customer service award for the third time in 1994. Debbie Emery has transferred to Loxton and the new employee is Karen Schell. [Photo.]

Tourism. The first joint brochure of the Mid North and Yorke Peninsula tourism regions will be launched today at the Bon Accord Museum.

BCS. The year promises to be busy:

The old Kooringa Building will be given a facelift – hopefully during the holiday at the end of term 1.

Almost $200,000 will be spent by the end of June on overdue maintenance – mostly painting.

Shade areas will be erected.

5BCS now has a radio studio.

Issue 198, 15 February 1995, page 7

Hallett Primary School Council has written a strongly worded letter to Rob Lucas, Minister of Education & Children’s Services, outlining the ‘lack of understanding and support shown by the Department and Members of Parliament’ during recent events surrounding the removal of the school bus service. At the time the bus was one child short of the number required for retention and a simple rerouting would have given sufficient numbers to keep it going – the family in question was incorrectly located on Departmental maps, making them seem closer to the Burra Secondary School bus. Now parents are being encouraged to remove children from Hallett because Burra’s secondary School buses are being made available to pick up Primary students.

[The article goes on to mention dissatisfaction with the headmaster and with the District Superintendent and the process of selecting a new headmaster. The Council feared the school was being undermined so that it could be closed, despite reassurances that this was not so.]

Issue 199, 22 February 1995, page 1

AFTA Fair. Burra was the only town represented by its own stand at the Australian Federation of Travel Agents’ Fair at the Exhibition Centre, North Terrace, Adelaide.

[Photo and details of staffing are given.]

Issue 199, 22 February 1995, page 2

Writers’ Workshop. The J150 Committee is co-ordinating a Writers’ Workshop to be run by well-known poet and writer and ex-Burra boy, Frank McMahon. He spent most of the 1930s as a boy in Burra and over the last 15 years has written extensively about the town and surrounding districts. He will hold a one-day workshop on Thursday 23 March. Cost $30 and limited to 12 people. Registrations of interest are required by 27 February with the J150 Co-ordinator.

Issue 199, 22 February 1995, page 3

The World Day of Prayer (Formerly Women’s World Day of Prayer) will be held in Burra at St Mary’s Anglican Church on Friday 3 March commencing at 10.15 a.m. This year’s speaker will be Barbara Devenport.

The Launch of Hit the Trail, the new tourism brochure for Yorke Peninsula and the Mid North at the Bon Accord Museum on 15 February is reported. [Photo of John Evans, State Marketing Manager of SA Tourism Commission with the brochure.]

Issue 199, 22 February 1995, page 6

BCS. Championship Swimming Carnival was held at the new Community Pool on 14 February after heats the previous Wednesday. The house competition was won by Jennison with 409 points from Steele 3781⁄2 and Riggs 3271⁄2. Photo of Champions:

U14 Boy Ben Dolphin

Peter & Margaret Rankine of Hallett will in future offer tours in the Burra District and trips from Burra to the Northern Festival Centre in Pt Pirie and possibly monthly shopping trips to Adelaide.

Issue 200, 1 March 1995, page 1

Burra-Morgan Road. Only one kilometre will be sealed this year, but a large part of the whole contract will be let in the 1995-96 financial year and all is expected to be finished by July 1999. The section through the Burra Hills will have extensive realignment.

Five UK Farmers spent last Friday night with a group of locals from Hallett, Mt Bryan and Burra at Tooralie Homestead, sharing information on the latest changes in agriculture.

Issue 200, 1 March 1995, page 2

Letter. Lionel M. Young L.Th., JP of Mowll Village, Castle Hill, NSW writes with some reminiscences.

He was presently 92 and his father was Joseph Hawkins Checcuci Young, born in Burra 27 November 1868 and his mother was Alice Ada Clode born 16 November 1869. He was related to the Woollacott family and a cousin of Stan Woollacott. He visited Burra in 1932, staying with his Aunt Kate, nee Woollacott and also with Aunt Essie, who lived opposite the railway station. His parents had moved to Tyabb in Victoria, where he was born 6 May 1903. He had a sister Evelyn born 6 May 1901 and a brother Keith born 24 May 1905.

They left Tyabb when he was aged 3 and of the 8 siblings three survive. He met Josie Battye last year at a church Friendship Luncheon. He recalls that one of the Woollacott boys opened a college in Essendon, Victoria and another who was a Methodist minister in 1928 over there.

Issue 200, 1 March 1995, page 3

Amy Wilson, daughter of Sue & Dennis Wilson of Burra, will graduate today from Fort Largs Police Academy and she has been posted to Holden Hill Police Station.

Martin & Joanne Lunn with son Ashley will soon move to Murray Bridge, where Martin will be working in the Police Force.

Rev. Barry May, a former Rector of St Mary’s, has been chosen by the West Australian newspaper as their Australian of the Year for his work as Chaplain to the WA Police Force.

St Dymphna’s Catholic Church at Booborowie will mark the completion of renovations with a special Mass next Sunday.

Birth. To Jo & David Gebhardt of ‘The Gap’ on 15 February, a son, Angus John.

Paul Smedley of Burra married Lone Nielsen of Denmark.

Marriage. Clare Country Club, 18 February

Trevor Wiseman of Burra married Anne Chadwick of Paruna.

Obituary. Jack Bogisch died recently aged 78.

[John William Bogisch, born 12 December 1916 at Pt Wakefield. Died 11 February 1995 and buried at Burra 15 February 1995.]

Issue 200, 1 March 1995, page 7

Burra Burra DC

Council decided not to proceed with a hard rubbish collection in Burra.

The Burra Passport agreement between the Council and the National Trust is finally being signed.

Council is liaising with the Department of Mines & Energy and the National Trust in deciding what to do about the mine shaft recently found in Linkson Street.

Issue 201, 8 March 1995, page 1

John Clark has been appointed Knappstein’s representative in Burra.

Stud Merino Field Days

Entries for the ‘Pairs’ and ‘Ram’ competitions are good.

‘Pair’ to be judged at 5.30 p.m. from 21 entries, Tuesday evening, Gala Night. The winner will represent SA in Melbourne in July.

The Ram of the Year will be judged at 6.45 p.m. from 24 entries.

Entertainment will follow – a 17-piece brass band – a comedian – a parade of woollen garments from Linda Ryan’s ‘Wool do it Australia’ fashions.

The Tennis Club will provide a roast meal from 6 p.m. and there will also be hot dogs, ice cream, drinks and bar facilities.

Issue 201, 8 March 1995, page 2

BCS. The school was broken into on Sunday 26 February. There was some minor theft and also vandalism, with graffiti on wall, windows, etc.

Issue 201, 8 March 1995, page 3

Burra Yacht Club Regatta

There were some 500 spectators and eight teams in the dragon boat event, which was won by the Boarding House students. The morning parade of entries included some very large stilted puppets from WomAdelaide’s the ‘Ringless Circus’. Flour bombs from the bridge played a part in the outcome of races. The Nourse bath-boat, complete with shower, was high in the style stakes, but with the heavier Nourse-Brak combination in the bath promptly sank upon their boarding. The last regatta was held in 1988. The idea began in 1985 when Jimmy James, in attempting to cross the flooded creek at the Bon Accord Hotel, lost his car to the floodwaters. Peter Reilly bravely mounted a rescue mission – some say against immense odds – and pulled off a famous rescue. This encouraged locals to immortalise his actions in the annals of local history, leading to the Burra Yacht Club and the boat races. [3 photos.]

Issue 201, 8 March 1995, page 4

Catherine Barker, daughter of Peggy & Tony Barker of Baldina Station, will give her final Honour Recital in Piano Performance at Elder Hall in Adelaide University on Friday 17 March at 6.30 p.m. She began studying with Jack Coombs in Adelaide when aged 8, until his untimely death four years later. She continued with Mary Warnecke and won several scholarships. In 1993 she was the first recipient in SA of the AMEB Fellowship under the tutelage of Noreen Stokes and in that year completed her Bachelor of Music (Performance) and Bachelor of Commerce, both at the University of Adelaide.

Burra Guides. On 28 February fourteen new Brownie Guides were inducted on the banks of Burra Creek. [Photo.]

Issue 201, 8 March 1995, page 7

Burra Picnic Race Club is worried that the SA Jockey Club has suggested that registered horses will not be allowed to race at meetings like that at Thistlebeds after August 1995. This would jeopardise the future of the meetings. The reasoning is to exclude ring-ins. A decision has been delayed until December and negotiations continue. The next Thistlebeds meeting will be on 2 April.

Issue 202, 15 March 1995, page 1

Kyron Statton, a Year 12 BCS student will leave for Japan on Sunday for an 11-month stay as an AFS exchange student.

BCS. Rolling stoppages in SA schools by the SA Institute of Teachers were a response to cutbacks in the State Government’s education arena. BCS was affected with a stoppage from 2-3 p.m. on Tuesday 14 March. For Burra a major cutback was the reduction of 30 hours of the student service officer’s time – time which had to be made up by teaching staff.

Issue 202, 15 March 1995, page 2

Advt. Auction of ‘The Citadel’ 11 Kingston Street Burra, Friday 21 April at 11.30 a.m.

On instructions from H.D. & A.E. Crane.

Issue 202, 15 March 1995, page 3

Burra Burra DC has received a grant of $40,500 towards an environmental training program employing three locals redeveloping the picnic area along Burra Creek. It covers three people for 20 weeks and a further 19 weeks employed by the Council. The program includes car parking, lawns and shelter areas.

Issue 202, 15 March 1995, page 5

Terowie

A sequel to the highly successful I Remember is presently being printed by Burra Community Print for the Terowie Citizens Association and author-collator Marina Gray. It celebrates Terowie in the 1940s when it was a mass of trains and troops. Terowie will be busy at the weekend for the 50th anniversary of VE Day marking the finish of the war in the Pacific on 8 May 1945.

[VE Day on 8 May 1945 marked Victory in Europe, following Germany’s surrender the previous day. VP Day (sometimes referred to as VJ Day), marking Victory in the Pacific was on 15 August 1945.]

Issue 202, 15 March 1995, page 7

BCS. Some 15 athletes went to Jamestown on 12 March for the Athletics Recreation and Outdoor Festival. BCS won the senior section and came second in juniors. [Students are listed.]

The National Trust’s display at BankSA 20-31 March features ‘A Day at the Office’ 60 to 70 years ago.

Issue 203, 22 March 1995, page 1

SA Stud Merino Sheepbreeders Association Gala Night attracted a crowd similar to 1994. The Kensington-Norwood Brass provided the music and there was an extraordinary magician, a talk by American Danny Neef, IWS representative in New York and a fashion parade.

The Champion Ram came from Dusty McGowan of ‘Deloshanda’ Stud, Kielpa, Eyre Peninsula.

Issue 203, 22 March 1995, page 2

SAIT Members at BCS write re the recent stoppage. It was not about pay rises, but against continuing cuts to schools:

Increased class sizes of 30+ in Years 5-7.

Less choice of subjects in Years 11 & 12.

Loss of one school service officer.

Practical class sizes that exceed safety limits.

Less time for children with learning difficulties.

Prospects of further cuts in the 1995-96 budget.

Issue 203, 22 March 1995, page 3

SA Leg of the Fleececare National Merino Ram Pair of the Year Competition was won by ‘Greenfields’ Merino Stud of Hallett.

Issue 203, 22 March 1995, page 7

Burra Lions Club has struggled along for some years with only seven members. In the last 12 months this has grown to 14. The club’s main project at present is landscaping the old swimming pool area and establishing picnic areas. The club is also currently sponsoring a 13-year-old Sri Lankan girl through World Vision.

Issue 203, 22 March 1995, page 8

Bill Pens has been honoured by the Baldina EFS-CFS for 36 years of service. [Photo.]

Issue 203, 22 March 1995, page 10

Junior Basketball Grand Final

Berryman’s 35 defeated Oppy’s 26.

Issue 204, 29 March 1995, page 1

Tracey O’Brien is representing Burra in the 1995 Miss Junior SA Quest. The competition is involved in raising money for the Epilepsy Association of SA. [Photo.]

The Adelaide Chemical Company announced on Monday that a 74% share in the production assets at Burra will be sold for $4 million. The new controlling shareholder Ausminco will take charge from 1 July. ACC’s subsidiary, Mt Gunson Mines makes up $500,000 of the deal. Ausminco is a private company controlled by Adelaide Chemical Company’s Mr Mark Woodhead. As of 1 July the company will adopt the name Adchem.

Issue 204, 29 March 1995, page 2

Accident. On 25 March in the early hours there was a two-car accident at the junction of Rymill & Jaffrey Streets, Burra. There were no injuries, but substantial damage to vehicles. It was caused by one vehicle travelling carelessly through thick dust. [Rymill & Jaffrey Streets do not intersect: perhaps Rymill & Peacock Streets – unless that section of Peacock St has been renamed.]

Cheryl Day opened the Mid North Games Little Athletics at BCS oval on Sunday. [Details on page 5.]

Poet Frank McMahon conducted a poetry workshop at Burra over last weekend.

Marriage. St Mary’s Burra, next Saturday

Julie-Anne Burton will marry Duncan McInnis.

Obituary. David Sorby-Adams, brother to Jan Tiver, has died.

Obituary. Judith De Hrabeczy died recently after a long illness.

Issue 204, 29 March 1995, page 6

Burra-Morgan Road. The Department of Transport has announced that a 20 km section of the road will be sealed – taking the sealed section nearly halfway to Burra. The last section into Burra still requires surveys of European and Aboriginal heritage and surveying of options for the route through Snake Gully and at the Kooringa Road junction along with parking bays.

Burra Burra DC

Ursula Street lighting is being investigated – in part to reduce the problem of urinating in that alley.

A piano will be relocated from the Town Hall to the Sports Complex.

Council decided a Dry Area adjacent to the Burra Creek picnic and barbecue area was not appropriate.

Council has been asked to investigate the future of the Burra Squash Courts.

A local resident has been given permission to use the unused concrete footbridge for testing his ideas for waterproof doors over the next three months.

Issue 204, 29 March 1995, page 7

Catt Bros. Servwell will become Booborowie Welcome Mart after 12 years.

Oppy’s Super Valu store in Burra will be renamed Foodtown.

The former names Servwell and 4-Square were owned by Independent Holdings, who have been taken over by the interstate company Davids and SA stores are now coming into line with names used by them in eastern states.

Issue 205, 5 April 1995, page 1

Burra Community Development Program has instituted an Excellence in Service Award to reward outstanding service from shop/office assistants in Burra – to be offered twice a year in June and December. The people of Burra will vote on a form and the award will be a framed certificate and a cheque for $100.

Burra Community Print

Cory Heneker, our second year apprentice has topped his first year at Croydon Park School of Printing and Graphic Arts. Gone are the days of lead type and linos, now he and fellow apprentice Julie Pawelski, formerly of the Northern Argus, share the workload on the latest desktop publishing equipment.

[Photo of Rob Wilson, Cory Heneker & Terry Wilson.]

Terry was the Lithographic Institute Apprentice of the Year in 1984 and his father, Rob was a winner in Melbourne in 1937.

Letter. Geoff Britton, Member of Council for the Law Society of SA writes thanking Burra organisers for the success of the Law Society’s Country Conference in Burra and in appreciation of the community activity shown, the dinner in the Unicorn Brewery on Friday night and at the Burra Sports Complex on Saturday night, as well as Sunday lunch at Kookaburra Woolshed.

Issue 205, 5 April 1995, page 3

Burra Picnic Race Club – Thistlebeds Races

The meeting was held in perfect weather. A number of stalls catered for all needs. The feature race was the Royal Exchange Cup and was won by ‘Gerard’s Cross’. The lizard race was much appreciated. Gymkhana riders also entertained the crowd. Proceeds will benefit the RFDS.

Issue 205, 5 April 1995, page 4

Scott Scholz has commenced employment with BHP in the company’s cadet program at Whyalla Steelworks. He is one of 15 cadets who will be studying mechanical engineering. Cadets will have a BHP mentor with whom they will work. BHP will work with educational authorities to encourage more students to do Maths in Year 12. Scott will study Mechanical Engineering at the Whyalla Campus of the University of SA.

Issue 205, 5 April 1995, page 5

Goyder House will host a conference for isolated parents on 12 April. Parents will come from as far as Tarcoola in SA’s northwest and Milparinka in NSW. They will be informed about Goyder’s facilities and will provide the committee with feedback. They will also visit Burra’s Heritage Trail while here.

Goyder House AGM will be held on 12 April. The facility presently houses 16 students and house parents are Peter and Maureen Heinrich. A submission is being prepared to get funds to extend the facility to accommodate an extra 8-10 students and another staff member and to enlarge the laundry and games/ leisure area. The Goyder House committee will soon farewell Mrs Marg Heath, who is transferring to Birdwood H.S. She has played a large role in establishing the facility and in its success.

Issue 205, 5 April 1995, page 6

The Copper Trail. Organisers are calling for community members to become involved in the inaugural copper trail commemoration walk from Burra to Kadina, starting on 2 May.

Burra Girl Guides helped to clean up along the Burra Creek recently and along the main road north of Peacock’s Chimney. [Photo.]

Issue 205, 5 April 1995, page 7

Joe Kazimour has a new venture in Market Square. Joe’s Super Snacks will be in the building previously occupied by ‘Looking Good Boutique’.

Birth. To Sharon [& Alan] Wiech of Oakvale Station, [at Burra,] a daughter, Bridgette Alanna Lee.

[Additional information Issue 206, 12 April 1995, page 2.]

Issue 205, 5 April 1995, page 8

Fox Baiting has been undertaken recently in a combined effort by The Burra, Eudunda, Robertstown, Northern and Broughton & Districts Animal and Plant Control Boards. It has been found that farmers who lay baits before autumn lambing commences are recording up to as high as 258 increase in lambing rates. [Sic.] Baits are laid for three days and then those not taken are collected from the marked sites and destroyed.
