Issue 231, 4 October 1995, page 1

Parade to Redruth

On Sunday morning there was a parade of marchers and floats along Commercial Street and thence to Redruth Gaol. The parade was led by the Caledonian Society’s Pipe Band. In the gaol grounds there were food stalls, market stalls and a ‘Victorian Picnic’. Inside the gaol past chairman of the Burra National Trust Dudley Cockington opened the interpretive display.

Saltbush Clothing Co. won the SA Government & Telstra Small Business Award for businesses with fewer than six employees, last Friday night at the Hilton Hotel in Adelaide. Accepting the award, Elspeth Radford said it was exciting for Burra and the Mid North. The company will be represented in Melbourne on 31 October for the National Awards.

Issue 231, 4 October 1995, page 2

Rockhill Sheep Dairy of Leighton with Adelaide cheese-maker La Vern, has been accredited with the highest points in the non-bovine cheese section at the Royal Melbourne Dairy Show recently. Penny & Steve Fielke entered their Barinia Blue (locally known as Rockhill Blue) with outstanding results.

SA Street Machine Association’s ‘Cruise, Show ’n’ Shine’ will be in Burra on Saturday and Sunday 28 & 29 October. [Issue 233, 19 October 1995, page 7, advised that this event would not happen.]

Issue 231, 4 October 1995, page 3

Editorial. Terry Wilson wrote arguing that Council amalgamations would only lead to a reduction in services.

Monique Florence & Vic Haddow, managers of Paxton Square, hosted breakfast last Friday morning for Councillors and tour operators. Monique& Vic are offering continental and cooked breakfasts to visitors in the former Bible Christian Chapel.

Burra Burra DC

Council is seeking finance to seal their 2 km section of the Farrell Flat to Mintaro Road.

Kooringa CoHousing Co-op. has permission to plant trees on the road reserve adjacent to their property.

Council will contact all traders, businesses and government agencies in the area for their comments on the general concept of an industrial area.

Issue 231, 4 October 1995, page 4

The Victorian Picnic at Redruth Gaol

A little before 8 p.m. there was a spectacular fireworks display for fifteen minutes.

The Council had set aside $10,000 for this event.

The following bush dance was attended by c. 300 people who swung to the music of The Wild Matildas and Dick Frankel’s Jazz Band.

[Photograph of The Adelaide Morrismen outside the gaol entrance.]

Back to St Joseph’s Burra School

The Back to Burra Schools Weekend is less than two weeks away.

The St Joseph’s School ran from 1871 to1970 and was situated behind the Catholic Church on Mt Pleasant Road. It is now the Parish Centre. On Sunday 22 October there will be a display of memorabilia of the recently sainted Mary MacKillop.

Advt. Work & Western Clothing Company will open soon at 20A Commercial Street – formerly G.J. Creations. Phone Carmela Mosey.

Issue 231, 4 October 1995, page 5

Advt. Program for the Burra Show on 7 October.

Issue 231, 4 October 1995, page 7

Creek Day

The festivities by the Burra Creek on Saturday were very successful. A large crowd spread along the park from 10 a.m. and the official launch was made by Barry Wakelin MP – the local federal member. There were plenty of arts and crafts stalls, food stalls and music. There was a fairground organ, Jeanette Wormald with her SA country music, the Celtic Broadsword Team and the Royal Caledonian Society Pipers. Dick Frankel and the Jazz Disciples and The Wild Matildas were also there, as were the folk combo, Brigalow and the Morrismen. Matt Reilly refereed the ice cream eating competition.

Issue 231, 4 October 1995, page 8

Football. Central District Bulldogs Senior Colts

The Best & Fairest medal for 1995 went to Michael McBride.

Bohdan Wall won the A.J. Cousins medal for Best & Fairest Junior Colts Player.

Issue 232, 11 October 1995, page 1

Burra Show 1995

The show went very well, with a record attendance. Gate takings were a record – up about 30% on recent years. Entries in the horse sections were at record levels, though cooking, produce and children’s sections were down somewhat. Shearing returned after being absent for some years and the trade stands were well represented.

Junior Miss Showgirl Samantha Kelly

Sub-junior Showgirl Lucy Krause

Mini Showgirl Stephanie Boyd

Miss Showgirl Natasha Burton

[These and the un-named Prince of the Show are pictured.]

Issue 232, 11 October 1995, page 2

Vandalism. Unknown persons caused some $1,000 damage to the carpet pitch of the Leighton Cricket Club, doing burnouts in their vehicle over the area.

Letter. Roy & Lettie Hunt of Two Wells write commending those who organised the Burra Burra Jubilee 150 event, including Leonie Fretwell and Robyn Page for making them welcome and the Wissell family for allowing them as descendants of Wilhelm Fuss, to view and photograph the old family home.

Letter. ‘Stretch’ Read of Burra seeks information about the descendants of James and Maria Reed, who arrived on the Trafalgar and reached Burra in 1854 with eight children. And also of Thomas Reed born 1835, who married four times and who died in Kooringa 20 August 1913. – or of the families of his wives, who had the surnames Evers, Daniel, Villis and Rowe.

[Thomas Reed married Mary Evers in 1862, Mary Daniel in 1880, Mary Villis in 1881 and Mary Rowe in 1887. Mary Villis was a widow and her birth name is given variously as Heffaran, Haferen and Heffernon. Mary Rowe also says she was a widow, though the marriage registration cites her father as John Rowe.]

Letter. Mrs Bev. K. Scheller nee Adams of Ponde via Mannum writes seeking ghost stories from the Burra District. She had ancestors who lived in Burra – Charles Adams, her great-grandfather was a stone mason there.

Issue 232, 11 October 1995, page 3

Burra-Morgan Road

A display showing the alignment of the Burra-Morgan Road as it enters Burra North can be seen at the Burra Council Offices. Sealing of the road is expected to be completed by late 1999, subject to funding.

Ford Ts in Burra. Last Tuesday the Australian Ford T Club assembled in Burra. The first Model T rolled off the assembly line 87 years ago on 1 October.

Notice. The final service at the Clare Salvation Army Citadel will be held on Sunday 22 October 1995 at 2.30 p.m. It will be conducted by Major David Wilson. Tea and coffee to follow.

Burra Show. Further details are printed of the shearing and wool handling.

Burra Masonic Ball on Saturday night in the Burra Town Hall was well attended. It followed the installation of Gerald Pens as Worshipful Master for the coming year.

Issue 232, 11 October 1995, page 11

Issue 233, 18 October 1995, page 7

Back to Burra Schools

This event at the weekend of 21-22 October 1995 is expected to attract up to 1,000 former students and teachers. A number of dinners have been arranged for Saturday evening.

On Sunday morning at 11.30 a.m. an assembly will be held at the school – taken by Mr Colin Morrison, past teacher at World’s End Primary and at Burra High Schools. Mr Ray Jennison will speak on behalf of old scholars and Mr Graham Kellock as Chairman of the District Council.

School memorabilia will be displayed in the library.

St Joseph’s School building will have memorabilia of Mary MacKillop.

Information from senior citizens has been compiled into a booklet and a bus tour to district school sites has also been arranged.

Lobethal Harmony Choir will give a concert in the Uniting Church Hall on Saturday 21 October at 8 p.m.

Advt. Work & Western Clothing Co. will open at 20A Commercial Street on 27 October.

Issue 233, 18 October 1995, page 10

Burra Bowlers gathered last Saturday for the opening of the season and the 75th anniversary of the club.

Issue 234, 25 October 1995, pages 1 & 2

A Tourism Forum was held by the Council last Thursday night at the Civic Centre and was attended by about 30 tourist related business operators. Council Chairman, Graham Kellock, said the Council wanted to know where it could help in tourism development. One problem raised was that the present passport was linked in only with Council and National Trust properties. The idea of an independent body running the Tourism Office was mooted.

Issue 234, 25 October 1995, pages 1, 4 & 5

Back to Burra Schools Reunion

Despite atrocious weather that included a few snowflakes, about 700 people registered for the reunion on 21 & 22 October. This included 35 from interstate and 40 former staff members. All events had to be held indoors due to the very wet and wintry weather. Information given allowed at least 40 schools to be identified. A booklet titled ‘School Daze’ was printed and each senior citizen was given a copy. Dinners on Saturday night were held at the Sports Complex and the Burra Hotel and each was booked out.

Sunday’s assembly was moved to the school gymnasium, where former headmaster Colin Morrison conducted the assembly. A salute to the flag was followed by much reminiscing. Addresses were given by:

Ray Jennison – dux of the school in 1942

Kevin Fahey – Present Principal

Graham Kellock – Chairman of the Burra Burra DC

Robyn Page – Chair of the Burra Jubilee 150 Committee

The Burra Community Library had a display of school memorabilia.

A bus tour in the afternoon visited the sites of St Joseph’s School and those at Copperhouse, Ayers, Leighton, Gum Creek, Wheetelande and others.

At Ayers a former teacher, Mr George Murray (almost 90) spoke to the group and a cairn of stones had been built by Don Lloyd in readiness for a plaque.

All in all it was a very successful reunion despite the weather.

Issue 234, 25 October 1995, page 2

The Races at Kimberly Station had to be cancelled due to the wet conditions, but two teenage girls ignored the advice and drove their Gemini sedan on roads unfit for a 4WD and were finally bogged 15 km east of Pine Valley Station. They were found at 1.30 p.m. the following day. 40 Burra residents who had gone out earlier were stranded at Kimberly until road conditions improved. Strangely, although the food delivery had been impeded by the road conditions, the alcohol supply seems to have made it through.

Issue 234, 25 October 1995, page 5

The ‘Man From Snowy River’ Competition was held at Corryong, Victoria, in the past week.

The event demanded competition in all aspects of horsemanship, including shoeing, bareback stock horse riding, cross country – including a rugged mountain ride that was ‘almost straight up’. Shane Cooper, Burra’s dog-catcher, took out 3rd place, with top scores in the bareback and stock-saddle buck jump. The winner was Bill Willoughby of Booleroo Centre. (1st prize $10,000, 2nd $1,500 and 3rd $500.)

Issue 234, 25 October 1995, page 6

The Main Street Committee will provide a free champagne breakfast to residents of Burra on the morning of the Melbourne Cup, Tuesday 7 November in Market Square from 7 a.m. This will mark the launch of the committee’s new name. (Previously the Burra Community Development Program.) At 8 a.m. Council Chairman Graham Kellock and a representative from SA Economic Development Authority will present their 1995-96 funding cheques.

The Terowie Heritage Gallery was established in 1987 with the help of a Bicentennial Grant. It has gone on to establish the Blacksmith Museum, opened in 1993 and later this year will open ‘Women’s Work’ and a historical perspective ‘Terowie Main Street’. The Pioneer Gallery contains 1,000 photographs of national, regional and local significance and on 18 October received a $4,000 grant on behalf of Terowie Citizens Association for conservation and reformatting of the photographic collection.

Advt. Jane & Peter Strawbridge advise that from 22 October 1995 their Doll & Toy Museum will be open only by appointment.

These workshops mark the launch of ‘Classic Permaculture’ as a new business in the Mid North. Ian is a member of the Kooringa CoHousing Co-operative, which recently gained Council approval to build a Permaculture-designed village on the southern edge of Burra. [Photo.]

Issue 236, 8 November 1995, page 1

Landscaping Along Burra Creek

Locals John Whitford, Lyal Harris-Coley & Robert Heading have been employed under the Greening Urban SA Project. As well as landscaping on the creek bank they have designed and constructed a stone footbridge as part of the project.

Issue 236, 8 November 1995, pages 1 & 2

Calici Virus

A report is printed on the recent spread of the Calici virus and its effect in greatly reducing the rabbit population.

There is a suspicion of human intervention in the release of the virus from Wardang Island, resulting in the outbreak at Yunta and in the Flinders Ranges. The former outbreak has now spread to over 10,000 km2 and the latter to some 5,000 km2. Pet rabbits need to be vaccinated.

Issue 236, 8 November 1995, page 4

Adchem has received a safety award.

The award is the SA Bonus Scheme Level II Gold Award.

This is the highest level a non-exempt company (i.e. for companies subject to WorkCover premiums) can achieve. The company achieved 131 days since the last lost time accident. It has since extended this to 160 days.

A Tourism Advisory Committee has been formed in Burra with representatives from the Council, the Burra Branch of the National Trust, the Burra Traders’ Association, Burra Main Street Program and community representatives.

Our State’s Farm & Country Holiday Association will hold a woolshed dance at Tooralie Homestead, Hallett, on 17 November. [See also advertisement on same page.]

A Burra Carer Support Group was formed earlier this year.

Issue 237, 15 November 1995, page 1

Olivia Mills, world authority on the sheep-milking industry, met with local producers Penny & Stephen Fielke on Monday. [Further details of the visit are printed.]

Issue 237, 15 November 1995, page 2

Letter. Ian Auhl writes concerning an invitation for Professor Blainey to speak at Burra on 9 December. He says he has been aware of Blainey’s importance to Burra since reading his book The Rush That Never Ended in 1964 – which first impressed upon him that Kapunda and Burra were Australia’s first mining towns. Blainey’s first contribution was to substantiate Auhl’s submission to the SA Government to have the whole of Paxton Square placed under the protection of the Historic Relics Act (1965). Blainey also gave Auhl permission to use his words ‘Australia’s Earliest Mining Era’ as the title for one of Auhl’s books in 1970. Auhl doubts if his research and submissions concerning the various historic sites would have proceeded without Blainey’s inspiration. Without Blainey’s insight, it is likely Burra would have remained a sleepy old town, almost unaware of its significance to SA history and it is doubtful if it would have become a Proclaimed Historic Town.

[This and rather more in a long letter.]

Issue 237, 15 November 1995, page 3

The Editor (Terry Wilson) writes on the need for Burra to have an industrial zone, which has been a matter of some discussion for quite a while. Three factors limit possibilities in Burra:

Zoning regulations

Perceived heritage conflict

Nearness to a watercourse

Enquiries from the Broadcaster over two years have elicited no replies except prevarication. A firm industrial base would help boost the town’s dwindling business activity and help the ancillary services and shopping facilities to thrive. Other towns in other areas with similar problems have tackled the difficulties and done things such as offering sites and services or free rate periods of up to five years.

A project with only twenty extra incomes would have a positive effect and look what happened to real estate values when Adchem shed fifty workers. As a result families left, school numbers fell and there was a glut of empty houses.

If the decline of the town as a service centre is not seen as a dangerous option, decisions will drift on as they have been for two years.

Advt. Mr Pickett’s Courtyard Café – Open for lunches – BYO – Thursday to Monday 11 a.m. to 2.30 p.m.

Issue 237, 15 November 1995, page 4

Burra Passport

The National Trust and the Council recently reviewed their policy and have agreed that locals and friends staying with them can have a free passport. This does not include entry to museums for visitors (though it does for locals) – The passport does require a $5 refundable deposit.

Issue 238, 22 November 1995, page 3

Burra Burra DC

The Council rejected the first stage of an appeal by the Kooringa CoHousing Co-operative to use the ‘Rotaloo 950’ in their planned housing development. These toilets are approved by SA Health Commission and were recommended by the Council’s own Development Committee.

Burra J150 Cookbook – recipes from a broad range of current and past residents is now available.

Ratepayers’ Association

A meeting of more than 50 concerned citizens last Tuesday resulted in the formation of a Ratepayers’ Association in the Burra Council District.

Mr Alan Hall said a major reason for its formation was the lack of response from the Council after the last public meeting at the Old Courthouse. This had called for Council to furnish a business plan for their different areas of activity. He was also critical of the Broadcaster for what he said was highly selective reporting of Council minutes.

A committee of 13 was elected with Alan Hall as Chairman and John Monfries as Secretary-Treasurer.

Issue 238, 22 November 1995, page 4

Tracey O’Brien of Burra has been an entrant in the Miss Junior SA Quest and has concluded her year promoting the cause of the Epilepsy Foundation.

Mt Bryan Uniting Church

When it was decided to close the church, locals rallied and encouraged others to keep services in the town. They asked the presbytery for support, which came in the form of a cluster of ministers who attended at various times. Members have risen and fellowship has blossomed to a dozen or so attending regularly. A service will be held this Sunday at 2 p.m., when a lay ministry team will be commissioned.

Issue 238, 22 November 1995, page 6

East Bungaree Merino Stud has been purchased by Hazeldean.

Hazeldean was founded at Cooma in NSW in 1865 and East Bungaree at Mt Bryan in 1841. Hazeldean proprietor Jim Litchfield said the quality of the operation and its location influenced the purchase.

[Further details are printed.]

The Burra Swimming Pool had a team of ‘Icebreakers’ taking a dip between 6.30 and 7 a.m. on weekdays this year.

Burra Hospital received a visit recently from the newly created Wakefield Regional Health Service’s Chairman Mr James Maitland. He said the process of regionalisation was going ahead although the new Health Services Bill was yet to pass through parliament, because the process is allowable under the Health Commission Act 1976. [Further details printed.]

Issue 239, 29 November 1995, page 1

Mike Scholz is a new face at the Tourism Office. [Photo.]

Issue 239, 29 November 1995, pages 1 & 5

Burra Traders’ Association

The Association seeks a new role and new members. A survey has told members that locals want to see a revitalised local economy. This coincides with the considerable local debate over the Council’s role in the tourism industry. There is a widespread belief that the Council should be doing more to attract new and essential business to Burra and relaxing some of its rules and regulations arising from heritage legislation. The Traders’ Association has fewer members than in the past and has decided its role needs re-defining. This is especially so in view of Council amalgamation prospects, with a possible base elsewhere.

People are especially concerned over the rapid turnover in shops, the absence of some essential services, which leads people to shop elsewhere and the large number of houses for sale.

While there was concern over high rates, there was no widespread disagreement with Council policies on tourism. Most people surveyed saw Burra’s future closely tied in with tourism and with heritage values. They were concerned with the perceived lack of communication between Council and the community. Customer service in Burra was said to have improved and prices were now broadly comparable with Clare. Most people associated the Traders’ Association with the Christmas celebrations, but with little else – though a need for an association to present traders with a united voice to talk with Council was accepted.

A suggestion was to re-name the Burra Business Association in an attempt to widen its base to represent tourism operators and other businesses. The survey also suggested it should:

Encourage people to shop locally

Undertake joint promotional activities

Worth with the Main Street Committee to provide a general facelift in the town centre

Help attract new businesses

Work with the school to promote local employment.

The Council was keen to work closely with the Association. Several people stressed that the Association should not be waiting for the Council to take the initiative. The town needed an Association to draw people together and in this context the recently formed Ratepayers’ Association was seen as retrograde – being more divisive than helpful.

Issue 240, 6 December 1995, page 2

Letter. Ian Auhl writes, pointing out that the J150 year has seen an emphasis in Burra on history, heritage and tourism. There will naturally be a reaction in the coming year and a need for a balance between heritage, tourism and Burra’s role as a service centre. He suggests part of the answer is as it has always been – loyalty to the town and its institutions with local shopping and the use of local services.

Issue 240, 6 December 1995, page 3

The Smelts Paddock

This article deals with the new trail and signage around the site and lists some of the points:

The Patent Copper Co. was formed in London in early 1848 to build and operate a smelting works at the Burra Burra Mine.

By mid-1849 the first smelting house was completed with eight furnaces and a refinery, with three furnaces added in 1850.

The English & Australian Copper Co. took over in 1851.

A second smelting house with nine furnaces commenced operations in 1854.

As payment the smelting company retained one third of the copper produced.

The operations were conducted by Welsh smeltermen, brought out from Swansea with their families 1849-55.

Houses for up to 75 smeltermen were provided at the works.

The village of Llwchwr was established about 1 km to the north in 1855.

The smelting works employed 1,000, including 400 teamsters in 1851.

At first refined copper was carted by bullock dray to Pt Wakefield.

After 1857 it was carted by mule teams to the Kapunda railhead.

Production declined after 1862, when smelting works were erected at Pt Adelaide and operations at Burra ceased in 1869.

In all some 28,000 tons of copper metal were produced from 150,000 tons of Burra ore – at today’s prices for copper this was worth some $100 million.

When mining began at Burra in 1845 Swansea in Wales was the world’s principal copper smelting centre.

The site at Burra is of world significance as possibly the only example where remains of a pre-1860 Welsh-style smelting works survive.

The site was listed on the State heritage Register in 1984.

Notice. Invitation to the Official Opening of the Burra Smelting Works Interpretive Area

Saturday 9 December 1995 at 4.30 p.m. by Professor Geoffrey Blainey.

Issue 240, 6 December 1995, page 6

BCS will lose as a result of Government cuts.

It will be without a bursar and one staff member in 1996. Officially the SSO reduction is 16 hours, but changes to the staffing formula could mean the loss of up to 40 hours.

Dee Hill, who replaced Marg. Heath as bursar will not continue.

Barb Secomb will lose her SSO position.

Voluntary community support could be needed to run the gymnasium.

Burra SAIT members will stop work for the last hour today.

Issue 240, 6 December 1995, page 11

The Burra Tourism Office has been encouraging school visits to Burra in 1995 and to date there have been 51 schools visit in 41 weeks.

Issue 241, 13 December 1995, page 1

The J150 Commemorative Dinner

Professor Geoffrey Blainey was the keynote speaker at the J150 dinner at the Burra Town Hall. He was welcomed by Robyn Page, Chair of the J150 Committee. Professor Blainey paid tribute to those responsible for preserving the history of Burra, specifically to Ian Auhl. He painted a picture of Australia on the eve of the Victorian gold rush, when Burra was the seventh largest town in Australia and the only one in the top ten not to be a port. It was then twice the size of Brisbane, with a population of 5,000. It had the first health benefits scheme in Australia and provided housing for miners. It was also the largest Cornish community outside of England. The first Bible Christian Church in Australia was built here in 1850. (Now the Paxton Square Cottages booking office.) He also placed Burra in later exploration. In 1873 Gosse named Ayers Rock after the Secretary of Burra’s mining company, Sir Henry Ayers. John Forrest, after an epic travel through Western Australia, was treated to a dinner at the relatively new Burra Town Hall. Ernest Giles also was given a dinner in his return to the outskirts of civilisation. Professor Blainey also mentioned the Lewis family and placed Burra in the wider plane of Australia’s history. [Photo.]

Issue 241, 13 December 1995, page 2

Letter. ‘Ulrike’ writes commending kangaroo meat as part of a healthy diet.

Letter. John Oates writes in response to Alan Hall’s alleged comment that the Council had an ‘arrogant and born-to-rule’ attitude.

It seems pointless to elect a ratepayers’ association to belt the Council that has just been elected.

Council would appear weak or foolish if it went to the ratepayers’ association to make a decision.

How can Councillors be unapproachable if they have not been approached?

Since May I have had four people outside of Council contact me over issues.

Ratepayers’ Association says it has c. 60 members – this number would not have elected a Councillor in May 1995.

As a ratepayer, I have concerns over the tourism industry in Burra. Some small or one large industrial development would bring probably as much or more growth, jobs and money as tourism at present.

Council is propping up tourism because it is saving the town from dying, until some industry is brought here. I can’t see we have much choice.

Sure, many things cannot be bought in Burra, but if people who shopped for everything outside of the town started shopping here, perhaps Council would not have to spend so much of electors’ money on tourism.

I too would like to see money spent on roads and see rates fixed for a few years.

Every time there is an election the few who do most complaining don’t have the courage to stand for election – using the same old excuse of lack of time.

The last thing we need is division in the town.

Issue 241, 13 December 1995, page 4

Marriage. St Mary’s Church, Burra, 3 December

Stuart Press, son of Mary Press, married Elizabeth Stamic, originally from Yugoslavia. The couple will live in Canberra.

Obituary. Mrs Addie Dention [sic: Denton?] died last week in Clare Hospital.

Thamm’s Garage has been rebuilt.

BCS. Staff members concluding their time at BCS with the end of the school year are:

Lisa Gerritts Helen Wurst Rod Grant

Jill Allcock Mary Sofis Adel Mossa

Several other positions are in doubt due to SSO time cuts.

Tiver’s Row. Maureen & Barry Wright have been notified they were awarded Best Project between $100,000 and $500,000 at the National Trust-St George’s Bank Heritage Conservation Awards. The six restored cottages known as Tiver’s Row are typical of cottages built in the early years of Burra.

Issue 241, 13 December 1995, page 5

Burra Burra DC has announced an operating surplus of $69, 017 for 1994-95, although it budgeted for a deficit. [Further details are printed.]

Council Amalgamations

The politics of council amalgamations continue. Burra’s District Clerk Steve Kerrigan said they were waiting for confirmation of the recent legislation and the role of the reform board, before entering into further discussions with other councils in the region.

Kooringa CoHousing will make a further attempt to avoid a court hearing over the use of composting toilets at their development in Allen Street. They will ask for Council to reconsider the issue on 18 December. A planning Commissioner has already suggested a compromise in which seven units are trialled in the first stage.

Burra Traders’ Association Christmas Festivities 22 December, 5.30 p.m.

Barbecue Tea Combined Choir Clare Concert Band

Christmas Auction On stage performances Father Christmas

Displays Solo performances Christmas Pageant

Burra Miners’ Walk

Issue 241, 13 December 1995, page 6

Helen Lloyd was farewelled by her pupils after teaching piano in Burra for many years.

Next year the classes will be in Clare.

Issue 241, 13 December 1995, page 7

The John McDouall Stuart Society

Nearly 50 members will visit Burra on Saturday 16 December as guests of the McDouall Stuart Board, which managed the Burra Art Gallery. They will bring exhibits to be on display over the weekend. A highlight of the visit will be the unveiling of a plaque on the Old Post & Telegraph Office to commemorate the achievements of the ‘South Australian Great Northern Exploration’ crossing from Adelaide to Australia’s northern shores and returning without loss of life in 1861-62. The group led by Stuart reached a point at Chambers Bay 129 km east of Darwin and on his return Stuart sent a telegram from the Post and Telegraph Office at Burra [to the Governor] and spent the night at the Burra Hotel [where the Hospital now stands] before going to Kapunda by coach and thence by rail to Adelaide.

Issue 241, 13 December 1995, page 8

The Calici Virus. Confirmation has been received that rabbits are dying from the virus between Florieton and ‘The Gums’.

Issue 241, 13 December 1995, pages 12 to 17

A Review of 1995

Council Mergers

Burra Burra DC could merge with up to six councils according to a report to State Parliament.

The Council has made it known that it is not in favour of forced amalgamations.

Wildlife Disease

An epidemic of blindness in kangaroos showed up in areas near Burra in April.

The Calici virus outbreak in rabbits made headlines later in the year.

Royal Adelaide Show

Local Merino studs did well.

Ashby’s Old Ashrose won five first places and nine other prizes.

BCS gained several minor placings in the Led Steer section.

Fashion Feature

A Sheep & Fashion Gala Night in March boosted Burr and its primary product.

Saltbush Clothing Co. relocated to Drew & Crewe’s Building and won an award for best small business with fewer than six employees.

Work & Western, a new business, has begun next to the Commercial Hotel, retailing work clothing and farm supplies.

Churches & J150

The 80th Anglican Synod was held in Burra 6-7 May and was presided over by the Bishop of Willochra, Rt Rev. R.D.H. McCall.

St Mary’s hosted the Quire Saint Nicolas in May with music for the sesquicentenary.

The Woodville Choral Group under the baton of Rosemary Nairn (nee Reed) performed in the Uniting Church on 28 May.

Adelaide Metropolitan Male Voice Choir sang at an ecumenical service on 2 September.

The Uniting Church and the Cornish Association combined for a traditional Methodist Service on 30 September and 1 October.

Boarding Facility

Goyder House, the boarding facility for BSC, was the venue for a conference of isolated parents on 12 April.

Sporting Successes

BBH Colts, Bohdan Wall & Michael McBride took the two NE Football Association’s Colts’ medals: Boh for the Junior Best & Fairest and Michael for Senior Best & Fairest.

BBH B Grade was the club’s only finals representative and dropped out after a close match with Mintaro-Manoora in the preliminary final.

New Year’s Ball in July

Burra Hospital Auxiliary staged an Irish New Year’s Ball on 1 July in the Burra Town Hall.

A feature was the dancing of Desme White’s ‘Heritage Dancers’ who performed in 18th and 19th century costumes.

Burra-Morgan Road

One Kilometre was sealed early in the year, with a longer section let out to contract in the 1995-96 year.

The SA Government has announced that 20 km will be sealed commencing in April 1996.

The Great Bike Ride from Burra to Morgan on 13 August focussed attention on the road.

Brown Water Classic

Memories of Burra Yacht Club’s regattas of past years were rekindled as 500 spectators enjoyed themselves.

Burra Girl Guides helped Council and the community when they spent time cleaning up part of the Burra Creek.

Tourism

Burra Tourist Office reported an increase in tourist numbers up to half-way through the year.

Concern has been expressed at the possible impact of council amalgamation, given the District Council’s involvement in supporting local tourism.

Conferences

There were several state gatherings in Burra for J150, including the Area Schools Principals’ Conference, an SES Conference in September, the Christian Women Communicating Conference in August and the SA Association of State School Organisations Conference in October.

A Quilting Exhibition titled Needles Through Time was a highlight of J150 Craft Weekend.

A wall hanging celebrating the sesquicentennial was presented to the Council.

Burra Community Development Program changed its name to Main Street

It adopted the slogan: Bringing Burra Together.

Mineral Surveys

Aeromagnetic surveys of SA paid special attention to the Burra Mine site to record characteristics of the remaining deep ore.

They also paid attention to areas to the north and to kimberlite deposits at Terowie and Pine Creek.

Burra Cycling Classic

The J150 Burra Open Cycling Classic was held on 9 September when a field of more than 60 competed in the race to Riverton and return.

New Businesses

Gilda Anderson & Mary Press have addressed the needs of the mature age generation.

Impressive Tourist Services has been offering a four day tour of the region.

Norm Mason’s new business at Burra North specialises in repairing small motors and garden implements.

Australia Remembers

More than 200 attended the Anzac Dawn Service in Burra.

Army vehicles and 35 personnel from the 8th Transport Squadron at Warradale attended.

Burra CWA

Hosted the Warnes Group Conference this year at the Sports Complex for its 50th anniversary.

100 guests included Carolyn Cooke, a granddaughter of CWA founder Mary Warnes, as keynote speaker.

Wesfarmers Dalgety

Celebrated 10 years in their present location in Market Square during the year.

Their ‘Ploughback’ scheme resulted in the provision of a cheque for $2,250 for the Burra Hospital that has enabled the hospital to purchase a foetal heart monitor.

Another cheque for $1,945 went to the Burra Kindergarten for a new fence.

Burra Branch of Greening Australia

Planted 500 trees opposite the Burra Hospital – most of them indigenous to the local area.

Visiting Musicians

The Tea Rose Duo

Piano & violin duo, Bernard & Sarah De Pasquale

Country artist Jeanette Wormald

The Copper Trek

A large group of walkers followed the 150 km route along the steps of miners who trekked from Burra to the Moonta Mines.

A larger contingent of children completed 5 or 10 km sections on horseback, in buggies or coaches or on foot.

Exhibitions and Fairs

Burra Arts Council annual art exhibition was held in the old Record Office as one of five art exhibitions on the same weekend.

This Art Experience Weekend also featured the S.T. Gill exhibition, The Allyson & Marie Parsons Burra and Beyond exhibition, The Regional Art Society’s showing at the former Bible Christian Chapel and the Russell Morrison collection in the Old Courthouse.

Pride of place in the Allyson Parson display was the magnificent painting commissioned by the Burra Burra DC to commemorate the town’s 150th anniversary.

The Morrison exhibition was supported by members of the Flute Society and the SA Police Choir.

The Antique and Decorating Fair was held in the Town Hall on the first weekend in May.

The Governor-General, Mr Bill Hayden visited Burra to unveil the restored S.T. Gill watercolours on view at Morphett’s Engine House in the Mine Museum and he awarded souvenir medallions to students at BCS.

Xavier Minniecon presented the ABC’s Weather Shots Exhibition at the Civic Centre in June.

Geology Weekend

The Geological Society of SA and the Field Geology Club provided a Geology Weekend 20-21 May, with speakers on geological formations and mining methods.

Burra Red Cross Branch

Sent $5,178 to headquarters this year.

Other J150 Events

Back to Burra Golf Club weekend 8-9 June saw many former members and friends return to the town.

Under a sister town arrangement dating from 1983 members and staff of the Broken Hill City Council visited Burra on 22 July and attended the Gem & Minerals Exhibition.

Mr Nick Van Buuren, retired engineer with Adelaide Chemical Co. constructed a scale working model of Morphett’s Engine House.

The Jubilee 150 Committee held a promotion in Adelaide Arcade from 31 July to 6 August.

Burra Bowling Club

The Division 3 Bowls Championship was hosted in Burra on 28 April.

Netball

Burra’s only teams in the finals were the A1 and A2 Grades, but neither won right through.

Ann Wiseman won the Association’s Best & Fairest award in the B1 Grade.

Burra Show

The show held on 7 October was the best ever with a record attendance.

The record gate was 30% up on recent years.

Back to School

Some 700 people attended the Back to Burra Schools Reunion held on 21-22 October.

They came from all over SA and 35 from interstate.

A booklet School Daze was printed for the occasion.

At the ‘Man from Snowy River’ Competition held in Corryong

Bill Willoughby of Booleroo Centre was the winner.

Shane Cooper of Burra took third place.

Burra Burra District Council’s Development Committee

Examined the options for an industrial area on the outskirts of the town.

The prospect of the sealing of the Burra-Morgan road and its development as a transport route through to the Barrier Highway made it seem desirable to zone an area for industry near both these roads.

The Season

Good rains led to a harvest beginning in November with prospects for good yields.

High prices should help those who have struggled in recent years.

‘Burra Blasts Back’

This saw a number of events over the weekend 30 September to 1 October.

Stalls and entertainment lined Burra Creek.

A grand fireworks display was held on Saturday night at Redruth Gaol.

There was a Sunday morning parade of floats from Commercial Street to Redruth Gaol, followed by a Victorian Picnic. The parade was led by the Caledonian Society Pipe Band.

A special souvenir edition of the Burra Record was published by the Burra Community Print.

A silent film night capped off a great weekend.

On Sunday morning the Burra Uniting Church was inundated with visitors, including members of the Cornish Association of SA for a traditional Methodist service.

Tourism Award

The Burra J150 Committee received the top award – the Perpetual Overall Tourism Excellence Award at the Mid North Tourism Awards in October.

Burra & District Residents & Ratepayers’ Association

The inaugural meeting was held at the Sports Complex on Monday 4 December.

Douglas Holloway, President of the SA Federation of Residents & Ratepayers’ Associations Inc. gave an address on the role of such groups.

Chairman Alan Hall said the Association was the only truly unified broad-based body in the community.

Members supported affiliation with the state body.

Their main request to Council was that Council respond to a motion passed at a public meeting at the Old Courthouse on 28 August, calling on Council to produce a Tourism Business Plan for Burra.

The Association will also lobby Council on matters it considers vital to the community and try to ensure Council provided the community with better information on its affairs.

Issue 241, 13 December 1995, page 18

KESAB has again acknowledged Burra senior Citizens with an awards for Meritorious Effort and Excellence.

Issue 241, 13 December 1995, page 21

Burra Burra DC

The cost of operating tourist sites 1994-95:

Nett cost $42,211

Burra Mine Museum $10,631

Smelts Paddock $Nil

Hampton Village $Nil

Unicorn Brewery Cellars $3,212

Caravan Park $13,282

Tourism Office $57,725

Paxton Cottages generated a net surplus of $42,639.

Issue 242, 20 December 1995, page 1

Stuart Plaque Unveiled

A plaque was unveiled in front of the Burra Art Gallery on Saturday morning to commemorate the return of the successful John McDouall Stuart expedition in 1861. Local resident of 36 years, Beth Field and her sister Pat Farquhar with husband Norman (who came from Victoria) were present. [Photo.]

The sisters were born in Gawler, not far from the house at Kingsford where the explorer Stephen King lived. He was their grandmother’s brother and had taken part in the 1861 Stuart expedition, crossing the continent from south to north and back. As a result of his involvement he also became involved in a survey for the erection of the overland telegraph from Adelaide to Darwin.

Judge Wilson, Chairman of the Gallery’s Board, is also related to Stephen King. He referred to the connection in his speech. The Mortlock Library had agreed to the display of four original sketches by Stephen King as part of a small exhibition of pictures and memorabilia associated with the expedition. About 50 members of the John McDouall Stuart Society attended the event. Their President, Tony Auld expressed their gratitude for the hospitality shown them.

Issue 242, 20 December 1995, pages 1 & 9

BCS had a permanent Agricultural teacher for 1995 and as a result has been able to develop a long term plan for the Agricultural curriculum. This will continue for 1996, with a vocationally based course in Year 11, said teacher John Agren.

Burra’s Years 6 to 10 students take Agriculture as a compulsory subject and it is an option in Years 11 & 12.

Two ‘farms have been used this year – one between the school and Smelts Paddock and the other at Kookaburra, behind the old Hampton Township. Ten acres were cropped at Kookaburra and ten at the school – mostly by Year 11 students.

The land near the school has copper toxicity problems and animals kept there too long die from copper overload. Onion weed and shallow soils also plague that site. All classes had some exposure to the led steers project, though the main work there was done by Years 11 & 12 students. The result had been considerable success at the Royal Adelaide Show. Year 8 students had mainly reared the eight ‘bobby’ calves.

Issue 242, 20 December 1995, page 2

The Smelts Walk was opened by Professor Geoffrey Blainey on Saturday 9 December. Many of the ruins of smeltermen’s cottages, chimneys and the smelthouse were uncovered in a recent archaeological survey. The walk shows how ore was brought from the charge yards to be mixed with the flux and loaded into the furnaces. The walk also takes you through the stages of the smelting process. [Photo.]

Issue 242, 20 December 1995, page 3

Letter. Christmas message from Eva Pink, Chair of the Burra Traders’ Association.

Letter. Richard Holbrook, Chairman of Main Street Committee writes commending the upgrading of BP Burra by Richard & Dawn Dollman.

Letter. John G. Monfries responds in a long letter to Cr John Oates’ recent long letter.

Over the past months we have heard a lot said about the Council and their management of community assets.

Throughout the Council has not asked the broader community for its views – even if it has consulted specific special interest groups.

This is quite apparent after the public meeting in August at the Old Courthouse.

Its response was to call a meeting of people involved in the tourist industry.

They were hardly likely to be critical of a body spending hundreds of thousands of dollars on their industry.

It is this type of approach that has led to the label ‘arrogant’.

[The writer goes on to condemn the lack of communication between the Council and the community and the lack of any time for questions from the community at Council meetings – or a forum of any sort for views to be expressed. Costs for Council agendas are $6 and likewise for a copy of minutes. He believes a Ratepayers’ Association is the only way for the community to be heard – all else having failed.]

Letter. David Baker also writes a fairly long letter spelling out the need for a Ratepayers’ Association:

Opposing views and diverse opinion are signs of a healthy community and democracy.

Elected representatives are expected to undertake the views of the majority and act upon them.

The Ratepayers’ Association is an ideal venue for elected people to hear views of some of the ratepayers.

Tourism will always be a part of the town and tourists will be made welcome.

But there are only a few – perhaps 15-20 that rely on tourism as their main source of income – mainly in the Bed & Breakfast business.

Council does not pay rates and income tax on its businesses and has other unfair advantages in competing with other Bed & Breakfast businesses.

Letter. John Oates writes to thank the paper for publishing his letter and says it has provided tremendous feedback.

‘ALL replies were positive at the time of writing.’

Issue 242, 20 December 1995, page 4

Alison Klinberg received the Ron. Thamm School & Community Award.

Issue 242, 20 December 1995, page 8

Burra Jubilee 150. Report of Chairperson, Robyn Page.

The celebrations for the sesquicentenary of Burra were spread over the whole year.

Burra played host to many local, state and national bodies during the year and promotions included:

Australian Federation of Travel Agents’ Fair in February.

Caravan & Camping Show in March.

Two displays in the SA Travel Centre Window (in Adelaide).

Display in Radio 5UV window.

Laura Folk Fair promotion.

A week long promotion in the Adelaide Arcade in August.

A display at the Royal Adelaide Show.

Events in which the Jubilee150 Committee was directly involved included:

Writing and poetry workshops conducted by Frank McMahon.

Commemorative Copper Trek Burra to Kadina, involving some 700 students, staff, parents and community members in May.

J150 Gem & Mineral Exhibition in August.

Art & Craft Exhibitions in August.

Visit by the Adelaide Metropolitan Male Voice Choir in September.

‘Burra Blasts Back’ with creek-side stalls and entertainment, fireworks display, bush dance, grand parade and Victorian Picnic in September.

Back to Burra Schools Reunion in October.

The Crime Prevention National Conference 21-24 November.

Commemorative Dinner with Professor Geoffrey Blainey in December.

Mike Artmann and family are welcomed to Burra. He is the new proprietor of Burra Oil & Diesel at the rear of Elders.

Issue 243, 17 January 1996, page 1

Sarah Jaensch recently won the Burra Excellence in Service Award, promoted by the Main Street Program. She works at Wilkinson’s Chemist. [Photo.]

Theft. Furniture and other items were stolen from Burra Golf Club about the 25 December to the value of several thousand dollars.

Theft. On 28 December a break-in was reported at Burra Bazaar when stock to the value of c. $6,000 was stolen.

Roadwork. A section of the Burra-Morgan road some 50 km from Burra and stretching towards Morgan is being prepared for sealing.

Rod Peppiatt (33) and his wife Kathy with children Rhiannon and Duncan have been welcomed to Burra. Rod will be inducted as the new minister for the Burra Uniting Church Parish on Friday night. Rod has been an optical technician by trade and Kathy has been a school teacher. Both come from Tasmania.

Issue 243, 17 January 1996, pages 1 & 2

Accident. A bus rolled over on the Burra-Morgan Road east of ‘The Gums’ on Wednesday 10 January. It was a Nissan mini-bus with eleven passengers. Four of them were taken to Waikerie Hospital with injuries and the others for observation.

Hoping the new Ratepayers’ Association and the Council can have a productive working relationship.

Outlining how tourist expenditure by the Council falls broadly into two parts.

Purchase, upgrading and maintaining sites by the community

Marketing and promoting these sites and others in conjunction with the National Trust and private operators.

Issue 243, 17 January 1996, page 5

Christmas in Burra. Many have commented on the success of the evening and especially on the Crazy Auction using the ‘specially minted’ Burra money.

The street parade with a host of floats was a successful innovation and the whole event went very well.

Issue 243, 17 January 1996, page 6

Weather. Storms on New Year’s Eve delivered 50 mm in just 25 minutes, causing floodwaters some two metres deep to flow across the Burra Creek Gorge ford and one metres deep across the Morgan Road.

Issue 243, 17 January 1996, page 9

Ken Tuckey and his team of camels are on an 8,500 km trek, raising funds for Children’s Leukaemia and Cancer Foundation. The team passed through Burra just before Christmas. [Photo.]

Burra Burra DC

Discussion on council boundary reforms are continuing with neighbouring councils.

Ursula Street (between the Burra Hotel and the Snack Bar) is being upgraded with improved lighting, paving, underground drainage and a ramp and steps leading to Burra Creek.

Burra Creek water will be used to irrigate lawns and garden areas adjacent to the creek in Burra.

Issue 244, 24 January 1996, page 1

Council Amalgamations

Burra Burra DC is in consultation with representatives of Clare, Saddleworth-Auburn and Riverton Councils. Nothing has been settled. Local councils must have in place a proposal for amalgamation before 31 March, to be acceptable by the Minister of Local Government by 31 December, to enable elections to be held in May 1997 – if not there will be forced amalgamations and in any event there is no guarantee that any merger proposal will be accepted.

Issue 244, 24 January 1996, pages 1 & 3

Robyn Page has been announced as Burra’s Citizen of the Year. She is a local school teacher and Chair of the J150 Committee. She has also directed the school’s musical productions and been acting as Senior Student Co-ordinator at BCS.

The Event of the Year Award has gone to the Back to Burra Schools Committee.

Issue 244, 24 January 1996, page 2

The Arrest of two Adelaide Men who had been living on a property near Eudunda has led to the recovery of four stolen vehicles and stolen property worth $20,000. Much of the property stolen recently from the Burra Golf Club and the Burra Bazaar was recovered.

Theft. Between 28 December and 2 January about 1,000 litres of diesel fuel worth c. $750 was stolen from Richard’s Garage.

Burra Morgan Road

The sealing of this road has begun. The road is presently sealed for 20 km west from Morgan. Sealing of the next 17 km has now commenced and should be completed in September this year. The entire project is due for completion in mid-1999. It involves a major rebuilding of the road, not just a sealing of the existing road.

Issue 244, 24 January 1996, page 6

Shirley & Brian Thamm have recently recorded the call of the frog Crina deserticola or the Desert Frog near the Pig & Whistle crossing – they sent their recordings to Frogcensus 1995.

BCS. Thirteen of fourteen students successfully completed their SACE in 1995.

Six students were offered University of SA or TAFE places in the first round of offers.

Issue 245, 31 January 1996, page 1

Accident. Two cars were involved in a head-on collision 43 km east of Burra on the Morgan Road on Friday afternoon. The driver of one car was flown by helicopter to Adelaide and an unconscious woman was taken to the Burra Hospital. Two other adults and two children were taken to the Waikerie Hospital and released.

Issue 245, 31 January 1996, page 2

Theft. About $250 worth of food and drink items was stolen from the Burra Swimming Pool canteen on 22-23 January. Damage to the building amounted to c. $500. On the same night a car in Market Square received c. $1,500 damage to its paintwork.

Burra Tourism

In 1995:

Total visitor numbers at the Information Centre were 70,866.

Total passports sold, 4,387. (Compared with 4,810 in 1994.)

Total payments to the National Trust, $52,816.58.

Issue 245, 31 January 1996, page 3

Burra’s Future

A joint meeting was held of Burra Traders’ Association, Burra Burra DC, the Main Street Committee & Burra Residents & Ratepayers’ Association. The main aim was to discuss key points in the report by Vincent Bourke, aimed at restoring a sense of community and increasing avenues of communication between the Council and the community – perhaps the need for something like a Burra Progress Association. This was seen as particularly pertinent in the face of a possible loss of an independent Burra Burra DC and a winding up of the Main Street Committee. A number of ideas were floated:

Promotion of more conferences and enhancement of facilities for same

A light industrial zone to encourage more businesses in Burra

Encouragement of home-based industries

The expansion of the school to agricultural college status

Ongoing cultural activities and a craft centre

The establishment of a retirement village

A permaculture centre

A mushroom farm in the Unicorn Brewery Cellars

The greening of Burra

Development of ecotourism at Redbanks

Devise on major event each year

Produce a visitors’ guide to the town and district

A meeting will be held in March to decide how best to proceed.

Issue 245, 31 January 1996, page 5

The Tourism Advisory Committee has been set up by the Council as a result of pressure from individuals and groups to have more say in tourism related issues that might affect them. It met first on 16 November 1995 and again on 14 December.

Sheepdog Trials are planned for Easter Weekend, the 6 & 7 April 1996. It is expected about 100 dogs and their handlers will be attracted.

Issue 245, 31 January 1996, page 6

[There is a 2-column report of a successful year of activities for Burra Gumnuts, Brownies and Guides.]

Yasmin Bunney has left Burra to live at Victor Harbor.

Mike Ortmann with his wife Heather and their children Fiona, Helen & Stuart have come to live in Burra. They have taken over the business Burra Auto & Diesel Repairs.

Cicely & Colin Bungey have moved to Burra. Their daughter and son-in-law, Diana & John Agnew and family, have been here for some twelve months.

Issue 245, 31 January 1996, page 8

Obituary. A Legal Notice reveals the death of Lorna Erica James late of 3 Chapel Street, Burra, who died 26 December 1995. [Born Lorna Erica Cox, 21 December 1913 at Redruth and married Kenneth Clifton James in 1940.]

Issue 246, 7 February 1996, page 1

BCS. This year there are a number of adult students doing SACE Stage 2 Personal Information Processing and a couple of others doing other subjects.

Council Amalgamations. Councils from the Mid North met in Clare on 1 February to discuss amalgamation and possible boundary changes. Consultants Emcorp were also present.

Issue 246, 7 February 1996, page 4

BCS. Photo of students new to BCS for 1996.

Issue 246, 7 February 1996, page 5

Ursula Street

The New Work Opportunity Team [Photo] is presently working on upgrading Ursula Street (between the Burra Hotel and the Snack Bar). The team had previously laid a slate footpath in front of Paxton Square cottages in Bridge Terrace and has laid a watering system and seeded the old swimming pool site and also given the creek bank below the motel a facelift. A few months ago they worked on box-thorn eradication at Redbanks Reserve.

Issue 246, 7 February 1996, page 7

The Inaugural Australian Country Games (formerly the Mid North Games) will be held 23 March to 28 April in the towns of Burra, Clare, Jamestown and Spalding. The name change comes from a broadening of the activities to be included, so as to embrace art and culture, food and wine, collecting and other recreational pursuits. [A longer list is printed.]

Issue 247, 14 February 1996, pages 1 & 2

Wesfarmers Dalgety hosted an information evening last Wednesday to introduce the electronic world of buying and selling Australian Wool through Woolink. Wool can be placed for sale by the broker on the seller’s behalf for a set, minimum or best price. Offers are made by computer over the telephone line. Other speakers updated the outlook for the wool industry. The price for wool in 1995 was the lowest ever in real terms. Dr John Miller, urologist, also gave an address on prostate cancer.

Issue 247, 14 February 1996, page 2

Back to Burra schools 1995 Committee had its final meeting and presented a cheque for more than $1,200 to the Jubilee 150 Committee – recommending it go towards paying for plaques for the old schools in the district.

Issue 247, 14 February 1996, page 4

Burra National Trust held its AGM. Report items:

Nan & Les Warnes were given special tribute for their contribution after resigning from the committee this year following 30 years of National Trust membership.

During the year the Trust spent $27,152 on capital improvements to its sites.

Branch membership was 81

Elected were: Chairperson, Elizabeth Robertson; Vice-Chairperson, Maureen Wright; Secretary, Timothy Horsnell; Assistant Secretary, Prue McDonald & Treasurer, Joan de Metris.

Burra Lions Club. Numbers have been reduced by a transfer, two resignations and the death of hard-working President Joan Steele. She will be remembered in the current project at the old town swimming pool garden and barbecue area, where remembrance roses will be planted in winter.

BCS students have not taken part in interschool athletics at Kensington this year. Some parents wonder why and what impact it will have on the development of students and their chance of growing into representatives with a rich life experience.

Burra Burrs DC is seriously looking at recycling waste – beginning with paper and cardboard.

A questionnaire will soon be sent to people calling on them to express their opinion.

Issue 249, 28 February 1996, page 3

Baby Care Room. The Burra Burra DC on Monday night agreed to make their storeroom next to the Tourist Office available for the purpose and voted $500 towards the cost of ant works needed. Council agreed in principle to fund a daily cleaning service, rubbish removal and its opening and closing.

Accident/Obituary. An accident occurred two kilometres south of Burra on the highway. It appears a car driven by Geoff March (35) of Clare veered across the road and struck the diesel tanks of a semi-trailer. The Ford Falcon then spun across the road to rest on the fence-line, where it burst into flames. Mr March was thrown clear of the wreckage, but died at the scene. [Photos.]

Shrove Tuesday, Pancake Night at St Mary’s Hall last week saw some 300 pancakes made and consumed.

Mt Bryan Progress Association (newly formed) has developed a landscape plan for the Mt Bryan Reserve area and suggested it be called ‘The Sir Hubert Wilkins Memorial Park’. Council has adopted the plan in principle, with the exclusion of a proposed development along the old railway line corridor.

BCS sent a group of swimmers to the swimming carnival at Riverton. The school’s drop in numbers meant for the first time it did not compete in Division 1.

[Secondary numbers cited were: Balaklava 432, Clare 375, Kapunda 372, Riverton 236 and Burra 110.]

Issue 249, 28 February 1996, page 8

Burra Burra DC will seek the advice of Mr David Woodard of the Department of Primary Industries on improving water retention of Kooringa Creek and so reducing the flood threat in Burra.

Burra Mine. The SA Meat Corporation dumped machinery at the entrance to the Burra Mine Museum. It had thought it could be used as a water wheel. It will now be removed.

Burra Show Society. AGM.

The last two years have seen a recovery in the society’s fortunes. This year will see more emphasis of trade and active displays. In the last two years there was a 100% and then a 20% increase in the Horses in Action section. For this year: President, Ric Williams; Senior Vice-President, Tom Broad; Junior Vice-President, Pam Shipard and Secretary, Jean Jamieson.

Issue 250, 6 March 1996, page 1

The local Emergency Services Committee has given an award of appreciation to Ruth & Gill Strachan at ‘The Gums’ as an acknowledgement for the help provided at accident scenes on the Morgan Road. [Photo.]

Issue 250, 6 March 1996, pages 1 & 3

Mt Bryan School. Some of the pupils have been found to have significant levels of arsenic in recent tests. Household water tanks are suspected to be the source and the arsenic is believed to have come from dust raised in grading and removing ballast stone from the abandoned railway. This has been removed and crushed at Mt Bryan since early 1994. First grade stone is stockpiled and used on existing lines. The second grade is finer and the third is quite powdery. For years the weeds along the line were controlled by arsenic sprays.

Issue 250, 6 March 1996, page 2

The Brian Letton Show at the Burra Hotel attracted a crowd of about 70 for this well-known country and western artist’s performance.

Regional Art Society. Last year the society held three master classes:

Harry Sherwin (mixed mediums)

Shirley Kimpton (painting on glass)

Sylvia Preston (water colours and mixed mediums)

This year’s first class will be by Heather Parker.

President this year id Pat Brereton. Vice-President is Helen Stockman and Secretary is Glenys Christopher.

Issue 250, 6 March 1996, page 3

Clean Up Australia Campaign. On Sunday 3 March 25 people collected half a tonne of rubbish from roadsides and along Burra Creek. At Redbanks three large trailer loads that were collected barely scratched the surface. Burra Guides collected three large bags of rubbish.

Burra Hospital Board has agreed in principle to pursue the option of forming a joint board with Clare. The two units are already sharing a CEO, payroll and creditor services and service manager positions. Similar amalgamations have become common across SA.

Issue 252, 20 March 1996, pages 1 & 3

Burra Burra DC has decided to restructure the control of its tourism assets. The Council’s Tourism Resource Committee has resolved not to renew the Tourism Executive Officer contract and also the managers of the Tourism Information Centre, Paxton Square Cottages, the Caravan Park and the Mine Museum will all be answerable directly to Council. The Council will also outsource tourism marketing.

Issue 253, 27 March 1996, page 2

‘Mongolata’ comprising 13,194 acres of grazing country 25 miles northeast of Burra was auctioned at Burra Civic Centre 22 March. The top bid of $340,000 was accepted by vendors Heather & Brian Guthrie. The Guthries will now concentrate their farming interests in the Hallett district.

Accident. A single vehicle roll over 9 km south of Hallett on Monday 18 March caused the driver only minor injuries, but damage to the vehicle was estimated at $30,000.

Issue 254, 3 April 1996, page 4

Burra Burra DC has given permission for B-double semi-trailers to access Burra Silos via Copperhouse Street and the by-pass road. Previously they could only travel as far as the Burra Sale Yards.

Issue 254, 3 April 1996, page 5

Burra Picnic Race Club – Thistlebed Races

The weather was perfect and the entertainment non-stop. The crowd was smaller than last year, but entries were not down, with more than 80 horses entered in the day’s events. [Photo.]

Obituary. Ian Auhl 1914-96 (By Mary Woollacott.)

Ian Auhl died peacefully at his Burnside home on 22 March aged 81. Burra has lost one of its greatest visionaries and most devoted sons.

Back in the mid-1960s Ian was Principal of Burra Primary School and his love of the area was apparent in his early writings, published in the Burra Record. He drew attention to the wonderful and fascinating history of the town and its role in the destiny of South Australia. It took Ian’s research, writing and verbal communications skills to bring the knowledge of Burra as a special place to life. An early article was ‘The Girls of Hampton Court’. He later produced a history of the Unicorn Brewery Cellars in ‘In Cellar Cool’ and a history of the Burra Model School for its centenary in 1977. Last September he was proud to have the Local History Room at the Community Library named the ‘Auhl Local History Room’. His masterpiece was of course ‘The Story of the Monster Mine’ – the result of intense labour and meticulous research.

Ian was born in Burra in [27 December 1914] and returned as the Primary School Principal fifty years later until the end of 1967. Throughout his working life he taught at a number of places in SA before retiring due to ill health.

Despite writing books on several other places in the state, it was Burra that had a tenacious grip on his loyalties and he sometimes became a lone and even unpopular voice in his quest for the status he knew to be Burra’s natural right. Saving Burra’s buildings and with them out heritage became his obsession. To achieve this he enlisted the practical and moral help of other townspeople and the local National Trust Branch.

The Burra Conservation Study, which he undertook in 1978 drew many previously little known matters to the attention of those with the power to do something. There were moments when his zeal must have been a thorn in the side of the Town and later the District Council – indeed right up to the end. Today we have a well preserved, interesting and attractive town and much of the initial credit for this development goes to Ian Auhl’s determinism and perseverance over decades.

In 1979 he was awarded the OAM for his services to conservation, but his greatest reward was probably the proclamation by the Governor Dame Roma Mitchell of Burrs as one of the few heritage towns in the country, in February 1993. Ian was the first to admit that much of Burra’s history has yet to be written and to that end he and Eva donated money to the Library’s Research Awards to help with further exploration of our rich past.

Issue 254, 3 April 1996, page 8

Interschool Sports were held at BCS on 29 March with students from Burra, Kapunda and Riverton. Overall the day was won by Riverton with 840.5 points to Kapunda’s 756.5 and Burra’s 618. [Exceptional Burra results are listed.]

Issue 255, 11 April 1996, page 1

BCS has purchased ‘Brewery Hill’, a 170 ha property overlooking Burra to the east. Most is grazing land, but about 40 ha is arable. The hill was previously the property of the Topsfield family. A $30,000 development grant from the Department of Primary Industries has been made available for the farm project as well as a large grant from the Education Department. The Department of Education and Children’s Services has provided a grant of $60,000 towards the purchase. The total investment will be $102,000. A parents’ forum this week was broadened to hear from two guest speakers about what was being done elsewhere – Mike Camac spoke about Cleve Area School and Dean Cresswell spoke as Assistant Principal at Urrbrae High School. Urrbrae has just been granted $16.4 million for a wide ranging development of the campus and curriculum – enabling development beyond wheat, sheep and cattle into horticulture, viticulture, environmental education, land care and associated technologies. Burra can look forward to developing projects with special focus areas for the farm, such as the use of contour banks, water harvesting, ‘alley’ farming, organic farming, rotational grazing and alternative agriculture.

Issue 255, 11 April 1996, page 2

Ian Lillington is facilitating a nine-day course on Permaculture Design at the Coach House from 13 April. Participants are also interested in the Kooringa CoHousing project. [See also advertisement page 9.]

Issue 255, 11 April 1996, page 3

Council Amalgamation discussions continued. The Mid North Local Government Region has released comments on proposals that Burra Burra DC will consider on 15 April and there will be a public meeting to canvass the issues in late April or early May.

The Government requires amalgamations and so far Kapunda and Light have successfully amalgamated and Angaston-Barossa and Tanunda are in the process.

A meeting of regional councils at Saddleworth on 3 April made progress on a potential pattern of amalgamation for the remaining Mid North Councils.

The current proposals involve:

Morgan, Ridley, Truro and Mannum to make a ‘River’ group.

Eudunda, Robertstown and Burra Burra with perhaps Hallett to form an ‘Eastern’ group.

Clare, Riverton, Saddleworth-Auburn with possibly Blyth-Snowtown to make a ‘Central’ group.

Blyth-Snowtown, Mallala and Wakefield Plains could make up a ‘Western’ group.

The councils concerned have yet to consider these suggestions and there would inevitably have to be some fine tuning and public consultation before any final action.

Issue 255, 11 April 1996, page 4

The First Women’s Agricultural Bureau Conference for the newly amalgamated Mid & Northern Regions was held at the Burra Sports Complex on 3 April. [Details are printed.]

Advt. T.J. Miller Band will be at the Burra Hotel, Saturday 30 April. Dinner, Dance & Show. $20 per head.

Issue 255, 11 April 1996, page 5

Mid North Sheepdog Trials – part of the Country Games – were held at Burra Showgrounds on Saturday and Sunday of the Easter Weekend. There were 95 entrants and it involved 300 sheep. The sheep proved unusually intransigent, resulting in many retirements and disqualifications. Antony Ireland of Clements Gap won the open event with ‘Percyton Flo Jo’.

Local farmer Stephen Kellock of Kelvale Merino Stud won the Farmers’ Trial with his Kelpie ‘Tinker’.

The Novice event went to Bernie Simonds with ‘Gramer Nellie’ (Kadina).

Improvers was won by Reg Michael with ‘Amadeus Wally’. (Barunga Gap)

Fastest Penning went to W. Trembath with ‘Willen ET’.

The highest score of the day was by Lew Noble with ‘Tungali Rose’. (South Hummocks)

Issue 256, 17 April 1996, page 1

New Dry Stone Wall. Three renovated cottages in Tiver’s Row have had a traditional dry stone wall built alongside by local tradesmen Chris Kelly and Neil Schiller. [Photo.]

Issue 256, 17 April 1996, pages 1 & 2

Council Amalgamations

Hallett DC Chairman, Peter Mattey updated residents on the amalgamation issue at meetings in Terowie and Hallett last Tuesday and Wednesday. He said there was no alternative to amalgamation and that Hallett Councillors considered the western cluster with Crystal Brook and Red Hill to be too remote and sought discussions with Burra Burra, Robertstown and Eudunda Councils. A phase two memorandum had been signed with Peterborough Town and District Councils, but a number of issues were still to be resolved. An alternative to going with the north or the south grouping was to split Hallett and so go both ways. The Wednesday meeting asked the Council to enter phase 2 negotiations with the southern grouping and if possible to re-open the discussions with Jamestown and Spalding.

Issue 256, 17 April 1996, page 2

The Editor reprints part of an editorial from Issue 208 of 27 March 1995 about the long delay in getting an industrial zone for Burra. The editorial suggested it could be time to dismiss consultants Bone & Tonkin.

He then went on to say that it took almost another year of inactivity before the consultants were sacked. Thus two years had passed with still no move towards the development of an industrial zone. He said demand could expect to increase with the sealing of the Burra-Morgan Road.

Issue 256, 17 April 1996, page 3

Burra Table Tennis Club has entered four teams in the North Eastern Table Tennis Association for 1996.

Goyder House held its AGM on 14 April. Richard Secomb was re-elected as chairman of the Student Boarding Facility. In the past year Peter and Maureen Hirschausen had been the house parents. Brett Hammerl had been the tutor and Jim Jackaman is filling that role this year. [The committee is listed.]

Issue 256, 17 April 1996, page 4

BCS sent a full team (after an initial decision not to compete) to the competition at Kensington Olympic Sports Field. Burra ended the day top of the G1 Division in both Boys & Girls Teams.

Issue 257, 24 April 1996, page 1

AdChem entertained visitors from its largest customer, Osmose (New York), at their Burra facility last week. [Photo and more details.]

Issue 257, 24 April 1996, pages 1 & 4

Council Amalgamations

The southern group of Councils has approached Hallett to enter into merger discussions. Last night Jamestown and Spalding met with Hallett Council even though they are well advanced with their own merger talks. A large number of Hallett residents seem to favour a split in the district with some area going north and some south, but Peterborough Town & District Councils are unenthusiastic about that idea. The southern option seems the only one still viable. Eudunda is arguing with Saddleworth-Auburn over an area of land near Marrabel and this may slow an outcome for Burra. It is hoped to present options to residents by the end of May.

Issue 257, 24 April 1996, page 2

Redbanks Reserve Committee hopes to have part of the reserve open to the public soon. Further cleaning up is needed. The use of firearms and off-road vehicles is and will continue to be prohibited. The idea of a Friends Group is being floated.

Issue 257, 24 April 1996, page 3

George & Gladys Heinrich (nee Scroop of Burra) now of Kingston S.E. celebrated their Golden Wedding last week.

Alison Eberhard has been promoted to a full-time position at the Clare branch of the National Australia Bank.

Rachael O’Connor has moved from Burra Stationers to a position at Naracoorte.

Peter & Josie Turner and children Nick and Emma are moving to Kangaroo Island.

Burra Oval has had extensive road works done around its perimeter and a plaque placed on the pillar of the oval gates.

Brewery Cellars have had a stone wall rebuilt.
