Issue 258, 1 May 1996, page 1

Neil Page, business development advisor with the Mid North Development Board has reported to the Council on the future or tourism in Burra – especially in the light of Council mergers. He recommends that certain aspects of tourism operations be transferred to community hands (excluding Paxton Square Cottages and the Caravan Park). An independent board should be established and not a Section 199 Committee.

Finance for the Board’s operations should be a mixture of:

Tourism operations including the passport.

Council grants

Membership fees

Mid North Development Board

The Board should be encouraged to pursue the use of volunteer staff, traineeships and other CES or DEET incentives for employment.

Issue 258, 1 May 1996, page 2

Letter. Vincent Burke writes urging those who are weekenders in Burra to fill up their petrol tanks while there – it may be a few cents dearer, but it supports the town and in fact with holiday price hikes in Adelaide, it was recently 80c per litre there and 72c per litre in Burra.

Issue 258, 1 May 1996, page 3

Burra Oval. The roadway between the gate and the Sports Complex has been sealed and extensive kerbing installed. The funds of more than $10,000 for the project came jointly from the Council and the Sports Club Committee. Playground equipment has also been installed.

Issue 258, 1 May 1996, page 9

Advt. Burra Hospital Auxiliary is sponsoring Annie Get Your Gun by the Jamestown Drama Group Inc. at Burra Town Hall on Sunday 2 June at 2 p.m. Adults $10, Concession $7 and Children 5-15, $5.

Issue 259, 8 May 1996, pages 1 & 2

Matt Reilly took a trio of old identities on a round trip through the eastern country that they were associated with when young. They were:

Ron Dewhirst (88), who had an accounting business in Booborowie until Trevor Willis took over some ten years ago. Ron recalled being a driller for I.J. Warnes in the 1920s and of riding his bike in from Koomooloo to play football in Burra.

Bob Radford’s family started at Glenora in 1892 and at Canegrass in 1903.

John McBride, also in his 80s started at 16 on a station out of Mannahill and spent nine years there, until war broke out. He was then stationed at Parafield and Mallala as a flying instructor, before being sent with 24th Squadron south of Darwin, from where sorties were run to Bali. After the war he went to Kia Ora, which he managed for forty years.

The group went out to Old Koomooloo, where Eddie Keogh and his team were shearing. They had lunch at Canegrass, where Bob Radford reminisced about how they bought sheep at Wilcannia and walked them down to Canegrass. They then passed Pine Valley, Sturt Vale and saw the abandoned homestead at Braeside before going on to Murkaby as they came home.

Issue 259, 8 May 1996, page 2

Danny Smith is the new working overseer at the Burra Burra DC. He and his wife Kathryn with son Cameron have come to Burra from Goolwa.

Ken & Ros. Horne and children Sally and Russell have moved down the highway to Barton Hill, where Ken has been employed for some months.

BCS. Vicki McDonald has taken over as the bursar at BCS.

Ian Fewings is replacing Bill O’Malley, who is on long service leave.

A group of local teenagers will go to Adelaide on Thursday night to attend the opera The Pearl Fishers.

Obituary. Jill Catt of Booborowie died on Saturday aged 74.

[Born Jill Tiver, 31 January 1922 at Kooringa. Married Leonard Clifford Catt in 1947.]

Issue 259, 8 May 1996, page 3

Burra Mine

On Saturday two eleven-year-olds, a girl and a boy, entered the mine site through a hole in the fence. They slid down a loose slope and came to rest on a ledge near the water’s edge. A third child with them ran for help. Police, parents and the local SES were alerted. After a rescue by abseiling down the open cut wall was deemed too hazardous due to falling rocks, the pair were retrieved by boat.

The SA Wether Trial Association will hold its annual shearing event at Balah Station this Friday. Twenty-five teams of eight Merino wethers from NSW, SA & Victoria will be involved in the trial.

Issue 259, 8 May 1996, page 6

Burra Main Street Committee has organised some cultural activities in the town to complement the Antique & Decorating Fair on 11 & 12 May.

Dinner Dance with Dennis Sheridan Swingtet at the Burra Hotel.

Glenys Christopher is organising an art exhibition in the Burra Art Gallery.

There will be a display of Dick Cleland’s photographs.

Poetry readings in the Burra Hotel and a workshop on Sunday.

Barber Shop Quartet in the Main Street on Sunday.

National Trust will run fire engine rides.

Various places will be open for food and if the weather proves chilly, mulled wine at the Burra Hotel.

Issue 259, 8 May 1996, page 10

The State Conference of Weightwatchers was held at Burra over the past weekend. More than 300 members attended. The Burra branch started in 1972.

Issue 259, 8 May 1996, page 11

Birth. To Barry (Stretch) & Jill Read on 26 April, a son, Douglas James.

Burra Burra DC has instituted the recycling of cardboard and paper from selected Burra businesses. A woolpack and frame from Red-Line Waste Management of Kapunda will be filled and collected by them as required. Residents can take part by taking their paper and cardboard to the woolpack at the Burra Rubbish Dump. A possible kerbside recycling service is being investigated.

Issue 260, 15 May 1996, page 1

AN has been testing for arsenic at Mt Bryan, in the former railway yards and in the town soil and water. Tests have found elevated levels in the railway area, but nearby soils and water tanks returned readings below levels requiring further investigation.

Helen Stockman has been appointed co-ordinator of Burra’s Main Street Program for the next twelve months, replacing Tim Horsnell.

Issue 260, 15 May 1996, page 2

Burra’s Cultural Weekend brought the town alive. A record crowd attended the 5th Antique & Decorating Fair. Market Square was decorated with balloons. The Gallery had a display of photographs by Dick Cleland, a barbershop quartet wandered the town centre and four poets provided poetry readings. Martin Johnson conducted a poetry workshop. On Saturday night the Dennis Sheridan Swingtet played for a dinner dance at the Burra Hotel. Food outlets and antique shops did well over the weekend.

Letter. Lorraine & Don Thompson of Pacific Palms NSW write in praise of the restored Paxton Square cottages.

Issue 260, 15 May 1996, page 3

The Burra art Gallery had an exhibition of 18 local artists as part of last week’s festivities. Thirty-five paintings were displayed along with the four S.T. Gill paintings loaned by the Council. Maureen Wright opened the exhibition. Almost 300 attended the gallery over the weekend.

The Antique Fair was described as a resounding success, with a record crowd passing through the Town Hall.

Issue 260, 15 May 1996, page 4

The Mt Bryan Hall Committee’s Annual Dinner Dance on Saturday 4 May was a success and c. $800 profit was made on the night. A farewell presentation was made to Melvin & Estelle Pearce, who will soon be moving to Adelaide.

Issue 260, 15 May 1996, page 5

Snowy Mountain Walk. An expedition organised and led by Mike Fretwell of Burra has completed a 210 km trek in the Snowy Mountains over 17 days in April. [Photo.]

Issue 260, 15 May 1996, page 8

Burra & District Obedience Dog Club held its AGM on 5 May. Elected: President, Renee Wilson; Secretary, Pat Svensdotter and Treasurer, Tony Svensdotter.

The club, now in its fourth year, has seven instructors and about 30 members.

Trial Wethers at Balah. The first shearing of this three year trial of wethers was completed on Friday 10 May at Balah Station. [Further details are printed.]

Issue 260, 15 May 1996, page 9

Recycling. Redline Waste Management has offered to collect paper waste from Burra and the Council has seized the opportunity. Redline will provide the containers and collect them from a central point in Burra. Various business sites will use woolpacks to collect their waste and Redline is looking for a club or organisation to help with paper drives to collect household paper.

Issue 261, 22 May 1996, page 1

BCS students won both the junior and senior heat finals in the ‘Voice of Youth’ held at Jamestown last Friday. Senior spoke for eight minutes and juniors for six, with prepared speeches and both then had three minutes to deliver short notice speeches. The winners were Evelyn Button and Rachel Vogel. The semi-finals will be held at Caritas College at Pt Augusta on 2 June.

Issue 261, 22 May 1996, page 2

Break & Enter. Someone broke into the Uniting Church Op Shop on 18 May and caused about $200 damage by jumping out through a rear window. Burra Bowling Club was also entered and drinks, cigarettes and bingo tickets stolen.

Letter. Jane & Peter Strawbridge write concerning the Neil Page Report on Tourism in Burra.

The report recommended a budget figure for tourism the same as last year’s and the establishment of an incorporated association to oversee the tourist office and other site activities excluding the Caravan Park and the Paxton Square Cottages.

‘Although this report sets council tourism ventures in the right direction for privatisation, there are some areas that need careful consideration’

If you have concerns read the report and voice your concerns to Councillors before 31 May.

Issue 261, 22 May 1996, page 3

Garry & Jenny Gebhardt and children are moving or have moved to Tanunda.

Brian & Angie Jamieson have gone to Keith with their two children.

Estelle & Melvin Pearce will be moving to Adelaide.

Dot & David Sandland are going to a property in the Truro area.

Cory Heneker has transferred in his printing apprenticeship to Gawler.

Judy Reilly has received her bachelor of Nursing Degree.

BCS students recently enjoyed their annual camp with a stay at Warradale in Adelaide.

Issue 261, 22 May 1996, page 4

Copperhouse School Plaque. A cairn for the Copperhouse School plaque has now been completed due to the generosity of Mr John Brown, a former student. Thanks also go to Mrs Trigg for allowing it to be sited near the school in which she now lives.

Issue 261, 22 May 1996, page 11

Lower North Golf Group Open was held at Burra on Sunday. Burra Club Champion David Robinson took out the event after a one hole play-off.

The Burra Team of Dave Robinson, Neville Kelly, Gus Wenzel and Pat Hallion also took out the Championship Team Event.

Issue 262, 29 May 1996, page 1

Burra-Morgan Road

The primer seal should be down on the first 20 km by the end of June, with the final seal to be done in September. Tenders for the final 45 km will be called in July 1996, with the planned finishing date by December 1998.

Issue 262, 29 May 1996, pages 1 & 3

Council Amalgamations

Hallett, Burra Burra, Robertstown and Eudunda DCs have signed a memorandum of understanding to investigate and report on likely gains from their merger. Ratepayers in the northern region of Hallett Council would prefer to merge with Peterborough, but the Corporation of Peterborough has indicated it does not want to merge with Hallett ‘Wholly or in part’. Any merging of Councils would involve consolidation of human and material resources and the rationalisation of boundaries, with consequent boundary adjustments.

Issue 262, 29 May 1996, page 2

Break-in. Two youths have been arrested for the recent break-in at the Burra Bowling Club.

Accident. A woman pedestrian was flown from Burra to the RAH in a critical condition after being struck by a car on 26 May. [Issue 262, 5 June 1996, page 1 gives the location as alongside the Burra Civic Centre, with the car travelling east.]

Issue 262, 29 May 1996, page 3

Burra Girl Guides Support Group had a successful ‘Night of Fashion & Frivolity’ at the Guide Hall recently.

Burra Picnic Race Club meeting at Thistlebeds was again a success, though due to a number of competing events attendance was lower than in previous years. Paul O’Bryan’s Band kept people dancing till the small hours and Day Care members provided food till 2 a.m. The reasonable profit allowed a reserve for next year as well as $1,000 for the RFDS and $500 to the Nursing Mothers Association of Burra.

Issue 262, 29 May 1996, page 4

Farrell Flat Dirt Kart Club held its monthly meeting on 26 May.

Birth. To Craig & Elisabeth Wissell of Burra on 22 May, a daughter, Caroline Elisabeth.

Birth. To Sharon & Alan Wiech of Oakvale Station on 21 May, a son, Tom Daniel.

Issue 262, 29 May 1996, page 9

Advt. Burra Hospital Auxiliary is sponsoring Annie Get Your Gun by the Jamestown Drama Group Inc. at Burra Town Hall on Sunday 2 June at 2 p.m. Admission $10, Concession $7, Children 5-15 $5.

Issue 263, 5 June 1996, page 1

Local Emergency Services groups met at Burra last Tuesday to hear a talk by Senior Constable Graham Hill of Port Pirie on crime scene preservation at emergency call-outs. About 37 members attended.

Issue 263, 5 June 1996, page 2

Letter. Ada Barkell of Booborowie writes deriding the idea that 85-100 people in Burra earned their living from tourist related jobs. She is tired of all the positive hype centred on the tourism industry and calls upon the editor to check his facts.

The editor replied with the following income sources:

24 Bed & Breakfast

14 hotel, motel and caravan park staff

20 eating services

5 tourist office staff

8 National Trust guides

10 second hand shops

12 various other shops

And perhaps 30 to 40 in casual employment like cleaning and waiting staff etc.

30% of Burra Community Press income (equivalent to 1 full-time position) is tourist related.

Issue 263, 5 June 1996, page 3

Birth. To Anne & Chris Drew of Burra, at Flinders Hospital on 27 April, a son, Thomas Henry.

A grandchild for Roma & Peter Drew of Booborowie.

Issue 263, 5 June 1996, page 4

5BCS Radio

Volunteer students play music and make announcements via a loudspeaker into the amphitheatre during lunchtimes. There is potential to broadcast to the town using the FM transmitter purchased in 1993 with funds provided by CAP. Trial transmissions were made in early 1995, but proved to interfere with TV reception – especially reception of Adelaide stations and so radio transmissions were suspended. A new trial of transmissions is planned to measure the extent of the problem and to investigate remedies.

Mid North Job Growth. Figures are printed for eight towns comparing 1991 & 1995.

Issue 263, 5 June 1996, page 5

Hallett-Terowie Railway Corridor

An article reports on the revegetation of this rail corridor – first seeding took place in May c. 3 km south of Terowie. Further seeding was planned for late May and June.

Issue 263, 5 June 1996, page 6

Burra’s 1924 T-Model Ford Fire Truck is currently centre of a display in Wesfarmers Dalgety’s Market Square showrooms. It has been lent by the National Trust. It saw service in Burra in the 1920s and 1930s and was superseded by the Diamond T. It is said that the last fire it attended was of a house that burnt down before it could be started. It was discarded and went to a farm, but was rescued and restored in the early 1980s. It then spent some time on display at the fire station in Wakefield Street in Adelaide.

Issue 263, 5 June 1996, page 7

Perpetual Lease Properties will be offered freehold in a move to secure greater security and improved tenure in agricultural areas. This offer does not extend to leases under the War Service Land Settlement Act and neither does it extend to rangeland pastoral country. It is likely to be offered to some 5,000 leaseholders.

Issue 264, 12 June 1996, page 1

Burra Hospital offered kidney health tests over three days last week and more than fifty people took the opportunity to be evaluated. [Photo of Raelene Waters & Alison Donhardt.]

Issue 264, 12 June 1996, page 2

Birth. To Janine & Andrew Baikie at Burra 2 June, a son, Joshua Alexander. [Photo.]

Issue 264, 12 June 1996, page 3

AdChem has just recorded a year of operation without any lost time due to accident or incident.

Advt. Eclectic Pelican Presents: The King’s Player – Shakespeare meets stand-ups by Trevor Gare and directed by Joanna Weir. Burra Town Hall, Friday 28 June at 8 p.m.

Issue 265, 19 June 1996, page 1

Woolgrowers are pushing for a reform of the fixed selling schedule for the 2.3 million bale wool stockpile – in favour of a more commercially flexible selling strategy. A vote on the proposal has been organised.

[Further details are printed.]

Issue 265, 19 June 1996, page 2

Advt. BCS. SRC Film Night, 21 June in BCS Gym at 8 p.m. Robin Williams in Jumanji.

Break-in. The Burra juvenile involved in the Burra Bowling Club break-in a few weeks ago was sentenced to four months detention. Another youth involved has been remanded for sentencing.

Letter. John G. Monfries, Secretary of Burra & District Residents & Ratepayers’ Association.

Is relieved to finally receive some advice from the Burra Burra DC about the reform of councils in SA.

Wished to make the following points about council amalgamation:

There has been no open debate between the proponents of amalgamation and the community.

This means the community has not been made aware of any disadvantages.

The community has not been given the opportunity to express their wishes for or against amalgamation or in respect of the proposed partners in proposed amalgamation.

The Memorandum of Understanding was entered into without community consultation.

The community has not been advised of any possible savings or other long term benefits.

Will local government remain ‘local’ and can we be assured there will be no loss of local democracy?

We believe some form of open forum is needed.

Issue 265, 19 June 1996, page 3

Marriage. Clare, last Saturday

Brett Eberhard married Rachel Maloney.

Obituary. Raymond Spackman died at Pt Augusta on 31 May aged 45.

Obituary. Mrs Esther Fairchild died at Burra Hospital on 3 June.

[Born Esther Blondina Semmler, 29 January 1911 at Geranium Plains. Married George Garfield Fairchild in 1933.]

Colleen & Shane Ramsey have moved to Broken Hill.

Issue 265, 19 June 1996, page 5

Burra Burra DC

Council will continue to operate the Burra Tourist Office, but with an increasing focus on it as a commercial entity – aiming for a balanced budget for the office in the 1996-97 financial year. Under this arrangement it will no longer provide the function of booking accommodation for visitors, neither will it book tours to private operators. Souvenirs and consignment goods will no longer be for sale. The upstairs room of the centre will not be used at all due to the hazardous nature of the stairs.

Issue 265, 19 June 1996, page 8

Burra Red Cross reported an average attendance at meetings for 1995-96 of 14. $272.10 was donated to help with the Burra Kindergarten fence. During the year $4,399.65 was raised and sent to headquarters. Red Cross had a float in the J150 Procession. During the year, long service awards were presented to Pat Kakoschke, Isabel Moxham, Irene Campbell and Joan Steele.

Also during the year Lorna James and Joan Steele died.

Elected were: President, F. Jones; Vice-Presidents, I. Hirschausen & A. Kelly; Secretary, J. Twin and Treasurer, P. Kakoschke.

Issue 265, 19 June 1996, page 13

Advt. Audrey & Bob Angel will celebrate their Golden Wedding with an open house at Maryann & Stephen’s home on 30 June.

Issue 266, 26 June 1996, page 1

Burra Burra DC. Rates

Council has decided on a 4% increase in rates, in line with inflation.

Burra Town 0.8336 cents in the dollar with a minimum payment of $335.

Rural rate of 0.534 cents in the dollar with a minimum payment of $335.

(Minimum rate to apply to town properties with value of less than $40,187 and other towns of less than $62,734.)

Issue 266, 26 June 1996, page 2

Letter. Barbara Wallis writes concerning the decision to strip Morphett’s Engine House of all its displays and exhibits so it can be put on the passport key system. This is said to be because it has gone over budget for the last two years, but when it was run by a section 199 committee it stayed within budget and even made a profit – the change she described as vandalism.

Letter. Wendy Burge & Stephen Angel write re further donations for the Baby Care Room.

Burra Quilters Raffle $335.

Burra Picnic Race Club $500.

Various others $190.

Burra Uniting Church Op Shop $200.

Plus donations of furnishings and labour.

Burra CWA AGM recently elected: President, Barbara Francis; Vice-Presidents, K. Scholz & E. Baker; Secretary, Peg Ahwan and Treasurer, Jean Jamieson.

Membership is 18 and 3 Life Members. Donations to State Office this year totalled $730.

$200 was given towards the new Burra Kindergarten fence.

Issue 266, 26 June 1996, page 4

Birth. To Mishelle & Paul Cousins on Monday at Burra Hospital, a son, Joshua Paul.

Burra Art Gallery has yet to be officially opened, but has been very busy.

The current exhibition has artists rotating paintings and new items added on a weekly basis. Jill Foster’s pottery is particularly interesting. Future exhibitions will be Marie Johnson-Harrison 2-28 July and ‘Junk Bonds’, Art from junk 2031 August.

Burra Burra DC

Denis & Joan Durdin have had their lease of the Caravan Park extended to 30 June 1998.

Council hopes to open part of Redbanks Reserve by August.

Stage 1 involves the waterfall entrance on the Eastern Road and a loop walking trail to the pump house.

Issue 266, 26 June 1996, page 5

Kooringa CoHousing

The project has received approval, but now it appears that following cuts by the new Federal Government the funding for the project is in doubt. A decision will be made today at a meeting of SA Community Housing Authority. Development work on designs and getting approvals will not be wasted as examples set are already being taken up by projects elsewhere in SA.

Issue 267, 3 July 1996, page 1

Woolgrowers met in Burra last week and voted 107 to 30 to support moves to alter the fixed selling schedule of the wool stockpile to a more flexible strategy. Countrywide the move has 90% support. In the last six years the combination of drought and the stockpile has seen sheep numbers fall from 150 to 120 million.

Issue 267, 3 July 1996, page 2

Audrey & Bob Angel of Burra have celebrated their Golden Wedding.

Kelly McInnes has left school to take up a traineeship at the local stationery and gift shop and part-time at the chemist’s too.

Birth. To Kent & Kate Burton (nee Nicholls) at the Women’s & Children’s Hospital 21 June, a son, Alexander Nicholas.

Obituary. Ross Berryman died on 26 June aged 75. He was the husband of Joan.

[Born 29 November 1920 at Clare. Buried Burra 1 July 1996.]

Issue 267, 3 July 1996, page 3

Editorial. The editor expresses disappointment that the anticipated public meeting on council amalgamations, scheduled for May, has not yet occurred. The Council is developing a proposal to be put to such a meeting – so far the community has not been consulted on the possibilities of a merger with Clare without Robertstown and Eudunda or a merger with Hallett alone.

Issue 267, 3 July 1996, page 6

Burra Residents and Ratepayers’ Association will hold a meeting on Sunday afternoon 21 July to address the issue of council amalgamations.

‘The King’s Player’, Trevor Gare performed more than twenty roles in an evening of Mediaeval Festivities in the Burra Town Hall on Friday night. The crowd was small, but they thoroughly enjoyed themselves, with a night of frivolity and feasting accompanied by mediaeval music from the well-known band ‘Hedgehog’.

Issue 268, 10 July 1996, page 1

Guppy (or the Small Pond Clown Show) performed at the Uniting Church Hall on Wednesday to the delight of children and adults alike.

Burra Burra DC. Expenditure on tourism will decrease in the 1996-97 financial year by c. 20% to $534,120 from $698,989.

Issue 268, 10 July 1996, page 2

Burra Residents & Ratepayers’ Association has sought the support of the Burra Traders’ Association in calling for a public meeting on council amalgamations.

The Local Government Boundary Reform Board will meet with Council representatives in Burra at the end of July to discuss council merger concerns.

Issue 268, 10 July 1996, page 3

Burra, Clare and Snowtown Hospital Boards continue to meet to advance their merger into a single Board of Directors. Initiatives to improve services are already being taken across the three hospitals, even before a final constitution has been agreed. They are sharing resources and expertise in quality assurance, occupational health, safety and welfare, payroll and financial reporting and a service manager. The new board will also manage the Lower North Community health Service.

Issue 268, 10 July 1996, page 4

Burra Burra DC.

Work planned for 1996-97 includes:

$3,500 for Burra Baby Care Room.

$5,000 for ongoing headstone restoration at Burra Cemetery.

$3,500 to paint the Burra Art Gallery.

$8,500 for Redbanks Reserve development.

$12,000 for a concept plan for Market Square and a work practice policy regarding heritage.

Sealing around Burra Oval will also continue.

About $15,000 is provided for a unisex disabled toilet opposite the Town Hall.

Sealing of the Town Hall car park.

[Further details are printed.]

The Wild Colonial Girl by Ann Clancy.

There is a 12⁄3 column on this historical novel about a young female who masquerades as a boy and becomes a bullocky c. 1849-66 and which includes a period in Burra in 1851.

Issue 269, 17 July 1996, page 1

Lesley Phillips, Director of Nursing at Burra Hospital has been appointed acting Director of Nursing at Clare Hospital for the next six months. Noreen Hallion will be acting Director of Nursing at Burra for the next six months.

Burra Senior Citizens’ Garden

A report from the KESAB crew is printed.

Council installed a mains fed water system south of the Kingston St Bridge and a bore fed one north of it.

Issue 269, 17 July 1996, page 7

Robertstown Council has been given $10,000 grant towards the Burra Creek Gorge Park developments.

Issue 270, 24 July 1996, page 1

Drew & Crewes’ Building

The eastern wall of a storage shed at the rea of Drew & Crewes’ building collapsed on Friday after heavy rains – perhaps the result of missing guttering. It was previously a storeroom for Drew & Crewes’ and then Bence’s. Most recently it was tenanted by Off-beat Arts & Crafts. Heritage advisor Douglas Alexander will advise on causes and a possible course of action.

Issue 270, 24 July 1996, pages 1 & 5

Burra Residents & Ratepayers’ Association held a well-attended meeting at the Sports Complex on Sunday afternoon and resolved to ask that the Council consider amalgamation with either Clare, Riverton and Saddleworth-Auburn or Robertstown, Eudunda and Part of Hallett. District Clerk, Steve Kerrigan explained the rate situation for the Burra Burra DC compared with the average for Clare, Riverton and Saddleworth-Auburn. Burra’s town rate was 46% higher and its rural rate 37% higher. He said Council had wished to gather enough information on merger proposals before calling a public meeting planned for 12 August. Council considered Burra would be better off if it remained the centre of a new district. Cr Kellock said that a number of Clare Councillors had said that they thought Burra’s eastern boundary was too far away and they did not want to include parts of Hallett, Robertstown or Eudunda.

Issue 270, 24 July 1996, page 2

Letter. Louise Miksza of Craigmore writes expressing shock and dismay at the degradation of the Burra Mine site:

The ore dressing floor was overrun by weeds.

Route signs were missing or illegible.

Pepper tree growth threatened the ore dressing tower.

Footpaths were eroded and hazardous.

The condition of the composting toilets was disgusting.

Council’s plan to leave the place unstaffed would be dangerous.

[The last point is elaborated upon.]

Letter. Ian Lillington writes regretting the departure from Burra of David Wilson, naturopath. He thanks him for his service over the preceding two years.

Issue 270, 24 July 1996, page 3

Stephen Short of Farrell Flat will compete in Tri-Track, a competition between Loxton, Renmark and Morgan Kart Clubs. Stephen has his eyes on the Australian titles to be held in Morgan in October 1997.

[Photo & further details.]

Issue 270, 24 July 1996, page 5

A Dog Attack on a farm near Burra on 17 July resulted in the death of ten sheep at a cost to the farmer of c. $300 in lost production.

Issue 270, 24 July 1996, page 6

Birth. To Monique & Vic Haddow on 10 July at Burra Hospital, a son, Lachlan James. [Photo.]

Issue 270, 24 July 1996, page 9

Advt. Burra Bootscooters Line dancing Cabaret, Saturday 27 July, [Burra Town Hall], BYO drinks and supper.

Issue 271, 31 July 1996, page 1

Burra Traders’ Association held its AGM on 25 July. The guest speaker was Elspeth Radford of Saltbush Clothing. She spoke on how it was quite feasible to run a business distributing product around the country from Burra.

Barry Wright read the annual report in the absence of Freda Pink (who was on holidays).

Elected were: President, Barry Wright; Vice-President, Phillip Tanner; Treasurer, Avian Pink.

Issue 271, 31 July 1996, page 2

Accident. A Farrell Flat man rolled his vehicle on the Barrier Highway just south of Burra on Saturday morning. He was unconscious in the vehicle for about six hours before being found and was transferred to the RAH with a badly broken ankle and minor head injuries – he will not be playing football for the Rams for the rest of the year.

Issue 271, 31 July 1996, page 3

Burra Burra DC

There has been correspondence from the Local Government Association Mutual Liability Scheme re the Draft Joint Use Agreement between the Council and DECS for the use of the Burra Community Pool. Council has decided that DECS be required to complete the process to divide the land on which the pool and surrounds, including the car parks, and to effect the transfer of it to the Council as a matter of urgency. Local State MP Mr Rob Kerin will be asked to assist.

Issue 271, 31 July 1996, page 4

Burra Burra DC. Meeting of 16 July

O’Connor’s shed is to be used to store the baled cardboard and paper recyclable material collected from Burra.

A sign is to be erected acknowledging the work of Senior Citizens in the garden area along the Burra Creek.

Council will loan $3,500 to the Burra Art Gallery interest free for the opening of the gallery – the sum to be repaid by 31 March 1997.

Council will approach the National Trust requesting they take responsibility for the old Burra Record printing machinery on behalf of the Burra Community.

Issue 271, 31 July 1996, page 5

Burra Pony Club competed on Saturday 6 July at Stirling North in the Northern Zone eliminations.

[Results are printed.]

The Kooringa CoHousing Project will not go ahead. Four years of work went into planning, getting approvals and finding funding for the project that went to tender earlier this year. The tenders were over budget and after redesigning work they remained so. Extra funding was not available and even more so after changes to Commonwealth funding from 1 July 1996.

Issue 271, 31 July 1996, page 7

Burra Community Print and Burra Broadcaster.

After three years as manager and proprietor here Terry Wilson has taken a new position as managing editor of the Northern Argus at Clare. Apprenticed to the family business in Pinnaroo, Terry was judge apprentice of the year by the Lithographic Institute in 1985. He ran the print shop on Groote Eylandt and then worked in high quality colour printing in Adelaide before coming to Burra in 1993 to run his own business. Burra Community Print will continue with Rob Wilson Sen. Editing the Broadcaster and Jill & Julie running the office and typesetting etc.

Issue 272, 7 August 1996, page 1

Burra-Morgan Road. All or sections of the road are likely to be closed to expedite sealing of the route. The first stage is expected to be completed in the next two months and the section from ‘The Gums’ to Burra will commence in November.

Burra’s Effluent Drainage System has been cleaned and cleared of obstructions using the latest technology. [Photo.]

Burra Art Gallery. The ‘Junk Bonds’ exhibition opened on 3 August, featuring art made from found and recycled materials. The exhibition is touring SA, Victoria, NSW & NT till the end of 1997.

Issue 272, 7 August 1996, page 7

Burra Golf Club. Championships 1996.

A Grade Neville (Ned) Kelly defeated Pat Hallion

B Grade Andrew Spackman defeated Bill McMahon

C Grade Darren Taylor defeated Tom Boulger

Keith Sichler won the Bogisch Match Cup.

Issue 273, 14 August 1996, page 1

Council Merger Meeting

Monday night’s public meeting was poorly attended, prompting Council Chairman Graham Kellock to conclude that people must be satisfied with what the Council was doing. He said that after much discussion the Council’s preferred option was to merge Burra Burra with Part of Hallett, Robertstown & Eudunda. A Structured Reform Working Party from those four councils had been meeting since 4 June 1996 and had reported to the Local Government Boundary Reform Board. In response to questions he said:

The Clare, Riverton and Saddleworth-Auburn option was not favoured either by that group or by Eudunda and Robertstown.

Cr Kellock had favoured one large group comprising both the optional groupings, but this had been opposed by Eudunda and Riverton.

The population for the council areas concerned was:

Eudunda 1362

Robertstown 812

Part Hallett 260

Burra Burra 1971 For a total of 4405

Clare 4200

Riverton 1643

Saddleworth-Auburn 2294 For a total of 8137

Burra already co-operated with Hallett, Eudunda & Robertstown on weed control and the Robertstown Council boundary was only 10 km from Burra.

On the other hand Burra and Clare Hospitals were linked and some Burra students went to Clare schools.

The proposed representation on a merged council would be:

Burra 5

Hallett 2

Eudunda 3

Robertstown 1

Harry Quinn thought that many Eudunda electors were unaware of their council’s activity concerning mergers and many of them favoured a merger with Morgan.

It was hoped to have the amalgamation in place by March 1997, in time for the next council elections.

Editorial on Council amalgamations

[Generally this is a sceptical view of any financial advantage and fearful of the loss of the ‘local’ identity of Local Government.]

Issue 274, 21 August 1996, page 1

Letter. Alan C.O. Hall writes suggesting that people did not attend the recent public meeting on Council amalgamations because Councillors have repeatedly said they will not take direction from ratepayers and so Burra will end up with Robertstown etc. regardless of the benefits of merging with Clare.

Letter. Jane and Peter Strawbridge write suggesting that the low attendance at the Council merger meeting was less an indication of agreement and more an indication of lack of confidence of ratepayers in direct consultation with Council. The recent Residents & Ratepayers’ meeting urged a stronger effort to merge with Clare, with which Burra has much closer transport, hospital and tourism links than with Eudunda, Robertstown etc.

Burra Main Street Committee held its AGM last week. Guest speaker was Chairman of Angaston Main Street Committee, Paul Mariani.

Paul is from the US, but now owns Angas Park Fruit & Nut Co. He spoke of success with KESAB Awards, undergrounding of power lines, street lighting, street furniture and tree planting. A $20,000 grant had encouraged owners to improve shop fronts.

Issue 275, 28 August 1996, page 2

Letter. Bob Skinner writes to say that if 13 people and 6 Councillors attended a public meeting the Council is justified in presuming there is little public interest in the business to be discussed. Mr Halls’ quotation ‘No way are we going to run back to the public for direction on every matter of policy’ was taken completely out of context.

Nevertheless, Burra has more interests in common with the growing economic centre of Clare and further investigation of the Clare amalgamation prospects should be pursued.

BCS. Thieves broke into the Technical Studies room and stole two electric drills, an electric sander and an electric jig saw. They also stole a cash box and confectionary from the canteen. The value of the stolen items amounts to $1,300.

Mr Pickett’s Café has recently been sold. The new owners are Troy & Rhonda Bannister from Adelaide. Troy will be the main host with his mother Rhonda and younger brother, Raymond helping at weekends.

Mrs Elizabeth Hounsell of Burra & Mr Colin Springbett of Farrell Flat will ride horses 750 km from Broken Hill to Adelaide, starting on 20 September on a 30-day journey. They are raising money to defeat cancer.

Issue 276, 4 September 1996, pages 1 & 6

Burra Hospital Board held its last AGM after 119 years and with the anticipation of amalgamation with Clare & Snowtown to form the Burra-Clare-Snowtown Health Service, Chairman John Brak read the final annual report.

Burra is now located within the Wakefield Region, which encompasses the previous Yorke Peninsula, Lower North and Barossa Regions. The Wakefield Regional Health Service will be responsible for its own budget, which includes budgets for each hospital in the region.

[Further details of the changes are provided in the report of Lesley Phillips CEO and Director of Nursing and extend over some two columns.]

Issue 276, 4 September 1996, page 2

Council Amalgamations

Eudunda Council District Clerk writes to dispute the assertion that most of its ratepayers would prefer an amalgamation with Morgan. Since a circular to ratepayers after the May meeting the Council received very little negative comment of the potential to amalgamate with Burra Burra, Hallett and Robertstown, which was the Council’s preferred option.

Calici Virus

Legislation has been passed to enable the release of the Calici Virus at 50 sites across SA.

Issue 276, 4 September 1996, page 8

A Saltbush Sheep seminar is to be held in Burra at the Civic Centre on Friday 13 September. It will discuss the opportunities available to sheep graziers supplying sheep for the ‘Saltbush Dija’ market. This is the trade name owned by Stephen Schmitz of Red & Beyond Ltd, who is providing marketing expertise on cuts of meat from saltbush grazed sheep for leading Australian restaurants. An export market is also being developed.

Burra Community Pool

The Council has budgeted for a projected loss for 1996-97 of $39,000.

This is made up of Loan repayment (principal) 20,500

Purchase of pool shades 3,000

Operating deficit 15,500

The operating committee will be expected to reduce the operating deficit either by reducing costs or increasing income or both.

The committee is desperate for community support, both in operating the pool and in fundraising.

Members will then proceed to Quorn for two nights. They will be riding bikes dating from 1914 to 1964.

Burra Daycare has had a busy year with nine permanent volunteers and four part-time and a team of six bus drivers. Mavis Brooks was farewelled at an afternoon tea after twelve years of service.

From 30 September the Burra Daycare will be known as Burra Leisure Activity Group. LAG is held three days a week at Burra Community Activities Centre. Activities include cards, table games, indoor bowls, crafts, ceramics, outings, special days and themes.

Issue 279, 25 September 1996, pages 1 & 4

Council Amalgamation

The District Councils of Burra Burra, Eudunda, Robertstown and Hallett are nearing the final stages of preparing an amalgamation to be submitted to the Local Government Boundary Reform Board. This follows work by the Structural Reform Working Party set up by the four councils, whose report from its three sub-committees will be considered at a meeting today to be finalised. There will be recommendations for the new Council to comprise four wards: Burra, Eudunda, Hallett and Robertstown, with a Council of eleven members with a Chairman elected from the Councillors.

Rate increases are to be kept in line with the CPI and rating parity is to be achieved by 2002-03.

[Further details on changes to Governance, Finance Services and Organisational Structure are printed.]

Issue 279, 25 September 1996, page 2

Rebecca Clark-Dollman has a part-time position at the National Australia Bank in Burra.

Allyson Parsons recently held a successful exhibition in conjunction with her mother Marie in Sydney. It was opened by Lady Neale, wife of the SA Governor, Sir Eric Neale.

St Mary’s, Burra. New stained glass windows will be unveiled next Sunday afternoon. They will be dedicated to the memory of Andrew Tiver.

Hallett School will close at the end of this week after serving the community for 116 years as a result of a gradual, but severe downturn in student numbers.

Birth. To Connie & Richard Dollman at Burra Hospital on 12 September, a son, Jordan Bryant.

Both are members of the SA Police Force based at Holden Hill.

Calici Virus. A dead rabbit found on the property of Chris & Maria Reed of Burra North has been found to test positive for the Calici virus. This is the first to do so in the Burra-Eudunda-Robertstown area.

Calici Virus. Commonwealth, State & Territory Ministers have agreed to declare the Calici Virus a biological control agent, clearing the way for its release around October this year.

Issue 280, 2 October 1996, page 1

Hallett School Closure

A celebration was held at the Hallett School last Thursday, 26 September to mark its closure after 116 years. Children from Hallett were joined by those from Spalding and Booborowie for a day of fun and recognition. Numbers at the school had dropped to nine. Principal Shane Misso said in 1977 there were 74 at the school and at the start of 1996 there were 18. This fell to 10 as families left the district. [Photo of Mr Misso and students.]

Issue 280, 2 October 1996, pages 1 & 3

Burra Main Street Committee has written to Federal Minister of Transport Hon. J. Sharpe, urging retention of the Gawler-Burra railway and the Burra railway yards infrastructure. Currently the line is used to cart grain to port, but in the past has allowed special passenger steam trains to visit.

Issue 280, 2 October 1996, page 2

Burra Police Celebrate 150 years

To mark this event the Band of the SA Police will visit Burra on 26 November for a series of concerts.

In the daytime they will play for senior citizens and school children and in the evening will perform at Redruth Gaol. There will also be a display of SA Police memorabilia at the Gaol. SA Police horses will patrol the streets, with memorabilia at the Old Police stables & Lock-up.

Vandalism. On 21 September a car was driven onto the Golf Club fairways and one of the scrapes.

Issue 280, 2 October 1996, pages 7, 8 & 13

Burra Show, 119 years old.

An article reviewing the history of the show makes the following points:

In 1925 memories placed the first show in 1875, but reports in the Adelaide Observer say the first show was actually in 1877. [There is no uncertainty about this; the first Burra Show is reported in the Burra News and Northern Mail 14 September 1877, Page 2.]

The first show was held in a walled enclosure of the old smelting works.

The first show was held in drizzling rain, but had a good attendance. Admission was 2/6 and 1/- after 2 p.m.

The show was held in the smelting yard for nine years, after which there was a recess until 1894.

The resurrected 1894 show was held at Victoria Park i.e. the Burra Oval.

The 1894 attendance was estimated at 2,300 and the society closed the year £100 in credit.

From 1877 till 1884 the show was followed by a banquet in the evening.

In 1895 a substantial stone building was erected for indoor exhibits. The society’s share of its cost was £90.

In 1897 the show was cancelled due to the appalling seasonal conditions of severe drought.

The show returned in 1898.

PAGES 9 TO 12 APPEAR TO BE MISSING (UNLESS NUMBERING IS ASKEW)

Issue 280, 2 October 1996, page 13

Past Presidents of Burra Show Society

1877-85 W.B. Rounsevell

1894-1911 P.L. Killicoat

?-? T. Sandland

1914-44 I.J. Warnes

1945-48 A.B. Riggs

1949 G.M. Finch

1950-53 W.H. Lloyd

1954-56 R.C. Warnes

1957-58 B.A. Riggs

1959-64 R.C. Warnes

1965-67 M.G. Stockman

1968-69 Rex Stockman

1970-72 R.E. Mason

1973-74 G.M. Kellock

1975-78 R.J. Shipard

1979-81 P.R. Stockman

1982-83 D. Kellock

1984-85 J. Duncan

1986-88 P.R. Stockman

1989-90 R.F. Jamieson

1991-92 I. Slade

1993 A. McInnes

1994-96 R.K. Williams

North Bungaree stud at Spalding is an offshoot of the Bungaree Stud founded in 1841. North Bungaree is now 90 years old and the Poll Stud is 41 years old. The property comprises 3,440 ha (8,500 acres) in a 500 mm (20 inch) rainfall area and devotes 6,500 acres to clover, ryegrass and natural grasses. It also produces cereals and hay. Shearing is done in September. Top price for a ram at 1995 field days was $1,500. Peter Riggs manages the property for Mary Hawker. North Bungaree sheep are known for large frames and deep bodies with soft handling medium wool.

Issue 280, 2 October 1996, page 14

P. & R. Stockman’s Springvale was founded 35 years ago and their sheep have achieved a top price of $12,000. The Merino Stud was established in 1961 with a ram and a ewe from ‘The Grove’. The Stockman brothers bought ‘The Grove’ in 1979 and have introduced breeding stock from Old Ashrose and Greenfields. The Poll Merino Stud was established in 1977. Shearing is spread in July, September and February. The property comprises 2,000 ha – half is cropped annually to wheat, oats and barley.

Issue 281, 9 October 1996, page 1

Search at Sturt Vale

Police attended an abandoned car at Sturt Vale Station last Friday. It was found with two flat tyres and a distressed dog in it. They took the dog to Burra at 10 p.m. Meanwhile Nuriootpa Police had ascertained that Mrs June Moesing (58), the wife of the car’s owner, had left home at 1 p.m. on Thursday. A search was then organised to begin at first light. SES units from Adelaide, Pt Pirie, Burra, Hallett, Spalding and Laura participated along with CFS units from Riverland, Baldina, Burra & the Eastern Districts. They were joined by two helicopters and the Burra Ambulance was on standby. Conditions were difficult due to rain making the roads slippery. The search continued on Sunday, when the dog was returned to the car and soon set off down the road. At 7.40 a.m. the woman was found alongside the road, suffering from exposure and dehydration. She was transferred to Burra Hospital. Burra Police officer Henderson praised the efforts of all involved in the search.

Issue 281, 9 October 1996, pages 2 & 3

Burra art Gallery was officially opened on Saturday with an exhibition called ‘Family Collections and Connections’ drawn from the private collections of the Wilson and Bonython Families. There were works by such famous names as Rembrandt, Holbein and Heysen. The Chairman of the McDouall Stuart Board introduced Mr Kym Bonython who opened the gallery. Curator Heather Parker explained how artists had interpreted the land as subject matter. Of South Australian interest are two water colours of 1838 showing Walkerville by Frederick Nixon. Also Edwin Barry’s two watercolours of survey camps at Belalie and Bundaleer Creek in 1868.

[Photos show Judy Kellock & Kym Bonython; Lady Wilson & Glenys Christopher; Andrew Wilson; and Jan Tiver with Heather Parker.]

Issue 281, 9 October 1996, page 4

Redfire Resources NL, based in Sydney, is interested in a licence to explore for minerals, especially copper and gold between Hallett and Robertstown. Their proposed area would have a western boundary through Hanson and an eastern one through World’s End, but would exclude 160 km2 centred on Burra, where a licence is held for exploration by Elliot Geophysics of Urrbrae, from April 1996 for 12 months.

Notice. Burra Burra DC. Public Meeting

A public meeting is called at the Civic Centre in Burra on 21 October 1996 at 8 p.m. to consider the Proposed Amalgamation of the District Councils of Burra Burra, Eudunda, Hallett and Robertstown.

Issue 281, 9 October 1996, page 6

Letter. Sheila Elder, who used to be a hairdresser in Burra in the late 1940s to the mid-1950s, with a once a week trip to Orroroo to set up her dryers etc. in a hotel there, reminisces about Burra in those times:

We came to Burra in 1946, just after the war and the partition of India – having left Kashmir and the lovely hill station of Darjeeling.

The first sight of Burra was of ‘a God forsaken place’, but they stayed long enough to have three sons and discover kind people, who never treated them like strangers.

Burra had been full of days of struggle after a life in India with servants and relaxation.

Burra brought pumping water from an underground tank on cold frosty mornings.

An outside toilet.

The children walking uphill with a billy to get milk.

On a return visit 28 years later Market Square and the rolling hills looked beautiful and the people were just as friendly.

They had a tour of the mine with Mr & Mrs Scroop.

And a lesson in painting from Mr Len Bence.

And visits from Mrs Jennison to see if I was OK.

A failed attempted break-in at Oppy’s Foodtown in Commercial Street at 5.15 a.m. on Saturday morning resulted in a broken window and damage to the door.

Theft. Between the 6 & 8 October c. $100 was stolen from St Mary’s Church’s two collection boxes.

Issue 281, 9 October 1996, page 7

Burra Calisthenics Club held its end of season concert on Sunday 29 October at the Burra Town Hall. More than 100 family and friends watched the performance. [Further details & a photo are printed.]

Issue 282, 16 October 1996, page 1

Businessman Dick Smith has established a fund to restore the Mt Bryan East birthplace of Sir Hubert Wilkins. A local body has been formed to oversee the project, with a major event planned for October next year. Mr Smith has raised $50,000 through an appeal in the Australian Geographic Magazine. The house is to be thoroughly restored through the National Trust. It lies on land owned by Brian Guthrie, which Mr Smith has offered to buy out of his own pocket.

Issue 282, 16 October 1996, page 3

St Mary’s Church

Two new memorial stained glass windows were dedicated on 29 September. They honour the life of Andrew Tiver. The artist was Owen Turner of Nairne. There was a sung Evensong led by Fr John Davenport, assisted by the local ecumenical choir, with Clem Davey as organist. The dedication was performed by Fr David Lamont who was the parish priest at the time of Andrew’s tragic death in September 1992. He is now at Heywood in Victoria. A sumptuous afternoon tea followed.

BankSA is reducing its operating hours. From 28 October the bank will open at 11 a.m. daily. Burra will lose its local manager, Keith Sichler, who will be replaced by a regional appointment based in Clare.

Issue 282, 16 October 1996, page 4

Family Health Day

A day of health information has been organised for Burra on 31 October. The morning session will cover SIDS, Care for Kids and Home & Farm Safety. The afternoon will cover Caring for yourself and Women’s Health.

Burra Churches have combined to offer a course on relationships on 25 & 26 October. It aims at improving communication skills, conflict resolution and helping the longevity of relationships.

Veterans’ Health Week. People are invited to join in a walking program to be launched on 25 October. Participants will report on their progress after five weeks.

Issue 282, 16 October 1996, page 5

Letter. Bob Skinner writes to query the usefulness of a traffic counter on Kooringa Road – given that in two months traffic is to be diverted to enable sealing of the Burra-Morgan Road. He also wonders whether the sealing of Kooringa Road is worth the cost – couldn’t people easily come in from the north via Young Street? Visitors would get an exciting view of Burra’s attractions.

Issue 282, 16 October 1996, page 9

Burra Hospital

Last Sunday bathroom renovations and the recently completed enclosed patio area for long term patients were officially opened. At the opening the newly formed Palliative Care Trained Support Workers Group was introduced. [Photo.] Lesley Phillips outlined the renovations to Burra Hospital over the last decade. The opening was performed by Craig Stanbridge, CEO of the Burra Clare Snowtown Health Service.

Issue 283, 23 October 1996, page 1

Vincent Burke has recently compiled a Grant Finder Manual for the Burra Main Street Committee. A condensed form of it is available to be read at the Community Library and the complete version at the Mid North Development Board’s Office in Clare, where it will be updated to keep abreast of changes.

Issue 283, 23 October 1996, pages 1 & 3

The Council Amalgamation Public Meeting

About 60 people attended the meeting.

Consultant Michael Barry was asked, ‘Where are the rate savings?’

Mr Barry replied ‘You won’t get it unless you give up significant reductions in service.’

[Ignore the double negative!]

The newsletter to householders said there would be a reduction of 3% in the total rates collected in the 1997-98 year, after which a rate equalisation program would be introduced.

Mr Barry said after the input of much work the working parties had come up with a workable solution.

John Monfries commented from the floor that if Councillors were not allowed to make the decision the Reform Board would step in and decide for them.

It was outlined that Burra rates would drop 9%.

Hallett’s would go up 20% over the ten year period, till parity was achieved.

The greatest concern overall was for local employment. The letter to householders said there was very little fat to be cut in District Councils and most of the benefits of amalgamation would be directed to protecting and improving levels of service delivery. If Government grants were cut in the future, it would be road maintenance that suffered the most. Past Council Chairman Jack McMahon spoke to say that he didn’t think they had any real choice but to make the most of the present changes.

Issue 283, 23 October 1996, page 3

Hallett School. A barbecue was held at Hallett on Sunday to farewell the school after its recent closure. About 200 former students, staff, families and residents attended. More than 30 former staff were present.

Issue 283, 23 October 1996, page 4

Probus. Clare Probus Club has approached retired and semi-retired professional and business people in Burra to found the Probus Club of Burra & District. Probus aims to provide regular meetings and fellowship and to provide addresses by guest speakers and visits to places and organisations of specific interest to members. Most such clubs meet monthly. A preliminary meeting is planned at Burra Hotel 25 October at 2 p.m.

Issue 283, 23 October 1996, page 5

Burra Swimming Club is affiliated this year with the SA Swimming Association and the Burra Swimming Pool Committee has decided that this year a family ticket of $150 will give the holder free entry during all swimming times and all swimming club times.

Issue 283, 23 October 1996, page 9

Birth. To Judy & Adrian Bruce of Hanson at Burra on 6 October, a son, Hayden Charles. [Photo.]

Birth. To Anne-Marie & Mick Young of Farrell Flat last Thursday, a daughter, Kimberley Anne. [Photo.]

Issue 284, 30 October 1996, page 1

ETSA is cutting its country employees from 320 to 260. Thirteen works depots around SA will close. Burra is one of two places that will lose all ETSA presence in the town. In future trucks and workers will have to come from Clare for maintenance or emergencies. The move aims to increase efficiency without loss of service according to a spokesperson. Burra had eight full-time positions five years ago and two at present. ETSA has been under pressure from interstate suppliers and electricity charges have declined significantly in recent years said Rob Kerin MP.

A Housing Trust Garden Competition for the Pt Pirie region has been won by Maurissa & Trevor Ahwan in the first-time entry category. They get $100 and a plaque. [Photo.]

Issue 284, 30 October 1996, page 2

Theft. Two men aged 26 & 29 and a 14-year-old youth were arrested after stealing a car owned by Danny & Kathryn Smith from a Kangaroo Street house on Friday. The car was recovered from the Morgan Road and sustained some $3,000 damage.

Theft. The Burra BP Service Station was broken into on 22 October and electrical goods worth $1,200 were stolen and damage was c. $100.

The Sichler Family is moving to Whyalla. [See changes at Bank SA. Issue 282, 16 October 1996, page 3.]

The Harrison Family from the ANZ Bank are moving to Kangaroo Island in mid-November.

The Ortmann Family who came to Burra early in the year will soon move to Parafield Gardens.

Birth. To Brett & Rachael Eberhard of Adelaide on 13 October, a daughter, Sophie Lauren. A first grandchild for Elaine & Robin Eberhard.

Birth. To Derek & Kerry Broderick on 15 October, a daughter, Tamynka Jane. A great granddaughter for Dawn Broderick.

Obituary. Irene Lonergan died in Adelaide on 23 October. She and husband Patrick and son Tom lived in this area for many years.

Issue 284, 30 October 1996, page 3

Burra Uniting Church has a new roof – replacing the original iron of 1914. It has been replaced at a cost of more than $15,000 with full lengths of 10.1 m galvanised corrugated iron laid on the 52°pitch roof. The gutters are 7.5 m above the ground and the apex of the roof is 18 m high. The roof structure was found to be in excellent condition and under the flashings workers found the name of J. White & Son, the original workers. The job was supervised by Paul Wilson, local building contractor. [Photo.]

Council Changes. A bill before Parliament aims to make Council proceedings more transparent and restricts the occasions for secrecy. It also intends to extend terms of councils to three years.

Issue 284, 30 October 1996, page 4

The Burra Heritage Advisory Committee has approached the Main Street Committee to help co-ordinate a series of workshops regarding the Market Square – Best Place Development Plan.

Main Street Committee is preparing for the popular car boot sale in Market Square on Sunday 3 November and a Melbourne Cup Breakfast in Market Square on 5 November 7 a.m. to 9 a.m.

Issue 284, 30 October 1996, page 5

Burra & Districts Combined Probus Club was formed last Friday. Elected were: President, Mary Press; Vice-President, Bob Skinner & Secretary, Heather Affolter. The first ordinary meeting will be on 19 November at the Burra Hotel.

Issue 284, 30 October 1996, pages 6 & 7

Council Amalgamation. Public meeting at Hallett. 186 people attended.

Hallett Council Chairman Peter Mattey said that the Council recommended amalgamation with Burra Burra, Robertstown and Eudunda after lengthy debate and negotiations. This he said was the best deal they had been able to broker with surrounding councils.

Cr Sullivan said a full-time gang will be on construction, giving greater efficiency and Hallett would be rated at the rural rate. Rating parity would be achieved over ten years and the net debt would be eliminated by 2002.

Cr Mattey said councils to the west had vetoed efforts to merge with them and those to the north would not commit to a financial direction of a merged council.

John Hale, a past Councillor and Chairman objected to suddenly having to ‘get in bed with Burra’.

Robert Jenson from Terowie questioned the benefits for the northern wards and other speakers expressed concern about Burra’s debts.

Burra Burra DC’s Steve Kerrigan has since confirmed their council’s net debt of $456,418 less self-servicing loans of $492,613, which leaves Burra Burra with a surplus of $36, 195 at the end of June 1996.

(The self-servicing loans were: Paxton Square Cottages 253,984

Effluent Scheme 187,940

Sports Complex 7,274

Half Caravan Park’s loan of 86,831 )

A speaker from the Hundred of Whyte (to the west of Hallett) expressed a desire to amalgamate with the west where most of their shopping activities centred upon Jamestown.

It was explained that this could be done if the Hallett DC and the three western councils agreed.

Council Amalgamation. Public meeting at Terowie last Wednesday. 128 people attended – many of whom had also attended the Hallett meeting.

Cr Mattey said the proposed option would make the whole [Hallett] Council area one ward, represented by two Councillors. The western option offered Hallett Council area one representative.

Cr Hill gave an overview of the Council’s deliberations.

Cr Harvey said he had asked for a referendum on the western option.

The meeting was told the western option had not been open until the last few weeks.

Jamestown, Spalding and Rocky River Councils had already reached agreement and were due to lodge documents with the Reform Board early in November and that would finish the option currently available.

Councils could be admitted later, but conditions then applying were unknown.

Council Amalgamation. 58 people attended the ‘Have Your Say’ meeting at Robertstown.

Council Chairman Denis Keller outlined the proposal. The present proposal to merge with the Hallett, Burra Burra and Eudunda Councils followed exhaustive consultations with those councils and also with Saddleworth-Auburn, Clare, Riverton and Morgan in varying combinations. The perception that Burra and Eudunda’s debt structure was excessively high and unmanageable was totally unfounded. Burra’s total debt was $793,556, but 58% of that was self-supporting and 42% was met by Council revenue. It also had cash reserves of $337,000. Eudunda’s total loan commitments were $355,309. Its self-servicing loans were $15,339 and $89,168 was funded by Council cash and investments totalled $72,000. A general show of hands at the meeting favoured the proposal.

Council Amalgamation. The editor commented that Hallett and Terowie meetings showed that whatever the outcome, there will be a large group of dissatisfied ratepayers. Terowie residents who look to Peterborough for shopping have already had the door slammed in their face and Hallett’s western residents will likely miss out on increasing their ties with Jamestown. Intransigence however, could be counterproductive if it prolongs argument to the point where it is too late to enter into a new area on your own terms.

Letter. Michael Barry, consultant writes to clarify a point from the Burra Council Amalgamation meeting, reported in the issue of 23 October 1996.

‘Rate Savings Linked to Loss of Services’ fails however to convey the main focus of the meeting.

The article seemed to imply that I said that the four councils seeking to amalgamate would reduce services if they implemented rate reductions. This is not the intention of the four councils. Their intention is to reduce rates overall by 3% in the first year after amalgamation, while maintaining services. My view however, is that experience shows that rural amalgamations at best produce modest savings because:

Most rural councils already have little fat to cut.

All councils face increasing demands for new and improved services through State Government regulation and removal of services as a result of their cost cutting measures in rural areas.

Some of the savings will need to be diverted to specialist staff to tackle these new or improved services. If greater rate reductions were required in rural councils, then that could only come at the cost of reductions in service levels.

Issue 284, 30 October 1996, page 8

Burra Pony Club will hold an Open Gymkhana on Sunday 10 November. [Further details and a photo are printed.]

Issue 284, 30 October 1996, page 10

Clip Clop for Cancer Report

Details of the 750 km ride from Broken Hill, starting on Friday 30 September are given. The ride ended at the anti-Cancer Foundation building on Greenhill Road, Adelaide. The ride raised $6,500.

[The report does not make clear how many rode or who they were except for naming Liz Hounsell and Kimberley Field aged 14.]

[A photograph of Kimberley with her horse in the issue of 11 September, page 9 suggests Colin Springbett was another rider, as does his mention in the issue of 4 September 1961 page 1.]

Issue 285, 6 November 1996, page 1

Council Amalgamation.

Hallett DC will be collating a survey on Friday night that was recently sent to residents, seeking the number wishing to merge west or south. The result will guide the Council in its final decision. The Structural Reform Working Party will meet on Wednesday 13 November to consider any changes to the draft merger proposal. The final proposal is due to be lodged with the Reform Board after approval on 20 November. The proposal is expected to ask for a regional council to be formed in February 1997.

Issue 285, 6 November 1996, page 2

Break and Enter. Intruders broke into Burra Motor Co. in Thames Street on Wednesday 30 October. They were reported to police at c. 1.45 a.m., but had fled by the time the police arrived. They were later stopped in a vehicle at Tarlee, where the stolen property was recovered. The value of the stolen goods was $5,000. A search of the offenders’ premises also recovered c. $1,200 worth of property stolen from Burra Motor Co. a week earlier.

Issue 285, 6 November 1996, page 3

Letter. Vicki & Roger Hamblin & Graham Swingler write re damaging rumours circulating about the – Empire Road Pty Ltd trading as the Royal exchange hotel. They say:

When we left the town we paid all outstanding debts including rent, to all local businesses and Adelaide based companies. If the rumours do not cease we feel we have no option, but to take legal action.

Issue 285, 6 November 1996, page 4

BCS. Year 10 students are undertaking work experience this week.

Burra Burra DC

A quote of $18,237 has been accepted for pre-construction work for the sealing of Kooringa Road and Kingston Street.

Design drawings for the planned upgrading of the Morgan-Burra Road have been received from the Department of Transport.

Issue 285, 6 November 1996, page 6

Mary Fahey submits a poem Hallett School – A Tribute.

Issue 285, 6 November 1996, page 8

BCS. A first draft farm plan for Brewery Hill has been prepared.

The intention is to divide the land into three paddocks according to soil type and topography.

Water supply around the land will be improved.

The Agricultural Committee has proposed three livestock enterprises for the block:

A self-replacing Merino flock of c. 50 ewes.

A flock of first cross ewes of c. 50 that can produce prime lambs.

A flock of meat goats of c. 50 does to produce prime kid. (The goats to be trained to an electric fence.)

The school is considering moving the shed to a less isolated and more sheltered site.

Issue 285, 6 November 1996, page 13

Advt. Bill & Betty Pens celebrate their Golden Wedding – having been married at Kooringa Methodist Church 6 November 1946.

Issue 286, 13 November 1996, page 1

The Hallett Community Management Committee has decided to ask the Minister of Education to consider passing on the use and ownership of the school to the committee. With the Council mergers the committee sees a potential for a bigger role for itself co-ordinating the needs of twelve current sporting and community bodies and perhaps being party to development application decisions, management of local assets and making formal budget decisions.

Council Amalgamation

The survey of residents conducted last week by the Hallett DC resulted in 85% of people returning responses and 52% favouring the southern option.

The interim Chairman of the new Regional Council consisting of Hallett, Burra Burra, Robertstown and Eudunda Council areas will be voted on at a meeting of the Structural Reform Working Party. The position will be for the period 3 February 1997 to elections on 3 May 1997. A CEO will also be appointed to commence on 3 February 1997.

The final amalgamation proposal will need to have a name for the new Council and submissions on that and on a logo will be accepted until 4.30 p.m. this Friday.

Issue 286, 13 November 1996, page 3

Letter. Kris Flamank & Wendy Mason write re the poor state of the Booborowie Cemetery – weeds, lack of water and unemptied rubbish bins. In contrast, they say, the Burra Cemetery was without weeds, had empty bins and water was available.

Issue 286, 13 November 1996, page 5

The Burra Art Gallery has a new exhibition – a South Australian Touring Exhibition curated by David O’Connor, called ‘Pulp Friction’ [from p.13]. It features works by Nicole Ellis, Nola James, Manne Schultz and Lindsay Herewane. The exhibition is on view until 24 November.

Issue 286, 13 November 1996, page 7

Don Lloyd has turned 60 and felt challenged to a bike-climb of Flagstaff Hill as he used to do when coming home from school. He used the occasion to raise money for cancer research and the Heart Foundation.

Issue 286, 13 November 1996, page 9

150 Years of the Burra Police

When copper was discovered at Burra in 1845 the nearest police were two mounted constables 30 miles away at Bungaree Station, where they were busy protecting the local flocks of sheep. In 1846 the Commissioner of Police, Captain Finnis came north to establish a police office and see to the appointment of a resident magistrate – made necessary by the Burra Burra Mine and the increased traffic on the North Road. Two mounted and two foot constables were allotted the area, though it took some time for them to arrive. The 150th anniversary of police in Burra will be marked by the visit of the Police Band, which will present a special concert in Redruth Gaol on Tuesday 26 November.

Issue 287, 20 November 1996, pages 1 & 6

The Burra-Morgan Road will be closed between Burra and Robertstown turn-off for road construction and sealing. The successful tender for the remaining 45 km is expected to be announced shortly. The road is expected to be closed from 2 January 1997 from Burra to the Robertstown turn-off. It is possible the remaining section to ‘The Gums’ will be completed by July 1998, ahead of schedule. [Map page 6.]

Issue 287, 20 November 1996, page 2

Accident. On Saturday 16 November an interstate driver tried to pass under the Young Street Bridge with an over-height vehicle. Police helped with traffic control while he reversed out.

[The bridge referred to was actually the railway bridge across Watt Road.]

Australian Transport Ministers met in Darwin last week and agreed to continue with a general urban speed limits of 60 km per hour, while allowing local councils to set lower limits.

Letter. Richard Nicholls of the Jailbreakers Committee writes to inform the community of his election as President with Caroline stockman as Secretary and Simon Drew as Treasurer. The next Jailbreakers Ball will be held on 19 April 1997. The committee has been able to hand over $3,900 to local sporting bodies.

Issue 287, 20 November 1996, page 3

Ivan & Irene Hirschausen celebrated their Golden Wedding on 9 November.

Peter & Claire Harvey are settling into their Market Street property after moving from Sydney.

Burra Golf Club is upgrading its course. A dam is being built to be fed via causeways [sic] and the length and difficulty of the course is being increased. The club is also looking at the possibility of an underground sprinkler system for the entire course. This would allow for an extended season with stable green fairways and perhaps greens rather than sand scrapes in the future.

Issue 287, 20 November 1996, page 6

Mt Bryan School pupils, with the assistance of the Petherton Road Tree Planters Landcare Group and the Mt Bryan Community Group, planted five rows of trees and shrubs in the old railway yards opposite the school. Last year 75 native shrubs were planted and this year 196. [Further details and a photo are printed.]

Issue 287, 20 November 1996, page 8

Burra National Trust held its AGM last week in the Old Courthouse. Among several speakers was Dudley Cockington, a pastoralist, who told tales of the early days of the branch.

Issue 288, 27 November 1996, page 1

Morphett’s Engine House

Following their meeting on 29 October the Burra Burra DC has contacted the National Trust with a suggestion for including the unstaffed Morphett’s Engine House Museum on the Burra Passport. If no agreement is reached beforehand the Engine House will be closed from 29 November due to financial constraints. Council has been staffing the museum for two hours a day during the week and for three hours at weekends. Some months ago the National Trust proposed it manage and staff the building and pay the wages and involve the general community through a committee. The Council would make a financial commitment and share any profit. Council has delayed discussion until they work out how to place the Engine House on the passport. Once closed the mineral displays will be removed. The Van Buuren model of a beam engine, the audio system and the video commentary will remain.

Polly Wilson of Burra will leave in January for a year as an exchange student in Germany. Polly has just completed Year 12 at BCS.

Issue 288, 27 November 1996, page 2

Graffiti. The public toilets in Chapel Street have been defaced with offensive graffiti relating to Asian migrants on at least seven occasions in the past two years. Police and Council are annoyed and seek public help in ending this poor behaviour.

Burra Traders’ Association held their Christmas dinner meeting last week. Guest speaker was Rob Olsen, executive officer of ‘Classic Country’, which promotes tourism in the Adelaide area and ‘Classic Country’ encompasses the Mid North and Yorke Peninsula. 85% of tourists come from SA and 78% from the Adelaide Metropolitan Area.

Burra Swimming Pool will open from this Sunday; weather permitting.

Issue 288, 27 November 1996, page 6

Burra CWA Branch turned 70 last Tuesday. The CWA in South Australia was started in Burra on 5 November 1926 by the late Mary Warnes. Sixty-two ladies attended the celebration, including the State President Marie Lally, Divisional President Roma Cook, Group President Mary Shattock and Mrs Warnes’ granddaughter, Carolyn Cooke. Burra Branch President Barbara Frances said it was sad that Burra had lost its CWA rooms in 1991. [Photo.]

Council Amalgamation

The Structural Reform Working Party has decided the new Council should be called the Regional Council of Goyder and that name will be submitted to the Reform Board along with the merger proposal.

Burra Burra DC

An offer of $40,000 for O’Connor’s Shed at Burra North has been received. Council has decided to offer the shed for sale at $75,000 until the end of December, after which time it will also be offered for lease.

Council is to have the land owned by Stockman’s adjacent to the Burra Golf Club rezoned as industrial.

Issue 288, 27 November 1996, page 11
