[Context implies the wife of Tom Ryan.]

[Born Shirley Meryl Butler 12 January 1925 at Jamestown. Married Thomas Francis Ryan in 1944. Died 30 October 1996. Buried at Burra 1 November 1996.]

Issue 289, 4 December 1996, pages 1 & 8

Police in Burra – The 150 year Celebration

The twenty-four-piece Police Band entertained locals to mark the occasion.

220 people attended the concert at Redruth Gaol on Tuesday night, with supper served in the interval.

The $500 profit from the night will aid local community groups.

Earlier that afternoon the Commissioner of Police, David Hunt unveiled a plaque at the old Police Lock-up at Burra North. [4 photos.]

Issue 289, 4 December 1996, page 2

Letter. Mrs Ernene Prosser of Gympie, Queensland writes, seeking help in tracing her ancestors who lived in Burra in the 1840s – Samuel Penglase and Elizabeth Trestrail.

Break-ins at Booborowie

On 1-2 December three Booborowie premises were entered:

The General Store where cigarettes, confectionery and blank cassette tapes to a total value of c. $800 were stolen.

Bowling Club where the front window was broken and home-made biscuits and cash was stolen.

Booborowie Seed, which suffered the theft of a $200 Australian Mint gold coin.

Issue 289, 4 December 1996, page 3

Burra Traders’ Association ran a Cake competition and turning on Christmas Lights event on Friday night last. The cake auction raised $358 for the children’s ward at Burra Hospital.

Issue 289, 4 December 1996, page 4

The Burra Heritage advisory Committee convened a workshop at the Civic Centre last week, which was well attended by a cross-section of the community. The purpose was to hear ideas on the redevelopment of Market Square and Best Place. Douglas Alexander said it was not about bringing in a bulldozer, but to guide and inform relatively minor decisions that when multiplied would amount to a significant impact. Further consultation will follow in February or early March. Much of the input called for upgrading of existing facilities – the greening of both areas and more shade and seating. Other comments focused on the condition of roads and footpaths and the need for the parking of buses. Better signage, especially for Burra North was another issue. Better street furniture was another concern.

Issue 289, 4 December 1996, page 10

Notice. The Local Government Boundary Reform Board

Concerning the amalgamation of the District Councils of Burra Burra, Eudunda, Hallett and Robertstown to create the Regional Council of Goyder.

The Country Councils Reform Committee will meet at the Council Chambers, City of Marion, 245 Sturt Road, Sturt, on Monday 16 December 1996. The meeting will be open to the public. Submissions in writing will be received up till 12 December or appearance in person by arrangement with the Executive Officer of the Board.

[Further details are printed.]

Issue 290, 11 December 1996, page 1

The Army was in town on Sunday last for manoeuvres. Headquarters were set up at the Burra North Tennis Courts and strategic sites were secured against airborne enemy attack.

Issue 290, 11 December 1996, page 2

Letter. Elly Nicholls for the Burra and Surrounding Districts Palliative Care Trained Support Workers writes to acquaint readers with the services they can offer.

KESAB awards for Burra have been announced.

Commendation plaques went to Audrey James, Shirley Broad and Sylvia Pearce.

Burra’s 150th Celebrations were awarded a Heritage & Culture Award.

Burra senior Citizens gained a Meritorious Award.

[Issue 291, 18 December 1996 page 8 carried a photo of Audrey James and Sylvia Pearce with their awards.]

Issue 290, 11 December 1996, page 4

Mark Bellman – previously employed by ETSA – is now working in the merchandise department at Elders in Burra.

Issue 290, 11 December 1996, page 5

The Main Street Committee has presented a cheque to the Burra Swimming Pool Committee to assist with the planting and landscaping.

BCS Year 3-4 has paid a visit to Mount Thebarton Ice Arena.

Birth. To Sheryl Keane & Frank Jones of Burra on 30 November, a son, Nathan Roy.

Issue 290, 11 December 1996, pages 6-14

Review of the Year 1996. [Note that the first ten points below actually refer to 1995 events.]

The J150 events concluded with a commemorative dinner at the Burra Town Hall with Professor Geoffrey Blainey as guest speaker.

Late night shopping and Christmas festivities in Market Square and a street parade ushered in Christmas 1995.

Burra Senior Citizens again won a Meritorious Effort & Excellence Award from KESAB.

John McDouall Stuart’s return to Burra 133 years ago was commemorated at a ceremony at Burra Art Gallery on 11 December 1995 attended by 50 members of the John McDouall Stuart Society.

BCS. 13 students completed their SACE in 1995 and six were offered places at Universities of TAFE.

BCS in 1996 had 30 new students enrolling to total:

Junior School 137

Middle School 101

Senior School 58

296

At BCS Speech night in 1995 Jeanette Wormald of Loxton was guest speaker.

The school used two ‘farms’ in 1995 – the area between the school and the smelts paddock and land at Kookaburra. 60 acres had been cropped.

BCS won a national basketball competition sponsored by Uncle Toby’s, which included a coaching clinic run by two national basketballers and $5,000 worth of sports equipment.

Steele won the 1995 House Competition at the BCS Athletics Day for the first time in 14 years. And the Annual Inter-school Sports was held at BCS on 29 March.

Burra Burra DC began to introduce recycling with paper and cardboard waste collection.

Neil Page was appointed business and rural advisor to the Mid North Rural Development Board.

Robyn Page – teacher and President of Burra J150 Committee was chosen as Burra Citizen of the Year.

Back to Burra Schools was the Event of the Year.

The sealing of the Burra-Morgan Road was started in January, continuing from the 22 km already sealed at the Morgan end. The $17.6 million project to ‘The Gums’ was due for completion in Sept 1996.

On Australia Day more than 200 people gathered in Market Square and Australia Day Awards were presented.

Over summer 119 swimmers (the same number as in 1995) were involved in Vacswim.

Wesfarmers-Dalgety conducted an information evening in February on the electronic world of buying and selling Australian Wool.

Mt Bryan Progress Association submitted a plan for landscaping the Mt Bryan Reserve Area to be named the Sir Hubert Wilkins Memorial Park. The plan was adopted by Council.

Mt Bryan children were tested and found to have significant levels of arsenic. It was thought to come from rainwater tanks contaminated by dust from crushed ballast removal. Movement of the stone was banned.

Burra Clean-up on 3 March saw a team of 25 working on the Burra Creek and the Redbanks Reserve.

Burra Main Street Committee undertook to develop a grants manual.

Local Basketball Grand Finals on 16 March saw Rebels as the Women’s Premiers and Mixed Nuts as Men’s Premiers. Magic won in the Junior Competition and also in Sub Juniors.

Hallett residents held their inaugural Pre-Easter Carnival on 31 March.

Burra Picnic Races were held at Thistlebeds on Sunday 30 March. From the profits $100 went to the RFDS and $500 to the Nursing Mothers’ Association.

Burra Community School purchased the 170 ha Brewery Hill property previously owned by the Topsfield Family. A $30,000 development grant was received from the Department of Primary Industries and $60,000 from the Department of Education & Children’s Services.

The 4th Mid North Sheepdog Trials were held at Burra Showgrounds over the Saturday and Sunday of the Easter weekend as part of the Country Games, which ran from 30 March to 28 April. There were 95 entrants. The Mid North Sheepdog Training Club is based at Farrell Flat.

The newly amalgamated Northern Regions of the Women’s Agricultural Bureau held its first conference at Burra Sports Complex on 3 April.

On 31 December 1995 50 mm of rain fell in 25 minutes. The 1996 season opened late with good rains in June, consolidated by 101 mm in July, leading to good crops in general.

A Tourism Advisory Committee was formed in November 1995. In March 1996 the Burra Burra DC decided to restructure its tourism assets. It decided not to renew the Tourism Executive Officer’s contract and managers of the several operations would now be answerable directly to Council. In its budget for 1996-97 the Council allowed for a 20% financial drop in its tourism involvement from $700,000 to $534,120.

Burra Burra DC voted for a 4% rise in rates to keep pace with inflation and a minimum rate of $335. The Valuer-General’s assessment of properties showed a 3-4% reduction.

Robertstown DC received a grant of $10,000 to upgrade facilities at the Burra Creek Gorge Recreation Park.

Burra creek Landcare Group received $20,000 from the Federal Government as part of $1 million in grants – it was for the removal of exotic pests along the Burra Creek.

The District Councils of Hallett, Burra Burra, Robertstown and Eudunda signed a memorandum of understanding to investigate and report on likely gains from an amalgamation of their councils. The working party of two members and the CEO from each council met in June. The Ratepayers’ Association repeatedly asked the Council why the option of a merger with Clare was not being pursued. A very poorly attended public meeting was held and reported in the Broadcaster of 14 August. Graham Kellock said it was hoped to have the amalgamation in place by March 1997, before Council elections.

Clare and Burra Hospitals continued to work together in areas of administration, payroll and trade accounts and in February Burra Hospital agreed in principle to form a joint board with Clare. Further negotiations include Burra, Clare and Snowtown Hospitals having one board of directors and one CEO. Buildings, plant and capital funds are to remain the property of each local community. Burra Director of Nursing, Lesley Phillips transferred to Clare in July and Noreen Hallion took over in Burra. The last AGM of the Burra Hospital reflected sadness at the end of 119 years of independent operation and excitement at the projected amalgamation.

Burra National Trust at its AGM reported having 81 members and had spent $27,152 on capital improvements.

The Merino Field Days in 1996 involved 53 studs. The pairs and ram competition was held at the Burra Oval. More than 900 people attended the Gala Night and judging. Top honours went to Eyre Peninsula’s stud ‘Deloshanda’.

Collinsville Mt Bryan offered 100 rams in September with buyers from all over SA and beyond. Top price was $8,000 for a Merino and $7,000 for a Poll Merino.

The refurbished Tiver’s Row cottages at Burra North were given a traditional dry stone wall.

Helen Stockman was appointed new co-ordinator of the Main Street Program.

Adchem saw BCS students and Adchem staff plant 300 trees on their property in August.

47 BCS students took part in an athletics competition in Adelaide on 11 April.

The Burra Antique and Decorating Fair on the weekend of 11-12 May was combined with a cultural weekend organised by the Main Street Committee with grants from the Festivals Assistance Fund and the Country Arts Fund. There was an art exhibition at the gallery, a photographic exhibition, a barber-shop quartet, a poetry workshop and a dinner dance.

The Girl guides held a Gathering of Owls weekend at Redruth Camp Centre in August, when 46 Brownie leaders from across the state met.

A committee formed in 1985 [sic – 1995?] to plan the clean-up and greening of the Hallett-Terowie railway corridor saw its first planting of seedlings 3 km south of Terowie.

The Veteran & Vintage Motor Cycle Club came to Burra on 21 September when the Burra Hospital Auxiliary catered for 130 guests at the Burra Town Hall.

Redbanks Reserve was opened to visitors on 22 September by Burra Burra DC Chairman Graham Kellock, after being closed for three years. A walking trail, camping area, picnic grounds and toilets have been established.

Burra National Trust Museum in Market Square celebrated its 30th birthday in September, when more than 175 people visited.

The Burra Art Gallery was officially opened on Saturday 5 October.

The Burra Show 1996 was highly successful in good weather. Gate takings of $3,286 were almost $400 more than in 1995.

Burra Hospital – bathroom renovations and an enclosed patio area for long stay patients were officially opened on 13 October.

The State Government cutbacks saw all ETSA presence in Burra cut.

‘Have Your Say’ meetings regarding Council Amalgamation drew 186 people at Hallett, 128 at Terowie and 58 at Robertstown.

Hallett School was closed due to falling enrolments. The end of an era was celebrated with a special students’ day, a sports demonstration, a birthday cake and an evening for parents and old scholars.

Burra Traders’ Association Christmas dinner had Rob Olsen as guest speaker from ‘Classic Country’, which is a body promoting regional tourism.

The Christmas Lights ceremony was held in Market Square on 30 November. The cake competition and auction raised $358 for the children’s ward at Burra Hospital.

Christmas Eve festivities are planned by the Burra Traders’ Association with a competition for best decorated businesses and houses.

Issue 290, 11 December 1996, page 15

Trevor & Jennie Wall are the new proprietors of Burra Motor Services behind Elders in Commercial Street. Trevor was for many years a mechanic with Richards Motor Co.

Burra Activities Centre held its Christmas Party. The raffle raised $550.

Issue 291, 18 December 1996, page 1

Fire. Children dropping a cigarette in dry grass on the bank of the Burra Creek started a fire on Saturday. The fire quickly spread upslope and burnt a pile of creosote posts at the rear of Wesfarmers-Dalgety before a passing MFS truck extinguished it.

Issue 291, 18 December 1996, page 2

Mt Bryan School held its annual concert on Wednesday evening, which included the musical ‘Phantom of the Music Room’. Guest speaker was Mrs Marcia Hayward, daughter of the late A.L. Collins. A new building at the school was officially opened as the A.L. Collins Room. Mr Andy Thomas on behalf of the school community farewelled Mr Barry Burney, who is moving to Mt Pleasant and Mrs Sandra Bailey, who will be teaching at Happy Valley next year.

Barker Homes in Burra has installed a pop-up sprinkler system in Pearce Row Commercial Street. (It was installed by Michael Jolly and his team.) Mrs Stella Angel has been welcomed to Unit 1 Pearce Row.

Christmas Message from Graham Kellock, Chairman of Burra Burra DC

When I took over as the Chairman six years ago I didn’t think I would be the last Chairman of the Burra Burra District Council. The new Regional Council of Goyder will cover a much wider area, but should supply the same wide ranging services, but more efficiently. This year has seen the sealing of the road from Morgan to ‘The Gums’ Station completed. Early in 1997 work will start from the Burra end to the Robertstown turn-off. The whole project will be completed in 1998. Plans have been drawn up to seal the Kooringa Road in the near future. This year Council has struggled to put its tourism budget on a more user-pays basis. The art Gallery was officially opened on 5 October. I thank the CFS and SES crews for their efforts in keeping the community safe. Thanks also go to all Council staff and elected members for their efforts.

Issue 291, 18 December 1996, page 4

Mary Woollacott announces she will stop writing her regular ‘Over the Back Fence’ feature after almost thirty years – though she is not sure whether the stoppage will be permanent or temporary.

BCS departing teachers:

Sue-Anne de Vries, Marie-Louise Heartfields, Bronwyn Rowe, Kathy Misso, Anthony O’Doherty, Deb Jackman, Leanne Filmer, Lyn Bradley and Paula Elsegood.

BCS Annual Prom was held very successfully with Polly Wilson and Andrew Breeding as Queen and King for the evening. Polly leaves for her year’s exchange in Germany next month.

The Bishop of Willochra confirmed three young people at St Mary’s on 24 November: Kimberlee Murdoch, Kimberley Stocker and Ben White.

The Ryan Family, Glynn, Sue, David and Peter have bought the former Page property opposite the Gaol.

Pastor Michael Dutschke is welcomed as the new Lutheran Pastor. He has recently moved with wife Gina to take over the Clare-Blyth Parish.

Cicely & Colin Bungey will return to the city after 12 months in Burra.

The Rolstones will move to Clare shortly, where Peter has been working at Elders for some time.

Michael Day & wife Kylie have bought Boud’s Butchery in Burra, he has worked there for several years.

Petrice Messenger is a new face at Oppy’s, taking over from Annie Kleinig.

Mary Woollacott caught up with Alan Baulderstone at his Burnside Village Fruit & Veg store recently. His wife Marcia helps out there on a regular basis and their elder son Philip is running the Silver Fruit Bowl in North Adelaide. Daughter Chris works with the CIB and son David has completed his intern year at Flinders Medical centre and moves to the Women’s and Children’s Hospital next year to follow his interest in paediatrics.

Birth. To Sarah & Ian Jaensch at Burra Hospital 6 December, a daughter, Emma Merle.

Marriage. Darryl & Pauline Venning’s Garden next Sunday

Christine McCann will marry Drew Nottle.

Obituary. Duncan McInnes died at Burra Hospital last Thursday aged 89.

[Duncan Henry McInnes died 11 December 1996. Buried at Burra 16 December 1996.]

Issue 291, 18 December 1996, page 6

The Burra-Morgan Road will be closed for about seven months from 6 January 1997 for rebuilding and sealing work. This is part of a $19 million upgrade, which when complete will see a sealed road from Morgan to Burra. The terrain between Burra and the Robertstown turn-off prevents a by-pass road. The road will re-open while the last section to ‘The Gums’ is completed.

Mr Steve Kerrigan, the CEO of Burra Burra DC has been appointed the interim CEO of the new Regional Council of Goyder. The new council is expected to be proclaimed 3 February 1997. Mr Kerrigan has been CEO at Burra for five years and prior service was with the District Council of Lower Eyre Peninsula and the City of Mitcham.

Issue 291, 18 December 1996, page 7

Mt Bryan Red Cross raised $1,281 during the 1995-96 year. In April Mrs Nora Heneker was presented with a 50-year laurel wreath.

Burra Guides have been busy in the 4th term with attendances averaging 5 Guides, 14 Junior Guides and 7 Gumnuts. Kylie Kaiser has completed her B.P., which is the highest achievement a Guide can work for.

Issue 291, 18 December 1996, page 8

Meal on Wheels in Burra had 20 volunteers in the year and delivered 2,245 meals. For 1997 the elected officers are: President, Celine Stockman; Vice-President, Jan Tiver; Secretary, Pat Brereton; Treasurer-Supervisor, Shana Nourse and Welfare Officer, Marg Dunstall.

Issue 291, 18 December 1996, page 9

BCS. Principal Kevin Fahey delivered his report for the year on Speech Night last Thursday.

He urged parents to reduce children’s TV watching and to improve reading skills and homework. He highlighted the enthusiasm that was generated by the establishment of Brewery Hill Farm. He urged encouraging a positive attitude among boys towards learning.

Musical items were included throughout the night.

[Award winners are listed – photo.]

Advt. Christmas Church Services are listed for:

Anglican at Hallett, Jamestown, Burra and Booborowie

Catholic at Burra, Spalding and Hallett

Lutheran at Burra

Uniting Church of Australia at Burra and Booborowie.

Issue 292, 15 January 1997, page 1

Police are concerned about road safety in Market Square and Commercial Street, with heavy transports negotiating the area. Heavy vehicles carrying dangerous goods should be banned from the town area. To achieve this, the bypass road needs to be upgraded. Officer Kaiser suggested also that the give-way sign at the T-junction on Market Square should be replaced with a stop sign. (It is difficult to see traffic approaching from Kingston Street Bridge because of the Council Chamber). Council does not have the funds to seal the bypass, but the Department of Transport has agreed to extend the median into the Market Square, Commercial Street intersection.

VacSwim has been taking place in Burra. [Photo of six children with Level 2 instructor, Kyron Statton.]

Issue 292, 15 January 1997, page 2

Vandalism. On 6 January extensive damage was done to a house in Essex Street, when walls were kicked in and windows smashed. Damage is estimated at $4,000. Three young men have been charged.

A Smash & Grad Raid at the Aberdeen Roadhouse on 21 December resulted in $40 belonging to the SES being stolen.

Theft. Money was stolen from a house in Lewis Street on 27 December.

Accident. A two-car collision 5 km south of Burra on 21 December caused c. $10,000 damage to vehicles and a female passenger was admitted to Burra Hospital.

Accident. An accident at Dare’s Hill on 27 December caused c. $5,000 damage to a vehicle and a female passenger was taken to Burra Hospital.

Fire. A grass fire at Dutton’s Trough burnt 250 acres of stubble on 28 December. A tractor striking a rock started the blaze, which was extinguished by units from Burra, Baldina, Robertstown and Eudunda.

NE Branch of the Isolated Children’s & Parents’ Association (ICPA) will host the State Conference on 5 April. At the AGM elected were: President, Jane Gloster; Vice-President, Paul Williams; Secretary, Deb Williams; Assistant Secretary, Sue Thomas and Treasurer, Pauline Crawford.

Burra Hospital will undergo an accreditation survey by the Australian Council on Health Care Standards on 26 & 27 February.

Issue 292, 15 January 1997, page 3

The Main Street Committee Chairman Richard Holbrook has retired and Russell Skinner has been elected in his place. Russel and wife Jan have moved to Burra and live in the newly painted Pearce’s Buildings.

Burra Burra DC – December

Council approved work needed to make and finish the sealing of the road around Burra Oval.

Mt Bryan dump is nearing the end of its lifespan.

Springvale Road is to be renamed Ironmine Road.

Council & BCS will share the cost of sealing the road from Smelts Road to the school and the northern car park. The total cost is c. $18,500. The school will assume responsibility for the maintenance.

Vic & Monique Haddow have resigned as managers of Paxton Square Cottages at the end of their contract, but will continue in the role until Easter. A Council sub-committee will select replacements.

Issue 292, 15 January 1997, page 4

The ‘In Town & Out’ Column changes authorship from Mary Woollacott to Helen Stockman from this issue. Mary had been writing the local social column for thirty years, starting with the Burra Record and continuing in the Burrs School & Community News before the Burra Broadcaster.

[Photo of Editor Terry Wilson & Mary Woollacott.]

Fire. The smoke from the Kangaroo Island bushfires reached as far north as Burra & beyond.

Burra Art Gallery’s present exhibition features artists from Burra and the Mid North.

Burra National Trust has proposed that it lease the Council’s heritage sites – Hampton, the Brewery Cellars, Smelts Paddock and the Tourist Information Centre – and also takes on responsibility for the Heritage Trail and Passport. Council has suggested a lease of $10 per site per year, payable on demand. The National Trust would be responsible for rates, taxes, power, water and maintenance. Council has offered to assist with a payment towards the cost of $10,000 for the first year, subject to annual review. The proposal is subject to approval by the National Trust of SA and the Hallett, Robertstown and Eudunda Councils.

Notice. The Department of Transport

The Burra-Morgan Road will be closed from 6 January 1997 for upgrading and sealing work.

The road will re-open in August 1997.

Birth. To Ian & Sarah Jaensch of Burra, at the Burra Hospital on 6 December 1996, a daughter, Emma Merle.

[Photo.]

Issue 292, 15 January 1997, page 5

The Four S.T. Gill Paintings have been valued by James Elder of Elder Fine Art Galleries at $300,000 to $400,000. He has suggested they could finance a major town project, such as the renovation of the hospital – possibly with a two to one subsidy from the Government of SA. He said they were of extreme historical importance and their conservation must be a concern for the local council. A likely purchaser would be the National Gallery of Australia in Canberra. The Council has said the paintings are to be housed in Burra and it resolved at its last meeting that they would not be sold or permanently removed from Burra.

Issue 292, 15 January 1997, page 6

Burra Christmas Pageant. More than 300 people assembled to watch the pageant of 24 floats. The Burra Hospital float was judged the best. [Photo.]

The best decorated houses were Bob Greet’s in Burra North and Ric Williams’ in Burra. Work & Western Clothing was deemed the best decorated shop.

Mt Bryan Red Cross will hold a progressive dinner on 8 February at $12 a head, as their main fundraiser for the year.

Central TV (GTS/BKN) is now broadcasting 24 hours a day.

Issue 292, 15 January 1997, page 7

Terowie. A crowd of c. 300 watched Terowie’s 34th annual Christmas pageant on 14 December. [Photo.]

Carols by Candlelight on the following Friday was also well supported.

Issue 293, 22 January 1997, page 1

The Season had a late start and winter was cold and wet, but despite its late start there has generally been a reasonable harvest. Canola has done very well and the acreage sown is likely to increase this year. Wheat and barley results have been variable. Lighter rainfall areas to the north did less well.

BCS. 87% of Year 12 students achieved their SACE and seven of the eight students were offered their first choice at either a university of TAFE.

Issue 293, 22 January 1997, pages 1 & 8

Boh Wall (15) is regarded as the best A Grade wicketkeeper in the Belalie-Mokota Association. He has now won the batting and the wicket-keeping trophies in last week’s U16 BankSA Country Cup held at Kadina. [Photo.]

Theft. Truck tyres and rims to the value of c. $2,000 were stolen from the Burra road train yards last Thursday night.

Fire. About 90 acres of grass was burnt at Booborowie last Friday 17 January, after a header struck a stone.

Vandalism. Considerable damage was done at BCS last Saturday night by persons spraying graffiti.

Police Changes. Peter Thompson leaves this week after two years here, to take charge of the Mannahill Police Station. Russell Disher, who is transferring from Peterborough, will replace him.

Letter. Anthony Thorogood writes re the S.T. Gill paintings and James Elder. He was left with the impression that James Elder thought the people of Burra were morons, who couldn’t possibly know, value or understand the Gill paintings. He thinks the Council was quite correct to have no intentions of selling them and that we must hold them to it. The paintings are part of the infrastructure of the tourist industry.

Issue 293, 22 January 1997, pages 2 & 3

Fire. About 5 acres of stubble on BCS property were burnt last Saturday. It started when a dog being exercised by a visitor knocked his cigarette from his hand.

Issue 293, 22 January 1997, page 3

Burra Golf Club has donated $500 to Burra Hospital, which has used it to buy new lightweight continental quilts for the acute area beds.

Issue 293, 22 January 1997, page 4

Burra Monthly Rainfall Figures with totals and averages are published for the period 1930-96.

Issue 293, 22 January 1997, page 10

The Great Southern International Sunrace visited Burra on Monday. [Photo.]

Issue 294, 29 January 1997, page 1

The ANZ Bank will close its Burra branch after 137 years in the town, having started as the Bank of Australasia. It will merge its branch with Clare on 21 February. The bank has announced that Beaut Fruit will continue as an agency and that present arrangements will continue for Booborowie.

Issue 294, 29 January 1997, pages 1 & 3

Letter. Russell Skinner, Chairman of the Main Street Committee writes to say he considers the closing of the ANZ Bank branch as but one aspect of the ugly face of the economic rationalism that is scorching rural communities as public utilities and commercial institutions centralise their operations. He regards their conveyance of the information in a form letter, with less than a month’s notice for customers to re-organise their financial arrangements, as appalling commercial ruthlessness. Perhaps rural communities like Burra need to consider establishing their own financial co-operative.

Issue 294, 29 January 1997, pages 1 & 6

Australia Day

Rosemary Opperman was Burra’s Citizen of the Year.

Darren Boulger was Young Citizen of the Year.

George Kaiser, Officer in Charge at Burra, accepted the award for local police who organised ‘150 Years of Policing in Burra’, which was Event of the Year.

Australia Day celebrations were held in Market Square, with a breakfast from 7.30 a.m.

Rosemary Opperman was nominated for her hard work as co-ordinator of the Burra Ambulance Service.

Darren Boulger was nominated (after a gap of three years with no nominations in this category) for being so instrumental in getting ‘The Miners Revolution’ up and running – this was an event staged on the night of the Burra Show. And for his involvement with the SES, the Arts Council and the family business.

Concerts associated with ‘150 Years of Policing in Burra’ resulted in cheques being presented to the Burra SES, National Trust, Ambulance and Burra Blue Light. [4 photos.]

Issue 294, 29 January 1997, page 2

Vacation Swimming. This year the program resulted in:

10 involved in senior life-saving levels

17 in lower life-saving levels

25 were middle level swimmers

59 were beginners.

All are listed.

National Trust Lease of Council Tourist Sites

This article reiterates the arrangement mentioned in Issue 292, 15 January 1997, page 4, but indicates that the Council has now accepted the National Trust’s proposal and has increased Council’s contribution to an initial $16,000 p.a.

Issue 294, 29 January 1997, page 3

Deb Jackaman, Daniel, Nick & Caili were farewelled from Burra on 19 January after a number of years here. They have returned to Adelaide.

Burra National Trust was recently given a small pure copper ingot by Peter & Jane Strawbridge. It was given to Peter by his uncle, who said it was presented to special visitors to the Burra Mine last century as a memento.

Burra Golf Club is seeking $320,000 to establish greens on the Burra Golf Course. They have written to the Burra Burra DC seeking $80,000 to match a similar amount to be raised by the club. They would then seek a matching $160,000 from the State Government. The project would include an irrigation system and the construction of dams. Council has approved it in principal and recommended it to the new Regional Council of Goyder.

Marriage. The Garden at ‘The Pines’ 26 January

Robyn Lunn married Tim Stockman. [Photo Issue 295, 5 February 1997, page 2.]

Obituary. Doug Burton of Mt Bryan died last week after a long illness. (Husband of Raelene.)

[A Return Thanks Notice Issue 299, 5 March 1997, page 9 gives the date as 20 January. The cemetery record says he was Douglas John Burton aged 65 and buried at Burra 23 January 1997.]

Obituary. Former BCS student and athlete Adam Day died last week.

Issue 294, 29 January 1997, page 4

Hallett Australia Day Events. Peter Boaden was Citizen of the Year for his tireless efforts as Council CEO as well as for his work as Secretary of the Swimming Pool, Hallett Fire Brigade, Community Development Board and the Sir Hubert Wilkins Memorial Committee.

The Event of the Year was the Terowie CWA’s ‘Una Bowden Art Show’.

Hallett District Council held an event last Friday night to celebrate 64 years of existence – the last function for the Council before next week’s commencement of the Regional Council of Goyder.

Issue 295, 5 February 1997, page 1

Regional Council of Goyder

The Council held its first meeting on Monday when 25 Councillors and four clerks crowded into the former Burra Council Civic Centre. Denis Keller of Robertstown was elected Chairman, with Graham Kellock of Burra as Deputy Chairman. Steve Kerrigan has been appointed CEO. [Photo.]

Two other appointments are yet to be finalised – Peter Boaden (previously Hallett District Clerk) as Director of Human Resources & Operations and David Jennings (Eudunda Clerk) as Director of Corporate Services.

Meetings will be held on the third Monday of each month in Burra Civic Centre.

Denis Keller was Robertstown’s Citizen of the Year for 1997 and has been Chairman of the Robertstown Council. He was elected for Bright Ward in 1977, became Deputy Chairman in 1980 and has been Chairman since 1982. He has been an executive member of the Mid North Regional Organisation and a member of all Council committees. He has also been active in the CFS and was Chairman of the United Farmers & Graziers for 10 years (now the SA Farmers’ Federation).

Issue 295, 5 February 1997, page 2

Letter. Rod Peppiatt writes to ask people who are angry about the ANZ closure not to take it out on the local staff, who had no say in the decision and very little warning.

Issue 295, 5 February 1997, page 3

Burra Probus Club. Bob Skinner has taken over as acting President, following the unexpected resignation of Mary Press. Freda Pink is acting Vice-President. Heather Affolter is Secretary and Ray Lloyd is Treasurer.

ANZ Bank Closure in Burra

Amanda, Karen & Sally will be re-deployed to Clare branch from 24 February.

Amanda Glazbrook started with the ANZ in Adelaide more than ten years ago and moved to Booborowie Agency in 1990. She has been in Burra for six years.

Karen Schell of Leighton has been with the Burra branch for a little more than two years.

Sally Richardson started at the Burra branch five months ago. She had previous experience with the Burra Rental Agency and with Bob Heath Real Estate.

Issue 296, 12 February 1997, page 6

Burra Burra DC held a special gathering in late January to mark its passing. A number of past members and employees attended including:

Tom Perry (a former Clerk)

Don Roberts and his wife Jean

Ray Jennison & Jack McMahon (former Chairmen)

Ben Kotz – the oldest employee, who was working for the council before WWII.

Elspeth Radford has been appointed to the Industry Development Board (Wool).

Burra SES members Mike Fretwell & Les Smale assisted with the flood recovery efforts in the Yunta and Olary areas over the weekend. Olary had been completely cut off by flood waters.

Birth. To Jason & Alison McLean, a daughter, Amelia Katharine.

Issue 296, 12 February 1997, page 10

Burra Tree Planting Group will this year concentrate on plantings along the approaches to the town.

Issue 297, 19 February 1997, pages 1 & 7

BCS. The Annual Swimming Carnival was held last Tuesday night. Jennison was victorious in the House Competition. Jennison 365 points to Riggs 280 and Steele 276. [Photo & results printed on page 7.]

Housing in Burra. The demand for houses was about the same in 1996 as in 1995. 24 houses were sold in the Burra Burra DC area and the average price remained fairly steady. It was $52,204 in 1992 and $56,318 in 1996. 1993 was a boom year when 50 houses changed hands at an average price of $63,576. AdChem’s rationalisation has placed a number of houses on the market and at present there are a number of fine bluestones available in a buyers’ market. A number of Burra businesses are still doing well however, by appealing to a broader market. These include: Stephen Angel’s Décor Made Easy, Gary McPhee of McPhee’s Butchers and Saltbush Clothing. The sealing of the Burra-Morgan Road could see some boost to economic activity.

Issue 297, 19 February 1997, page 2

Editor. In view of the Olary floods, which suggest that replacement bridges should be wider, he expresses concern that the new bridge at Snake Gully can handle only 35% of the volume of the old one.

Classic Country Tourism Board has released its 1997 Visitor Guide – a 64-page publication for attractions across Yorke Peninsula and the Mid North.

Issue 297, 19 February 1997, page 3

Fr John Devenport was among 800 delegates from all over Australia, New Zealand and Papua New Guinea at the National Anglican Conference in Canberra last week. He was invited to celebrate Holy Communion at the conference.

Issue 297, 19 February 1997, page 5

Burra Swimming Pool patronage is up this year and income with it. New shades were erected by volunteers and one provides shade for the toddlers’ pool. This Friday Vince Henderson has organised a Blue Light Disco at the pool. [2 photos.]

BCS screened the film 101 Dalmatians in the school gymnasium last week and exactly 101 patrons turned up.

A Power Outage was caused in Burra on Saturday when a magpie short circuited a 33,000 volt power line, caught alight and dropped to the ground, causing a grass fire.

Issue 297, 19 February 1997, page 6

Burra & Districts Obedience Dog Club resumed for 1997 on 2 February. It is now in its fifth year.

Issue 297, 19 February 1997, page 7

Birth. To Paul & Sally Fritz of Hamley Bridge, at Burra Hospital on 8 February, a daughter, Rebecca Ann.

Advt. Adelaide Bank is now offering a banking service through the local post office.

Issue 297, 19 February 1997, page 10

Obituary. A Return Thanks Notice reveals the death recently of Rosemary Ann Heneker.

Issue 298, 26 February 1997, page 1

Goyder Council is considering the balance of fire services and possible savings. This comes after Cr Quinn asked that the Minister for Emergency Services be asked to look at the feasibility of withdrawing the Metropolitan Fire service (MFS) and transferring the responsibility to the CFS from 1 July. Naracoorte lost its MFS unit ten years ago and Eudunda three years ago. Burra MFS is staffed by 9 personnel and has responsibility primarily for the town area and has equipment specifically designed for urban fires. The MFS acquires surplus trucks from the Metropolitan Area at no cost. The Council is looking at ways of reducing the estimated $52,000 cost of fire protection in a financial year.

Weather. Burra (and SA generally) has experienced high temperatures for the last two weeks, comparable with the heat wave of 1939. From 18-24 February maxima in Burra have been: 41.0 oC, 39.5, 39.5, 40.5, 40.0, 38.5 & 27.5.

Issue 298, 26 February 1997, page 2

BCS has a male primary school teacher for the first time in quite a while. Mark Holman will take Year 5 and has transferred from Ceduna. In SA the primary teaching staff is 75% female.

Marriage. Recently

Leighton Dollman married Wendy Hughes of Reynella.

Birth. To Kevin & Jane Miller, a daughter, Alexandra Jane. A granddaughter for Martin & Moira Miller.

Birth. To Andrew & Jacinta Secomb, a son. A grandchild for John & Valmai Secomb, previously of Burra.

Obituary. Maxine Beinke, wife of Mick Beinke, died recently.

Obituary. Mrs Dorothy Tattersall died recently.

Obituary. Mr Bill Nankivell died last week.

[Ronald William Nankivell, born 14 April 1923 at Baldina.]

The Old Burra Swimming Pool Area is being transformed into a rose garden.

The Burra Lions Club will wind up in June after nineteen years, due to falling membership.

Hamish Arthur, son of John & Elaine, is appearing as a sports reporter on Channel 9.

Maureen & Barry Wright have recently traversed the Murray from Yarrawonga to Renmark in preparation for a new edition of River Murray Charts.

The Department of Education & Community Services recently held a two-day conference in Burra studying Ngadjuri people, their history and culture. Four BCS teachers attended along with others from Orroroo, Peterborough and Waikerie.

Issue 298, 26 February 1997, page 3

Goyder Council has decided not to support the Burra Golf Club’s request for $85,000 to match their own $85,000. The club had asked for the sum and for Council’s support in their request for a $150,000 Federal grant.

BankSA has denied that it is contemplating closing its Burra branch or further reducing its hours. Last year the branch reduced its hours to 11-4 Monday to Thursday and 11-5 on Friday as well as closing for lunch from 1.30-2.00 p.m. It also removed its manager.

Issue 298, 26 February 1997, page 8

Issue 298, 26 February 1997, page 10

The Bon Accord Hotel has not been open for business since Saturday night, with a note for customers outside on a blackboard. Regulars are concerned about appearances and think it would be sad to see a business close in the town.

Issue 299, 5 March 1997, pages 1 & 4

Burra Hospital was visited by an accreditation survey team last Wednesday and Thursday. The feedback was positive, but the written results of the survey will be some months away. The hospital celebrated its 120th birthday with a special cake at a celebration with patients, staff and the Ladies’ Auxiliary. The formal celebrations will be on 6 April, when a fair will be held in the hospital grounds. The hospital serves a wide area that includes Burra, Mt Bryan, Booborowie, Farrell Flat, Hallett & Robertstown districts. Over the years the board of management has constantly striven for improvements and innovation and in that has been greatly assisted by bequests and the commitment of the Ladies’ Auxiliary. The amalgamation of the Burra, Clare and Snowtown Hospitals last September saw the formation of the Burra Clare Snowtown Health Service Inc. Services will be reviewed over the next two years, including the provision of theatre, long stay and short stay beds. John Brak, Burra Hospital House Committee Chairman said the biggest threat facing country hospitals was the loss of theatre facilities and that will ultimately depend on government funds. [3 photos.]

Issue 299, 5 March 1997, page 2

The Ironmine Church was found on 26 February to be the location of a hydroponic set-up growing 13 cannabis plants. No one lives in the church and police are seeking information relating to the matter.

Letter. An anonymous writer suggests the so-called concerned regulars who lament the closure of the Bon Accord Hotel, are in fact probably the cause, given that most have failed to patronise it for the past two or three months.

Booborowie Swimming Pool has a chlorine emergency on Monday when chlorine was found to be bubbling out of a large storage drum in the pool shed. Police, CFS and HAZMAT officials conferred and ICI safety expert Ray Tyson was called in. Eventually it was decided to tip the contents of the 44 gallon plastic container into the pool to be broken down by sunlight.

Issue 299, 5 March 1997, page 3

The Burra-Morgan Road between Burra North and Fords Corner should be sealed by mid-April and the section from there to the Robertstown turn-off by the end of July. About 40 people are working on the project. [Photo of site manager Angelo Rossi with Glenys Christopher of Fords Corner.]

Issue 299, 5 March 1997, page 4

Burra Golf Club is disappointed to learn of Goyder Council’s decision not to support their request for $85,000 towards the greening of the golf course, but has put together a proposal of $150,000 from the State Government’s Regional Development Grant.

Issue 299, 5 March 1997, page 5

Fox Baiting. Within the Burra Eudunda Robertstown Animal & Plant Control Board’s district newborn lambs losses have been as high as 25% due to fox depredation. A new baiting program using 1080 in chicken heads is being launched in a carefully managed program. Baits not taken must be collected and destroyed.

Notice. Regional Council of Goyder. Nominations are called for the position of Councillor by 27 March.

Burra Ward 5 required

Eudunda Ward 4 required

Hallett Ward 2 required

Robertstown Ward 2 required

A postal voting election will be held if required.

Issue 299, 5 March 1997, page 6

Birth. To Natalie & Brett Matson at Burra on 18 February, a son, Jesse James.

Issue 299, 5 March 1997, page 9

Notice. World Day of Prayer – Friday in St John’s Lutheran Church, Burra.

Issue 300, 12 March 1997, page 1

Merino Field Days

53 leading studs will take part in the 1997 SA Stud Merino Field Days.

Earthquake. Last Wednesday a quake measuring 5 on the Richter scale was felt across a wide area of SA. It was centred about 14 km south of Burra. In Burra some items fell from shelves or walls, but no structural damage has been reported.

Letter. ‘Very concerned Burra resident’ queries rumours that surgery will no longer be done at the Burra Hospital and wonders whether that also means the end of having babies there too.

The Uniting Church annual Kids Campout was held last weekend. Some 34 children and 8 leaders from Burra took part.

Ian Denton of Farrell Flat has announced a scaling down of his business. After some 74 years in the town, Denton’s will be a ‘parts only’ business from 30 June.

Issue 300, 12 March 1997, page 2

Burra CFS held a Level 3 Advanced Fire Training Course last weekend.

Len & Nancy Simpson will celebrate their Golden Wedding on 22 March.

Burra National Trust hosted a barbecue at the Old Police Lock-up last Friday night for a group of Asian travel journalists.

Obituary. Clarrie Williams died on 22 February.

[Clarence Albert Williams born 29 August 1931.]

Issue 300, 12 March 1997, page 3

Redfire Resources has extended its mining lease between Hallett and Robertstown to include the town area of Burra and its surroundings. They are following up ‘targets’ from aero-magnetic and geological data.

Issue 300, 12 March 1997, page 4

BCS. The foundation stone of the old school building was laid 120 years ago on 27 February 1877 by Thomas Bath. It was built to accommodate 800 to 900 students at a cost of £6,976. Construction was by G. & W. Sara and Dunstan. The opening of the Burra Hospital took place on the same day. The town celebrated with a half holiday – shops closed at noon and miners had time off. Sir Henry Ayers opened the hospital and after ‘a capital lunch’ the official party proceeded to the Burra Institute, from which a procession was formed to go to the school site. It was led by the Burra Brass Band, followed by 20 Freemasons, Oddfellows, Foresters and Rechabites, each order in full regalia. At the rear came the members of the Ministry present, the Mayor and Councillors of Burra, Mr Bath, etc. A crowd of almost 1,500 gathered at the school site, where Mr Bath as the earliest established businessman laid the foundation stone with a silver trowel made by Alfred Day, an Adelaide jeweller. The band then played the Song of Australia and the crowd then gave three cheers for The Queen, three for Mr Bath and three for the ladies. The official party ended the day with a fine dinner and the usual speeches. For the general public there was a musical and literary entertainment at the Institute.

[Photo of present students from Reception to Year 6 on the steps of the building.]

Galahs 16 defeated Burra bears 11. [Photo.]

Issue 301, 19 March 1997, page 1

The National Bank held an evening at the Sports Complex last week with specialists from Adelaide attending to explain the banking products available locally. The Burra branch of the National Australia Bank was the second one established outside of Adelaide, back in 1856[sic.]. [Photo of pharmacist John Barton with Joe Siragusa, NAB’s area manager.]

[Note that the National Bank of Australasia was established in Victoria in 1858. The Burra branch was opened on 25 April 1859.]

SA Merino Field Days. Numbers seem to have been down a little, but there was still plenty of buyer interest. Barton Hill sold one ram for $5,000 and another for $4,000.

Issue 301, 19 March 1997, page 2

Burra Antique Fair & Main Street Committee are pleased that local traders have donated $920 towards the cost of special advertising for the fair, on Central Television. The 6th Annual Fair will be held on 2-4 May, to coincide with the Cultural Weekend.

Letter. An anonymous writer complains about heavy traffic using Smelts Road, creating noise and dust.

[This was traffic generated by the Burra-Morgan Road sealing project.]

Advt. Russ & Jan Skinner announce the opening of ‘Sweet Reflections’ 21 Commercial Street on Saturday 22 March. Art & Craft – Old style Sweets – Antiques – Bric-a-Brac – Books – Clothes – Home Produce.

Issue 301, 19 March 1997, page 3

Accident. A large truck loaded with alcohol, groceries and electrical goods rolled over on the Barrier Highway c. 26 km south of Burra on Saturday at c. 4 a.m. The road was blocked until c. 10 a.m. The driver suffered minor injuries.

Accident. On 11 March a vibrating roller used on the Burra-Morgan road works some 5 km east of Burra rolled down a 5 m embankment and finished upside-down. The driver was thrown clear and admitted to Burra Hospital with back and chest pains.

Advt. J.J. & B.C. Richards Motor Engineers of 7 Market Street Burra announce their closing down sale – to end on 27 March.

Issue 301, 19 March 1997, page 4

Birth. To Susan & Chris Thomas of Parnaroo Station via Peterborough on Friday last at Burra Hospital, a son, George William.

Issue 301, 19 March 1997, page 5

Burra Art Gallery has a unique art exhibition at present. ‘Power of a Small Brush’.

It comprises a wonderful collection of loaned works by famous Australian painters, including:

Arthur Boyd Russell Drysdale Arthur Streeton

John Rowell David Dallwitz Allyson Parsons

Ainslee Roberts Bernard Hesling John Horrocks (the explorer)

Elizabeth Durack Robert Hannaford Ferdinand Bauer (who sailed with Flinders 1801-05)

Louis Kahan Sir Hans Heysen Penny Dowie (formerly of Mt Bryan)

Gwen Barringer Walter Wotke John Tiplady

Jeffrey Smart’s sketch of ‘Fellow Student, Bob Skinner’.

Junior Cricket Grand Final

Issue 302, 26 March 1997, page 1

The SA Stud Merino Sheepbreeders Assoc. gala night on Tuesday drew visitors from across Australia and from Germany and the USA. The award for Merino Capital Champion Ram went to Deloshanda Stud for the third year in a row. The Champion Pair Award went to Old Ashrose Stud. Sales reported from most studs were a slight improvement on last year.

The Alf Romeo Owners’ Club of Australia will be in Burra next weekend for its National Rally. It is celebrating its 21st anniversary. The 120 or so attending will be accommodated at the Paxton Square Cottages, Burra Motor Inn and the Burra Hotel. There will be a street parade on Saturday morning and a 160 km observation run, finishing at Leasingham Winery for lunch. The Show ʼn’ Shine display will be on the BCS Oval on Sunday.

Issue 302, 26 March 1997, page 2

Sheepdog Trials will be held at the Burra Showgrounds over Easter.

The Variety Club’s Desert Challenge will leave the Burra Mine site on Saturday 5 April.

Issue 302, 26 March 1997, page 3

The State Government’s Development Assessment Commission has refused approval for an internally illuminated sign for Joe’s Super Snacks in Market Square – based on advice from the Heritage Adviser and because it would have jutted out at 90o and not been flush with the parapet and ‘would not conform with the development plan’.

Letter. The CEO of Burra Clare Snowtown Health Service writes to say that changes to Theatre or Obstetric Services at Burra have not to date been an issue for discussion.

Issue 302, 26 March 1997, page 5

BCS held its annual sports day last Wednesday. The winning house was Steele with 2265 points, followed by Riggs with 2020 and Jennison with 1980. [2 photos.]

Age Group Champions.

Issue 302, 26 March 1997, page 6

The Australian Country Games were competed for at the weekend. Luke Spackman won Athlete of the Day for the U13 to 15 Age Group. He had won gold in the 200 m, 100 m, and the triple jump.

Other Burra athletes to win medals were:

Tina Williams with gold in the 100 m and 200 m and a silver in the triple and high jumps.

Boh Wall won silver in the 800 m and the triple jump and bronze medals for the 100 m, 200 m and discus.

Nicky Taylor won silver in the long jump and bronze in hurdles.

Goyder Council

John Brak has been appointed senior administration officer.

Various proposals for changes to the Market Square area are displayed in the Council foyer. Comment is invited.

Burra Community Print has added another printing press in their Commercial Street premises. The three-tonne Fuji press was off-loaded last week.

Howard Matson & Bev Fleming have been appointed interim managers at Paxton Square Cottages.

Mokota Cricket Grand Final

Burra 1 for 142 defeated Belalie-Mannanarie 9 for 139.

For Burra Matt Opperman was 62 n.o. and Boh Wall 71 n.o. while Michael Opperman took 3 for 24 and Darren James took 3 for 29.

Tennis Finals

A Grade Burra Kooringa 11 defeated Andrews 9

A2 Grade Redruth 14 defeated Hampton 5

B Grade Booborowie 11 defeated Aberdeen 9

Juniors Wandillah 9 defeated Kookaburra 3

Issue 303, 3 April 1997, page 1

The Alfa Romeo Owners’ Club had more than 140 members in Burra for the Easter weekend in a very successful visit.

Burra Show Society held its AGM at which President Ric Williams said the society was at a turning point and with teamwork further improvements could be made. The stockbreeders had installed skylights and the Miners Revolution Committee had done well returning a $100 profit on their first year. Ian Slade has been elected Senior Vice-President and Barbara Frances is the Junior Vice-President. The show hall will get some attention this year because several groups are interested in using it on a long term basis. The Society’s constitution is currently being reviewed.

Theft. $80 was stolen from the cool drink vending machine at BCS over the Easter weekend.

Native Grasslands preservation groups were addressed at meetings at Burra and Spalding recently. There are significant remnants of grasslands along the Hallett-Terowie rail corridor and at Banbury. The tussock grassland was a habitat for the pigmy bluetongue. Such areas are important habitat for threatened flora and fauna.

Issue 303, 3 April 1997, page 3

Russell & Jan Skinner of ‘Sweet Reflections’ reported a great first week of operations that coincided with the Easter long weekend. Several hundred adults went through each day. The Burra Roadhouse and the antique shops also reported good business.

Issue 303, 3 April 1997, page 6

Probus Club AGM was held in March and officers for 1997-98 are: President, Bob Skinner; Vice-Presidents, Freda Pink & Marty Hogan. Linda Sutton is relieving secretary.

The Isolated Children’s Parents’ Association annual conference will be held in the Burra Town Hall this year. Dot Sandland, life member of the North Eastern branch will open it and the guest speaker will be Xavier Minniecon from the ABC. The Minister of Education, Rob Lucas will attend.

Issue 303, 3 April 1997, page 7

Burra Bowling Club. Howard Griffen has been presented with a super veterans’ badge (for bowlers over 80 years of age). [Photo.]

The club hosted three bowling tournaments over Easter:

A Tanunda team won the Men’s Fours on Saturday.

On Sunday the Pairs Competition was won by K. Went & B. Herrmann.

On Monday the Cosmopolitan Pairs was won by Kevin & Valda Williams.

Five Councillors are required and therefore an election will be held on 3 May to be conducted entirely by the use of postal voting papers.

Issue 304, 9 April 1997, page 1

Burra National Trust will manage the Tourist Information Centre and the heritage sites on the passport upon the appointment of a consultant-manager (on a 12-month contract). Goyder Council has agreed to this proposal.

Australian Young People’s Festival occurs every two years and as part of it Burra & Mt Bryan school students were out in force as ‘Take Over ʼ97’, a festival activity aimed at boosting the schools’ arts program.

Issue 304, 9 April 1997, page 2

Fires

5 ha of grassland were burned on Murray Tiver’s land at Springbank Road last Thursday.

20 ha of Stockman’s ‘Mitchel Vue’ property 20 km south of Burra were burnt on Monday.

Redruth Camp Centre had a large Uniting Church Youth Group over Easter. The group also occupied the Town Oval.

The Sheepdog Trials at the Burra Showgrounds over Easter attracted competitors from all over the state.

Issue 304, 9 April 1997, page 3

The Isolated Children’s Parents’ Association held its annual conference at the Burra Town Hall on Saturday. It was attended by the Minister of Education & Children’s Services, Barry Wakelin Federal Member for Grey and Peter Dunn MLC as well as other representatives of educational bodies and parents – about 100 people in all. Guest speaker was the ABC weather presenter and journalist Xavier Minniecon. The conference ended with a dinner at the Sports Complex. [Photo.]

Issue 304, 9 April 1997, page 4

Notice. Regional Council of Goyder

Market Square and best Place Concept Drawings were presented and discussed at a public workshop on 5 March 1997 and are now on exhibition at the Council Office, Post Office and at venues in Best Place. The third workshop will be on 30 April at Burra Town Hall. This is your chance to comment.

Burra Picnic Races will present a total of 29 events. The main race will be the Kooringa Cup worth $1,000. There are also gymkhana events and two sleepy lizard derbies and a long kick competition for footballers.

BCS. The northern car park was sealed on Monday along with the Town Hall car park.

Issue 304, 9 April 1997, page 5

Burra Hospital Gala Day celebrating 120 years of the Burra Hospital was held last Sunday. Special visitors were brothers Bob & Peter Brunnitt [sic] descendants of one of Burra’s first doctors. The event was a great success. [Dr Robert Brummitt arrived in Burra in 1877. He stayed for 23 years and was very active in civic affairs, being Mayor December 1883-November 1884 and again December 1894- November 1897, but given that the mine opened in 1845, he can hardly be said to be one of the first doctors in the town.]

Terowie Citizens’ Association has completed a project working on its collection of c. 1,500 historic photos. They have been cleaned and stored in an acid free and stable environment. A start has been made on identifying them all and copying the most significant and the most fragile. The program was enabled by a grant of $4,000 from the National Library and $3,000 from the Association’s resources along with more than 700 hours of voluntary labour.

Issue 304, 9 April 1997, page 6

The Variety Club’s Desert Challenge commenced its trial from the Burra Mine on Saturday morning. There were about 140 challengers who set off on the seven day trip through Horseshoe Range, Chambers Gorge and then the Strzelecki Track, Mt Lyndhurst, the Gammon Ranges and Arkaroola.

Major Margaret Garratt was born at Burra and became part of the Salvation Army because her parents and maternal grandparents were members. She joined the Army aged 11 before moving to Adelaide. Her parents were Wilf Garratt & Ruth nee Aberg. [There is no obvious reason for this snippet. Aberg & Sons opened a butcher shop in Burra in 1933 and Ruth Aberg married Wilfred Garratt in 1935.]

Issue 305, 16 April 1997, pages 1 & 12

The Burra Railway Line is planned to be sold by the Federal Government. The sale includes passenger rail, SA freight services and the Tasmanian Railway System. There have been more than 30 expressions of interest. AN says the broad gauge lines in SA’s Mid North are not viable. Studies by Rail 2000 however, suggest they are viable if not shackled to poor work practices. The Burra track is in a very bad condition and has been neglected, but is nevertheless adequate for the present rail traffic. [Bulk grain haulage.]

Those bidding for the SA lines appear to fall into two groups. One would aim to keep operating only the profitable main line grain services and the Leigh Creek coal traffic. The other would want to rehabilitate the system, including branch lines, with a long term regional commitment. Rail 2000 is concerned that the government will take the highest bidder without reference to long term implications for SA.

Issue 305, 16 April 1997, page 2

Australian Country Games. Part of these games is a graded combined driving event held by the Mid North Carriage Driving Club at Burra this coming weekend. It will involve presentation, dressage and a 23 km marathon on Sunday morning. [Considerably more detail is printed.]

Issue 305, 16 April 1997, page 3

The 13th Annual Burra Picnic Races were held at Thistlebeds. The crowd was smaller, but horse entries were still good. Goyder House and Burra Day Care did the catering very well. The track was fast and dusty, though Peter Reilly tried to keep it down with a water cart. The main event, the Kooringa Hotel Cup, was won by Show Landy.

The Tea Rose Duo will perform in Burra as part of the Burra Antique Fair & Cultural Weekend. The concert will aid the Burra Art Gallery. The duo play a wide range of music from Bach to Led Zeppelin, Scott Joplin to Schubert. They have appeared at venues across Australia, at the Edinburgh Fringe and in Penang and have supported Dudley Moore and Stephen Grapelli. They will perform in the Old Courthouse on 3 May at 8 p.m.

Tickets $15. [Advt. & article.]

Birth. To Jodi & John Lehmann of Mt Bryan, a daughter, Anna Grace.

Issue 305, 16 April 1997, page 4

Mid North Sheepdog Trials were held in Burra over the Easter weekend. There were 25 competitors with 60 dogs. Organisers were pleased to attract eight entries for the Farmers’ Trial. Winners:

Open Trial Michael Nuske of Cleve with Barunga Jinx.

Improvers Trial Joanne Flavel of Narrung with Adrina Toby.

Novice Trial Geoff McDougall of Collinsville with McDougall’s Abbey.

Farmers’ Trial Damian Ryan with Jake.

Issue 305, 16 April 1997, page 5

Allyson Parsons of Redcliffe Station recently won the 1997 Victor Harbor Rotary Art Show’s open section prize worth $7,500. She also won the Barossa Art Show’s Acquisition Prize worth $5,000. [Photo.]

Issue 305, 16 April 1997, pages 6 & 7

Goyder Council Elections – Burra Ward Profiles

Colleen Woodgate

Booborowie Councillor for 10 years

Believe there is a need to maintain a certain continuity and big picture focus with the new council

Over the years have been involved with many community, sporting and school organisations, library, Council committees, health service boards, etc.

I believe I am an effective and committed Councillor with experience and much still to contribute to the new Council

Graham Kellock

Chairman of Burra Burra DC for the last seven years

I believe it is important I stand again and see through the task of amalgamation and ensure the old Burra Burra Council is well catered for in the new and larger Regional Council of Goyder

Have been involved in many organisations and committees over the years

Am pleased to see the sealing of the Burra-Morgan Road, for which I lobbied for many years

We are now endeavouring to get Kooringa Road from Fords Corner sealed.

Kevin William Wallis

Moved to Burra with wife Barbara and three sons during 1985-86 to mine the Mongolata Gold Field

Burra Councillor 1993-97

Chairman of the Burra cemetery Committee 1993-97 and the Mine Museum Committee 1991-94, when it was disbanded

Objectives would be to set the Council with firm guidelines re tourism and general work practices, such as to oversee the greening of the golf course, improve tariffs at Paxton Square Cottages and the contracting out of grader work

Trevor John Underwood

From Booborowie and married to Rhonda and have 1 son and 3 grandchildren

Lived at Booborowie for 15 years, prior to which was in the RAAF for 9 years

Have been involved in various committees and managed the refuse depots at Booborowie, Mt Bryan and Hallett

Believe it is necessary that the smaller towns get representation by a person prepared to voice their opinions and needs as well as representing the community as a whole

James Quinn

Am a current Councillor

A lifetime resident of Mt Bryan and married to Rosemary, with 8 children all gainfully employed or studying

Worked zealously for the Burra Burra DC 1983-87 and 1989-97

Offer a wide range of experience with Council procedure, policies, roles and responsibilities, at local state and national levels, having represented Burra at the National Local Government Assembly in Canberra in 1995.

Currently an executive member of Mid North Region of Local Government (since 1994)

Was Deputy Chairman of Burra Burra DC and Chairman of the Finance Committee and a member of the Finance Committee in the Regional Council of Goyder and a member of a number of other committees

Adrian Gill

Have resided in Burra for 20 years

Operated an electrical contracting business there for 18 years

Member of the Burra Burra DC for the last two years

Active in the reconstruction of the Tourist Office and Council owned tourist attractions

Involved in the amalgamation to form the Regional Council of Goyder

Russell Skinner

Chairman of Main Street and a Member of the Mid North Regional Development Board

Committed to attracting new industry and securing physical improvements to the town and to the supporting of new events and projects to the benefit of the community

Aim to be aware of and sympathetic towards the needs and aspirations of all the communities in Goyder and will give the job all I have

[Profiles for candidates for the other council wards are also printed.]

Issue 305, 16 April 1997, page 8

Letter. A long letter from Freda Pink urges people to vote at the council elections and because this was the first time all voting was postal, she included a detailed set of instructions on how to vote.

A Survey of People in Burra gave a list of things they believed important for the new Regional Council to address for Burra. They included:

A boost for tourism

Handing tourism to the National Trust to run was a good move

Market Street needs rebuilding

The entry to the town from the north is not well signed

Removal of heritage restrictions

Don’t change Market Square

Lower rates

Attract more/new businesses

Bituminise the bypass

Keep prices low in Paxton Square

Maintain the MFS in Burra

Seal the Kooringa Road

Tim Stockman of Stockman Electronics provided a group sponsored by the Burra Traders’ Association with an insight into how computers could help everyone in their homes and businesses and gave them a Cook’s tour of the Internet and demonstrated computer peripherals like printers, scanners and digital cameras.

Issue 305, 16 April 1997, page 11

Marriage. Wellington Point, Queensland, 26 April

Jeff Hirschausen will marry Bronwyn Terrell.

Issue 306, 23 April 1997, page 1

Jailbreakers Bachelor & Spinsters Ball was held on Saturday night at Redruth Gaol. It had more than 500 patrons with music supplied by the band Chunky Custard. Sunday’s recovery event was held at Burra Creek Gorge, where The Journeymen provided the music. People came from across SA and interstate.

The Mid North Carriage driving Club event provided plenty of excitement for drivers and spectators last weekend. At 9 a.m. the formal Presentation at Halt and Concourse de Elegance was held in Taylor Street. Local organisers Geraldine Smedley and Donna Kelly were disappointed with the number of entries, but those who entered praised the course layout for Sunday’s marathon. Next year the Mid North Carriage Driving Club is hosting the State Championship combined driving event at Clare. [Photo.]

Issue 306, 23 April 1997, page 2

A Blue Light Mini Jailbreakers was held on Friday 18 April and 70 local youths enjoyed the atmosphere.

Issue 306, 23 April 1997, pages 2 & 6

Letter. Joe Kazimour of Joe’s Super Snacks, Prices Bakery and Golden Fried Chicken writes a very long letter, taking exception to the decision-making process re his illuminated sign that was recently disallowed for his business in Market Square. Some of his points:

When he invested in the Golden Fried chicken franchise the deal included an internally illuminated two-sided sign designed to be set at 90o to the building and high enough for all to see.

When he applied for permission to erect the sign the initial reactions from John Brak and Douglas Alexander (Heritage Adviser) were so negative that he immediately regretted having placed the order for the franchise.

Although the sign carried a trademark registered all over Australia, the Council wanted a change of colour and design.

He agreed to mount the sign flat against the parapet.

He then found that a single-sided sign cost as much as a two-sided one ($500) so he opted for the latter and applied for permission to mount it at 90o to the parapet – and was refused.

Mr Alexander objected because:

This was contrary to what he was originally advised.

The site was highly visible in Market Square, the focus of the State Heritage Area, which would be adversely affected.

The corporate design and colouring are not sympathetic to the individual historic character of the square.

The sign would lead to the proliferation of similar inappropriate signage.

If Council did not adopt Mr Alexander’s recommendation it would be necessary to obtain the concurrence of the Development Assessment Commission.

Mr Kazimour then comments on the already installed illuminated signs – some at 90o to the buildings on the Service Stations, BankSA, Hotels and Lotteries Commission – BUT let’s not disturb ‘Big Businesses’.

Council voted to allow the sign 6 votes to 2.

Mr Kazimour then writes at length on the negative decision of the Development Assessment Commission and the biased way it rushed into its decision, railing against the role of the Heritage Adviser and the consequent negative impact on the town’s economic progress as the result of such heritage nonsense that is supported by ‘Douglas Alexander and his Heritage Stooges’.

Issue 306, 23 April 1997, page 10

Burra Art Gallery. The next exhibition will be by the Burra Quilters’ Group.

12 Burra Bootscooters joined two busloads of others for a fun weekend in Wentworth and Mildura on 12-13 April.

Chris McCabe, the first principal of BCS and his wife Denise will be moving to Melbourne where Chris has accepted the position as Principal of Xavier College in Kew – a large educational facility with three campuses and 1,600 boys from Years 5-12.

Marriage. Adelaide last Saturday

Justin Fidock, son of Colin & Dany Fidock, married Jenny Finch.

Obituary. Merv. Humphrys, a former Burra resident died recently.

[Mervyn Roy Humphrys, born 29 August 1918 at Kooringa.]

Issue 307, 30 April 1997, pages 1 & 5

SA Tourism is enjoying high bed occupancy rates, but local responses are mixed. Country SA recorded a 3% increase in the last quarter. Barry Wright of Tiver’s Row Cottages said they had 47.2% occupancy in December 1966 quarter, up 5% on 1995, but summer occupancies are the downfall. Paxton Square income for 1996-97 is expected to fall by 20% from the previous year.

Issue 307, 30 April 1997, page 2

Letter. Dawn Broderick writes a letter vaguely in support of Joe Kazimour, but largely comprising a meandering set of reminiscences of the good old days of her youth.

While clearly against heritage restrictions, most of the letter rails against changes that are merely the result of the passage of time.

Issue 307, 30 April 1997, page 3

Letter. Bob Skinner writes applauding Joe Kazimour’s attempt to increase his business and so benefit the town, but he goes on to question some of Joe’s outrage:

It would seem that Mr Kazimour could still display his sign flat against the parapet, as he said he agreed to. (Any safety issues could surely be overcome.)

As for existing garish signs, they are not in keeping with heritage values and he hopes they will go in time.

Advertising can be eye-catching and effective without being offensive. He feels Mr Kazimour does the Council CEO and planning officers an injustice – they can only advise the Councillors as to the legal requirements and recommended planning procedure.

Letter. Shaun Dollman also writes in support of Joe Kazimour:

‘standing up for the little people of this town.’

‘Is the same thing going to happen with the Main Street/Best Place Plan concept program. We want our opinions to be heard, not just pushed under the rug.’

Letter. P.L. & D.J. Strawbridge also write in support of Joe Kazimour, following rejection of their signage proposal as well: because it was ‘overly ornate…free standing, and signage was excessive.’

Issue 307, 30 April 1997, page 4

Advt. Burra Station Gallery. Grand Opening, Friday 2 May at 9 a.m.

Art & Craft Railway Display. Open Weekends 9.00 a.m. to 4.30 p.m.

Issue 307, 30 April 1997, page 5

Birth. To Trevor & Ann Wiseman of Burra on Friday 25 April, a son, James William. [Photo.]

Issue 308, 7 May 1997, page 1

Regional Council of Goyder

The new council reduced its elected from 29 on amalgamation to 13 at the council election. Valid votes were cast by 2330 of the 3,652 persons eligible: a 63.8% response. A further 90 invalid votes were received with the declaration flap removed or incorrectly completed. 44 envelopes also came in too late to be counted. This may have affected the outcome in Eudunda Ward, where there was a tie after the distribution of preferences, between R. Leditschke and J. Wibberley. Returning officer Stephen Kerrigan then had to draw a name ‘out of the hat’ to decide the candidate to be excluded. Mr Wibberley’s name was drawn out.

Issue 308, 7 May 1997, page 2

Burra Probus members enjoyed a guided walking tour of Mintaro on 14 April. They started with lunch at the Magpie & Stump, which opened in December 1850, albeit illegally, as the licence did not arrive until January 1851.

Delia Kraft has opened the Railway Station Gallery.

Burra Women’s Bowls recently elected President, Val Spackman; Vice Presidents, Joyce Lloyd & Joan Durdin; Secretary, Hazel Stockman and Treasurer, Di Day.

The Annual Mt Bryan Dinner Dance was attended by 115 people.

Birth. To Ian & Natalie [Alderson nee Gill] on 24 February, a daughter, Tyla.

Birth. To Peter & Heather [Watkins nee Alderson] on 21 March, a son, Sam.

Two grandchildren for Margaret & Ray Alderson.

Obituary. Margaret Quinn of Mt Bryan died recently.

[Born Margaret Mannion 25 July 1906 at Hawker. Married John Lawrence Quinn in 1933.]

Issue 308, 7 May 1997, page 3

Letter. Yvonne Tanti writes to commend the Burra Art Gallery for the quality of their exhibitions.

Letter. Gilda Anderson writes seeking any information on Burra examples of weighbridges, iron lacework or other items made by the Hawkes Foundry in Kapunda.

Issue 308, 7 May 1997, page 4

The ‘Tea Rose Duo’ Concert was a sell-out on Saturday and generated a nice profit for the gallery.

The 6th Annual Burra Antique Fair had record crowds browsing through the Town Hall. They were also entertained by the musical duo ‘Tamarisque’ and frequent appearances of the Jamestown Barbershop Quartet. The National Trust fire engine provided rides.

Issue 308, 7 May 1997, page 5

The Burra Art Gallery’s exhibition of quilts by the Burra Quilter’s Group is a striking display. The group comprises about 25 ladies who meet regularly and was founded about ten years ago.

Issue 308, 7 May 1997, page 7

Birth. To Michelle & Steve Berryman on 22 April, a daughter, Amy Lee.

Issue 308, 7 May 1997, page 8

Burra Station has been closed since the late 1980s, but is now open as Delia Kraft’s ‘Burra Station Gallery’.

On the walls are recorded a number of stories:

‘Noel Miller, Bill Kotz & Tom Prance have worked here.’

‘J.D. Jones, the last resident on at the Burra commenced at Burra 9th May 1981. Completed last shift at Burra 5th August 1988, on VRIS…Amen.’

‘L.J. Robinson, start 28th April 1969.’

G. Hirschausen started April 29th 1968.’ Gary was a porter.

Others who worked there were Dave Robinson, Morris & Wayne Broad were porters. Mr Green and Cynthia Burnette’s father were stationmasters.

BCS students competed at the recent interschool athletic championships at Kensington in the F Grade. A number of BCS students gained 1st places:

Tina Williams, U16 girls’ triple jump, 100 m and 200 m.

Samantha Kelly, open girls’ long jump.

Kim Lindblom, U15 girls’ triple jump.

Karen Phillips, U15 girls’ 800 m.

Boh Wall, U15 boys, discus and 1,500 m.

Ben Dolphin, U16 boys’ javelin.

Adam Willis, U15 boys’ long jump and triple jump.

Jason Schuppan, open boys’ 400 m.

Luke Spackman, U15 boys’ 400 m.

Simon Breeding open boys’ 1,500 m walk.
