Trent Nicholls of Black Springs married Tracy Reimann.

Obituary. Shirley Woodman died recently.

[Born Shirley Dawn Moore, 11 January 1932. Married Brian James Woodman in 1951. Died 28 November 1997 and buried at Burra 2 December 1997.]

Issue 339, 10 December 1997, page 3

McPhee’s Butcher Shop

Gary & Joanne McPhee have been operating their shop in Burra for ten years and in that time have trained four apprentices and now have a staff of nine between their Burra and Clare meat stores. Russell Skinner, Chairman of the Main Street Committee presented Gary with a Burra Achievers Award in recognition of their value to the community.

Issue 339, 10 December 1997, page 4

Red Cross Service Awards were presented recently to Joan McBride (40 years), Lillian Opperman & Estelle Nicholls (20 years), Aileen Kelly & Irene Hirschausen (50 years), Muriel Bence (40 years) and Barbara Devenport (20 years).

Burra Regional Art Gallery has three exhibitions open this week:

A textile touring show

A continuing regional artists’ exhibition

The permanent S.T. Gill paintings display.

Issue 339, 10 December 1997, page 6

KESAB Tidy Towns Awards

Special mention to Shirley Broad of Burra.

Meritorious Effort Plaque to Burra Senior Citizens in their 17th year of involvement.

Issue 341, 17 December 1997, page 1 [Note: there was no Issue 340.]

Special A3 sized edition instead of usual A4.

Malowen Lowarth has been found to house a rare quilt. Jenny Manning, who is researching for her book The Australian Quilters Directory visited Burra on 11 December, especially to view the quilt. Embroidered on it is the inscription ‘AN to SN 1829’. Jenny examined it carefully and believes it probably originated in England and is done in a naïve primitive style. She also believes it to be among the five oldest quilts in Australia. It came to Burra from National Trust Headquarters in Ayers House, Adelaide about ten years ago.

Aged Care.

Burra may receive up to four more lower-care aged places out of 24 allocated within the Wakefield Region. If approved this may see some redevelopment at Burra Hospital to meet Commonwealth standards and providing a home-like environment for nursing home and hostel type residents. This in turn means that acute services would be separated from the aged care component of the hospital. No change to acute care is currently being discussed.

Goyder Council has received applications for three Telstra mobile phone towers:

A 20 m tower on John Tilley’s land northwest of Hallett.

A 35 m tower on Brewery Hill at Burra.

A 35 m tower on Maurice Nitschke’s land at Eudunda at the junction of Marrabel and Kapunda Roads.

Provision has been made in the design for other users to share the structures.

Issue 341, 17 December 1997, page 2

‘Welcome Inn’ organisers had a ‘Just for You’ event in the form of a Strawberry Fair at the Uniting Church recently. It was meant simply to be a happy time, but since they did more than cover costs, they have decided to give the surplus to the Burra Hospital.

Policing in Burra.

Some Burra residents have been concerned about how the district has been policed recently and on Monday night this concern surfaced on the Channel 7 news. Matt Reilly was one of those who spoke to the press, but says there were a number of inaccuracies in the item that just made them sound like a bunch of whingers. As a result there will be a public meeting on the issues raised. Tonight those who feel they would rather a spokesperson took their concerns to the public meeting will meet together at the Civic Centre. The public meeting will be held in the Burra Town Hall at 8 p.m. on 18 December. Guests will be the Chief Inspector Jim Langmead, Officer in charge of North East Division and Senior Sergeant Dean Harris of Peterborough Police.

Issue 341, 17 December 1997, page 3

Burra Hospital. It is hoped that a joint Director of Nursing for Burra and Clare Hospitals can be appointed in the near future. Lesley Phillips commenced this month acting in a duel campus role, with her temporary position ending on 19 January 1998. Management is waiting for a report from the Australian Nursing Federation on the viability and feasibility of the idea to be tabled with the SA Health Commission and to give them direction in the matter.

Fire. A broken insulator on a power line started a fire next to Wildildie homestead last Saturday afternoon. It was contained quickly by Burra & Baldina CFS units.

Birth. To Many & Ian Dolphin of Booborowie at Burra Hospital on 9 December, a son, Jake Connor.

Issue 341, 17 December 1997, page 4

Terowie Institute was built in 1879 and has been undergoing restoration. In 1995-96 and 1996-97 financial years $25,000 was spent on replacing the roof, re-wiring and repairing and repainting the interior. The cost was split between Council and the local community. The present financial year has seen work focused on the exterior walls and plaster work. This required $1,110 to be raised locally, plus $1,250 from Goyder Council and a loan from Council of $1,250.

Issue 341, 17 December 1997, page 5

Advertisement & Advertorial for Fraser’s Mid North Motor Co. in Clare with an emphasis on Rob Gill and Rob Gill Jnr of Burra who work there, but with strong connections to Burra, where they live and who can provide a great service to the town including picking up and delivering vehicles and providing a loan car while vehicles are being serviced. [Photo.]

Issue 341, 17 December 1997, page 6

BCS held its speech night on Thursday. The Principal Kevin Fahey, in his report said that teaching children was a joint effort of parents and school and family factors outweighed school factors in determining educational success. This year the installation of the irrigation system was a major improvement.

[The school awards are listed.]

Issue 341, 17 December 1997, pages 8 & 9

Review of the Year 1997

Christmas Pageant 1996

More than 300 people watched the procession of 24 floats. The Burra Hospital float was judged the best.

Australia Day

Burra Traders’ Association provided breakfast in Market Square.

Citizen of the Year was Rosemary Opperman.

Junior Citizen of the Year was Darren Boulger.

Event of the Year was the 150th anniversary of Policing in Burra.

The ANZ Bank

After 137 years, having started in Burra as the Bank of Australasia, the ANZ Bank closed, blaming falling customer demand. Limited services will continue from an agency.

Swimming

Vacation Swimming Program

10 swimmers were involved in Senior Lifesaving levels.

17 were involved in the Lower Lifesaving awards.

There were 25 middle level swimmers.

59 were beginners.

Jennison was the winning house at the BCS Swimming Carnival in February.

Goyder Council

The new Regional Council of Goyder was launched on 3 February.

Denis Keller of Robertstown was elected its first Chairman.

Graham Kellock, formerly Chairman of the Burra Burra DC was chosen as Deputy Chairman.

Peter Boaden of Hallett became Director of Human Resources.

David Jennings of Eudunda became Director of Corporate Services.

In May there was the first election for the new Council – conducted entirely by postal ballot.

The number of Councillors was reduced from 29 to 13.

There was a 63.8% response to the ballot.

Hallett and Robertstown each elected 2 Councillors, while Eudunda had 4 and Burra 5.

Community Committees are being formed in the major towns of Goyder to assist the Council in running towns.

Burra Hospital

This year the hospital was recognised as an accredited hospital on 8 May, following a survey by the Australian Council on Health Care Standards. More than 100 people attended a Hospital Gala Day to celebrate its 120th anniversary.

Main Street Committee

Richard Holbrook retired as Chairman, to be replaced by Russell Skinner. Helen Stockman continued as co-ordinator.

Tourism

Richard Holbrook and Jenny Field won awards at the Mid North Tourism Awards Night at Clare for the Antique Clock Workshop and Tearooms and for Griffiths’ Cottage B & B.

Bon Accord Cottage received a commendation at the Tourism Awards Night.

The Council owned and operated tourist sites in Burra were leased to the Burra Branch of the National Trust – i.e. the Tourist Information Office, Mine Area, Smelts Site, Hampton and the Unicorn Brewery Cellars.

Classic Country Tourism Board released a 64-page Visitor Guide.

The National Trust appointed Alan Botting as consultant-manager of the Tourist Office.

Greyhound-Pioneer initiated a new Burra Day Tour and the Burra Visitor Office became a booking agent for Greyhound.

Visitor number grew substantially for the year.

Burra-Morgan Road

The section from Burra North to Ford’s Corner was sealed by April.

The next section to the Robertstown turn-off was sealed in June and the road re-opened to traffic.

The final section from Robertstown turn-off to ‘The Gums’ was then sealed by December.

Cricket

Boh Wall (14) notched up his first A Grade century in the 2nd semi-final.

In the Grand Final against Mannanarie Boh scored 71 n.o. and Matt Opperman 62 n.o. in Burra’s win.

Football

BBH Seniors Colts lost the grand final by 4 points.

BBH Junior Colts’ Captain Ric Giles won the 1997 Best & Fairest in the North Eastern Football League.

BBH Senior Colts’ Jason Schuppan was runner-up for Best & Fairest in the North Eastern Football League.

Tennis

Burra Kooringa won the A Grade final.

Redruth was victorious in the A2 Grade final.

Booborowie won the B Grade premiership.

In the Junior’s final Wandillah defeated Kookaburras.

Netball

The grand finals were held at Mintaro. Thanks are due to netball reporters who provided such excellent reports throughout the season.

Field Days

55 leading studs took part in 1997 SA Stud Merino Field Days held in March.

Visitors from Germany and USA were among visitors crowding Burra Oval for the Gala Night.

Sheepdog Trials

The Mid North Sheepdog Trials were held at Burra over Easter.

25 competitors brought 60 dogs.

Conferences/Meetings

The Isolated Children’s Parents’ Association held its State Conference on 5 April.

The Mid North Carriage Drivers’ Combined Driving Event was held in April.

The Arts

A rare exhibition early in the year saw works by famous Australian artists including, Arthur Boyd, Russell Drysdale, Arthur Streeton and local painter Allyson Parsons.

The 6th Annual Antique Fair drew excellent crowds in May.

Allyson Parsons won the 1997 Victor Harbor Rotary Art Show’s open section prize worth $7,500.

Burra Quilters held its biennial exhibition in the Burra Art Gallery in May.

The Burra Railway Station – disused for some years – opened briefly as Delia Kraft’s Burra Railway Station Gallery.

The Jailbreakers Ball

This Bachelors & Spinsters’ Ball attracted more than 500 patrons to the Redruth Gaol.

Sunday’s ‘recovery’ was again held at Burra creek Gorge.

Burra CWA

The CWA had a good year. Donations were made to help Flood Relief, Dorothy Dolling Memorial Trust, The Lymphoedema Clinic at Flinders University and $2,000 was set aside for the Burra Baby Change Room.

Credit Union

Burra has held meeting to foster the idea of a local Credit Union following the closure of banks across country SA. Public meetings were held in August at Burra and Eudunda and appointed a working party to report on the feasibility of establishing a local Credit Union. The working party is currently trying all avenues to obtain a locally owned service to ensure a broader service into the future.

BCS

The 120th anniversary of the laying of the foundation stone on 27 February 1887 [sic: for 1877] was celebrated.

Steele House won the BCS Sports Day.

Luke Spackman was ‘athlete of the day’ in the Australian Country Games, winning in the triple jump, 100 m and 200 m.

Tina Williams won gold at the Australian Country Games in the 100m and 200 m.

The northern car park at BCS was sealed in April.

A revegetation grant from Primary Industries SA was won to enable the revegetation of part of Brewery Hill and to compare the effect of saltbush on the productivity and health of animals.

Variety Club Bash

This event came through Burra on 14 September and the BCS fundraising committee arranged a sumptuous lunch for the 315 guests.

Emergency Services. Burra CFS, SES and Ambulance services have all been active and effective throughout the year.

Shows

BCS gained a Reserve Champion Trade Steer at the Royal Adelaide Show. 166 steers were entered.

Eudunda’s 100th Show was held.

Mr Graham Gunn MP opened the Burra Show this year.

At the Burra Show gate takings were up $450 on the previous year.

Sheep Sales

The 1997 SA Stud Merino Ram Sales were a ‘tough sell’, but nevertheless there were some good prices:

One Collinsville ram sold for $68,000, another for $30,000 and another two went for $20,000 each.

Redbanks Reserve

This continues to be redeveloped as a recreational and nature reserve, aided by a grant of $15,000 from the State Government Planning & Development Fund.

Peacock’s Chimney

State Governor Sir Eric Neal & Lady Neal attended the unveiling of a plaque marking the 25th anniversary of the re-siting of the chimney. Local citizens, members of the National Trust and the Main Street Committee gathered at the redeveloped site for a champagne breakfast.

Part of ‘Outback’

The Burra antique Fair Committee spent five days at Hawker, where they organised the Hawker Antique Fair. This was part of the Visual Arts Program in Hawker that was in turn one of the events during ‘Opera in the Outback’.

Local Industry/Businesses

Burra Community Print successful printed 7,500 copies of River Murray Charts for local publisher Maureen Wright.

Richard Holbrook has continued his work with some of SA’s most famous timepieces, including that in Adelaide Town Hall. He and Jenny have been most successful in establishing their Clock Shop and Tearooms and Griffiths’ Cottage B & B.

Mongolata Gold has been added to Commercial Street.

Henry Cullen retired in June from the Eastern Mail Run after covering over a million miles since his father took over the service in 1949.

Refire Resources have identified four exploration sites near Burra to be investigated in the future.

Golf Greens

The Goyder Council has approved $170,000 towards greening the tees, fairways and greens at the Burra Golf Club, subject to a grant of $150,000 applied for from the Department of Sports and Recreation.

Telephone Tower

BCS Principal Kevin Fahey has confirmed an agreement between the school and Telstra for the lease of land for the erection of a mobile phone tower overlooking Burra on Brewery Hill. It will give a coverage for a 35 km radius.

Tour Guides

Thirteen people have completed a course to become Accredited Tour Guides to bring the total to 17. The free local passport key for residents will be retained.

Issue 341, 17 December 1997, page 10

Mt Bryan School Concert was presented with great enthusiasm. Mr Kevin Fahey, the BCS Principal was guest speaker. After the concert the annual awards were presented.

Issue 341, 17 December 1997, page 13

Advt. Burra Traders’ Association – Christmas Festivities in Market Square from 5.30 p.m. 24 December.

Barbecue Tea

Combined Choir

Clare Concert Band

Free Raffle

On Stage Performances

Father Christmas

Displays

Line Dancing

Christmas Pageant at 6 p.m.

Follow the Reindeer

School Band at 6.45 p.m.

Free Horse & Carriage Rides.

Issue 342, 24 December 1997, pages 1 & 4

Public Meeting re Over-policing

More than 300 people attended the meeting called as a result of pressure on senior police to address allegations of over-policing. Council CEO Steve Kerrigan acted as an independent convenor and said has view was that what was needed was an atmosphere of two-way commitment between the police and community. Police were represented by Superintendent Dave Eason from Adelaide, Divisional Commander Jim Langmead from Pt Pirie and senior Sergeant Dean Harris from Peterborough.

Jim Langmead said police resources had been directed towards reducing the road toll through random breath tests and speed detection and they could make no apologies for that.

Local farmer Graham Kellock said constant radar guns and breatho’s in front of businesses were discouraging people from coming into town.

Matthew Reilly spoke of being inundated with complaints about police officers.

Rosemary Seaford said that as a representative of senior women, she described policing now as rude, arrogant, intimidating, threatening and demeaning. She wanted a return to firmness and respect and called for respectful and confidential policing – to which she received a standing ovation.

Charlie Bourne, wishing to represent the younger generation, said he had no issue with the law, but urged officers to act with dignity and honour.

James Hawker spoke in support of Officer Russell Disher who is currently on stress leave.

Jack McMahon said you couldn’t umpire without a whistle and acting now could avert a problem down the track.

Chief Inspector Eason said everyone’s personalities were different and if they had genuine concerns they were there to see if they could fix it.

Gary Illicevs, a resident with 17 years police experience, said the police needed to have the confidence of the town – ‘we are not complaining about the law’.

Rosemary Seaford moved a motion prepared by a meeting of about 60 locals held the previous night:

‘That the residents of Burra and the surrounding districts object to the aggressive policing of officers Cousins and Kaiser, and the adverse affect [sic] this has on our community. It creates a definite sense of loss for the community: that the SA Police Department note that this is a vote of no confidence in the two officers and that action be taken to replace them with officers respected, knowledgeable and experienced in community policing.’

This motion was amended to say that the Burra community wait until the police investigation is made until the issue of no confidence is further considered.

The amendment was carried 125 to 110.

Six people were then elected from the meeting to consider the issues raised with senior police and then report back to the community as soon as possible.

Issue 342, 24 December 1997, page 2

Letter. Elic Gillett from Hampshire writes as a third time visitor and with due respect to comment on the public meeting re policing – which he understands to be largely in relation to spot fines on drivers who had exceeded the legally permitted amount of alcohol in their blood. Firstly he is surprised that a fine is considered appropriate, because in most European countries the penalty would be loss of licence for three to twelve months. Secondly he is surprised that a small number of people think it worthwhile to arrange a public meeting to criticise the police for carrying out the job they are paid for.

Letter. Bob Skinner writes to praise Steve Kerrigan for the manner in which he handled the difficult meeting on policing in Burra.

Burra National Trust members started their Christmas party for this year with drinks at the Powder Magazine, which turned 150 years old in November. They then moved on to Morphett’s Enginehouse for a pooled meal.

Marriage. 3 January 1998

Nick Lamont, son of David & Rhonda Lamont will marry Taryn McPherson.

Many will remember David as a former Rector of St Mary’s in Burra.

Marriage. St Mary Magdalene’s Church, Adelaide, 17 January 1998

Anne Field, daughter of Beth & the late Bill Field, will marry Dr Mark Brown. They will live in the UK.

Issue 342, 24 December 1997, page 3

Goyder Council

Decided to demolish the original toilet block at the Burra Town Hall, where the cutting in the hill on three sides of the hall will be battened, stabilised with bitumen and a safety fence installed along the new edge. Earth Levels adjacent to the hall are to be excavated to below damp course level and a report on the roof iron made prior to obtaining a costing for any needed re-roofing.

[This work, other than the demolition of the toilets, would appear not to have been carried out despite this resolution.]

The final draft and comments on Market Square and Best Place Concept Plan and the Works Practices Policy are to be forwarded to the Works Committee prior to being presented to Council for adoption.

Council decided to allow the relocation to Burra Art Gallery of the Mayoral paintings and photographs depending on the Main Street Committee’s decision on Management of the Town Hall.

Burra Paint ʼn’ Panel owners A.D. & K.A. Eldredge have been granted permission to erect a paint spray booth, subject to conditions laid down by the Environmental Protection Authority.

SA Ambulance Centre has been given permission to extend the Burra Ambulance Centre.

Council deferred a decision on granting $10,000 to the Burra National Trust for Burra Promotions pending further information.

Issue 342, 24 December 1997, page 10

Vacswim ʼ98 will be held 5-15 January 1998.

District children can take part at the Burra, Booborowie and Hallett Pools.

Issue 343, 21 January 1998, page 1

Christmas in Burra. Festivities in Market Square had the place abuzz with excitement. The pageant was well supported and the Clare Concert Band was present, along with the school band and the Magic Cave. Several hundred people enjoyed a barbecue put on by the Burra Traders’ Association. [Photo.]

The Eudunda Branch of the National Australia Bank will close at the end of January.

Issue 343, 21 January 1998, page 2

Notice. Ronald John Lycett and Karen Dee Lycett, proprietors of the Royal Exchange Hotel, have applied for permission to have extended trading hours to 2 a.m. on Thursday, Friday, and Saturday and to midnight and on Christmas Day. [Check – this does not make sense.]

Vandalism. There have been several incidents of graffiti around the town and of a vehicle doing wheelies damaged the newly painted tennis court surface, the Leighton Cricket Club pitch and a fairway at the Burra Golf Course. Three juveniles have been reported for the graffiti and one of them for the property damage.

Letter. Grace Delaney writes, calling for the townsfolk to band together to attract new businesses to Burra, provide employment and lift town morale.

Mt Bryan Red Cross members have arranged for their Annual Progressive Dinner to be held 7 February.

$12.50.

Vacswim involved more than 110 students this year. The Booborowie Pool had more than 30 and Hallett 12.

[Higher award winners are listed.]

Burra Policing. There has been no word back from the Police department yet in response to the public meeting on policing in Burra. The committee formed at the meeting has met twice with department personnel.

Issue 343, 21 January 1998, page 3

The Season. The 1997-98 harvest turned out to be surprisingly good, considering the weather was terrible up to August.

Locusts have been plentiful on Christmas Day and immediately after. Now there has been another hatching.

The ‘Midnight Oil House’ [Cobb & Co.’s Corner] features in Ken Duncan’s new book The Great South Land and also in the January edition of Australian Women’s Weekly.

Garry Disher [formerly of Booborowie] has a new book out: Straight, Bent and Barbara Vine.

Jessica Sullivan (now a Channel 7 reporter) received second prize, as part of the Telstra Rural Media Awards, for a series of articles she wrote while working for The Stock Journal.

Bronwyn Drew, daughter of Ross & Dianne Drew and Georgia Arthur, both attending Annesley College, have done very well in Year 12.

Alison Slade of Princess Royal has secured a position as Landcare Development Officer at the Community Agricultural Centre in Corrigin, WA.

Justin Scholz, a recent graduate in Mechanical Engineering, has begun work with Bestec Pty Ltd, consulting engineers.

Issue 343, 21 January 1998, page 5

Locusts. The Christmas locusts have now bred another swarm – they are densest in the Booborowie Valley. Spraying is being undertaken. Local Councils are giving away chemicals to spray, on behalf of PISA.

Issue 343, 21 January 1998, page 11

Ron & Jean Winders are celebrating their Golden Wedding solemnised at Riverton Methodist Church 24 January 1948.

Obituary. An In Memoriam Notice gives 20 January 1997 as the date for the death of Rosemary Ann Heneker.

Issue 344, 28 January 1998, page 2

Accident. Last Wednesday a semi-trailer left the highway 19 km south of Burra and collided with a drain, causing $50,000 damage to the prime mover. The driver suffered minor injuries.

Accident. At Ford’s Corner last Friday at 9 p.m. a Holden Commodore struck a guard rail after skidding on loose gravel. There was no injury to the driver, but damage to the car of c. $10,000.

Accident. At 10 p.m. on Sunday a utility collided with some sheep on the Spalding Road near Booborowie. Five sheep were killed and, while the driver was uninjured, damage to the car was estimated at $5,000.

Vandals broke a light on the Rotunda, inflicting $80 damage and a speaker was broken in the Unicorn Brewery Cellars, with damage estimated at $400.

Letter. Colin Lloyd considers the meeting on policing ended in confusion. An overwhelming vote of no confidence in the police ended in a show of hands to defer such a description before consultation, etc. But, ‘It is impossible the present police can regain our respect.’

Letter. Avian Pink writes re proposed changes to the constitution of Burra traders’ Association, aimed at widening its parameters to include tourism.

Regardless of the tourism issue the constitution need updating.

If adopted the change would simply place tourism matters on the same level as business, commerce and industry and broaden the membership base.

Burra would have one strong association to liaise with the Council and the National Trust.

If the Traders’ Association stays unchanged then the growing interaction at local, state and national levels in business, commerce and tourism development will not be serviced adequately.

Issue 344, 28 January 1998, page 3

SES Burra has just received a new truck.

WEB Logic, an Internet consulting business established by Dick & Helen Cleland has established a web page for Burra: http://www.weblogic.com.au/burra/.

Issue 344, 28 January 1998, page 4

Meals on Wheels was cited for long service by Celine Stockman at the Australia Day Breakfast. The service in Burra started in 1971 and has served more than 81,700 meals. Three ladies have been part of it from the beginning – Anne Finch, Betty Thamm and Jan Tiver. They have been recognised for 25 years’ service. Judy Eberhard, Eunice Bake and Laurel Neill received a 20 year service award and Nancy Simpson & Mary Dunstall have given 15 years of service. [Photo.]

Issue 344, 28 January 1998, page 5

Burra’s Bed & Breakfast Establishments will hold an open house on Sunday 1 February. Pale green balloons will mark premises that are open for inspection 3-6 p.m. The motel will also be open for inspection.

Issue 345, 4 February 1998, page 1

Burra’s Little Athletes have dropped in numbers this year from 44 to 15 and the club is contemplating its future. They are to host part of the Australian Country Games on 5 April. Some members visited the new Athletics Stadium at Mile End on Saturday to see their heroes in action.

Issue 345, 4 February 1998, pages 1 & 4

Refire Resources has identified an increase in copper values 1.5 km north of the old Burra Mine, using the Mobile Metal Ion geochemical technique. The indications are that the Burra deposits extend some 15 km north under alluvium. [Further details of holes drilled are printed.]

Issue 345, 4 February 1998, page 2

Policing in Burra

The local committee appointed to report on progress says:

The complaints fell within the Resolution Process.

The investigation process is basically completed.

When finalised, the report will go to the Police Complaints authority, who will make the decision.

The management side of the report is likely to be handled by Inspector J. Langmead of Pt Pirie.

Local officers will undergo behaviour and leadership courses conducted by the Police Academy.

The local police station will undergo random behavioural management audits.

Ron & Jean Winders have celebrated their 50th wedding anniversary.

Birth. To Justin & Sharon Goodwin of the NAB, at Burra Hospital, a son, Bailey Jakob. [Photo, page 5.]

Birth. To Robyn & Stephen Venning Smith, a son, Thomas Charles. A first grandchild for Darryl and Pauline Venning.

Birth. To Kylie & Michael Day in Clare on 17 January, a son, Blake Adrian.

A grandchild for Di and Allen Day.

Marriage. Marrabel, 31 January.

Toby Cousins married Carmel Allchurch.

Philip Walsh, son of Connie Hallion, has been studying at PAC and did very well in Year 12, with 83/90 and was Dux of the Boarding School.

Letter. Pauline Walker writes, asking why police officers are not like other public servants – stood down or given leave or ‘moved sideways’ while being investigated.

BCS. Last year nine of ten Year 12 students achieved their SACE. One student received 3 As. All who applied for University or TAFE diploma courses received entry to their first choice.

Goyder Council

Better load limit signs will be made for the Kingston Street Bridge.

The National Trust will plant a woodlot on the site of the old Burra Dump in the Burra Mine site.

CEO Steve Kerrigan will seek to meet with the Minister of Transport re the case for sealing the arterial road to Robertstown.

CFS & MFS have been asked for their position regarding the future of the MFS in Burra.

Issue 345, 4 February 1998, page 4

The Season. SA’s harvest has been a record for the third consecutive year. Grain received topped 4,922,046 tonnes, compared with last season’s 4,921,236 tonnes. The season started out poorly, but ended very well. Grain from the South East is still being delivered and the final figure is expected to be c. 4.96 million tonnes.

BCS. New teachers for 1998:

Tammy Nottle – itinerant teacher

Maureen Hawke – Year 6

Andrew Cousins – Senior English & Social Science

Linda Baldwin – Senior English & History.

Burra Guides had a great year in 1997.

The highlight for Junior Guides was a Pack Holiday at Marineland, Adelaide. Seven of the eight juniors attended, with two leaders.

The Guides had two camps early in the year – one was in Adelaide and the second at McLaren Vale Girl Guide property of ‘Douglas Scrub’. [Other of the year’s activities are listed.]

Mt Bryan Red Cross Progressive Dinner, due to be held on Saturday 7 February, has been cancelled.

Issue 346, 11 February 1998, page 1

Jacki Cox has arrived as the new principal of the Mt Bryan School, with her daughter Rebecca (Year 2). Husband, Greg, is senior physical education teacher at Riverton High School.

SA Stud Merino Field Days will this year have a different format. They will start with a centralised display at Burra Oval with c. 27 studs from across the state on show on Monday 16 March. On Tuesday and Wednesday a further 28 studs will host on-property displays. On Monday there will be three fashion parades during the day and the judging of the Elders Merino Capital Ram Championship and Championship Pair will commence at 3.30 p.m., with the presentation at c. 5.30 p.m. Lunch on Tuesday will be available at Hallett Hall and on Wednesday from Collinsville, Mt Bryan and Kelvale, Farrell Flat.

Issue 346, 11 February 1998, page 2

Letter. Dr Tim Simpson writes urging the use of the ambulance for anyone with sudden onset unrelieved chest pains – rather than getting them to stand up and/or walk to a car.

Burra Traders’ Association is unable to alter its constitution because it did not get an 80% response to its request to go ahead with a meeting on the matter, as required by its constitution. Vice-President, Terry Wilson thought it a shame that the members were not even prepared to put the question to a vote yes or no. For those interested in forming a tourism association, it seems they will have to start from scratch. The National Trust is keen for such an independent body to be formed, because it would free the Trust to concentrate more fully on their key task of maintaining the sites they own in the town.

Issue 346, 11 February 1998, page 3

Local Government Voting

A draft report to the Government and the LGA has recommended that all local government elections be conducted by postal voting. This was encouraged by the success of postal voting for the councils that used it in 1997.

Burra-Morgan Road

The celebration of the completion of the sealing of Highway 64 is being organised for Sunday 29 March, with a bike ride from Burra Creek to ‘The Gums’ for the opening and lunch and then on to Morgan. Teams are being organised now and entry forms are at the Council Offices. Prize money is being offered in several categories.

St Mary’s, Burra will benefit from an Auction and Petticoat Lane with stalls and morning and afternoon tea on the church grounds on Saturday 14 March.

Issue 347, 18 February 1998, pages 1 & 4

Eudunda & Robertstown communities have organised a Rural Banking Seminar following bank closures.

Issue 347, 18 February 1998, page 2

Burra CFS has taken delivery of another truck – allocated and funded by the CFS Board. It is a two wheel drive Hino and carries 2,000 litres of water.

Letter. Vincent Burke writes re a tourism Association.

The attempt to achieve an expanded and unified organisation via the Burra Traders’ Association has failed, which is a great pity. Tourism is a vital part of the town’s economy and it is important to have an organisation that is separate from the National Trust. A public meeting is therefore called for Thursday 26 February to proceed with the establishment of a Burra Business & Tourism Association. We are keen to include the ‘Unique Accommodation’ group, hotels, motel, caravan park, antique shops and any business with a link with tourism or that provides a service to those directly involved.

Issue 347, 18 February 1998, page 3

Burra & District Eight Ball Association Grand Final was played at the Royal Exchange Hotel on Thursday night. Bon Accord 5 defeated Burra Hotel 4.

Issue 347, 18 February 1998, page 4

Marriage. Burra, recently

Narelle Hill married Matthew Ferguson.

Marriage. Burra, St Valentine’s Day

Tracey O’Brien married Chris Rains

Marriage. Burra last Saturday

Sharee O’Bryan married Bill Stockman.

Obituary. Mr Darcy Tiver of Flagstaff has died.

[Husband of Phyllis implied by context. Darcy Mack Tiver, born 11 November 1908 at Aberdeen.]

Rex & Flo Blieschke have celebrated their Golden Wedding.

National Trust of SA AGM. Shirley Thamm and Colin Fidock both received Honour Awards for long and notable voluntary service.

Burra Art Society – Glenys Christopher is the President for 1998.

Burra Kindergarten Annual Report

Parent support in 1997 was fantastic.

The Kindergarten received visits in 1997 from the police, fire brigade, hospital nurse and ambulance officers, each of whom talked about how they helped the community.

Visits were paid to the bakery and to Mt Bryan School (the latter in return to a visit to us).

The Kindergarten raised funds by catering for the Romeo Car Club.

A picnic by the creek was fun.

A visit from Bubby Brown, Aboriginal artist, was another memorable event.

Emma Miller is welcomed as a teacher.

Office bearers for 1998 are: President, Lisa Murphy; Vice-President, Cathryn Peppiatt; Secretary, Lee Cousins and Treasurer, Vanessa Hinge.

Issue 347, 18 February 1998, page 6

Birth. To Sue & Peter Cochrane of Burra on 31 January, a daughter, Danika. [Photo.]

Birth. To Miles & Allyson Cockington (nee Parsons) of Redcliffe Station, 7 February, a son, Henry Miles.

Shirley Thamm has been given an Honour Awards for her notable services to the Burra Branch of the National Trust. She has been a member for 27 years and has spent all that time on the branch committee, including three years as treasurer and on fundraising, the Bon Accord Cottage Committee and all three museum committees. She has represented the National Trust on various town committees. She has been curator of the branch’s archives for 13 years.

Advt. Burra Golf Club presents a Film Night at BCS Gym on Saturday 28 February at 8 p.m.

Robert Carlyle in The Full Monty.

Issue 347, 18 February 1998, page 11

Obituary. An In Memoriam notice give the birth and death dates for Bill Nankivell:

14 April 1923 to 19 February 1997. [Ronald William Nankivell, born at Kooringa.]

Issue 347, 18 February 1998, page 12

BCS. The 1998 Swimming Carnival was held last Wednesday. In the house competition Jennison won for the fourth year in succession. [Results are listed.]

Strangely the results for the SA Secondary Schools Interschool Program next Monday are also printed. [Presumable the Monday following the carnival.]

In competition with Clare, Balaklava and Riverton, Burra came third in Division 1, won the Improvers’ Shield and came second in the Handicap Shield.

Issue 348, 25 February 1998, page 1

Burra & Districts Obedience Dog Club has collected nearly 30 tonnes of newspapers and cardboard for recycling. Fourteen tonnes have been taken to the recyclers with a further fifteen tonnes at O’Connor’s Shed. Last week both Adelaide and Melbourne recycling depots announced they would accept no more newspapers and cardboard until an enormous backlog had been cleared. The club has therefore had to cancel their monthly kerbside collection. This will also affect Hallett, Booborowie and Mt Bryan. [Photo in O’Connor’s shed.]

Issue 348, 25 February 1998, page 2

Burra Op Shop has sent seven large bags of clothes to Adelaide to be forwarded to the Katherine flood victims, as well as a $500 cheque.

The Baby Change Room

The triangular room between the Tourist Office and the Lucky Dip has been completely gutted to remove old fixtures and a rotted floor. Plumbing and wiring have had to be routed through the Tourist Office. Burra’s Craig Berryman, new apprentice builder with Michael Gill, has been hard at work on the renovations. [Photo.]

[Note: the room was actually located on the other side of the Tourist Office, between the Office and Drew & Crewes’ Building.

Issue 348, 25 February 1998, page 3

Chris Parker of Burra is one of 33 rural leaders from across Australia to win a place in the Australian Rural Leadership Program. This two-year part-time program will develop skills, knowledge and networks for participants to become better leaders in rural Australia. The program is now in its 5th year. Course 5 begins in April 1998. The nine women and 24 men were chosen from a field of 170 applicants.

Burra Golf Club – Course Greening

Kym Traegar, superintendent of the Berri Golf Club, is assisting as a consultant. Preliminary design work has been completed and costings established. Council will loan $175,000 to the club, to be repaid over ten years and will grant $50,000 at $10,000 per year for five years. Private guarantors will be sought for the amount of $100,000. Final plans and a report will now be drawn up.

Issue 348, 25 February 1998, page 4

Tree Planters. A report outlines the work of the Petherton Road Tree Planters, who have been active since 1993-94 and they have received Commonwealth funding of $2,535 for 1997-98 to continue revegetation and preservation of natural vegetation in the vicinity of the ‘Old Petherton Estate’.

Issue 348, 25 February 1998, page 5

Eudunda CMC. An information night in preparation for the formation of a Eudunda CMC will be held in the Eudunda District Hall on 26 February.

The Lower North Farmsafe Group was established earlier this month. The aim of the ‘Farmsafe’ network is to co-ordinate farm health and safety programs in local communities and regions. There will be an interactive display at the 1998 Stud Merino Breeders Field Day at Burra on 16 March.

Issue 348, 25 February 1998, page 7

Advt. ETSA. A full-page advertisement from the Government of SA:

‘Why selling ETSA means a better future for SA.’

Issue 348, 25 February 1998, page 10

Ray & Joyce Lloyd celebrate their Golden Wedding, solemnised at Redruth Methodist Church on 6 March 1948.

Issue 349, 4 March 1998, page 1

Burra & Districts Tourism Association

At a well-attended meeting, it was decided to proceed with the establishment of the association. An executive committee was elected: President, Bob Howell (Burra Motor Inn); Vice-President, Kevin Wallis (Mongolata Gold); Secretary, Barbara Wallis (Mongolata Gold) and Treasurer Bryan Dunow (Somerset House B & B).

May & Frank Ironside of Burra North have won a trip for two to the UK as a part of an Advertiser promotion.

Booborowie Ladies’ Bowling Club won the 1997-98 Pennant Competition – their first such win in their 23 year history.

Burra Show Society. At the AGM last week no one came forward for the position of Secretary and a special public meeting is called for 10 March in the Show Hall to fill the position and to consider the society’s future should that not be done. Elected: President, Ian Slade; Vice-Presidents, Ric Williams and Ron Shipard. Patrons, Peter Stockman and Ron Shipard (continuing).

Issue 349, 4 March 1998, page 4

The State CWA donated $26,633.02 towards the cost of a new Perometer costing $31,000 to facilitate the diagnosis and assessment of lymphoedema. The machine has finally been delivered to Professor Neil Piller at Flinders Medical Centre.

The Governor, Sir Eric Neal will visit the district for the field days this year and will also visit the BCS on Monday 16 March, where he will be a guest at the SRC induction.

Issue 349, 4 March 1998, page 5

Rural Statistics

Sheep numbers in the region have fallen from 1.3 million in 1994 to c. 850,000 in 1997. The average tonnage for wheat and barley per hectare has increased since 1971 on the basis of ten year averages.

Figures for the Hundred of Kooringa

Burra Quilters recently took part in a project initiated by the Roxby Downs Scrapbag Quilters, in which 300 quilters contributed blocks. The RFDS benefited by $1,200 from one quilt when it was raffled and two more sold for $650 and $500 respectively. [Photo of a quilt made by the Burra Quilters.]

Issue 350, 11 March 1998, page 1

SA Governor, Sir Eric Neal will visit the first day of the 1998 SA Stud Merino Field Days. He is a patron of the SA Stud Merino Sheepbreeders’ Association and will attend the display at Burra Oval on 16 March.

The Jowett Car Club will visit Burra over the Easter Weekend. The Jowett is a British car manufactured between 1910 and 1954 in both sports and saloon format. This club claims to be the oldest car club representing a single make in the world. Twenty-five cars are expected to make the journey.

Issue 350, 11 March 1998, page 2

BCS sent a group of students to the SASSSA Grade One Swimming Carnival in Adelaide on 23 February, where they gained one second and two third place certificates.

Mt Bryan has a new emu crossing near the school.

Issue 350, 11 March 1998, page 4

Burra Art Gallery will have a special showing titled ‘Merino Country’ to coincide with the SA Stud Merino Field Days 16-18 March.

Telstra will provide an information evening next Thursday night in Burra to explain the latest technology available in our region. There will be information on the proposed mobile phone tower for Brewery Hill and examples of mobile phones and how they can be used. Burra Traders’ Association is hosting the night at the Old Courthouse at 7.30 p.m.

Burra Show Society

At the special meeting called to fill the position of Secretary, Lee Cousins stepped forward and offered her services and Len Newcombe offered to be Assistant Secretary. The Society’s executive is due to ratify the offers next week.

Grace Delaney of the Old Bakehouse, Burra North, won her first art prize with her painting ‘Forgotten’ at Kapunda recently.

The Savings Bank of SA – the predecessor of BankSA, opened for business on 11 March 1848 in Adelaide. The 150th birthday was celebrated in Burra on 11 March with a birthday cake and balloons.

Issue 352, 25 March 1998, page 1

First Aid. Approximately 15 tour guides and museum attendants are currently studying for their first aid certificates at Burra’s Ambulance Centre.

Telstra. Neil Gale, Operations Manager of Telstra Mobile Net in Adelaide, has confirmed that two mobile phone towers have been approved for erection in Hallett and Eudunda, with a tower for the Burra area to be approved next month. This network will improve service of mobile phones in the area, though there could still be dead spots in hilly terrain.

Burra Golf Club. Work on the western side of the Burra Golf Course is progressing with thousands of tonnes of soil already moved. A large holding dam is being built to hold water from a creek running through the course. It will be both a beautification feature and a source of water for irrigation. The whole of the western side of the course will be closed while re-development goes on and as soon as the 1998 season is over, work will begin on the eastern side.

Issue 352, 25 March 1998, page 2

The Twilight Jazz Affair will come to ‘Petherton House’, Hallett on Saturday 28 March. From 4 p.m. E-Type Jazz, the Eddy White All Stars and Gumbo Ya Ya will perform for the evening. The event is organised by the Sir Hubert Wilkins Memorial Trust to aid the program to restore his birthplace.

Issue 352, 25 March 1998, page 3

The Drinking Fountain. Shirley Thamm has uncovered some interesting facts concerning the fountain. The fountain was erected in 1888 as part of Queen Victoria’s Jubilee celebrations. It commemorates a trip of district children to Adelaide by train to visit the Jubilee Exhibition. 455 children were joined by 175 teachers and other adults, leaving Burra at 6 a.m. after assembling at 5.30 a.m. in Market Square. They picked up 43 more passengers at Farrell Flat. They returned the same day.

Mid North Bible Christian Church has arranged for Dr Colin & Mrs Mary Peckham to speak in Burra at the BCS staffroom on Tuesday 21 March at 7.45 p.m. and also at a special ladies’ night at 5 East St on 7 April at 1.30 p.m. Both are powerful international speakers. Dr Peckham is Principal of the Faith Mission Bible College in Edinburgh, Scotland and Mrs Peckham is from the Isle of Lewis in Scotland, with incredible testimony of the 1949-53 revival there.

Issue 352, 25 March 1998, page 4

Advt. Humphrey Bear live in concert at Burra Town Hall, 11 a.m., Tuesday 31 March.

Issue 352, 25 March 1998, page 7

The Last Miss Northern Showgirl will be chosen on Saturday 28 March and the new award for Young Rural Ambassadors will be launched. The Saddleworth Agricultural Society is host to the occasion. There are five Young Rural Ambassadors and six Showgirls.

Ian McLachlan AO MP, Minister for Defence, will be guest speaker at the Rump and Red evening hosted by the Burra & District Liberal Party, at Redruth Gaol on 4 April.

CFS. Two Burra units and units from Booborowie, Baldina and Farrell Flat, held combined exercises on 15 March, with support from Burra Police, SES and Burra Ambulance. Ten different exercises were covered.

Issue 352, 25 March 1998, page 8

Bowls. At the NEWBA Championships at Spalding on 16 March, Dawn Broderick and Estelle Nicholls won the Championship Pairs. Joyce Lloyd, Dulcie Clark and Joylene Kelly were runners-up in the triples.

Issue 353, 1 April 1998, pages 1, 6 & 7

The Burra-Morgan Road

The sealing project for the Burra-Morgan Road was officially opened by the Minister of Transport and Urban Planning, Diana Laidlaw. Councils had been lobbying for the sealed road for about sixty years. The Minister unveiled a plaque.

The Road building and sealing was undertaken by L.R.M. Constructions and overseen by Luigi Rossi of the Department of Road Transport. At one point the road was closed for seven months to speed up the process. The dry winter in 1997 may not have pleased farmers, but helped to bring the project in early and under budget. Already traffic on the road has increased. Burra traders are commenting on the number of buses using it as well as truckers, holidaymakers and boating enthusiasts. It is part of the shortest east-west route across Australia. The opening was also marked by a Bicycle Blitz. Eighty breakfasts were served on the banks of the Burra Creek at Burra before Graham Gunn flagged off the first two riders – Brian Thamm and Ivan Venning (Member for Schubert) at 8.30 a.m. In all 137 riders participated. The ride went to ‘The Gums’ for the official opening of the road by the Minister, Hon. Diana Laidlaw and then continued on to Morgan, where prizes were presented. The first solo finisher was Kathy Bruce, the first senior team was Peterborough Football Club and the first junior team was Goyder Student Boarding Hostel. Some fundraising during the ride meant that $569 will be split between Burra and Morgan ambulance Units.

[6 photos and a reprint of an article on a proposal to seal the road from The Burra Record of 8 January 1946.]

Issue 353, 1 April 1998, page 2

The Twilight Jazz Affair at Petherton was a resounding success. Some 350 people attended and listened to music by E-Type Jazz, Eddy White All Stars and Gumbo Ya Ya. Misty rain for about 30 minutes did not dampen the spirits of the revellers. [2 photos.]

Letter. Ron & Jan Bering of Moonta write in praise of the Twilight Jazz Affair and hope for a repeat.

Letter. Kevin D. Fahey, Principal of BCS, writes urging dog owners not to use the school oval to exercise their dogs, as it poses a health hazard for the school community.

Burra Picnic Race Club will hold its Annual Races on 4 April at Thistlebeds. The Royal Exchange Cup has a prize of $1,000. New amenities this year are a shower block, new holding yards, a Members’ Bar and a fresh coat of paint.

Advt. Private sale: 1 Mt Pleasant Road: $142,500.

Advt. Burra Regional Art Gallery presents ‘I’m Not a Dentist’, written and performed by Henri Szeps,

Star of ABC TV’s Mother and Son. Burra Town Hall, 8 p.m., Friday 8 May. Tickets $15.

Issue 353, 1 April 1998, page 4

Advertorial spruiking the show ‘I’m Not a Dentist’ by Henri Szeps, saying it is a funny, moving and inspiring autobiographical show from his birth in a WWII refugee camp in Switzerland to his rise to eminence in Australian theatre. He is best known now for his portrayal of Robert Beare, the favoured son (and dentist) in Mother and Son on ABC TV.

Burra-Morgan Road Opening

Those back for the occasion included: Ray Jennison and Jack McMahon, former Chairmen of the Burra Burra DC and their wives and also Tom Perry, a former District Clerk.

Lettie & Bob Disher have celebrated their Golden Wedding.

Obituary. Mary Ramm, wife of Colin Ramm, has died after a long illness.

Obituary. Len Hentschke, husband of Sue Hentschke, died suddenly.

Len was involved in many groups, including Senior Citizens, Day Care, and the Creek Bank Gardens and had been a former Councillor for the Robertstown DC.

[Leonard Hugo Hentschke born 1 October 1913 at Bright SA; died 20 March 1998.]

Issue 354, 8 April 1998, page 1

[Photo.]

Issue 354, 8 April 1998, page 2

Accident/Obituary. A 20-year-old jackeroo from Donald in Victoria died when he crashed his ute near Secomb’s on the Burra-Booborowie Road on Sunday afternoon.

Archaeology at Burra

In the coming week a collaboration between the National Trust in Burra, Goyder Council and Flinders University will result in staff and students from the University conducting field work in Burra. Their first work will be to provide an archaeological pre-disturbance survey on the dugouts used by miners at Burra.

Issue 354, 8 April 1998, page 3

Ian McLachlan, Minister for Defence, was the guest speaker at the Liberal Party dinner at Redruth Gaol last Saturday night.

Samm Halmam has a full-time position at Thamm’s Whitehart Garage, as an apprentice.

Issue 354, 8 April 1998, page 4

SA Parliamentarians Visit Burra

On 31 March Burra was visited by Deputy Premier, Graham Ingerson, Mark Brindal Minister for Local Government, Stewart Leggett, Don Swincer and the CEO of the SA Commission, Carole Hancock.

The Burra Picnic Race Meeting last Saturday 4 April was well patronised. The weather was perfect for the 28 event program. The features this year included foot races for children, tugs-of-war and two sleepy lizard races instead of one.

Little Athletics Day in Burra on 5 April was part of the Australian Country Games. Although membership of the local Little Athletics Club has dropped from 42 to 22, there was considerable local talent and they won five medals.

Burra Visitor Centre has won a grant of $6,000 to assist with its promotions.

Mike Fretwell has been appointed to the position of manager of the Port Pirie Tourism and Arts Centre.

Issue 354, 8 April 1998, page 7

Barry Wakelin MP visited the Burra & District Obedience Dog Club on Saturday morning.

Issue 354, 8 April 1998, page 9

Obituary. Martin Sheehan died 5 April 1998. (Buried from the church at Donald.)

Issue 355, 15 April 1998, page 1

Telstra has raised a cherry picker to a height of 32 metres on Brewery Hill to demonstrate what a telephone tower would look like. State and national heritage bodies will provide comment. A tower is expected to be able to reach 99% of the town.

Issue 355, 15 April 1998, page 4

Burra Girl Guides spent the weekend of 4-5 April at ‘GTS Dolphin’ in Adelaide.

Humphrey Bear visited Burra on 31 March, when 240 people filled the Town Hall for his show, which was sponsored by the Main Street Committee.

Birth. To Rosie & Jim Pritchard on 22 March, a son, Nicholas James.

Marriage. Shelly Beach Park, Manly (Sydney) recently

The 20th Laura Art Prize was won recently by Carolanne Wasley. Other section winners were Dennis Dale and Glenys Christopher.

The Bicycle Blitz raised enough to give about $500 each to the Ambulance Services at Burra and Morgan.

MFS annual exercise will be held on 19 April.

Issue 355, 15 April 1998, page 5

Easter Weekend in Burra was busy. 2,100 visitors came through the door of the Visitor Centre and 127 passports were sold, equating to c. 900 people doing the Heritage Trail. The caravan park was busy with up to 100 people per night and Paxton Square had three nights at capacity. The Motor Inn was also full on three nights and three-quarters full on Monday night. The Radford horse and wagon was active showing people around the town.

Issue 355, 15 April 1998, page 6

Mary Warnes Community Room (The Baby Care Room)

The room will be officially opened on 24 April. It will be opened by Carolyn Cooke, granddaughter of Mary Warnes. It was first mooted as a project in 1994, when the old swimming pool facilities were vacated. They proved unsuitable and after consultation with the Council, they made the space between the Visitor centre and the former Boulger store available. Many of the town’s contractors have worked on the site and have donated a wide door for double pram and wheelchair access, a sink with hot and cold water, a large change trolley and bench and a playpen area for toddlers and comfortable seating. The CWA, which was founded in SA by Mary Warnes, has also been a supporter.

Issue 355, 15 April 1998, page 9

Burra Golf Club has almost completed stage 1 of its course redevelopment. Recently Darryl Venning (President) turned on the water pipeline that will supply water via a creek to the dam, recently completed as part of the beautification of the western side of the course. Water from the dam will be used to green the fairways and tees and later for the greens. A creek has been made from the Barrier Highway area to run water from the pipeline to the dam. Soil from the dam site will now be used as a base for the tees and greens. Eventually holes 3 & 4 will be repositioned to give 8 holes on the east side of the highway and 10 on the western side, with holes 9 and 18 finishing at the clubhouse.

Issue 356, 22 April 1998, page 1

Goyder Council is looking into reducing the number of rubbish dumps in its area. Kerbside collection is also being investigated – at resent this is only done in Burra. A review of recycling will also be undertaken. Council will seek funding to seal Kooringa road (from Kooringa to Ford’s Corner). And also the road from Farrell Flat to Mintaro and Garden Hill (Inspiration Point) Road at Robertstown.

Issue 356, 22 April 1998, page 3

Cultural Tourism & Archaeology Students from Flinders University are in Burra. The Archaeology students are studying the remains of dugouts and the cultural tourism students are recording the activities. It is hoped these activities will mark the start of a long term collaboration.

Goyder Council

Will discuss with Police and the Bon Accord Hotel management the problems associated with youth hanging around the streets after hours. The sealed area near the hotel is a mixture of hotel land, council land and roadway.

Council has declined to provide public toilets at the saleyards/road train depot site.

Mayoral paintings and photos in Burra Town Hall are to be moved to the Art gallery for twelve months, following reports of damage.

Issue 356, 22 April 1998, page 4

Mt Bryan Progress association has purchased a tractor and slasher to keep the town free of high grass and weeds, especially around the more than 600 trees and shrubs established in the old railway yards.

Issue 356, 22 April 1998, page 5

Burra MFS went through its annual competition/evaluation on 19 March – this comprised a four man hose drill and simulated working incident involving a shed fire in Morehead Street.

Issue 357, 29 April 1998, pages 1 & 7

The Mary Warnes Community Room was opened on Friday by Ms Carolyn Cooke, granddaughter of Mary Warnes. In 1994 it was suggested that the buildings at the old swimming pool could become a baby’s changing room. After much discussion, the Council offered the small storage space adjacent to the Visitor Centre for conversion to a safe, comfortable and hygienic area to feed and change babies. There were a couple of disabled local teenagers who also needed these facilities. More than 24 local groups and families donated goods and money. A number of generous local tradespeople were also vital in getting the place transformed. It will be open during Visitor Centre hours and will be maintained and cleaned by Council. Mr Graham Kellock represented the Council and was presented with a certificate of accreditation to say the room meets criteria set down by the Nursing Mothers’ Association of Australia and the Australian Parent Magazine. After the opening the CWA provided morning tea. [2 photos.]

Issue 357, 29 April 1998, page 2

Members of the Adelaide Art Society visited Burra last week. In a week-long visit, they studied portraiture and painted some buildings and streetscapes. They ended with an exhibition of their works at the old Courthouse Hotel.

Accident. Three people sustained minor injuries when their car left the road south of Hanson and collided with the Morgan-Whyalla pipeline. [Photo page 3.]

The Anzac Dawn Service was conducted in Market Square on Saturday by Rev. Rod Peppiatt. The service was well attended.

Issue 357, 29 April 1998, page 3

Burra Ambulance Service. Rosemary Opperman writes an article outlining the work done by the 15 volunteer members in Burra and stressing the need for more volunteers.

Issue 357, 29 April 1998, page 4

Robertstown Agencies offered a free service to dispose of chemical drums, but only 25 farmers of the 622 notified responded, delivering 2,765 steel drums and 552 plastic drums – a disappointing response.

The National Trust will display a collection of hats in the BankSA window this week – arranged by Shirley Thamm.

Catherine Barker featured in an article in The Advertiser of 15 April, detailing her life from living at Baldina and attending BCS, through to becoming manager of the Boston Philharmonic Orchestra at the age of 27.

Obituary. Martin Sheehan was killed recently.

Burra Probus Club visited Pt Adelaide last week for a cruise and lunch on the Port River.

Burra Art Gallery’s new exhibition of Aboriginal art ‘Printabout’ will open at the weekend.

Glenys Christopher won a portraiture award in an art competition on Kangaroo Island recently.

The Bartholomaeus Family reunion will gather at Redruth Camp Centre next Saturday.

Issue 357, 29 April 1998, page 5

The Sporting Car Club of SA will hold a Burra to Morgan run of veteran vehicles on 9-10 May. This has been inspired by the completion of the bituminised road and celebrates similar runs in the early 1900s. Three cars that took part in the 1906 run will take part this time:

A 1905 Wolsley formerly owned by the Warnes family and now by Ian & Marie Tilbrok of Clare.

1904 De Dion Bouton formerly owned by Dr Sangster of Burra and now to be driven by current owner John Wien Smith.

Les & Nan Warnes will drive their Newton Bennett.

[The last named could not have been in the 1906 run, as it was a 1913 model car.]

[Photo of the cars in the 1912 run in Market Square.]

Issue 357, 29 April 1998, page 6

The Bon Accord Hotel had not complained over patrons in the car park after hours, but the concern was over the lack of public toilet facilities in the area.

Issue 358, 6 May 1998, page 1

The Credit Union Working Party met with the House of Representatives Financial Institutions Committee on 30 April to discuss alternatives for banking services in rural and remote areas.

Issue 358, 6 May 1998, page 2

Aged Care – A Christian Perspective – was the title for a discussion held at St Mary’s Church Hall, Burra on 28 April, sponsored by the Burra Branch of the Mothers’ Union. There were three speakers: Trevor Briggs, CEO of Willochra Home at Crystal Brook; Maureen Hobbs, supervisor of Care at Willochra and Noreen Hallion of the Burra Hospital.

Issue 358, 6 May 1998, page 3

Burra antique Fair & Cultural Weekend saw some 1,400 people attend over the weekend of 2-3 May. Market Square was festive with balloons and bunting. The weather was perfect and there was music, art, food and wine. Sixteen antique dealers travelled to Burra from all over SA to set up stalls in the Burra Town Hall. The Main Street Committee organised music and singing and the popular Irish Dancers as well as a gigantic game of draughts in the rotunda. The gallery had a continuous stream of visitors and the whole weekend was a great success.

Issue 358, 6 May 1998, page 4

Les & Kathy Smale and family were given a farewell by the Burra SES on Monday night, prior to their departure to Katherine (NT). Les & Kathy had been closely involved with the SES while in Burra, with Les becoming Controller of the Unit in early 1995. During his time in the office, the SES raised funds for a new vehicle and became prominent in various Burra events. In 1997 they were able to purchase a new vehicle and the official handover of keys was made at the 1998 Australia Day Breakfast – which was cooked by the SES.

Issue 358, 6 May 1998, page 5

Teresa & Clinton Thomson and their three children are off to Tasmania for a tour in their recently restored 1960 Ford Zodiac, along with two other members of the Zephyr and Zodiac Club of SA.

Issue 358, 6 May 1998, page 6

BBH Social Club will re-introduce a Sportsperson of the Year Award at a dinner to be held at Burra Town Hall on 18 June. The award was last presented in 1987.

Previous winners included Jean Roberts, John Redden, Di Day, Estelle Nicholls and Rick Williams.

Junior winners have included Rosie Lloyd, Darren James and Petrea Piggott.

Issue 358, 6 May 1998, Supplement

A full page advertisement for the Sportsperson of the Year Dinner, with a nomination form on the other side.

Issue 359, 13 May 1998, page 1

Burra Probus Club went for a luncheon cruise on the Port River on 21 April on the MV Port Princess. [Photo.]

Issue 359, 13 May 1998, page 2

‘I’m Not a Dentist’ starring Henry Szeps of Mother and Son fame drew a good crowd at the Burra Town Hall on Friday night.

Burra Art Gallery had almost 400 people through the doors on the Antique Fair weekend and 56 members of a visiting Probus Club last Monday.

Shane Keane is now fully employed at Foodland in Clare.

Belinda Lomman is working up to four days a week at Nuriootpa with her hairdressing.

Marriage. Recently

Brett Pink married Katrina Penna. Brett is the oldest grandchild of Avian and Freda Pink.

Birth. To Sally & Neil Hackett on 2 May, a daughter, Emma Jade. A grandchild for Judy & Graham Kellock.

Obituary. Don Gare of ‘Dilllowie’, Hallett and lately of Jamestown has died. He was a well-known Merino stud breeder. [Was this Donald Ralph Gare born 5 June 1927 Kooringa?]

Ron Dewhirst, formerly of Booborowie, turned 90 recently.

Issue 359, 13 May 1998, page 3

The Sporting Car Club’s Burra to Morgan Run at the weekend was a great success. Fourteen veteran cars and motor cycles participated. Deputy Chairman of Goyder Council, Cr Graham Kellock, flagged off the vehicles from Market Square. There was morning tea 18 km out and lunch at the Burra Creek, where the Girl Guides Support Group cooked a chop picnic for them. There was a barbecue tea at Morgan and a return run to Burra or Adelaide on Sunday.

[Photo of Les & Nan Warnes with their 1913 Newton Bennett.]

Issue 359, 13 May 1998, page 4

Burra & Districts Obedience Dog Club held its second Dog Owners Information Evening.

Guest speakers were Jackie Horton from RSPCA, Adelaide and David Merrill, ex-RAAF police dog handler.

The AGM followed and elected: President, Merilyn Baulderstone; Vice-President, Renee Wilson; Secretary, Len Newcombe and Treasurer, Jo Baulderstone.

By arrangement with the Burra Hospital Auxiliary.

Issue 359, 13 May 1998, page 7

Redbanks Reserve is now open to the public, with walks, camping in the designated area, toilet facilities, tank water for washing (not for drinking) and a recreational ‘oval’ area. A brochure is available at the Visitor Centre.

Issue 360, 20 May 1998, page 1

Kooringa Road. Council has begun work to improve the alignment of two corners on Kooringa Road. Next financial year some vertical re-alignment will be carried out.

Burra Golf Club Greening. Thanks are extended in particular to Rodney and Peter Cullen, Dick Secomb, Peter Boaden, Simon Eberhard, Richard Tiver, Phil Thompson, Leo Robinson, Adchem and the Goyder Council. These supplied the machinery or the man hours needed to excavate the dam or move earth.

Issue 360, 20 May 1998, page 2

Birth. To Donna Farley on 23 April, a son, Peter Samuel Anthony.

Burra & District Tourism Association. With its constitution now set up and a subscription passed, the association has begun operating. The association ran a barbecue over the antique Fair weekend and has made a submission to Council on improved signage. Tourist traffic along the Morgan Road has increased dramatically since it was sealed. The association is looking at producing a full-colour tourist brochure for the district.

Issue 360, 20 May 1998, page 3

Advt. Captain Boggles presents Joy Flights at Burra commencing Wednesday 20 May for five days, weather permitting: straight scenic, aerobatic and streamer cutting, in an open cockpit Tiger Moth.

Corner of Barrier Highway and Burra Bypass. (Wes Hooper’s)

Family Day Care is provided in Burra, offering flexible 24 hour service for children from birth to 16 years. Providers are self-employed and approved by the Department of Education, Training and Employment.

Issue 360, 20 May 1998, page 4

International Nurses Day was celebrated with a barbecue at Burra Hospital on 12 May.

Issue 360, 20 May 1998, page 5

Indoor Bowls. A monthly competition is held between Saddleworth, Riverton, Auburn, Kapunda and Burra. It has been going on for 25 years, hosted by the Ladies’ Auxiliary of the Burra RSL. Burra won the 1997 trophy.

Burra Hospital Auxiliary held its AGM on 8 May. The guest speaker was Tim Horsnell from Carers Link.

The Auxiliary raises funds largely by catering. It provides teas for Council meetings and conferences (like ICOMOS) and for clearing sales and of course, the Melbourne Cup Luncheon. This latter moved from the Town Hall to the Sports Complex this year and raised c. $1,400. Money spent on helping the Burra Hospital this year totalled $2,721.45. Elected were: President, Hazel Newcombe; Secretary, Celine Stockman and Treasurer, Kaye Boulger.

The Vicbash, organised by the Variety Club of Victoria, will pass through Burra on 27 May, with lunch at the Burra Oval.

Adchem Profile

Adchem, Burra, is the largest production facility of its kind in the world, producing high quality cupric oxide. It has been developed to use a broad base of copper bearing materials.

Cupric Oxide has many uses and some of the principal ones are:

Copper chrome arsenate compounds used in the perma pinewood preservatives.

Production of friction material for brakes and clutches

As a catalyst in chemical industries

A colouring agent in glass and ceramics

A raw material for copper chemical production

Production of ferrites for the electronics industry

Animal feed supplements

Trace element fertilizers in agriculture

Manufacture of fungicides

A component in air bag safety systems in vehicles.

Currently the product is exported to:

Issue 360, 20 May 1998, page 9

Break-in. A break-in and theft has occurred at the Burra Pistol Club.

Theft. R.M. Williams boots and cash has been stolen from Burra sports & Community Club.

Vandalism has occurred at a bore near World’s End, with rubbish forced down the bore.

Burra Quilters had a felting workshop on the Mother’s Day Weekend, led by Mollie Littlejohn, one of Adelaide’s leading felt-makers. It was sponsored by SA Country Arts Trust and held in the Home Economics Room at BCS.

Issue 361, 27 May 1998, page 1

Accident. A car and caravan rolled over on the Barrier Highway adjacent to Porter Lagoon. [Photo.]

Goyder Council has approved the building of a digital mobile phone tower by Telstra on Brewery Hill. It will form part of a network with another two towers built at Hallett and Black Springs. State Heritage has indicated its approval. Subject to conditions:

All servicing of the tower is to be done via underground trenching.

A small colorbond building associated with the tower is to be located behind the hill, so as to be invisible from the town.

The approval was for a 35 m steel lattice tower, with provision for two other mobile phone companies to share if they wish.

Issue 361, 27 May 1998, page 2

The Salvation Army Red Shield Appeal in Burra raised more than $850.

Issue 361, 27 May 1998, page 3

The State heritage Branch provided a $10,000 cheque, which was handed to Goyder Council last week by the Heritage Advisor, Douglas Alexander. This is a one-off grant over and above the normal Stage Heritage Fund grant. Burra’s Heritage Advisory Committee will formulate guidelines to spend the grant.

Burra Community Library now has four computers where users can surf the internet at a cost of $4 per hour or $2 per half-hour.

Captain Boggles and his Tiger Moth have been barn storming around Burra skies for a few days. [2 photos.]

Issue 361, 27 May 1998, page 6

Sharon Mostyn has recently graduated from the Centre for Tourism Studies with the Certificate of Travel and Tourism and also won the Ansett Award for ‘Most Motivated Student’. She has begun a part-time degree in Applied Science – Business Management.

Burra Art Gallery’s new exhibition opening on 6 June is called ‘Caravan’ and is an exhibition of contemporary jewellery by nine SA artist jewellers. It runs until 22 June.

Burra Trading Post is a venture set up in the former Boulger’s store. It has had a couple of busy weekends offering local art, tie dyed clothes, bric-a-brac, pots of plants, etc. More space is available at this market-style venture if you are interested.

Judy Baker has now a full-time job with a law firm at Mt Barker. She formerly worked at the Page Evans Office.

Terowie Cemetery

The 1998 Clean Up Australia Day effort saw two trailer loads of rubbish, weeds, clippings etc. removed. Since then Deryck Skinner has put in much effort to tidy the cemetery. A number of descendants of early residents have indicated an interest in marking previously unmarked graves of relatives. Albert Kloester has worked on behalf of a number of families to restore grave sites and to exterminate large colonies of aggressive ants on site. Deryck and Sue Miller have undertaken to uniformly mark all presently unmarked graves. John Aver Mitchell was the founder of Terowie. He was a Scot born in 1832 and died in Terowie in 1879. In March 1872 he purchased Section 158 in the Hundred of Terowie and built the Terowie Hotel on the edge of the Section. He then had the rest of the Section (and later other areas) surveyed into town allotments. Terowie CMC is setting up a fund to restore Mitchell’s grave for the 120th anniversary of his death in 1999.

Issue 361, 27 May 1998, page 7

State Heritage Branch has given a grant of $3,600 to fund a landscaping plan for Paxton Cottages. The implementation of the plan will use funds from the cottages themselves.

Issue 361, 27 May 1998, page 8

The venue has been changed to the Burra sports Complex. 18 June at 6.30 p.m.

Issue 362, 3 June 1998, page 1

BCS. Sue Langford’s Year 3-4 class has won the National Trust Living Health School Art Competition Prize – a computer package worth $2,000. This was a state-wide competition and the students produced a set of collages of local history sites.

Issue 362, 3 June 1998, page 2

BCS. The school’s Boer goats escaped through the fence last week and made a meal of some fifty four-year-old trees on the property of Glenys Christopher and Bob Skinner. Yesterday they were found to have defoliated some 200 of their trees and eaten some to ground level. [Photo.]

Helen Stockman, as editor, writes questioning the proliferation of late of ‘plans’. She wonders if all the money spent on plans leaves any for implementation. It is all wasted if all that gets done is the planning and not the doing.

Peter Phillips has just returned from a five day adventure sail training voyage on the One and All, having been nominated by Burra Police. The crew for the voyage comprised 23 boys and girls from across SA. The voyage was all in Gulf waters.

Obituary. Mr Ron Pearse, formerly of Koonoona, died on 28 May. He was long an active member of the community, being the inaugural chairman in 1970 of the Barker Cottage Board and was also Chairman of the Burra Hospital Board for many years as well as being a noteworthy figure in the stud Merino industry.

Barker Homes. The cottages in Pearse Row are having their bathrooms upgraded. Three have been completed, with six to be done in the next two months.

Boh Wall has been selected for the SANFL U16 State Football Squad.

Issue 363, 10 June 1998, page 3

Chris Reed, Chairman of the Eastern Districts Soil Conservation Board, writes in response to Helen Stockman’s query about ‘plans’, saying they have much work to do Regional Strategies and without plans they would not get any funding, the money would go elsewhere and no rehabilitation would take place.

Issue 363, 10 June 1998, page 6

Burra Visitor Centre. In the eleven months to end of May 1998:

4,435 Heritage Passports were sold compared with 3,902 the previous year.

15,867 visitors compared with 14,670 the previous year.

WISE (Women’s Information, Support & Enrichment) is a group that has been meeting fortnightly since October 1996. It provides information for quality of life and health in an informal format and has stringent guidelines of confidentiality and respect for each other’s views. The group meets on alternate Mondays at the St John’s Ambulance Centre.

This duo have been together since 1983 – Grant Wildman and Trevor Wright. They offer a wide range of drama, through Dramatic Solutions – a company that presents thoughtful drama for all age groups and situations.

Goyder Council has voted to support a twelve month trial allowing A-double vehicles or road trains access through Ludgvan Street to link the Barrier Highway with the Burra-Morgan Road – there will be a speed limit of 40 k.p.h. in the 60 k.p.h. zone for such vehicles and discouragement of the use of exhaust brakes.

Zac, Burra Hospital’s Pets for Therapy black Labrador, has retired to Hyde’s household in Gawler, at the age of eleven years. He had been at Burra hospital since May 1995. Thanks to Pauline Venning for tending to Zac’s needs over the years and to Wesfarmer Dalgety for generous donations of tinned and dried dog food over the three years. Thanks too to Goyder House students and others who walked Zac regularly.

Weather. A storm on 19 June brought high winds that ripped the roof off a caravan near ‘The Pines’ and carried it across the former railway reserve, cartwheeling it 200 metres into an adjacent crop.
