Issue 594, 26 March 2003, MISSING

Issue 595, 2 April 2003, page 1

The 77 mm Artillery Gun that has been on display at Burra North for several years has been relocated to the Army Museum of SA. It was captured on 8 August 1918 at Warfsee in France by the 27th Infantry Battalion.

The Burra Hospital Auxiliary has been fundraising recently and a charity auction at the Hospital on 28 March raised c. $900. The Auxiliary is planning its garden party at the beautiful Princess Royal for 13 April. The funds will go towards furbishing [sic] the hostel units presently under construction.

[Since furbishing means renovating, furnishing would be more apt.]

The film Breaker Morant will be screened at the Town Hall on Friday 11 April as part of the 25th anniversary celebrations of BCS. Among locals that may be glimpsed in their roles as extras are: Mrs Jessie Rooke, the late Rex Opperman, Elspeth Radford, Maria Reed, Nellie Seidel, Don Griffen, Roger Boehm, Rob Radford and Chris Reed. Scenes were shot at the Redruth Gaol and in Market Square, where the Burra Hotel appears as the Pietersberg Hotel.

Goyder Council Elections

When nominations closed on 27 March the following had nominated for the five seats in Burra Ward: Peter Reilly, Bob Radford, Tim Stockman, Trevor Underwood, Colleen Woodgate, Jim Quinn, Adrian Gill, Kevin Wallis and Maureen Wright. For Hallett Ward, Doug Wiltshire, Peter Mattey and Laurie Sullivan had nominated for the two seats. For the Robertstown Ward, Dennis Keller and Warren Mosey were elected unopposed. In Eudunda Ward, Don Pfitzner, Jim Reese, Paul Schiller and Stan Simper were elected unopposed.

Issue 595, 2 April 2003, page 2

Professor Rod Wells has been in Burra with a group of palaeontology students.

A helicopter and film crew have been about, filming in Burra and Hawker areas.

Birth. To Petrice Messenger & Richard Irlam on 13 March, a son, Jackson Edward Irlam. [Photo]

Birth. To Daniel & Stacey Neill on 13 March, a daughter, Carly Marie. Another grandchild for Bob 7 Idrienne Neill and another great grandchild for Laurel Neill.

Birth. To Roger & Alison Schutz nee Quinn on 14 March, a daughter, Ruby Mary. A grandchild for Jo & Harry Quinn.

Bob & Lettie Disher of Booborowie celebrated their 55th wedding anniversary on 20 March.

Gladys & John Brown celebrated their 50th wedding anniversary on 4 April.

Obituary. Dr Peter Davies, who practised here with Rob Oswald some years ago, has died.

Issue 595, 2 April 2003, page 3

The Department of Environment & Heritage conducted a controlled burn at Mokota Conservation Park near Mt Bryan last Saturday. It was part of a plan to develop a program for the management of the park. Mokota Conservation Park was declared in October 2000 as the first park in SA acquired for the protection of native grassland.

Burra Show Society held its AGM on 25 March. Ken Broad was elected as the new President. Sharon O’Connor was elected Vice-President and Kaye Broad will continue as Secretary. The 126th show will be held on 11 October 2003. [Actually the 111th show.]

Pastor Raymond Moore of Lisburn in Northern Ireland will be the guest speaker at several meetings this weekend in Burra. He was born in Northern Ireland’s County Tyrone and grew up on a dairy farm before becoming a University Lecturer and later attending Bible College. [The page 11 advertisement says he is the Pastor of Lisburn Independent Methodist Church, but gives no indication of the theme or topic of his addresses; neither is there a follow-up report.]

Issue 595, 2 April 2003, page 4

Burra RSL has received a grant of $3,658 to restore eight WWI & WWII honour boards.

Burra Theatre Group is working on its production ‘The Girls of Hampton Court’. Robyn Day is presently taking the role of Matron, while looking for a replacement. Robyn wrote the play about the Girls’ Reformatory at Redruth, set between 1897 and 1922. Robyn says the girls’ stories ranged from tragic to very amusing and the play will be presented sometime in September and there will also be grant applications with a view to shooting a movie.

Burra Community Sports Club held its AGM. Chairman Paul Wilson said the past year had largely been one of consolidation. New sprinklers were being introduced. A new fence on the southern boundary allows heavy vehicle access from Essex Street. After ten years some repairs are needed to the complex and some fittings are now in need of replacement. The netball/tennis building should be extended to give spectators greater protection from the weather. The car park above the netball court has been endorsed by the Council for sealing and kerbing for several years, but the work is yet to be done.

Issue 596, 9 April 2003, page 1

Regional Tourism Awards, 6 April

Helen Szuty won the Media Award for her publication The Visitors’ Monthly.

The National Trust of Burra Burra won the Perpetual Award for Tourism Excellence.

Issue 596, 9 April 2003, page 1

Goyder Council has adopted a plan for some redevelopment of the creek area – much of it based on a concept drawn up in 1994. Plans are afoot to use water from the Mine Pool to maintain the creek flow, rather than bore water. A solar pump is being investigated. A walking trail on the west side of the creek, reaching north from the foot bridge could also be included.

The Effluent Ponds

At present the southern ponds are being made into one large pond, to be separated from the northern area, which will become four smaller ponds. A liner will be laid in the larger pond, where the treatment cycle begins, before the effluent is pumped through the remaining four ponds. Council is looking for a customer to use the end product.

Issue 596, 9 April 2003, page 2

Letter. J. Pederson writes to commend the people at work in the Computer Centre. He was able to do some research on a relative who once lived in Burra and even to get a photograph. The three hour visit to Burra turned into three days.

[Note: in Issue 597, 16 April 2003, page 2 this report is corrected to indicate that the help was provided by the Burra Community Library Staff.]

The Burra Community Internet & Computer Centre is now open and provides email and Internet access to the local community and visitors. It is located in the Burra Town Hall and was established with a Commonwealth grant under the Networking the Nation Program. The computers have large 19 inch monitors and high speed access. The centre has a good software library, enabling users to do a wide range of things. It opened last month and can also provide secretarial and business services when required. It can also offer for hire a multimedia projector for special events.

R.M. Williams. A quest to find the oldest pair of R.M. Williams boots was launched in Sydney last year. 167 pairs of boots were submitted and the winner was deemed to be a pair submitted by Gillian Barnard of Burra, with a pair that belonged to her father, Jack Snell. She said he bought them in 1936. He was Australian buck-jumping and steer-riding champion in the 1930s and 1940s. They were first worn at the 1936 Clare Rodeo. She and son Charles will be flown to Sydney on 14 April for the Great Aussie Muster, where they will be provided with a new pair of R.M. Williams boots valued at $799.

Issue 596, 9 April 2003, page 3

Burra Red Cross gave the Hospital Auxiliary a cheque for $678.56 on 4 April to assist with furbishing [sic: furnishing] of the Hostel Wing, currently under construction.

Mt Bryan Red Cross will host the 44th Annual Zone Conference on 14 April. Guest speaker will be Geraldine Smedley on ‘Searching for my uncle’s WWI grave in France.’ Local singer, Kathy Nicholls will also provide entertainment.

Burra Community Development is exploring the idea of a ‘Burra Foundation’ as an independent charity to meet the specific needs of the local community. The foundation for Rural and Regional Development will conduct a feasibility study for the purpose.

Issue 596, 9 April 2003, page 4

Burra Bowling Club. The Grand Final for second division white was played last Saturday at Booborowie.

Burra Green 80 defeated Saddleworth Gold 64. [Photo]

Issue 596, 9 April 2003, Supplement

Four unnumbered pages marking the 25th anniversary of the Burra Community School

Page 1 carried advertisements from the Burra Record – Matthews Emporium 1968 & 1976 & Bence’s 1968.

And a collage of clippings from 1976.

Page 2 was a reprint from the Northern Argus 4 April 1978 and three photos of BCS in 1978.

Page 3 carried the program of the celebrations.

Page 4 carried reminiscences of Burra School & Community News

Some of the points:

BSCN began in 1978, the year the school opened with 456 students compared with this year’s 270.

Ron Thamm was the School Council Chairman.

BSCN was printed on an offset press purchased for $6,000 by the School Council.

It began as a solo effort by Cynthia Burnett, but soon became community based with a group of volunteers.

At first it was supported by Burra Apex and later, when it was commercially printed, by them and a series of sponsors and individual donors.

Issue 597, 16 April 2003, pages 1 & 4

BCS 25th Anniversary

About 300 people attended under threatening clouds.

First Principal of the school, Chris McCabe, ceremonially re-opened the school on Saturday afternoon. Deputy Principal Gus Wenzel was MC and introduced the other principals and first Librarian of the Burra Community Library, Colin Fidock.

Winners of the literary competition; ‘When I Lived in Burra in 1977’:

Open Section Marie Henson & Rosemary Quinn

Middle School Bridget Hallion

Junior School Hayden Noble

Kevin Fahey, who had been principal for ten years when he left last year, mentioned some of the highlights of his time:

1993 Establishment of the Middle School

1995 The town sesquicentenary and back-to-school celebrations

1996 BCS purchased Brewery Hill

1997 Water conservation project on the school oval

1998 Appointment of a chaplain

1999 Funds from leasing Brewery Hill site to Telstra for a phone tower enabled the development of the farm

2001 Erection of the shearing shed

Mike Day, Principal 1987-92, recalled the school’s involvement with the Royal Adelaide Show and its concentration on its agricultural program as highlights, along with the production of ‘The Breaker Morant Retrial’.

[Page 1 carries photos of some former students and the former principals.]

Ron Thamm, Chairman of the School Council in 1978 said that today was a day of thanksgiving and he recalled the role of the Burra Burra District Council in getting the gym built, aided by the buy-a-brick campaign.

[3 photos of various visitors, plus one of the librarians, Beth Wiley, Tess Hopkins and Colin Fidock and a photo of Chris McCabe.]

Issue 597, 16 April 2003, page 2

Letter from Roman & Betty Piwowar who were in Burra in 1981 on teacher exchange from Canada. The letter outlines their lives since returning to Canada and those of their children, one of whom was born while they were here.

Letter. Tiffany Murray, Project Manager of the Burra Cultural Centre writes to say that with the aim of establishing Burra Town Hall as a centre for weddings, she is establishing a registry of all associated services in Burra and calls on all to contact her if they need to be included.

Letter from Stephen Angel on behalf of the Year 11 Class of 1978. He writes to express his gratitude for the great work of all involved with each of the events of the weekend of celebration.

Elly Nicholls married John Monfries.

They will live at Kimba.

Burra Hospital Auxiliary’s garden party at Princess Royal on 13 April raised c. $1,200 for furnishing the new hostel rooms at Burra Hospital.

Burra Pony Club held its annual gymkhana on Sunday 13 April. About 30 competitors faced a wild and windy day. [Trophy winners are listed.]

Issue 597, 16 April 2003, page 5

Goyder Council Elections: Candidate Profiles – Burra Ward

Peter Reilly

Born in Burra & lived there all my life

Educated at Burra and Rostrevor College

Since then been a farmer and private contractor to several councils and Department of Road Transport

Interested in football, cricket and squash as a player and administrator

Have been involved with the Burra Picnic Race Club, Burra Yacht Club, Burr-Broken Hill Barrow Push and West Burra Land Care Group

Concerned about youth unemployment and training and the retention of the Burra Hospital.

Bob Bradley

Born in Burra & live at Farrell Flat

Manage the family farm and with wife, Heather, am a company director of Clare Valley Tours

A member of Clare Valley Region VIC Tourism Committee

Represented Council on MNRDB

Committee member of Mid North Rural Counselling & Information Service

Vice Chair of SA Association of Rural Counselling Services

Tim Stockman

Local businessman and son of a local farming family

Resident of the area all my life

Self-employed in the area for nearly 11 years with two staff

Involved over the years with SES, MFS, SA Ambulance Service, MNRDB, Hockey Club

Would bring a younger person’s perspective to Council and with my family background also an understanding of the rural sector.

Concerned with population decline in rural sector and its impact on the region

Trevor Underwood

Married to Rhonda, a popular instructor with the Burra & Districts Dog Obedience Club

Have lived in the district for 20 years, prior to which spent 9 years with RAAF

Manager of the Burra & Booborowie Refuse Depots

If elected would be a voice of the people.

Colleen Woodgate

Married to Ashley Woodgate and have been a member of the community for more than 40 years

Have a concern for the community well-being with interests in health, transport, aged care, sport, schools etc.

Have supported the road sealing program and the mobile phone tower

James Vincent (Jim) Quinn

Currently a Burra Ward Councillor and have been since 1997

Have long been involved with local government at all levels – Regional, State and National – President of Mid North Local Government Association and Executive Member of SA Local Government Association and Delegate to National Local Government Association

Have had involvement with Burra Ambulance, Mid North Passenger Transport Board, Rural Counselling Committee and the McDouall Stuart Board, which established the Burra Art Gallery.

Long experience in all local government matters in Burra and the district.

See myself as a voice for the people

Adrian Gill (Gilly)

Aged 56 and have lived in Burra since 1977

I run my own business as an electrical contractor

Have served two years on the District Council of Burra Burra and six on the Regional Council of Goyder.

Support the establishment of new industries in Burra and other towns in Goyder

A supporter of tourism, but it needs the backing of other industry as well.

Kevin Wallis

Have lived in Burra for 16 years

Have previously been a councillor

Chairperson of the Burra Cemetery Advisory Committee

Supporter of recycling and of an industrial park for Burra

Keen to see employment growth

Question why Burra pays nearly twice the rate in the dollar for its rates.

Maureen Wright

Resident of Burra since 1983 and live in Burra North with husband, Barry

Own and run an antique shop and heritage cottage accommodation

Have jointly published a book of River Murray Charts

Over the years have been on many committees such as the Paxton Square Committee, Jubilee 150 Committee and am presently Chair of the Goyder Heritage Advisory Committee

Chaired the Burra National Trust when it managed the Visitor Centre and have served on the State Heritage Authority

Believe my business experience and knowledge of the Burra tourism product can be of benefit to the Goyder Community

Issue 598, 23 April 2003, page 1

Burra Effluent Ponds. Work is progressing with the liner laid over half the southern pond.

Thefts. A spate of thefts occurred in Burra in the early hours of 15 April. Vehicle damage amounted to c. $800 and property losses to c. $3,000. Twelve reports were made to police in relation to these thefts.

Issue 598, 23 April 2003, page 2

Letter. E.R. Fuss writes suggesting that if the RSL is restoring WWI & WWII honour boards, it would be a good time to consider adding honour boards for the Boer War and post WWII conflicts.

Letter. Bob Skinner of Ford’s Corner writes to compliment and thank Council for eventually providing a concise and informative newsletter, which refutes the numerous innuendoes that have been flowing through the community.

Marriage. Redruth Camp Centre, 19 April

David Keane married Alice Burns of Burra.

Robyn Day of Burra has a brother, Joe, who is currently on exchange with a frontline US marine unit in Iraq. He crossed into Iraq from Kuwait four weeks ago and has seen action in Baghdad and Tikrit and was recently featured in a picture in the Australian.

Issue 598, 23 April 2003, page 3

Goyder Council Elections: Candidate Profiles – Hallett Ward

Doug Wiltshire

After requests from many ratepayers, careful thought and legal advice, I offer myself for Hallett Ward

If elected my priority would be to see the Council is proactive in worthwhile community projects and undertaking its mandatory obligations to ratepayers

I will make myself available on alternate months in Hallett and Terowie to hear ratepayers’ concerns

Mt professional career includes: senior management positions and consulting in the accounting profession in a wide variety of company areas

I am semi-retired

S. Peter Mattey

I am 50 and married to Jacki

We have four children and I have been a Councillor for 25 years

I am committed to sound financial management and a fair allocation of resources to all parts of the Council area.

I support only modest rate increases

Laurie Sullivan

I have nominated for re-election to see through the process of change started with the amalgamation of Councils

I believe the amalgamation to have been successful, despite the increasing imposts placed on us by the State Government

The amalgamation has allowed more roads to be sealed

I served on the Hallett Council for 13 years, some of that time as Chairman

Issue 599, 30 April 2003, page 1

Burra Golf Club’s 9th half-yearly auction on the former Aberdeen Oval involved 60 vendors and 184 registered buyers. Gross takings were $18,300 from the auction and $2,000 from food and drinks.

A Police Blitz on speeding resulted in 12 infringements out of 50 vehicle on Copperhouse Street and 12 out of 110 on Smelts Road.

Goyder Heritage Advisory Committee has vacancies for two additional community members.

Burra Motor Company was burgled on Easter weekend when thieves broke in through the roof.

The Anzac Day Dawn Service drew a crowd of about 150 in Burra, where Fr Quinn took the service.

Rev. Maurice Lind concluded his three months as interim Uniting Church minister with a heritage service on Sunday. It featured hymns by Wesley, Sankey, Crosby and Moody that are no longer in the hymn book.

Issue 599, 30 April 2003, page 2

Graham Kellock, a Councillor since 1985 and a former Chairman of the Burra Burra DC, was farewelled at the last Council meeting and thanked for his contribution over 18 years.

Len & Nancy Simpson went to Melbourne recently to see their grandson, Adam Simpson, play in the AFL for the Kangaroos.

Merino Studmasters held a meeting in the Burra Town Hall last Thursday to review the 2003 Field Days and plan for 2004.

Ron & Betty Thamm have celebrated their 50th wedding anniversary. They shared their celebration with Betty’s sister Fay and her husband Roy Partridge, recalling their double wedding at St Mary’s, Burra in 1953.

[25 April.]

Birth. To Leanne & Mitch Michelmore, formerly of Burra, a son in Yorketown, David Andrew.

Obituary. Mr Harold Broad of ‘Old Canowie’ died on 21 April.

[Presumably Harold John Broad born 12 June 1919 at Aberdeen.]

Letter from Des Woolley complaining about the lack of parental training, control, interest and responsibility that results in vandalism by the young in Burra.

Goyder Council

The review of council’s Development Plan is nearing completion. Council’s Senior Administration Officer, Mr John Brak, was somewhat disappointed by the low attendance at informal drop-in sessions, but heartened by the number of written responses.

The Cockatoo Café at Ryan’s Deer Farm has been renovated and expanded with undercover seating, transparent blinds for greater comfort and a take-away facility for venison tasting and venison smallgoods. [Photo of Glynne Ryan]

Issue 599, 30 April 2003, Supplement

A folded A3 sheet giving a four page guide to the Burra Antique Fair, which includes advertisements, a town map and plans of the stall lay-out in the Town Hall and in St Mary’s Church Hall.

Issue 600, 7 May 2003, page 1

Burra Antique Fair was very successful in fine weather and the crowd of 1,600 made it one of the most successful.

Burra Visitor Centre has made a good start to 2003. Manager Andrew Glen says there has been a smooth transition to the new management, with the transfer of former employees John Arthur and Elly Monfries and two new enthusiastic employees in Stephanie Bavistock and Stephanie Crowley. Weather has also been good and the re-accreditation process has ensured SA Tourism funding for 2003. Support from the National Trust, Goyder Council and local businesses has been excellent.

Issue 600, 7 May 2003, page 2

Burra Quilters are holding their bi-annual exhibition in the Burra Art Gallery at present.

Issue 600, 7 May 2003, page 3

Stockman Electronics was the successful tenderer for the provision of 45 new computers to BCS in a major upgrade of information technology at the school. Principal Rob Knight said the tender was worth $60,000 and was affordable by leasing rather than buying the equipment. A further $5,000 will be spent on expanded network cabling. [Photo and further details printed.]

Sharyn Roberts was presented with the Centenary Medal by Barry Wakelin MP for Grey on Monday 5 May. Her citation says for service to the community of Burra. She was nominated for her services to sport, particularly in encouraging junior sport. The medal was established in 2001 as part of the Australian Honours System. It commemorates the centenary of federation and honours contributions made to Australian society and government by its citizens and others.

Issue 600, 7 May 2003, page 4

BCS held a modelling day on Saturday. The gymnasium was the site for radio-controlled and rubber-band powered planes and in the Technical Studies block the Burra Battleship Group worked on the construction of their models. A great drawcard was the launching of water rockets from the hockey oval.

Issue 600, 7 May 2003, page 5

Burra Girl Guides have again volunteered to collect for the Salvation Army’s Red Shield Appeal in late May and early June.

Issue 600, 7 May 2003, pages 8 to 24

The Therapeutic Goods Administration lists hundreds of goods manufactured by PAN Pharmaceuticals Ltd that were the subject of an Urgent Medical Recall, due to serious quality and safety breaches in the manufacturing process since 1 May 2002. The quality, safety or effectiveness of these items could not be assured.

Issue 601, 14 May 2003, page 1

Local Government Elections

Final results will await distribution of Preferences in Adelaide. On first preference totals it would seem that in Burra Ward:

Peter Reilly 209 is certain to be elected

Bob Bradley 145 is safe

Adrian Gill 132 is likely to be elected

The last two positions are less clear:

Colleen Woodgate 109

Maureen Wright 90

Tim Stockman 73

Jim Quinn 62

Kevin Wallis 43

Trevor Underwood 41

In Hallett Ward final counting confirmed

Laurie Sullivan 133 elected

Peter Mattey 111 elected

Douglas Wiltshire 91

Results are yet to be confirmed by the Electoral Commission.

Burra Artist Len Bence turned 80 on 9 May

One of the gallery spaces in the Regional Art Gallery in Burra is named after him. In his life Len has been a jackeroo in Queensland, a Lancaster bomber pilot in WWII, proprietor of Bence’s the long-time department and clothing store in Burra and a successful professional artist. He is still actively painting and teaching and also an active horticulturalist growing superb tulips and Roma tomatoes. A collection of his paintings is on show at Thorogood’s Cider Cellar, where they can be purchased. [Photo]

Burra Hospital Auxiliary. At the AGM President Helen Dunow reported on an active year of fundraising:

Catering for the Antique Fair

Justices’ Dinner

Goyder Regional Council Dinner

Trading Table

Melbourne Cup Day Luncheon

Auction of old hospital furniture

Garden Party at Princess Royal

During the year more than $7,000 was raised, including $500 from Community Aid, $679 from the Red Cross and $614 from the Children’s Christmas Cake Auction.

Issue 601, 14 May 2003, page 2

Birth. To Arleta & Wayne Smith at Mildura 27 April, a great granddaughter for Anne & Aub Finch.

Professor Rod Wells, palaeontologist is continuing his fossil excavations around Burra, revealing diprotodon fossils more than 30,000 years old. Over the years the area has produced fragments from a giant emu, the marsupial lion and the Tasmanian devil as well as from diprotodons.

Marriage. In Jane & Greg Kellock’s Garden, 5 April

Sharon Kellock, daughter of David & Bev Kellock of Farrell Flat, married Marty Rodda.

The reception was in the Burra Town Hall. They will live at Kimba.

Issue 602, 21 May 2003, page 1

Goyder Council met yesterday with two new Councillors representing Burra Ward. The Council comprises: Dennis Keller, Warren Mosey (Deputy Chairman), Adrian Gill, Peter Mattey, Jim Reese, Don Pfitzner, Paul Schiller, Peter Reilly, Stan Simper, Tim Stockman, Laurie Sullivan (Chairman), Bob Bradley and Colleen Woodgate. [Photo – except Colleen Woodgate]

Weather. The last ten days brought very variable rains, but enough for many farmers to begin seeding. The inside country got from 50 to 85 mm generally. To the east it was more variable. Ian Warnes for example had falls of from 70 to 140 mm over different parts of Woolgangi.

Burra SES has just taken delivery of a new Isuzu truck as their main vehicle for call-outs. It is large enough to carry all their equipment compared with the limited size of the previous Toyota Dyna. SES still needs volunteers. An extension to the shed to make a new truck bay will also benefit the MFS.

Issue 602, 21 May 2003, page 2

A Rostrum Voice of Youth heat was held at the Burra Community Library on Thursday evening. Four BCS students took part, giving prepared speeches. They were Amy Wilson, Sarah Earle, Katie Thomas & Lisa Simpson. Katie Thomas and Amy Wilson will compete in Adelaide this Sunday in the next heat.

Katie Esser, Community Projects Development Officer with the Goyder Council has applied for about $120,000 worth of funding in the first six months of her twelve month contract and so far all seven of the applications have been successful, with just over $53,000 received and injected into our economy. [Photo]

Letter. Pat O’Brien, who visited Burra over Anzac Day long weekend, writes to praise Cousin Marjorie (Marge Edmonds) at Malowen Lowarth, for bringing the mining period to life.

Letter. D. Woolley writes, saying ‘We elect what we deserve, we deserve what we elect.’ He also complains about another bout of mindless vandalism in Burra.

Issue 602, 21 May 2003, page 3

The Burra Community Internet & Computer Centre was officially opened by Barry Wakelin, the Member for Grey last Friday. $160,000 had been accessed to set the centre up. The manager is Paul Williams, assisted by Carly Heinrich. [Photos]

Elspeth Radford & Graham Gunn both received Centenary of Federation medals presented by Barry Wakelin. [Photo]

Goyder Council is preparing costings and a report on sealing the Bower Boundary Road. This connects the Morgan-Burra Road with the Morgan-Eudunda Road. It provides a link to abattoirs at Murray Bridge and Pt Wakefield and its sealing is regarded as vital to the development of the intensive animal industries and other primary industries in the Bower area. One major pig producer has been established and two additional development applications are being considered. The area could potentially accommodate up to 53 enterprises, with 23 being in the Regional Council of Goyder. The Minister for transport does not support the project when money has recently been spent on sealing the parallel Burra-Robertstown Road.

Threatened plant found near Burra. A small ground cover type native plant has been found at Ford’s Corner. It is the small scurf pea; Cullen parvum. It is rated as endangered. Three or four clumps have been found at the site and it has also been found in the Mokota Conservation Park. There are also a few plants south of Oodla Wirra.

Issue 602, 21 May 2003, page 12

Burra Real Estate

12 Best Place [formerly Clode’s]

6 allotments, residence, offices, shops, showrooms. $180,000

Issue 603, 28 May 2003, page 1

Railway Track Inspection

Australian Rail Group (ARG) ran a locomotive to Burra and Kapunda last Wednesday to inspect the condition of the track. They wanted to use a heavier vehicle than the usual Toyota inspection ute fitted with small guide wheels. While there are no plans to use the lines on a regular basis, there will be infrequent running of a locomotive for inspection purposes. The engine ran first from Dry Creek through Roseworthy to Kapunda and then returned to Roseworthy before going on to Burra. Goyder Council was asked to remove the bitumen seal from the tracks on the heavy vehicle bypass to allow the engine access to the Burra yard.

Burra Railway Station. Goyder Heritage Advisory Committee has accessed a grant from State Heritage Fund for $13,000 to repair verandah posts, guttering and painting at the Burra Railway Station.

BBH Football Club. Robert Sullivan played his 250th game for the club on Saturday.

Goyder Council

The first meeting of Council since the recent elections.

Council proposed to the Geographical Names Advisory Committee that the area northwest of Hallett be named McVitties Flat after William McVittie, who arrived on the Baboo in 1840. The name has been used locally for years.

Council resolved to prepare a brief for a consultant to undertake a feasibility study into the development of the Farrell Flat Airstrip along with a costing study.

Council will ask Transport SA to declare the length of Commercial Street from the end of the 80 km/hr sign to the Council Office in Market Square and Market Square/Market Street to St Joseph’s Lane a 50 km/hr zone. [Along with various other listed changes in the Council area.]

[Issue 604, 4 June 2003, page 1 corrected this to the effect that Council ratified a TSA decision to declare the 50 km/hr zones as listed in the paper.]

Burra Show Society will receive a donation equal to 50% of its rates.

Rate relief for Barkers of Baldina Cottage Homes in Burra was refused.

Issue 603, 28 May 2003, page 2

BBH Football & Netball Club’s Great Burra Barrow Push on Sunday drew twelve teams compared with five the previous year. Winners were ‘Road Ragers’ comprising Kerry Eldredge, Andrea Rowe, Jo Gebhardt & Chris Kerrigan.

Scott Donaldson of Wesfarmers Landmark’s Burra branch was awarded the Golden Gavel Award by the Society of Auctioneers & Appraisers of SA in the Under 29 Years section earlier this month.

Donna Kelly, driving ‘Harvey’ the wonder pony, gained first place in the Novice Pony in the SA Carriage Driving Championships at Owen.

Birth. To Julie & David Hoyle, a son, William James Lloyd. A sixth grandchild for Don Lloyd.

Obituary. Alan Drew of Leighton died on 17 May.

Letter. Flemming Jensen wrote complaining of a marauding band of stray dogs at Burra North attacking bike riders and those walking dogs. On Sunday they entered the writer’s property and killed pet laying hens.

Issue 603, 28 May 2003, page 3

Burra Uniting Church is selling the pews from Redruth Church. They were made from solid Huon pine and ranged in length from five to ten feet. They were offered first to people with a personal connection to the church.

[Personal interest. Many of the pews were inscribed with graffiti, some of them dating back more than a century. For example:

The Burra Record 28 Sep. 1898, page 3

L.R. Fuss (aged 12) won a prize at the 1898 Burra Show for ornamental text, but this example of his skill was not likely to have received such approbation.]

‘Welcome Inn’ ran a morning tea at the Uniting Church Hall as part of Australia’s Biggest Morning Tea fundraiser. $187 was raised for cancer research.

Issue 604, 4 June 2003, page 1

Golf. Burra ladies won the Pennants Final for the first time in 21 years when two Burra ladies’ teams played off on 2 June at Clare. In the final Burra Green defeated Burra Gold.

Stardust Circus is coming to Burra on 16 June at Burra Showgrounds. It is an old time circus with a performing elephant, lions, monkeys, ponies, aerial acts, clowns, etc.

Goyder Safe Community. An informal meeting of people interested in the health and safety of the community resulted in a unanimous ‘Yes’ to the establishment of a Goyder Safe Community Group. An invitation is extended to community groups and individuals to come to the next meeting, which will be held in the Council meeting room at Burra 2 p.m. 30 July. [Just over a column of detail is printed on the background and aims of Safe Communities.]

BCS has three students, Micah Blakey, Steven Haverland and Brendon Hucks, who will go with a teacher Tatiana Anesbury to a dam in the ACT to take part in the Australian Battle Group Inc. Biannual Battle. Teams from across Australia will try to sink each other’s WWI & WWII replica battleships. Teams are required to build radio controlled battleships at 1/144 scale, with a powered cannon and with thin balsa armour. Standards are exacting, with some 50 pages of regulations.

Issue 604, 4 June 2003, page 3

Youth Conservation Corps Program begins.

Three young people have begun working in the program in the Mid North, with three spaces still available to interested parties. One of the projects will be the Burra Restoration of Riparian and Grass Ecosystems Project. It has locations in Mokota, Redbanks, Caroona Creek and Spring Gully Conservation Parks. For two days a week over a twelve week period students will be involved in monitoring water quality, flora and fauna surveys, erosion control, pest control, revegetation, fencing, GPS mapping, site preparation and plant propagation. On day three they will participate in accredited training. After twelve weeks they will join a club where they will put together an employment portfolio and undertake job search training and work experience.

BCS. Nine students attended an art workshop in Pt Pirie last week, studying dance, drama, voice, film and music.

Uniting Church. Frank Tuppin and his wife will begin their ministry in Burra from the start of 2004. Currently they are at Murrayville in Victoria. Lay preachers will conduct services until July, when for three months Rev. Tony Chapman will serve in Burra with his wife, as supply minister.

Issue 605, 11 June 2003, page 1

Weather. Last week produced several days of stormy weather. The only damage seems to have been to a light tower that was toppled at Burra Town Oval.

Goyder Council. There are plans to pave all the protuberances into the street in Burra, removing all plantings except for one tree in the centre. In Market Square the plan would see the central island lawned around the War Memorial and paved to the north. The crazy paving in front of the BankSA would be taken up and the area of lawn extended.

Annette Walker, a former Burra resident and student of Burra Primary and High Schools, now lives at Goolwa. She has just released her junior novel The Drop Kick, a humorous novel for children aged 8-11. She has a second junior novel due for release early next year.

YAC. A committee of four young people – Sarah Earle, Maddie Jonas, Josephine Williams and Amy Wilson, has recently been adopted by the Regional Council of Goyder as their Youth Advisory Committee.

Letter. D.R. Woolley writes wondering just how serious we are about the state of the River Murray when he saw a large stockpile of large diameter pipes alongside the already existing pipeline serving the Clare Valley. It seems the increased supply would be largely to expand the dripper-fed vineyard systems that are rapidly expanding in the area.

Issue 605, 11 June 2003, page 4

Burra Auxiliary of Friends of the Women’s & Children’s Hospital held its 47th AGM. Over the last five years they have raised $15,034. Elected: Patron, Colleen Spackman; President, Leonie Ryan; Secretary, Colleen Spackman and Treasurer, Pat Taylor.

Story of the Redruth Church

The first mention of Redruth is in the circuit minutes in 1859 and later that year Redruth received from the Government an allocation of 20 acres of glebe land and half an acre in the township in Tregonning Street.1

On 2 February 1851 the cornerstone of the first Redruth Chapel was laid.

The Chapel was opened on 4 May 1851. The building cost £260.

The exodus of men to the Victorian gold rush caused the chapel to fail and in 1854 it was dismantled by the trustees. The roof, floor, windows, doors, pulpit and seats were transferred to the new chapel at Spring Farm near Clare.

In 1856 the Burra Burra Circuit was changed to the Kooringa Circuit, of which Redruth was a part.

There was no chapel at Redruth 1854-57.

In 1857 the Kooringa trustees decided to restore the Redruth Chapel by using old windows, seats, the pulpit and part of the roof made available when the Kooringa Chapel was enlarged. This cost £150.

This second Redruth Chapel was opened on 22 April 1857.

In August 1873 the trustees resolved to build the existing chapel in Ludgvan Street at a cost of £1,310.

The front section of the building was added to the existing building,2 with four foundation stones being laid on Thursday 23 April 1874.

On the Sunday services were held in the Lutheran Church at Redruth by Rev. G.W. Patchell in the morning and afternoon. On Monday a tea meeting was held in the old Redruth Chapel, followed by a public meeting in the Lutheran Church.

At the stone laying and opening ceremonies £400 was raised and the rest was borrowed. The building measured 42 ft x 24 ft and would seat 200. The architect was Mr R. Rees and it was built by Mr James Tiver and Mrs Ann Pearce & Sons.

The trustees then decided to build a Sunday school behind the chapel. This was completed in September 1875 in the form of a T-piece at the back of the chapel at a cost of £300.

For want of room this building was annexed as a transept for the church at a later date.3

The Sunday school was transferred to Jubilee Hall 4 – the former Primitive Methodist Chapel.

In 18765 £200 was paid for land near the chapel for a Sunday school and this was opened 7 February 1925, free of debt much to the credit of Mr James Reed.

In 1889 the Redruth Circuit was created – cutting links with the Kooringa Circuit.

The first Redruth minister was Thomas M. Rowe, 1889-90.

United Methodist came in 1900.

The first Methodist minister was Rev. W.H. Rofe, 1900-01.

In 1940 the circuit became Burra-Redruth when Rev. Neil Usher was incumbent.

Rev. A.S. Barratt 1943-46. (Father of Mrs Olive Oates.)

Rev. C.L.H. Pitman 1947-50.

1951 Rev. C. Christopher was followed by Rev. D. Haydon, Rev. R. Jenner and Rev. M. Edwards.

Redruth Church closed as a centre for regular worship in 1970, since when all services have been at the Kooringa (Burra) Church.

The Redruth Trust Committee then decided that the property would become a conference and camping centre and additions and changes were made. The church building was made available as a worship centre for campers.

[1. Tregony Street.

  1. This makes no sense. The two buildings were on different sites. All the evidence suggests that the second chapel was on the site of the first. The cost cited alone suggests the original walls were reused. The Tregony street property was sold only in 1876 and circumstantial evidence suggests it was used as a private school.

  2. This was done in 1879.

  3. This is at best misleading. In 1879 the Sunday school was transferred to the Lutheran Church and the Wesleyans continued to use this until Methodist Union. The Methodist Church continued to use it until the Jubilee Hall became available in 1902 – a total of c. 23 years. The Primitive Methodist Chapel became available in theory from 1900, but it was in a poor state of repair and before it could be used the rear wall was demolished and rebuilt ten feet further back. The enlarged building became available for use only in 1902.

  4. Actually in 1882.]

Issue 605, 11 June 2003, page 5

Nigel Winzar retired from Adchem after 28 years of service. Twenty-five employees of Adchem attended a dinner celebrating his retirement on 28 May. Nigel started work with Adelaide & Wallaroo Fertilizers at Pt Lincoln in 1974 as Works Chemist. He later became Production Superintendent of Fertilizers at Pt Adelaide. In November 1983 he was appointed Technical (later Project) Superintendent. This role involved technical support for the Burra operation as well as evaluation of Leigh Creek and Mt Gunson mining leases. He visited Burra weekly at that time. He was involved in the commissioning of the Mt Gunson plant in 1987 and moved to Burra full-time in November that year. He later became Quality Assurance Manager with a leading role in establishing ISO 9002 accreditation for copper oxide production. He has overseen the operation of the plant to record production levels over the last two years and has a reputation as a dedicated and loyal employee over 28 years with Adelaide & Wallaroo Fertilizers, Adelaide Chemical Company and Adchem.

Diabetes. After a recent Diabetes Information Day, it has been decided to form a Diabetes Support Group in Burra. The first meeting will be held on 17 June at 1.30 p.m. in Chris’s Kitchen.

Burra Red Cross held its AGM recently. The year’s Red Cross Baby was Declan Bitter, son of Lisa & Thym Bitter. Elected were: President, F. Jones; Vice-Presidents, L. Ryan & P. Venning; Secretary, J. Coathupe; Treasurer, P. Kakoschke and Assistant Treasurer, J. Lunn.

Issue 606, 18 June 2003, page 1

Stardust Circus was a sell-out on Monday with c. 300 attending.

Burra Girl Guides have collected c. $500 for the Salvation Army Red Shield Appeal and are still going.

Accidents

A van and trailer coming east on the Booborowie Road were completely destroyed when the driver failed to give way at the T-junction with the Barrier Highway.

A single vehicle roll-over in fog occurred on the Farrell Flat-Black Springs Road on 15 June.

Goyder’s Line has been added to the BankSA Heritage Icons List.

Issue 606, 18 June 2003, page 2

Betty Pens has compiled a brief history of the Burra Women’s Agricultural Bureau, which operated 1983-99. It was instigated in March 1983 by Freda Pink of Basin Farm and the first President was Pat Brereton, with Betty Pens as Vice-President, and Janet Slade as Secretary-Treasurer. In 1994 the Clare and Burra branches merged, but numbers were so low in 1999 that it was decided to close. The minutes, banner and this history book were lodged in the Local History Room of the Burra Community Library.

Issue 606, 18 June 2003, page 3

BCS students have been visiting the Quilt Exhibition at the Burra Gallery in groups over the past month. They were also able to see artist Glenys Christopher working on a still life.

Issue 606, 18 June 2003, page 5

Burra Regional Art Gallery has new exhibitions. The main gallery and its annexe features regional artists and the Bence Room shows works of Burra Art Society artists.

Issue 606, 18 June 2003, page 11

Market Square Snack Bar will be closed at 3 p.m. on 22 June to allow for the transfer of the business from Gerry Baulderstone & Jo Van Gasteren to Peter & Tressna [Martin].

Issue 607, 25 June 2003, page 1

The Market Square/Best Place Development Plan is to Proceed

Work is already underway in the area adjacent to the Council Office. Elements include:

Extending the car parking in front of the Council Office

Replacing grass and concrete around the rotunda with pavers

Upgrading the concrete island in Market Square

Negotiations are continuing with ETSA about the lighting upgrade including underground cables

New street trees will be planted

Public information signs will be made uniform

The plan will be implemented over a number of years

Goyder Council aims for a rate rise of 5% from 2002-03 for the coming year. Their preferred option is a fixed charge of $150, a rate rise of 10% in the Burra town area, 8% in Eudunda and 4% in the rural area.

Peter Harris has been appointed Senior Authorised Officer of the Goyder Animal & Plant Control Board. He has a family background in pastoral and farming areas and his recent experience in pastoral areas. His role is to promote an advisory service, to identify, control and eradicate proclaimed pests and inform and advise the public and agricultural community of obligations and responsibilities under the Animal & Plant Control Act.

Issue 607, 25 June 2003, page 2

Letter. Sue Ryan writes as Co-ordinator Burra Community School, to thank those who provided a series of work placements for Adam Jones in the last six months or so.

Letter. Paula Illicevs writes to say farewell, having been the postie in Burra for the last 31⁄2 years.

Letter. D.R. Woolley writes, concerned at the lack of police coverage in Burra and Eudunda. He wonders whether the answer is volunteer police aides as he believes has been tried in Broken Hill.

Burra Senior Citizens held its 23rd birthday celebrations at the Leisure Activities Centre 19 June.

Thorogoods of Burra received an excellent review of their apple wines in the last Food & Wine Supplement in the Advertiser – ‘Burra Old Sleepy’ 1999 and ‘Sweet Panic Apple Liqueur’.

[Born 8 November 1919 in Aberdeen.]

Issue 607, 25 June 2003, page 3

Peter & Tressna Martin, formerly of Darwin, have bought the Market Square Snack Bar and have renamed it the ‘Cook o’ Burra’.

New Life for Scroop Park, Burra North1

Over the years the tennis courts at Burra North and their associated amenities block have fallen into disuse. Council is currently removing the amenities block and taking up the court surface,2 before asking the community for ideas on future use.

[1 The name Scroop Park was an informal one. At least from the establishment of the playground there in 1923 this area was known as Lowe Park. It was named after Mr Charles Lowe 1854-1925. Until 1921 he lived at Redruth where he had a bakery near to the park. He was also a member of the Town Council, representing North Ward from December 1907 to November 1913. The name Scroop Park certainly derived from much later. In March 1972 the Aberdeen Tennis Club erected gate pillars at the entrance to the Aberdeen Tennis Courts in appreciation of Mr & Mrs Scroop’s 30 years of service (1940-70) as joint secretary-treasurers of the club and for the many hours spent working in this sports area. (Syd. Scroop 1904-83 and Florrie Scroop nee Hirschausen 1905-91) Thirty odd years later the bronze plaques were stolen, but the pillars were left there when they were enclosed in the Off Leash Dog Park in late 2014.

2The surfaces of five courts were still there in 2016.]

Council has voted to inform police of its concern about the excess noise in the vicinity of the caravan park and acts of vandalism in the town.

Burra Town Hall stage and associated equipment has been upgraded over recent weeks. This brings the stage to a standard to be included in SA Country Performing Arts Touring Program. The first such performance will be the comedy Reserved Seats Only on 8 June [sic: error for 8 July]

[Details of the upgrade are printed.]

Issue 608, 2 July 2003, page 1

BCS is to receive $508,400 for maintenance to its buildings. It will be spent on:

Roof replacement on the old building.

Upgrading of science laboratory to meet health and safety standards

Heating and cooling upgrades.

Speed Limits. On 30 June a number of connecting roads in the Mid North had their speed limit reduced from 110 km/hr to the 100 km/hr default speed limit. [They are then listed.]

Issue 608, 2 July 2003, page 2

Letter. Tiffany Murray writes as her term as Project Manager at Burra Cultural Centre comes to an end. She was pleased to have seen the Town Hall gain an industrial kitchen, a state of the art Telecentre, a wonderful Mary Warnes Meeting Room and new stage lighting system and new stage curtains. She introduced Carly Heinrich, who was located in the Community Internet & Computer Centre and had taken over Town Hall Bookings from 1 July.

Telstra held an information meeting at Burra Town Hall last Tuesday on their ADSL & ISDN phone and internet service. ISDN type phone connection is available within 17 km of a telephone exchange and offers a faster and more reliable phone hook-up than standard dial-up. ADSL service is not available to country towns.

Issue 608, 2 July 2003, page 3

Julie Keane is the new postie in Burra from 1 July.

Issue 608, 2 July 2003, pages 4 & 5

Article celebrating Burra Community Print’s 10th Birthday

[Actually this date celebrated the 10th anniversary of Terry Wilson’s arrival as owner/editor and the transformation of the publication from a largely advertising medium to a more conventional newspaper. The Burra Broadcaster began in 1991 and the information in the 100th issue indicates that Burra Community Print predated the Burra Broadcaster:

Issue 100, 24 February 1993 page 1: The Burra Broadcaster

This issue is the 100th since changing to the present format. All in all the advertising medium put out by the Burra Community Print has seen 415 editions and editorial comment has been running for 112 editions. The Broadcaster began when BCP moved to new premises in December 1990.

In fact the origin of Burra Community Print as a business appears to be in August 1984, with an announcement in Burra School & Community News of 16 August 1984

[An insert] Burra Community Print 7 Bridge Terrace, Burra.

From the beginning of August we announce a new printing service for Burra and the Surrounding Areas.

Design – Artwork – Print – Collate – Bind

Trevor Walshaw.

The reference to editions before January 1991 is unclear, but presumably refers to material distributed by insertion in Burra School & Community News. I have noted advertising inserts in that publication from 1985 onwards. These insertions were certainly printed by Burra Community Print and frequently carried large advertisements for that business.]

When Terry Wilson took over in 1993 there was one casual employee, Cory Heneker who then became an apprentice. Within a few months the business needed another employee and Julie Pawelski was taken on as a Graphic Arts apprentice. The business was then located where Mongolata Gold now operates, but this proved too small and a move was made to the Jennison Building, which had previously housed Burra Video and Photographics. Equipment was updated, allowing full colour works and the whole gamut of commercial printing. The opportunity to offer the Eudunda community a newspaper content they had not enjoyed for more than twenty years was a challenge that was eagerly embraced. An office was opened in Pt Pirie and one briefly in Pt Augusta. Danny Smith completed his apprenticeship with Burra Community Print early in 2003. Helen Stockman has been the editor for much of this year. Burra Community Print produced Maureen & Barry Wright’s 7th edition of their book River Murray Chart; a project involving more than three tonnes of paper and board. [5 photos.]

Issue 609, 9 July 2003, page 1

The National Bank’s Community Fund for 2002 has been allocated as follows:

Burra Kindergarten $156.50 to assist with PVC blinds.

Burra Show Committee $45 towards printing costs.

Burra Clare Snowtown Health Services $94.50 for a fountain pump at Burra Hospital.

Burra Leisure activity Group $399 for a Janome sewing machine.

Burra Pony Club $305 to provide a shade area.

‘Belcunda’ 19 km north of Burra has been sold by Jim Litchfield’s Hazeldean Company to neighbouring Collinsville for $3 million.

Hazeldean will continue to rub its East Bungaree & Hazeldean seedstock interests. It is understood Collinsville will sell some other property, in order to purchase ‘Belcunda’ and so benefit from it as forming a contiguous parcel.

Saltbush Clothing is a finalist in the 2003 Retailer of the year Award, Regional Category.

Goyder House Boarding Facility

Maxine Lucas, who has been ‘Mum’ for the last five years to students boarding at Goyder House, was farewelled recently. She is moving to Quorn. [Photo]

BCS. Judy Hawker will move to Clare High School for the remainder of the year.

Father Laurence Joseph Quinn celebrated the fortieth anniversary of his ordination on Sunday 29 June. A special celebration was held at Burra Town Hall attended by many relatives, friends and parishioners. Fr Laurie was brought up on the Quinn family farm at Mt Bryan and after study at St Francis Xavier’s Seminary in Adelaide, was ordained in St Joseph’s Church, Burra on 29 June 1963. He has since served at Whyalla, Loxton and Pt Lincoln before returning to Burra on 31 January 2000.

Theft. Plants have been taken from the Senior Citizen’s Garden of the Burra Creek bank.

Tony & Natalie Chapman have been welcomed to the Burra Uniting Church. They will be here for three months, pending the arrival of the new minister.

Issue 609, 9 July 2003, page 3

Burra Senior Citizens held their AGM on 3 July. Elected for 2003-04 were President, Shirley Broad; Secretary, Laurel Neill and Treasurer, Ben Kotz.

Tourist Railways

An article on how the public liability insurance problem is causing these to close across the country. For example, Steamtown Peterborough ceased operating trains in 2002, Pichi Richi Railway Preservation Society is threatening to close, the St Kilda Tramway Museum stopped public rides on 1 May 2003 and is confined to static exhibits and the Limestone Coast Railway in the South East ceased operations last week.

Issue 609, 9 July 2003, page 5

Clode’s Pty Ltd.

A half page article on Clode’s Pty Ltd – Mid North Funeral and Bereavement Services and their new establishment at Clare. Also a half page advertisement for same. [2 photos]

Issue 610, 16 July 2003, page 1

Burra Parks

A new Friends of Parks group is being formed to help conserve the national parks reserves in the Burra area, such as Caroona Creek, Redbanks, Mokota and Pandappa. The parks are quite diverse in nature.

Pandappa lies east of Terowie and grades from rocky hill country to chenopod scrubland and mallee. It covers 1,100 ha and is noted for its birdlife.

Caroona grades from spectacular rocky ridges with great views of the eastern rangelands to mallee vegetation and scrubland intersected by creek lines with fresh water springs and plenty of bird and animal life.

Mokota is 500 ha of grassland with more than 200 species of native plants, some of them rare and threatened. Wild flowers are abundant in late winter and spring.

Redbanks contains Baldina Creek with mallee and wildlife. Fossils of note have been found in the area. There is a designated camping area.

Friends of Parks could become involved in conservation of historic and fossil sites, revegetation, pest management, wildlife management, wildlife surveys, writing and information work, administration, photography and fundraising. A meeting is scheduled for 5 August. There are 117 such groups in SA.

The Annual Mt Bryan Soldiers’ Memorial Hall Dinner Dance will be held on 26 July.

Accidents. A single vehicle roll over one kilometre north of Farrell Flat on 12 July resulted in the driver being reported for drink driving.

A cyclist received minor injuries in a collision with a car on Market Street on Monday.

Issue 610, 16 July 2003, page 2

Medicins Sans Frontieres has benefited by $506 from a stall in Market Square last Saturday morning.

Letter. G.F. Shooter of Grange writes as a recent visitor to the Bon Accord Hotel; praising both the décor and the quality of food in their dining area.

Issue 610, 16 July 2003, page 3

Issue 611, 23 July 2003, page 1

Telstra has two new CDMA mobile phone towers at Mintaro and Booborowie. Barry Wakelin MP for Grey launched the service on 16 July. The $564,000 project would greatly boost reception across a wide area. A tower at Hamley Bridge was already in service and towers at Saddleworth, Snowtown and Mallala would be up by August.

Goyder Council at its July meeting adopted the rate for 2003-04. The differential rates adopted were:

0.7278 cents in the dollar for Burra township

0.4744 for Eudunda township

0.3867 for all land in the Hallett and Robertstown Wards and for remaining areas of Burra and Eudunda Wards.

This represents an increase of 8% in Burra town rates and 5% in the rural areas and 5.5% over the Council area as a whole.

Reminder Notice

The Goyder Animal & Plant Control Board has moved from the Regional Council of Goyder Office to 2 Kingston Street in Burra.

Letter. Glenys Christopher of Ford’s Corner writes to thank all students and staff of BCS who planted trees along the boundary of their Brewery Hill property and Kooringa Road.

Judith Hubbard is the new house-parent at Goyder House Boarding Facility. She comes from Wilderness College and has a teaching background stretching back more than 20 years.

Issue 612, 30 July 2003, page 1

Burra Show Society is holding a ‘Survival Gig’ in Burra Town Hall on Saturday 6 September. The aim is to raise funds to help with the public liability premium, which has risen 30% from last year.

The Miss BBH contest at the Sports Complex last Saturday night raised $463.60 for the club. Miss BBH for 2003 is Boh ‘Dizzy Lizzy’ Wall.

A ‘Doctors & Nurses’ Night at the Bon Accord Hotel raised $500 for the Burra Hospital.

Burra Regional Art Gallery will have two new exhibitions from 1 august. Recent Works by Clare Valley Artists will feature in the Main Gallery and Annexe and in the Len Bence Room there will be works of Renata Plane.

Issue 612, 30 July 2003, page 2

Letter. Ike Sab writes expressing concern about plastic bags and other rubbish piling up along fences around the Burra dump.

Letter. Meredith Satchell writes concerning the WWI activities in Burra of the Cheer-Up Society. She was particularly concerned about the fate of some 200 photographs that once graced the walls of the Cheer-Up Room in Pearce’s Buildings. She says that she and Eric Fuss are researching details of the district’s WWI soldiers, with a view to publishing a book detailing them and the references to the in the Burra Record. She appeals for any photographs that would enhance the publication.

KESAB visited Burra recently and inspected the gardens of two entrants; Shirley Broad and the Burra Senior Citizens’ Project. [Details of the latter are printed.]

Issue 612, 30 July 2003, page 3

Letter. B. Wilson writes concerning bullying in the junior school at BCS.

Burra Cycling Classic is to be held this weekend, 2 & 3 August. The classic event this year is to be dedicated to the memory of the late Vic. Dodman. Vic was a dedicated cyclist who competed for more than 60 years. He was a keen amateur as a teenager and a professional in his 20s. After a bad fall he had to retire in 1949. At the age of 51 he made a comeback when doctors recommended ‘a little exercise’. He trained some 300 to 400 miles a week and in 1968 won the Adelaide to Burra Race. He then went to Victoria for the Lakes Entrance Race of 197 miles, coming 7th. He came 5th in the Melbourne-Warrnambool race of 161 miles. He travelled to Europe and competed in a number of veterans’ events. He continued to compete in Australia till illness forced his retirement, when he moved to Burra with his wife, Gill. The 2002 event was won by Brian Toseland, a cousin of the famous Deane Toseland, who took fastest time honours in 1938. This year’s event will feature a race to Eudunda and back over 140 km. There will be junior races in the afternoon and on Sunday an 8.5 km town course. [Photo of Vic. Dodman in 1978.]

Issue 612, 30 July 2003, page 4

Market Square Fire Station. The stobie pole adjacent to the station was used for years to dry fire hoses. It was removed last Tuesday. [Photo]

Issue 613, 6 August 2003, page 1

Fire broke out in a kitchen of a house in Thames Street on Monday night. It was quickly extinguished, but left a bill of c. $50,000 damage. [14 Thames Street.]

Burra Telecentre has proved popular with locals who have found a need to expand their computing skills.

Burra Regional Art Gallery. Two new exhibitions were opened on Friday night by the Chairman of the Goyder Regional Council, Laurie Sullivan. They are ‘Recent Works of Clare Valley Artists’ and ‘Women Dreaming’ by Renata Gilli Plane.

Other locals competing were Kathy Nicholls, Tracey Rains and Rifka Kelly.

The Annual Booborowie reunion will be held on 27 August in the Old London Tavern in the basement of the Myer Centre.

Burra Boxer, Drew Nottle had his first amateur bout in Adelaide on 12 July. Fighting in the 60 kg division, he scored a knockout in the second round.

Accident. A trailer came loose from the rear of a truck on Monday 4 August and collided with the rear of a parked car at Water’s Bakery. It inflicted about $8,000 damage to the car.

Burra Real Estate

Issue 614, 13 August 2003, page 1

Burra Burra Branch of the National Trust was a winner at the inaugural Edmund Wright Heritage Awards, receiving the Minister’s Award for Outstanding Contribution. The award was accepted by the Branch Secretary Susan Parker and Chairman, Maureen Wright. [Photo]

Liberal Party Dinner. Dean Brown, Shadow Minister for Health was the guest speaker. He said that as a result of the Government’s Generational Health Review, local hospital boards could go and their powers be transferred to regional boards, which would be non-representative. The Mayors of Goyder Council and Clare & Gilbert Valley Council voiced their concern at this possibility. Mr Brown said country people were losing out under the Rann Government through cuts to services and insufficient funding and the closure of some obstetric services.

Weather. An unexpected cold snap hit the Mid North last week. While a few snowflakes were reported from the Barossa, Hallett and Peterborough areas, Burra experienced low temperatures and sleet.

Issue 614, 13 August 2003, page 2

Chris Lauder has set up a wool shop next to Polly’s in Commercial Street until 20 August.

Burra Red Cross Baby for 2013 is Jackson Irlam, son of Petrice Messenger and Richard Irlam. Their 2002 baby, Declan Little, came 2nd in Category 5 of the competition.

Letter. Dennis & Pam Parker of Peterborough write with advice about Peterborough’s ‘Back to Peterborough’ event planned for the October long weekend and marking the district and town’s 150th anniversary.

[Geoffrey Manning says the land on which the town stands was first held under pastoral lease no. 30 by Alexander McCulloch from July 1851. The town was laid out in 1880 when J.H. Koch, unable to sell his farm, subdivided it instead into town allotments.]

Carly Heinrich of Burra Internet Centre has been selected as one of ten state wide finalists for ‘Trainee of the Year’ awards.

St Dymphna’s Catholic Church at Booborowie is celebrating its centenary in September 2003.

It was blessed and opened for worship on 20 September 1903. The blessing was conducted by Rt Rev. Monsignor Byrne VG, assisted by Rev. Fr O’Dowling SJ. It was built on a block of land acquired for £10-10-0. The architect was Mr John G. Hogan and the builder was Mr Pomeroy, assisted by Mr Bob Morris. Tim & Joe Kelly dug the foundations and local stone was used. In the 1920s a chancel, sanctuary and front porch were added. In 1930 a small room was added on western side for overnight stays by the priest. A centenary mass will be held on 14 September at 10.30 a.m. [Photo of the building.]

Issue 614, 13 August 2003, page 3

Burra Community Library will be 25 years old next month. There have been changes recently. There is lower shelving in the non-fiction area and new Easy Fiction, Magazine and Video shelves. Non-fiction shelving has been swung from an east-west orientation to north-south.

Friends of Burra Parks was proclaimed as the 125th Friends of Parks group in SA at Burra recently. About 50 people attended. Elected were: Patrons, Chris Reed & Stephen Kerrigan; President, Ms Heidi Nicholson; Assistant President, Ms Sally Nieman; Vice President, Robert Heading and Treasurer, Libby Hallion.

[Details of possible activities as previously noted are repeated.]

Issue 614, 13 August 2003, page 4

Burra Kindergarten will host a Party Plan and Home business Expo at Burra Town Hall on Friday 15 August with 19 exhibitors. Admission of $2 will aid the Kindergarten.

The Burra Cycling Classic was won by Mathew Rex, by a good length from Olympian Brett Aitken on a five rider sprint for the line. Rex is an under 19 rider and was even more excited on Sunday when he took out the double by winning the A Grade criterion. [Other results are printed.]

BCS was the inaugural winner of the Area Schools Best Practice Awards at the SA Area Schools Leaders association Annual Conference, held in Clare this week.

Issue 615, 20 August 2003, page 1

Jazz in the Monster Mine Committee has made donations to three Burra organisations:

$1,500 will be shared among the Hospital Auxiliary, the Regional Art Gallery and the Lower north Leisure Activity Group.

The Committee spent money this year at the mine on electrical installations, which will reduce future hire costs, so profits should improve next year.

Pigmy Blue Tongue Lizards have attracted the interest of Australian fauna smugglers. A trespasser was observed behaving suspiciously on Thorogood’s grassland recently and on 15 August many diggings were found on the sanctuary where a trespasser had been digging for the lizard.

Pet Kangaroos Killed. One night last week two dogs that had escaped from the Council’s pound killed the seven kangaroos at Chris and Maria Reed’s and maimed a further six sheep belonging to Henry Lunn, so that they had to be destroyed. The oldest of the kangaroos had been at Reed’s for more than 15 years. There have been kangaroos on the Morehead Street property for most of the years since the 1920s. The kangaroos will be replaced.

Issue 615, 20 August 2003, page 2

Goyder Council has received a grant of $12,487 to subsidise a Natural Disaster Risk Management Study Program. The local Government Act requires Councils to have a disaster mitigation plan. Earthtech Engineering will undertake the study. They will gather data on the history of natural disasters in the region and seek information, including photos of past disasters from people.

Peter Quinn, son of Jim & Rosemary Quinn recently graduated in Law from Adelaide University. He did his secondary schooling at BCS.

Birth. To Meg & Will Nolan on 13 August, a son, Lachlan William Harvey.

Birth. To Tanya & Jamie Murphy on 11 August, twins, Jack James & Mikayla Allyson.

Birth. To Michelle & Steve Berryman on 9 August, a daughter, Kloe Ann.

Jim & Rosemary Quinn will celebrate their 50th Wedding Anniversary on 22 August.

Clarrie & Elsie Hore have celebrated their 60th Wedding Anniversary. Clarrie was Kooringa Methodist minister at Burra during the 1970s. [1972-75.]

Kimberley Stocker has graduated with a Retail Certificate levels one and two. She has been working at Burra Stationers and Newsagency.

The Burra Kindergarten Party Plan & Home Business Expo was a success with 22 different businesses represented and more than 150 patrons.

Issue 616, 27 August 2003, page 1

Weather. A storm on 23-24 August resulted in some minor flooding, a blackout in some areas of the district and an uprooted tree in Queen Street. The Burra Creek flowed for the first time in five or six years and it was added to by flows from Springbank Creek and Firewood Creek. Over 50 mm fell in four to five days.

Some areas of the town were blacked out by an electrical storm in the early hours of Saturday.

Goyder Council has three new appointments.

John Brak has been appointed planner.

Kate Esser has been appointed grants officer.

Stephen Woolley is the new General Inspector – a role shared with the Clare and Gilbert Valleys Council.

BBH Auction on Saturday night was successful in raising considerable funds for the Social Club. Highlights of the evening were the sales of signed and framed Port Power and Crows Guernseys. Ian Williamson bid $900 for the former and Kimberley Field paid $975 for the latter. [A number of other items that were auctioned are listed.]

Burra CFS held its AGM recently and elected Captain, David Nourse; 1st Lieutenant, Mark Bellman; 2nd Lieutenant, Michael Freak; 3rd Lieutenant, Chris Taylor and 4th Lieutenant, John Taylor. The CFS is looking for new members.

Issue 616, 27 August 2003, page 2

Blyth and Clare Uniting Church Congregations write to the Editor advising that those congregations do not agree with or accept the decision of the National Assembly of the Uniting Church allowing practising homosexuals to be ordained for ministry in the church, believing that to be contrary to Holy Scripture and an assault on the family.

Graham Radford and Matt Reilly of Burra have purchased four houseboats from a fleet operator on Lake Eildon in Victoria and intend to base them at Waikerie. (They had considered selling two after refurbishment.)

Theft. A car stolen from Blair Athol on 8 August was found burnt out on 20 August 20 km SE of Burra on the Morgan Road.

The Marrabel Horse Trials scheduled for 23-14 August had to be cancelled due to the wet weather, which made the ground unsafe for riding.

The 7th Balaklava Eisteddfod was held 1-3 August.

Cathy Nicholls was placed 2nd in the Open Contemporary Vocal Section.

Nathaniel O’Brien got an Honourable Merit award in the Junior Contemporary Vocal section.

Issue 616, 27 August 2003, page 3

Launched its Visitor Information Pack on 19 August. It contains information for all of the Goyder Council area and the material is held in a brightly illustrated presentation folder.

Council will continue to be represented in ongoing discussions with other stakeholders re the Farrell Flat Airstrip.

Council will write to Transport SA expressing concern of the Goyder Heritage Advisory Committee about the deteriorating state of the Burra Railway Station.

Councillors agreed to consider providing a disabled parking space outside the Burra Pharmacy.

Issue 616(2), 3 September 2003, page 1

BCS. Twenty-five Year 10 students attended the First Edge Camp at Bungaree Station recently. This is the second year a BCS group has attended such a camp.

AWB Ltd has bought Wesfarmers Landmark for $718 million. The Wesfarmers business will continue as Landmark – an AWB Company.

Greg Drew, Senior geologist with the Department of Industry and Resources was guest speaker at the National Trust AGM, on the topic The Burra Mine Revisited. He invited those interested to join him the following morning in a walk through the buddle pit area. He explained the place to about ten people who came out on a crisp cold morning.

Issue 617, 10 September 2003, page 1

BCS students had great success at the Royal Adelaide Show last week. They won Grand Champion on hook and hoof for their Shorthorn steer and also won the Lightweight Champion on the hook with a Red Poll.

Wendy Smith, IT Manager for SA Tourism Commission will speak on Atlas and IT Systems.

Anthony Perre, Tourism Accreditation Manager will address the value of accreditation.

David Row of SA Tourism Commission Industry Department will present an inspirational video on Pike’s Fish business.

‘The Survival Gig’ at the Burra Town Hall on Saturday night attracted c. 150 and was very encouraging for the Burra Show Society.

SA Tourism Commission members visited Burra on 3 September.

Letter from D.R. Woolley, who is in the process of forming a discussion group to consider the problems of vandalism, hoon driving and theft in Burra and their causes.

Megan Brooks has been successful in athletics this year at National Youth Championships (Track & Field) in Sydney in March, where she came 8th in U18 3,000 m and 7th in the U16 3,000 m.

In April she won the Pt Pirie 12 km Fun Run.

In May she came 3rd in the Clare Valley Fun Run.

In June she won the Barossa 5 km Fun Run.

In July she won the Pichi Richi 10 km Run.

In August in the National Cross Country Championships in Melbourne she was placed10/44 in U16 Division.

In the National Schools Cross Country Championships in Brisbane she came 13/40 in the U16 4 km event.

Issue 618, 17 September 2003, page 3

Vandalism at the Paxton Square Cottages on 26 august resulted in the police reporting 5 local youths.

BCS. A lengthy article gives further details of the students’ successes at the Royal Adelaide Show with led steers and led goats.

Toni Gisi has started Goyder Auto Service at the rear of the BP Service Station. In the late 1960s his parents Vic & Lotte Gisi started a car repair business in what is now known as the Bazaar Building. [Next to the BP Service Station.] The business was H.V. & L. Gisi Auto & Electrical Repairs. In time Toni was employed as an apprentice. After completing his apprenticeship, Toni worked for BEA Mercedes in Adelaide and then Frank Wann Motors. He has now returned to Burra to establish a car repair business. [Photo and advertisement.]

Issue 618, 17 September 2003, page 5

Heysen Trail. A group of Friends of the Heysen Trail have made Burra their base for four walking weekends, as part of a series of programmed walks to eventually complete the 1,200 l, trail from Cape Jervis to Parachilna. [Further details and photo]

Issue 618, 17 September 2003, page 6

Marriage. St Columba’s Church. Hawthorne, 6 September

Trent Waters, oldest son of Raelene and Graham Waters, married Jayne MacDonald. They will live in Adelaide. [Photo]

Issue 618, 17 September 2003, page 14

Burra Real Estate

12 Kangaroo St, Burra [Former Wesleyan/Methodist Manse], $230,000

Kooringa Lodge No. 6, $70,000

The Chook House Café [Corner of Lloyd & Commercial Streets], shop with working kitchen and dining area, 2 large storage sheds, toilet facilities, cellar and laneway access.

Issue 619, 24 September 2003, page 1

The Austin 7 Club visited Burra last week. They were on their ‘Flinders Odyssey’ celebrating the 50th anniversary of the SA Austin 7 Club.

Wind Prospect Pty Ltd is proposing to develop a wind farm in the Mt Bryan-Hallett area. The proposal is for up to 150 wind energy turbines to produce up to 300 MW. They would be 3-bladed multi-pitched horizontal axis machines at a height of 110 m (tower plus blade in vertical position.). They would be located in five clusters on the mounts and ranges. The feasibility study will include a qualified heritage consultant to cover indigenous and non-indigenous heritage values.

Burra Pool. There is serious doubt that the Burra Pool will open this year. The existing pool coating has failed and tenders have been called for tiling the pool. There is also an issue with the Department of Education, Training and Employment in finalising the Joint-Use Agreement with the Council. This should have been resolved soon after the construction of the pool in 1993. Council has resolved not to accept any tender until Council has ownership of the pool and the Joint-Use Agreement has been agreed upon. The swimming season normally starts on 4 November.

Issue 619, 24 September 2003, page 2

Lee Amber is the proprietor of a new antique store that has opened at 12 Best Place. [Photo]

Issue 619, 24 September 2003, page 3

BRTBA sponsored a forum on marketing at Burra Hotel last week.

[See Issue 617, 10 September 2003, page 1 for details.]

Goyder Council invites applicants for another round of heritage funding.

Issue 619, 24 September 2003, page 11

Advt. BRTBA Film Night at Burra Town Hall

26 September Lizzie McGuire

Terminator 3

Issue 620, 1 October 2003, page 1

Burra Community & Sports Club presented two Life Memberships on 26 September. They went to Di Day and Trevor Wall for Outstanding Service. Di Day has been Treasurer for 23 years, after taking over from Colin Baker. She has had a number of other executive tasks in that time, as well as being a member of the Ladies’ Auxiliary. Trevor Wall has been a committee member since its inception, holding many positions, including President and Bar Manager for ten years. He is currently Vice President. The Burra Community & Sports Club was formed in 1979 for the purpose of improving facilities at Burra War Memorial Oval.

McCafferty’s Greyhound Bus Service between Sydney and Adelaide via Broken hill will cease in late October 2003. It currently runs through Burra, Hallett, Whyte Yarcowie and Terowie three days a week. Fifty people have used the service to or from Burra between 1 January and 31 July 2003.

Wind Prospect Pty Ltd has announced the commencement of a feasibility study into the Hallett Wind Farm Proposal. A public exhibition on the proposal will be held at Hallett Hall on Friday 17 October from 3 p.m. to 8 p.m. This will provide information and highlight the virtues of the farm and discuss any issues. About 150 turbines are proposed, connected via underground electric cables to the power grid.

Mid North Regional Development Board (MNRDB) has delivered results. Some major achievements in 2002-03:

Baiada Eudunda – a $700,000 capital investment in poultry expansion

O’Leary Walker Winery established at Leasingham, representing a $6.9 million investment

Clode’s Funeral Parlour at Clare – a $650,000 capital investment

Coffee n’ Cork restaurant and wine outlet in Clare – a $600,000 investment

Glenbower-Eudunda – a new $4 million piggery

2 CDMA mobile phone towers with a total investment of $564 million.

The Clare Valley Water Scheme construction has commenced – a $28 million scheme overall

Consultants are working on a report on the Bower District intensive primary production zone concept

Burra Community Library celebrated its 25th anniversary with an afternoon tea on Wednesday 24 September.

Sarah Putzke has begun as an apprentice in Graphic Design-Prepress at Burra Community Print.

Marriage. 4 October

Kym Harvey, son of Marie & Graham Harvey of Porter Lagoon, married Michelle Redden, daughter of David & Ann Redden.

David Burgess, Kate McGarry and daughter Olivia left Burra this weekend. David had been the Anglican priest at St Mary’s for more than two years. There was a farewell lunch on 27 September.
