Issue 620, 1 October 2003, page 14

Burra Real Estate

Mill Cottage, 2 Mill Street, Burra, $168,000

Issue 620(2), 8 October 2003, page 1

Premier Mike Rann visited Burra en route to Adelaide from Pt Pirie last Wednesday. He undertook to get a resolution to the Burra Swimming Pool impasse. It appears that defining the boundary of the land to transfer to Council had been one sticking point, but when this had been agreed as the land within the pool’s perimeter fence, the Department’s manager then could not accept the terms of use agreed to by the school and council in 1997. [Details are printed.]

Mr Rann also had a look at the Burra Hospital. The Government recently announced an extra $20 million over the next four years for country hospitals.

He then visited the Smelts Road facility occupied by SES & MFS and stopped also at the closed Burra Railway Station with Heritage Officer Douglas Alexander and Brenton Greenslade, Vice President of BRTBA.

[3 photos]

Chris & Maria Reed have been offered a number of kangaroos to replace those recently killed at ‘Wandillah’ in Morehead Street. There are two or three in residence with more to come.

Burra Visitor Centre has received two grants from SA Tourism Commission. $5,000 will aid the development of the Heartland Heritage Trail between Burra, Mintaro, Auburn, Two Wells, Gawler, Kapunda and Eudunda. A grant of $7,790 will go towards upgrading disabled access to the side [?] of the Visitor Centre and to new shelving and staff training.

Issue 620(2), 8 October 2003, page 2

Burra Red Cross held a trading table on Saturday morning, raising funds for the branch’s Baby of the Year for 2003.

BRTBA farewelled Bob & Lorraine Howell and Linda & Ian Williamson recently. Bob & Lorraine have run Burra Motor Inn for the past nine years and Linda & Ian have been the publicans at the Commercial Hotel for five years.

Cheryl Day has been selected in the North Eastern Netball Association’s A1 Team of the Year.

BBN Netball Club has conferred Life Membership on Sharyn Roberts. Her involvement with the club and the Burra Club prior to that goes back at least to 1980. In that time she has been a coach and umpire for many years and served on the committee, holding many executive positions throughout that period. [A detailed history is printed.]

[Other life members are pictured with her: Hazel Stockman, Jenny (nee Hirschausen), Di Day, Mich. Phin and Robyn Baker.]

Letter. David Hook writes as President of the BBH Football Club expressing his disappointment at the lack of coverage afforded the NEFL & NENA football and netball grand finals. Over 4,000 people attended and injected much money into the clubs and the community.

Issue 620(2), 8 October 2003, page 3

Burra’s Op Shop has donated a wheelchair or more correctly a transporter to the Burra Medical Centre for the use of patients.

Thorogood’s Apple Wines helped to host a breakfast at Tateham’s Restaurant at Auburn over the weekend. Up to 120 national and international journalists are currently showcasing areas of SA during the Tasting Australia event. In a day in the Clare Valley they had the opportunity to task local wines, olive oil blends, Burra Saltbush Hogget, free range grain fed chicken, handmade condiments, carob products, blue gum honey and of course, Thorogood’s Apple Wines.

Burra Regional Art Gallery. The Art of the Flower exhibition was opened at the gallery on Friday night (the 5th year of the event). 108 paintings were submitted this year and the winner was Robert Hannaford with an oil painting of roses. The People’s Choice is still being voted for. Running concurrently in the Bence Room is the exhibition ‘It’s My Party’ by Glenys Christopher – a display of portraits to mark her 60th birthday.

Issue 621, 15 October 2003, page 1

Burra Red Cross. A stall run by Burra’s Baby contestant Jackson Irlam’s mother, Petrice Messenger, raised $600 for Red Cross on 4 October.

The ‘20 Ghost’ Club brought 21 Rolls Royces to Burra on Tuesday morning. The group was based at Clare for a few days and was en route to Bundaleer Station Homestead. The oldest car dated from 1911.

Accident. On 10 October a car that was parked on a hill at Burra North, without being in gear of having the handbrake engaged, rolled down the slope and crashed into a bathroom and toilet at the rear of a house. No one was injured, but damage to the house was estimated at $20,000.

[An advertisement in the ‘Personal’ column in the issue for 3 December 2003 apologises for this event and reveals that the driver was Richard Bailey-Hill of Mt Bryan.]

Issue 621, 15 October 2003, pages 1 & 5

Burra Show. The 126th show* on Saturday 11 October drew a good crowd with gate takings of $2,272. Dr Tim Simpson opened the Show. The two biggest attractions were the Horses-in-Action and the non-stop action in the shearing shed, where the day started with a demonstration by a lady shearer, Amy Bailey-Hill of Burra.

Prince of Show Samuel Rains

Princess of Show Caitlin Drew

Baby of Show Josephine Rains

Junior Princess of Show Amy Berryman

[Selected results are printed along with 7 photos.]

[* Actually the 111th Burra Show, as a result of years missed due to WWI, WWII and periods of recess.]

[Photo]

Marriage. 11 October

Ben Short, son of Dennis & Natalie Short, married Julia Garrard. They will live at Farrell Flat.

Issue 622, 22 October 2003, page 1

Burra Swimming Pool. In answer to a question in Parliament, the Minister for Education, the Hon. Trish White said that the Joint-Use Agreement would be forwarded to Council this week for its consideration. An easement for draining purposes was also being prepared and should be finished in two weeks. An agreement with SA Water is also needed as only one sewer service feeds both the school and the swimming pool. Council Planner, John Brak says that even if all this goes smoothly there is no certainty that a contractor can be found to do the tiling in time for the season’s opening.

Issue 622, 22 October 2003, page 2

The First Mt Bryan Market Day was a winner. The Mt Bryan Progress association intended it to be a monthly event to raise funds to renovate the tennis clubrooms to be used for community activities.

The World Solar Cycle Challenge 2003 will go from Clare to Kapunda via Burra, Robertstown, Eudunda, Marrabel and Auburn on 25 October.

[Issue 623, 29 October 2003, page 9 has four photos as they passed through Eudunda.]

Burra Open Gardens event will be held this coming weekend. [Gardens are listed.]

Burra Show. Some further results are printed.

BCS will gain access to a counsellor for the first time next year.

Issue 623, 29 October 2003, page 1

SA Museum’s Outback Road Show came to BCS Gymnasium on Thursday 23 October. Students were able to handle meteorites and space objects, excavate fossils from dirt-filled containers and locals could meet and talk with visiting scientists. There was also the opportunity to visit a dig site at Redbanks. [5 photos]

The Minister for Emergency Services, Patrick Conlon visited SES facilities at Burra, Spalding and Jamestown when the State Cabinet met in Clare this week.

The Burra Golf Auction on 19 October grossed $15,000, of which the club will receive 10-15%.

Issue 623, 29 October 2003, page 2

The World Solar Cycle Challenge passed through Burra on Saturday morning. The challenge is held every two years and started in Ceduna on 19 October. The whole route is 1,500 km.

The MG Car Club visited Burra on Saturday.

The Open Gardens event raised $700 for local charities.

Ian & Janet Slade have moved from Burra to their property near Pelican Point on the River. They had spent 25 years at Princess Royal and in that tine had been active in the community. Ian is a Past President of the Burra Show Society and both were involved in the Burra Boy Scouts and Ian has been a Board Member for Barkers of Baldina Aged Cottages.

Issue 623, 29 October 2003, page 3

Letter from Anthony Thorogood appealing for people to come forward and save Terowie, which is slowly disappearing from a combination of neglect, apathy and vandalism.

Issue 623, 29 October 2003, page 13

Advt. ‘WANTED OLD SINGER PETAL [!] SEWING MACHINE

Issue 623, 29 October 2003, Supplement

Advertising feature:

Mega Health News, Issue 4 2003: 8 pages of advertising for health supplements etc.

Issue 624, 5 November 2003, page 1 [Wrongly dated on page 1 only as 5 October 2003.]

Burra Swimming Pool

Following a letter from the Minister for Education guaranteeing that the land surrounding the Burra Community Swimming Pool would be transferred to the Goyder Council, the Council has let a contract for the tiling of the pool. It is anticipated the pool will be repaired, tiled and open by Christmas. The Council has received the draft joint-use agreement and returned it to DECS and also the proposed land division plan for the site. Vacswim will proceed as usual and the Burra Swimming Club will be able to operate much as usual, despite a late start.

A Woody Weeds Field Day will be held at Sturtvale Station on Wednesday 12 November, conducted by the Eastern Districts Soil Conservation Board. It will concentrate on control measures for a large infestation of Boxthorn at Manunda Creek. Onion weed will be a secondary focus.

Burra Leisure Activity Group held an event in Burra Town Hall on 29 October called ‘Every Generation: It’s On for Young and Old’. This was the sixth such annual rally – formerly called ‘Celebrate Seniors’. 150 people attended. Entertainment was provided by the Whyte Yarcowie Vaudeville Troupe, now in its 19th year. Over the years it has raised more than $85,000 for various charities and organisations.

Issue 624, 5 November 2003, page 2

Letter. Olive Oates writes to express her great appreciation of all the effort that went into organising the ‘Every Generation Rally’ and marvelling at haw impressive the hall decorations were.

Letter. Mary Alderson writes also with respect to the ‘Every Generation Rally’ to express appreciation for the tireless work of the BCS girls.

Goyder Council has requested that SA Police Department reviews the staffing level of the Burra police station. Some time ago it was a three man station. Now it is two, but there is community disquiet about vandalism and other anti-social activity.

Remembrance Day in Burra this year will be attended by Federal MHR for Grey, Barry Wakelin. Afterwards he will unveil the restored Honour Boards, now re-hung in the RSL/Council Chamber. The ‘Burra Remembers’ project received $3,658 from a ‘Saluting Their Service’ funding round to allow the work to be done. The local RSL contributed $1,000.

Goyder Council & the Galah Problem

Council has set out first to gauge the level of public concern before taking any action to reduce galah numbers.

Ian Falkenberg, district Ranger for the Department of Environment and Heritage suggests a working party to examine the issue of large numbers in Burra. Council will then discuss the matter further.

Burra’s Christmas Celebrations will all return to Christmas Eve this year; the pageant, arrival of Father Christmas, the Christmas cake decorating contest and auction and Carols by Candlelight will all combine in one big community event.

Issue 624, 5 November 2003, page 4

The Melbourne Cup Luncheon organised by the Burra Hospital Auxiliary was held at the Burra Sports Complex. Funds raised will go towards the purchase of a cardiac monitor for the hospital. [5 photos]

Marriage. At the Creek Bank Gardens south of the Kingston St Bridge 25 October

Vicki Goodridge, second daughter of Les & Muriel Goodridge of Coonalpyn and formerly of Gum Creek, married Wayne Van Gasteren, second son of Reece & Pat Van Gasteren of Burra. [Photo]

Goyder Youth Advisory Committee Formed. The Council will have three non-voting representatives on the committee.

Issue 624, 5 November 2003, page 5

Burra Ward Project Funds were allocated at Council’s October meeting. Four projects applied for funding:

The Burra Community Development Program $7,500 as matching funding for the refurbishment of the stage, auditorium and foyer flooring at the Town Hall.

Burra Senior Citizens for an automatic watering system for Burra Creek Gardens. This was referred back for further costing and reconsideration by Burra Ward Councillors.

Burra Regional Art Gallery $5,000 for a part-time administrator/curator. This was not supported as being outside the fund criteria.

Burra Community Sports Club $8,300 to $9,000 for a retaining wall. This was not supported because Council had already made provision for this work in its annual budget.

Obituary. Kenneth Douglas Short died at Burra Hospital 26 October aged 78. He was the husband of Mavis Short for 57 years and father of Geoffrey, Dennis and Robin. [Born 17 July 1925 at Kooringa.]

Alfred Street, Hallett, St Catherine’s Anglican Church building. $30,000.

It had been consecrated in September 1957 on a bitterly cold and snowy day. See Issue 640, 24 March 2004, page 3 for the closing service that was held after the church had been sold.]

Remembrance Day in Burra. Fr Quinn led the service before a good crowd. After the service Barry Wakelin MHR spent time with RSL members and inspected the newly restored Honour Boards and framed memorabilia now hanging in the RSL/Council Chambers. [3 photos]

Hallett Hall Management Committee has obtained a $2,037 grant under the ‘Saluting Their Service’ program to upgrade the Hallett War Memorial and repair the Hallett Honour Roll and the Willalo & District Honour Roll.

Policing in Burra – connected to vandalism and anti-social behaviour

Burra Swimming Pool – the issues have since been resolved

Passenger transport needs.

On Sunday 16 November ladies from the Woodville Choir under the baton of Rosemary Nairn (nee Reed) will perform at St Mary’s. There will also be performances on the organ by four organists:

Dennis Nettleton – a former manager of the Savings Bank of SA in Burra

The Melbourne Cup Luncheon last week raised $1,920 for the Burra Hospital.

Les & Nan Warnes have recently celebrated their 60th wedding anniversary.

Ned & Jeannie Kelly and the Chatfield Family are about to leave Burra. The Golf Club will hold a farewell on 5 December.

Birth. To Thym Bitter & Lisa de Vries, a daughter.

Issue 625, 12 November 2003, page 3

Theft. A small amount of alcohol was stolen in a break-in at the Bon Accord Hotel last Tuesday.

Burra Hospital. CEO of Burra Clare Snowtown Health Services, Justine Ragenovich recently said it was pleasing to have all six low care beds in the new Holder Wing occupied. Premier Mike Rann, on a recent visit described the facility as one of the best of its kind in the state. The hospital offers 24 hour triage and emergency services, six acute beds, including two for high dependency purposes. There is also a big array of visiting on site services including physiotherapy, speech pathology, mental health, outreach nursing, dietetics, social work, etc.

Friends of Burra Parks held an orientation day last weekend to look at future projects in both Redbanks and Caroona Conservation Parks. About 30 members attended at Redbanks. Here the priority project is revegetation of the old oval site for which a grant of $8,000 has been obtained. Members later moved on to Caroona Conservation Park.

Issue 625, 12 November 2003, page 4

Burra Meals on Wheels delivered 2,763 meals last year. At the recent AGM elected were: Chairperson, Celine Stockman; Secretary, Jan Tiver; Treasurer & Staff Officer, Shana Nourse and Welfare Officer, Marg. Dunstall.

Issue 625, 12 November 2003, page 11

Obituary. Valma Ada (Val) Spackman died 26 October at Burra Hospital aged 69. She was the wife of Colin Spackman and mother of Kym, Andrew, David and Robyn.

[Born Valma Holman.]

Issue 625(2), 19 November 2003, page 1

The Sunday Concert at St Mary’s was a delight for music lovers. [Photo of the four organists.]

TV. Within a few weeks Central Television will offer a second channel featuring programs from the Ten Network to viewers in Burra on UHF.

The National Australia Bank in Burra has a ‘Vinnies’ Christmas Tree where people can buy a present to suit an age corresponding to a star on the tree and put it in the box at the bank.

Issue 625(2), 19 November 2003, page 2

Burra Visitor Centre has been busy with more than 10,000 visitors between July and October and Passport sales to just under 5,000 of them. The caravan park has been busy as well.

[But see the report Issue 629, 17 December 2003, page 6.]

Booborowie Hotel hosted a Hot Rod Show & Shine car display over the weekend of 15-16 November.

A Woody Weed Field Day at Manunda Creek on Sturtvale Station was held on 12 November. It was focused on control methods for a large infestation of boxthorn, but also featured displays and presentations on onion weed. About 60 people attended.

Issue 625(2), 19 November 2003, page 4

Advertorial on The Cook o’ Burra and its new owners, Peter & Diana Martin.

A supplement with this issue was four A4 sides of menu.

Issue 625(2), 19 November 2003, page 5

Barkers of Baldina Homes Inc. held its AGM last week. Chairman Jock Duncan presented his report:

Units 9 & 11 had bathroom upgrades, leaving only two others to be done.

All Chapel Street homes now have ducted air conditioning.

Lighting has been improved in Commercial Street units.

During the year two tenants died; Mr Ernst Osterhage and Mr Geoff Pearce. Also Mrs Audrey Little and Mrs Secomb moved into higher level care.

New residents were Mrs Pat Hanlin in Unit 1 Commercial Street and Mr John Stockman in Unit 3 Chapel Street.

Two units are currently available in Pearse Row, Commercial Street.

Jock Duncan was re-elected as Chairman, with Ron Thamm as Vice Chairman and John Arthur as Secretary.

The Barkers of Baldina Cottage Homes in Commercial Street were first built in 1970, since when 75 people have lived there. Mr Barker left a bequest for high quality retirement accommodation for the aged in Burra. Firstly nine units were built in Commercial Street, followed by a further five in Chapel Street* and more recently by four more in John Barker Street.

[*This seems to imply that the Chapel Street units were built after 1970. They have all the appearances of older stone buildings and it seems more likely that they were adapted for this new purpose, rather than actually built. Further research would be needed to verify their history.]

All units are fully equipped, air conditioned, have carpets and are maintained regularly. Lawns are cared for and small gardens are available for tenants. There is a mixture of one and two bedroom units. Previous Chairmen of the Board have been the late Ron Pearse and Mr Ray Jennison.

Issue 626, 26 November 2003, page 1

Burra Regional Art Gallery is in crisis. While it has a good number of enthusiastic volunteers to run the gallery on a day to day basis, it needs an injection on manpower on the Board to continue the excellent management of the past. It needs people to organise/curate exhibitions, to oversee a social program for the Friends of the Gallery, to send out newsletters, to manage the volunteer roster and to organise the ‘hanging’ committee etc. Key people have been lost, leading to the current crisis. If positions cannot be filled soon, its activities will have to be curtailed or it could even have to close its doors altogether.

Friends of Burra Parks. Approximately 15 people attended an orientation day at the new Hopkins Creek Conservation Park on Saturday 22 November. It is located near the Burra Creek Gorge and has a range of treasures from waterholes to breath-taking vistas. District Ranger Ian Falkenberg gave a talk on the history and ecology of the park. Harvey Neal and John Smyth shared results of a recent biosurvey.

The Premiers’ Food Awards last week saw Thorogood’s Apple Wines take off the coveted Horticultural Industry Achievement Award for below $1 million businesses.

Will Rayner, formerly of Hallett and now editor of the Stock Journal has won the title of ETSA Utilities Young Journalist of the Year at the Home Start Finance SA Youth Media Awards. He is the youngest editor of the Stock Journal in its 99 year history.

Issue 626, 26 November 2003, page 2

Adam Simpson, grandson of Len & Nancy Simpson of Burra, is now Captain of North Melbourne AFL team.

Birth. To Tanya Waters & Anthony Jones on 11 November, a daughter, Eve Amelia.

Birth. To Dallas & Paul O’Bryan on 14 November a son, James Paul.

Wayne Clonan married Cheryl Day. [Photo]

Issue 626, 26 November 2003, page 4

The Commercial Hotel has new proprietors; Shane Darwin and Jo Holthuyzen. They have moved to Burra from the Adelaide Hills with their 5-month-old son Oliver.

Issue 626, 26 November 2003, page 5

BRTBA. The Burra Regional Tourism & Business Association now has almost 70 members from a broad spectrum of businesses, employing many and training apprentices. BRTBA strives for local development. It recently launched its own logo.

Issue 626, 26 November 2003, page 11

Advt. BRTBA Film Night at Burra Town Hall

5 December Sea Biscuit

Freaky Friday

Issue 627, 3 December 2003, page 1

Minister for Tourism, Jane Lomax-Smith has responded to a letter from Tony Thorogood re Terowie and in it indicates her concerns about its future.

Preserving its key visitor attractions is beyond the resources of a small community. It needs the co-operation of all key stakeholders: The SA Tourism Commission

Regional Council of Goyder

Department of Environment & Heritage

The Community of Peterborough

She identified three issues:

The need to identify, stabilise and conserve/maintain key surviving heritage assets.

The need to develop good visual interpretation at several significant sites.

The need of the host community to exercise some degree of care and management over any improvements undertaken.

The minister has asked SATAC to convene meetings to canvass these issues and see how these challenges could be met.

Volunteer Drivers for Mid North Regional Passenger Transport were recognised with certificates at a Christmas Luncheon at Burra Hotel on 20 November. These recognised completion of all four stages of the Volunteer Driver Accreditation Pilot Scheme being funded by the Passenger Transport Board.

Qantas Advertising. On Thursday 11 December Location Professionals will be filming a Qantas advertisement with the Children’s Choir at two places in the district; the Midnight Oil House and the Burra Railway Station. The cast and crew will number about 60.

Burra Railway Station. A meeting is called at the Burra Hotel for 8 December for anyone interested in forming a Burra Railway Station Community Action Group. Action needs to be taken now before it is too late.

Issue 627, 3 December 2003, page 2

The ADC School of Dance has classes in the Burra Town Hall every Wednesday during school term. The Burra U12 Modern Dance Class won Best Overall Class out of many from Burra, Clare &Balaklava classes at the end of year performance at Clare last Saturday. Burra has U9, U12 and an Open Class. [Photo]

BCS has announced two new staff positions from the start of 2004.

Phillip Bryant replaces Di Agnew as senior Maths teacher within the school on a permanent basis. He is currently at Clare HS.

Laura Hadley has been permanently appointed replacing Michelle Schaeffer. She is a specialist in Middle School Music and Dramatic Arts and also in Primary School Physical Education. She has been at Solomontown Primary for the last three years and previously at Hawker and Quorn Area Schools.

Issue 627, 3 December 2003, page 3

BCS Formal was held at the Burra Town Hall on 28 November. It was deemed a big success.

The King and Queen of the Formal were Micah Blakey and Jo McInnes.

Issue 627, 3 December 2003, page 11

Advt. BCS Student Boarding Facility – Goyder House – is seeking House parent(s)/Supervisor for term 1 2004.

Issue 628, 10 December 2003, page 1

Burra Swimming Pool repairs are underway. Damaged sections of marble sheen are being removed. John Brak from the Council said it was still expected the opening date would be 3 January 2004.

Saltbush Clothing has closed its doors in Burra and relocated to Adelaide.

The business began in October 1988 when Elspeth Radford opened her first shop (next to Beaut Fruit) called Saltbush for Kids. It was an immediate hit, with stylish country-style, well-made clothing. Later she moved into adult clothing and the business grew. Over the years Saltbush Clothing has won a string of business awards. The departure of Saltbush and Glasgow House now leaves Burra without a clothing store.

The Burra Railway Station. There was quite a lot of interest in the railway station, with about 20 people attending the meeting at the Burra Hotel on Monday evening. As a first step a request will be made to see whether Transport SA could hand it over to the group. A full report of the meeting will be made available to anyone interested from Simon & Bruna at the Newsagency from next Friday.

Issue 628, 10 December 2003, pages 4, 5 & 6

Review of 2003

January

Burra Visitor Centre began the year with a new manager, Andrew Glen.

Drought was serious out east – dry bores were a concern.

Citizen of the Year was Colleen Woodgate.

Young Citizen of the Year was Kylie O’Connor.

Event of the Year was a great disco arranged by the Youth Group.

February

Successful Rock ’n’ Roll Weekend.

Two day manhunt on the Morgan Road for escaped asylum seekers.

CFS members went to fight fires in the eastern states.

Burra North Railway Bridge was hit again by a truck.

Goyder Council decided to strengthen the Kingston Street Bridge.

Burra Picnic Race Club cancelled its race meeting due to public liability insurance costs.

March

Merino Field Days.

Jazz in the Monster Mine was a sell-out.

Market Square Fire Station was closed.

MFS moved to a new home with the SES on Smelts Road.

April

25th Anniversary of BCS.

Funds were being raised for hostel units in the former maternity wing of Burra Hospital.

May

The Antique Fair was a success.

Local Government elections brought two new Councillors in Peter Reilly and Tim Stockman for Burra Ward.

Burra Internet Centre officially opened.

Scott Donaldson won the Golden Gavel award from the Society of Auctioneers & Appraisers in U29 years section.

June

Burra Ladies Pennant Golf Team was victorious.

Goyder’s Line was declared a Heritage Icon by BankSA

Stardust Circus, a traditional circus with performing animal acts, was a sell-out.

A storm toppled one of the town oval’s lighting towers.

July

Best rains for years filled dams and creeks flowed.

BCS was allotted $508,400 for maintenance – the roof of the old building to be replaced, science laboratory upgraded to occupational health & safety standards and heating and cooling upgraded.

Burra Community Print 10 years old [i.e. 10 years since acquired by Terry Wilson.]

August

A meeting formed Friends of Burra Parks.

New mobile phone towers were launched at Mintaro & Booborowie.

At the Inaugural Edmund Wright Heritage Awards, Burra won the Minister’s Award for Outstanding Contribution.

BBH auction saw $975 paid for a signed and framed Crows Guernsey and $900 for a signed and framed Port Power Guernsey.

Jazz in the Monster Mine Committee gave cheques to Burra Leisure Activity Group, Burra Hospital Auxiliary and Burra Regional Art Gallery.

There was further wild weather with some minor flooding.

September

BCS students attended the second First Edge Camp in Youth Leadership.

BCS did well at the Royal Adelaide Show with Grand Champion on the hoof and on the hook with their Shorthorn steer and Lightweight Champion on the hook with a Red Poll.

Burra Show Society’s fundraiser ‘Survival Gig’ was a great success.

Burra Men’s Hockey Team were premiers.

BBH’s Aaron Spicer won the NEFL Senior Colt’s Mail Medal.

October

There were visits to Burra by the Austin 7 Car Club, the MG Car Club and the 20 Ghost Club (Rolls Royce).

A feasibility study was announced for a Hallett wind farm.

Di Day & Trevor Wall were made Life Members of the Burra Community & Sports Club.

Sharyn Roberts was made a Life Member of the BBH Netball Club.

Robert Sullivan was made a Life Member of BBH Football Club.

Premier Mike Rann visited Burra and was made aware of the Burra Swimming Pool impasse.

Burra Show was a success.

The 1st Mt Bryan Market was held.

Staff from SA Museum brought the ‘Outback Road Show’ to Burra.

‘Every Generation – It’s On for Young and Old’ event was hosted by Burra Leisure Activity Centre.

November

Musicians & Masterpieces Concert at St Mary’s Church with four guest organists and the Woodville Ladies’ Ensemble.

Burra Regional Art Gallery was urgently in need of new members for its Board of Management.

BRTBA launched its logo.

Thorogoods won the Horticulture Industry Achievement Award in the Premier’s Food Awards.

December

Minister for Tourism, Jane Lomax-Smith initiated an investigation into how to ensure Terowie’s future.

Qantas filmed an advertisement at Burra Railway Station and the Midnight Oil House.

Allen Day & Di Day were made Life Members of the Burra Golf Club.

Issue 628, 10 December 2003, page 7

KESAB Awards.

S. Broad, Burra, won a special mention for well-presented and improved premises.

BCS was awarded a Special Effort School Award Plaque.

Burra Senior Citizens were given a Meritorious Effort Plaque – their 23rd award.

Issue 629, 17 December 2003, page 1

Qantas Commercial

On 11 December about sixty people including children worked from 5 a.m. on filming take after take in morning light at the Midnight Oil House. They then moved to the Burra Railway Station for more filming, before taking a break of several hours. At 5 p.m. they were back at the Midnight Oil House with its oat crop for sunset filming. Quite a few locals watched the session.

The Midnight Oil House has featured on many postcards, calendars, posters etc., but this is the first time it has been used for a television commercial to be screened around the world. The crew flew in from New York only thirty-six hours earlier. Their camera was valued at $300,000 and was mounted on a crane, which was in turn mounted on a truck. They came with a wind machine, a catering van, a truckload of gear and other equipment. Burra CFS attended the shoot.

The Midnight Oil House got to be called that because it featured on the first album produced by the band Midnight Oil, called Diesel and Dust.

Jean Button and her husband Des have just completed 29 years of school service with Booborowie & BCS. Their youngest son James has now just finished his secondary schooling. [Photo]

Christmas Eve Reminder

The Pageant assembles at 4 p.m. for a 4.30 p.m. start. Father Christmas will be in the Rotunda from c. 5 p.m. to 7 p.m. Santa’s Trail has been well supported. Barbecue, soft drinks and ice cream from 5.30 p.m. onwards. The Christmas cake entries are to be at the Lucky Dip by 5 p.m. Christmas Eve. Carols by Candlelight is to start at c. 8 p.m.

Issue 629, 17 December 2003, page 3

Fire. A windrowing machine started a fire at Farrell Flat on 10 December that destroyed about 1⁄2 acre of straw.

Burra Regional Art Gallery had more than 30 at its AGM on 16 December, following the crisis report in the Broadcaster on 26 November. Christine Brinkworth of Robertstown was elected Chairperson. (She was also told that night that she had won the People’s Choice Award for her painting of a magnolia at the Art of the Flower Exhibition.) Colin Wood was elected Secretary and Bryan Dunow is Treasurer. Geraldine Smedley is Minute Secretary.

Issue 629, 17 December 2003, pages 4 & 5

BCS Presentation Night is reported with 7 photos and a list of awards. Dux of the School for 2003 was Micah Blakey.

Issue 629, 17 December 2003, page 6

Birth. To Tanya Waters & Anthony Jones on 11 November, a daughter, Eve Amelia Waters-Jones. [Photo]

Birth. To Dallas & Paul O’Bryan on 14 November, a son, James Paul. [Photo]

Burra Leisure Activity Group had a Mystery Trip on 12 December. They went to Pt Adelaide and boarded the Failie for a six hour cruise, returning to land at 4 p.m. and then headed home to Burra.

Burra Visitor Centre

Manager Andrew Glen says it attracts mostly people in their late 40s.

50% are from SA.

40% come from the rest of Australia.

10% are overseas visitors.

Autumn, winter and spring are busy, with summer a quiet period.

The Burra Passport has always been the most popular product.

The centre saw 8,000 visitors in 2002 and 10,000 in 2003.*

This was thought to represent 20% of visitors to the town.

[* Note that this does not accord with the report in the issue of 19 November 2003, page 2 that said the Burra Visitor Centre had been busy with more than 10,000 visitors between July and October with Passport sales to just under 5,000 of them. The December version seems more believable.]

Christmas Messages are printed from:

Pastor Nigel Rosenzweig of St John’s Lutheran Church

Fr L.J. Quinn for the Catholic Church

Rev. Julianne Parker for the Uniting Church of Australia

Mary Woollacott for St Mary’s Anglican Church

Issue 629, 17 December 2003, page 7

Goyder House 2003

Robert Van Gills reports on activities and changes in the boarding facility in 2003.

Issue 630, 14 January 2004, page 1

Burra Christmas Pageant entertained with colour and variety. Father Christmas installed himself in the rotunda for an hour or so with the youngsters and the evening included a family barbecue in Market Square.

Burra Swimming Pool has been newly tiled and opened in time for Vacswim. More than 50 young swimmers have participated in rather cold conditions.

Adchem has had to cut back on production following the fire at Moomba Gas field that reduced the availability of gas to SA. Supplies were minimal for three days and slightly restricted for a further week. In all about 100 tons of production was lost as a result, but they hope to be able to make that up later.

Andrew Glen of the Visitor Centre reports that Burra Tourism has had a good year, with good attendance at events throughout the year and a very healthy flow of visitors. Dove and Brewery Cottages have been added to the available accommodation and Burra Trail Rides are now set to resume.

Michael Christian Miller, son of Ross & Rhonda Miller of Toowoomba, Queensland.

A New Year’s Ball in Burra Town Hall was fun for about 120 people, who dressed to the theme ‘Black and White with a Touch of Glitz’. [2 photos]

Senior constable Andrew Dredge is the new policeman in Burra. He has moved in with his wife and three daughters.

Aileen & Ron Kelly have celebrated their Golden Wedding (50th).

Obituary. June Burdon nee Dollman, formerly of Burra, died in Sydney 30 December 2003. She was the wife of Errol Burdon and sister to the late Guy Dollman. She left Burra many years ago and since then had lived in Tasmania, overseas and in NSW for the last twenty years. [Born June Dollman 15 June 1926 at Kooringa.]

Obituary. Charles Barnard (by implication).

Issue 630, 14 January 2004, page 3

Rev. Frank Tuppin has arrived in Burra with his wife Helen and daughter Rebecca.

Mokota Conservation Park

A management plan for the park has been released. Located 15 km north of Burra, the park is the first reserve in SA to be acquired with the primary aim of protecting native grassland. The plan aims to use grazing trials and fire to develop a regime to maximise biodiversity conservation. The park contains more than 150 indigenous plant species, including 32 of conservation significance.

Jeannie Kelly has been awarded Honorary Membership of the Burra Basketball Association. Over the years she has been President for 2 years, Vice President for a year, Secretary for 5 years, Assistant Secretary for 3 years, Treasurer for 3 years, a Recorder for 2 years and has drawn up the program 8 times. She has also been an Association selector, player and umpire.

Letter. Senior Constable Margaret Day writes a farewell note and thank you to the community.

Issue 631, 21 January 2004, page 1

Burra Regional Art Gallery. The current exhibition is ‘Pastel Artists of South Australia’; running to 5 February. It will be followed by ‘All That Jazz’ to 8 April.

Australia Day Awards

Burra Citizen of the Year 2004 is Bob Greet.

Bob is a retiree who has been a tireless worker sweeping gutters and streets, picking up litter and mowing grass. He was an active member of the Lions Club while it operated in Burra.

Community Event of the Year is the 25th Anniversary of the establishment of SA’s first Community School.

[As previously noted.]

Morphett’s Enginehouse. Goyder Council and the National Trust have been busy trying to source replacement timber beams for the balconies. Council has allowed funds for the milling and freight of the timber this year and the National Trust will store it until funding for the installation can be arranged later in 2004.

Mid North Passenger Service has organised a shopping shuttle to get people from their homes to Burra shops. YP Coaches have contracted to provide the service, which was previously run by Rodney & Marlene Phillips.

Burra Community Library. Revamping Stage 2 is almost completed. New cream coloured shelving has been installed for the reference, large print and general fiction sections, which has meant a complete re-shelving of stock.

BCS. New staff:

[Photo]

Burra Trail Rides have resumed. Graham Radford ran Burra Trail Rides for nine years, leading three day horseback adventures. Fourteen months ago excessive public liability insurance costs forced him to close. Now he will resume in March, offering two and three day rides.

The Rangeland Integrated Natural Resource Management Group met in Burra last week to discuss the Government’s spending priorities in that area.

Obituary. Charles Dewhirst – 1 June 1969 to 20 December 2003.

Charles was the third child of Gillian & Alan Dewhirst and was born at Clare. He had two sisters, Virginia and Andrea. He was an adventurous and independent young boy, walking at twelve months and swimming the channel at Fisherman’s Bay and diving from the Pt Broughton Jetty at five years of age. He began school at Booborowie and played football and cricket, but his real love was trucks. At age 11 he was driving all manner of farm machinery and soon moved onto motorbikes and cars. He went to BCS, but left at 151⁄2 to drive trucks. After working locally for a few years, he went to Kalgoorlie, working for Roche Bros. Two daughters, Ashlii-Maree and Laimii-Lee, were born to him and Jenny. Returning to SA in 1944, Charlie was driving trucks for as many hours as the law allowed. In 1999 he started work at Booth Transport in Tanunda and in 2000 moved to Freeling. A highlight was carting water at the eclipse at Lyndhurst. Leisure time was spent at the Murray River, teaching his daughters to swim and skiing on his knee-board. Charlie’s ashes are to be interred at Burra Cemetery.

Issue 633, 4 February 2004, page 1

Accident. A B-double rolled over on the Burra By-pass on Saturday 31 January due to a mechanical fault. It was loaded with pineapples and sweet potatoes and the total damage/loss is estimated at c. $90,000.

[There is no mention of injuries to the 34-year-old male driver.]

Goyder House boarding facility is almost full, with six boys and six girls this year. Michelle Cooper is the ‘parent’.

Issue 633, 4 February 2004, page 2

Police from Eudunda and Burra addressed the members of Goyder Council on 20 January re the apparent increase in vandalism in the region. They pointed out that more interaction with the community is needed. Council has authorised $5,000 to be spent on efforts to reduce vandalism with Police and Council keeping a close watch on progress.

Issue 633, 4 February 2004, page 3

BCS. The Year 12 SACE results for 2003 Stage 1 were of a similar standard to those of 2001 and 2002, but the Stage 2 results from a small cohort were disappointing. Only 53.3% of senior students completed a full SACE Certificate. This reflects the views of staff that numerous senior students exhibited a lack of both attendance and effort. The principal said he looked forward to better results this year.

BCS has 26 new students for 2004, 14 of whom appear in a photo.

The First Ghan Passenger Train to Darwin left Keswick terminal last Sunday morning. The 1.1 km train comprised 42 carriages.

Men’s Champion Don Schulz

Goyder Council is seeking feedback from Burra ratepayers about a perceived galah menace in the town, causing the death of trees. Although they are not a protected species, culling would have to be done according to the Code of Practice for the ‘Humane Destruction of Birds by Shooting in SA’.

Issue 635, 18 February 2004, page 1

Goyder Council has moved into the 21st century with state-of-the-art laptop computers to assist Councillors with their Council duties.

Vandals smashed two front windows of a local business this week.

Issue 635, 18 February 2004, page 2

Marriage. Tanunda, 20 December 2003

Melissa Ramm married Brad Agars of Tanunda. Melissa is a teacher at Burra Kindergarten. [Photo]

Issue 635, 18 February 2004, page 3

The Department for Environment & Heritage has acquired the Tooralie Gorge property of 2,900 ha, adjoining the Caroona Creek Conservation Park. The park contains exceptionally high biodiversity values and has long been ungrazed by livestock. Short term management issues include road reserve closures and feral animal control. Hopkins Creek Conservation Park in the Burra Hills also contains exceptionally high biodiversity values and it is for these that it is being maintained rather than for visitor access. Redbanks Conservation Park will be promoted by the SA Museum as a site where the public can see and visit mega fauna fossils. A resource centre is required in Burra to display replicas and examples of mega fauna. Successful burning and grazing trials were held at Mokota Conservation Park in autumn 2003 and more are planned for 2004. Burns have proved particularly useful in removing horehound seed, with 80% gone in one year and most in subsequent years. Aerial feral goat shooting is planned for Caroona Creek and Redbanks Parks in March. Co-ordinated fox baiting is also planned for 2004. Funding has been allocated for boxthorn, peppertree and artichoke control along Baldina Creek. A section of the Hallelujah Hills has been acquired by World’s End Conservation Pty Ltd, a private group of conservationists. It is a 415 ha property of high biodiversity. There is concern over vandalism of Aboriginal rock art along Stone Chimney Creek.

Issue 635, 18 February 2004, pages 4-5

Burra Ambulance Service. A two page spread outlines the challenges and rewards of being an ambulance volunteer and appeals for people to take on the role. [5 photos]

Issue 636, 25 February 2004, page 1

Letter. Kerry Fitzpatrick writes a letter recounting her experiences in Mt Bryan after buying the school there in 2003. They expected to be moving into a safe and friendly place, but found they had one contractor who never came back and one who did, but ripped them off. They awaiting welcoming neighbours in vain and the kids were bullied at school. Small things were stolen from around their home, including her daughter’s pet rabbit and someone armed with a gun at night terrorised their animals, eventually shooting their pet duck in the back. Décor Made Easy offered genuine help and support and some of the community gave support and comfort so that things have now somewhat improved.

Rod Phillips has resigned from Burra MFS after 21 years of service, due to work commitments in Adelaide. Rod has been officer-in-charge at Burra for the last seven years. He was presented with a Certificate of Service on Monday night, the first retained fire fighter in the state to receive the award.

The Kingston Street Bridge will be strengthened later in the year.

Issue 636, 25 February 2004, page 2

Weather. On Saturday 14 February the temperature peaked at 44°C.

Marriage. By Burra Creek, 14 February

Geoff Jenkins married Mary Pisani.

Marriage. At Brown’s Forest (next to what was previously Secomb’s on the Booborowie Road) last Saturday.

Leanne Ellbourn married Alex Stockman.

Obituary. Frank Kneebone, a Minister in the Dunstan Government, died recently. He was the father of Barbara Frances and grandfather of Simon, Paula and Belinda.

Obituary. Greg Downs-Woolley died last Tuesday.

Les & Joan Taylor celebrated their Golden Wedding last weekend.

Letter. Dr Roger Cross writes a long letter on galahs, in which he notes how the favourable comments on them in the nineteenth century changed, as in the twentieth century the word became slang for an idiot or had other connotations of derision or contempt. The assertions about the bird in the recent Council newsletter that the galah ‘is causing the death of many trees’, is quite without evidence.

Has anyone actually done a count to verify that ‘many are dying’?

Has the cause of any deaths of trees been verified? For instance could it be borers or flocks of starlings or could it be dieback?

Galahs are noisy and colourful and large and numerous – so it is easy to blame them.

He concludes by asking for a proper environmental impact study before taking any action and wonders whether people’s complaints are truly because of dead trees, or actually sparked by the noise the birds make coming to roost or on getting up.

Letter. Stephen Kerrigan, Goyder Council CEO writes a long letter focused on vandalism.

Vandalism has increased over the past two years.

It takes workers away from the other jobs they could/should be doing.

It costs the community on average $400 per week or:-

$20,800 p.a. for damage to toilets

$19,988 p.a. for damage to street signs

$2,964 p.a. to re-erect white guide posts

$13,439 p.a. to replace white guide posts

$1,820 to repair pine railings in Burra

Overall the cost is c. $56,000 p.a.

The damage is largely (though not exclusively) the work of a small group of young people for whose behaviour parents must shoulder some of the responsibility.

He goes on to list the possible penalties, but stresses that in order for these to have an impact on the problem, the offenders have to be caught and the community needs to be united in reporting offences/offenders if there is to be any impact on the problem.

Issue 636, 25 February 2004, page 3

Inter-school Swimming Carnival was held at Riverton on Monday night. Burra won the Division 2 Shield and the Most Improved Shield. [Photo]

Issue 636, 25 February 2004, page 4

MNRDB. The CEO Craig Wilson has resigned, to be replaced by Geoffrey Gray from Carisbrook in Central Victoria.

SA Pop Vocal Contest. This is run by promoter and vocal coach David McMenamin and finalists are competing for a recording package with Access Studio. A group of Burra singers is in the finals: Brooke Starr, Tracey Rains, Jess Reid, Nathaniel O’Brien, Kiya Norris and Ruby Neiman.

Issue 636, 25 February 2004, page 5

Burra Ambulance Team is still seeling more members.

Farrell Flat Uniting Church will hold its closing service next Sunday at 10.30 a.m.

The original church was the Hanson Wesleyan Church, dating from 1878. In 1934 this was demolished and a new church was built on its foundations. Power and lights were installed in 1954 and a Sunday school room was added at the back in 1956. An old Housing Trust room was added in 1963 and this in turn was replaced in 1963 with an Atco style building. The property will be sold.

Issue 636, 25 February 2004, page 11

Birth. To Damien & Lisa Wedding nee Booth at Lyell McEwin Hospital on 10 February, a son, Liam Jeffrey.

Issue 637, 3 March 2004, page 1

Jailhouse Rock

The Rock ’n’ Roll Weekend started on Friday night when Paul O’Bryan’s Band played at the Burra Hotel. On Saturday morning there was a dance competition in Market Square with Paul O’Bryan’s Band again. Saturday morning also featured cars and motor cycles in a Show and Shine along with SA Super Trikes. Quite a few people then headed for the Booborowie Hotel for the afternoon, where the fun continued. More than 250 people attended the main event at the Redruth Gaol on Saturday night, which was a 20% increase on last year. Paul O’Bryan’s Band kept up the tempo into the night. About 170 people capped the weekend off with a leisurely brunch on the Burra creek bank on Sunday morning. [2 photos]

The Svensdotter Family, who run the Black Springs Country Boarding Kennels have been repeatedly the target of vandals who have damaged their signage.

Burra Ambulance service has attracted twelve enquiries from locals in its latest recruiting drive and there are hopes that some will take up the challenge.

Issue 637, 3 March 2004, pages 1 & 2

Farrell Flat Uniting Church held its last service on Sunday. More than 150 people attended, including several past ministers and families no longer in the district. Ministers or relatives who came back were:

Mrs Rita Hanson with husband Frank. Rita was the widow of Rev. Everleigh Tregilgas

[*Pictured]

Also back for the day were Robin & Sharyn _________ (nee Short) who were the last couple to be married in the church in 1991. There had not been a wedding there then for quite a long time.

Issue 637, 3 March 2004, page 4

BCS enrolment in 2003 was 288.

Letter. Aileen McIlree Moorhouse writes at some length in support of Roger Cross’s views on galahs.

Letter. Carolyn Wiseman of Ballarat also writes re the galahs – disgusted to see a petition in one of the service stations to get rid of them. She is also critical of the lack if signage and, in her words, the ‘total lack of community services for the youth of Burra, leading to the vandalism that I even witnessed’.

Letter. Bob Skinner and Glenys Christopher write about the galah ‘problem’, suggesting more trees be planted and pointing out that the trees in Burra Gorge seem to survive the ‘galah onslaught’ and have been doing so for many years.

Letters from Dee & Brenton Greenslade, Stephen Angel and Sue Ryan all express gratitude for a great Rock ’n’ Roll Weekend and thank all who made it possible.

Issue 638, 10 March 2004, page 1

Collinsville is leading the way with the uptake of radio frequency identification (RFID) ear tags for sheep.

Issue 638, 10 March 2004, page 2

MNRDB offered a course in sound business practices for the past two years in Burra and this has now concluded.

Damien Sommerville has begun working at Elders in their Burra Branch as a Sales Agronomist. He has a Bachelor of Agriculture from Roseworthy and has previously worked in the Murray Mallee and on Yorke Peninsula.

Obituary. Michael Connors died recently.

[Michael Francis Connors was born 2 December 1923 at Mt Bryan. He was buried at Burra Cemetery 3 February 2004.]

Issue 638, 10 March 2004, page 3

Jazz in the Monster Mine. About 400 lovers of jazz gathered in the mine by the water’s edge last Saturday to enjoy several hours of music supplied by ‘The Dukes of Jazz’ and ‘Marmalade Fieta’. [3 photos]

Lisa Wall, Chris Baulderstone & Scott Richardson are all new faces at Oppy’s IGA in the last few weeks/months.

Letter. Paul Besanko of Saffron Downs writes to report the theft of 50 Merino ewes from that property.

Issue 638, 10 March 2004, page 4

Letter. Bryan & Helen Dunow write with respect to the galah debate and in support of ‘our magnificent gums’. They include from a 1955 CWA Calendar of Fish & Meat Courses a recipe for August 2: Roast Galah.

Letter. Stuart & Ruth Norris submit a lengthy letter on galahs. They call for research to substantiate any claims and say galahs do not kill trees, and they rather lay the blame for such death on land clearing, irrigation practices and the effect of both these on the water table. They deny that the noise problem is real. Visitors love the flocks of galahs that are far less offensive to their ears than the dangerous drivers that use the roads as race tracks.

Letter. Glenys Christopher & Bob Skinner write again on the galah ‘problem’. Their point is that grain farmers inevitably create a windfall source of food for galahs, who then like to roost in trees at night. The few remaining trees in this area are in the town. If farmers planted more trees around their paddocks the birds would roost there and it would most likely have other advantages as well with respect to reducing wind erosion, providing shelter and shade.

Issue 638, 10 March 2004, page 12

Burra Real Estate

2 Young Street, $140,000

Issue 639, 17 March 2004, page 1

SA Stud Merino Field Days at Burra Oval featured more studs than in previous years. Collinsville Stud featured for the first time and so did Minta from Eyre Peninsula and Glenlea of Pinnaroo. This year’s Champion Pair came from Balaklava Stud ‘Nyowee’. Greenfields were judged as having the 2004 Elders Merino Capital Ram – a prize they also won in 2001 & 2002.

Vandalism has seen $200 damage to a local business’s window and $100 to the public toilets behind the Royal Exchange Hotel.

Theft. A tourist had two bags stolen from his car parked in Market Street. A digital camera was stolen and then smashed and the bags were weighted with rocks and thrown into the creek, damaging passports, airline tickets etc.

Issue 639, 17 March 2004, page 5

Burra Darts Final. Burra Hotel defeated The Bon 4 to 2. [Photo]

Issue 640, 24 March 2004, page 1

Redbanks Reserve. Eighteen months ago local Danny Heading noticed some bones poking out from the wall of a creek bank at Redbanks. National Parks ranger Ian Falkenberg was informed and he passed the message on to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, which contacted representatives of the Ngadjuri Aboriginal group. Their heritage chairman Vincent Branson attended the site last week for the careful excavation and examination of the remains by archaeologists from Flinders University. Their conclusion was that the bones were those of an adult Aboriginal woman with the body of an infant under her arm. The Ngadjuri will arrange a suitable reburial.

Over the years the area has yielded significant finds of mega fauna fossils.

[Photo of the excavation with Archaeological undergraduate Rob Williams, Vince Branson, Peter Birt a Flinders University PhD student, Tim Ormsby an Archaeology honours student, Soren Blau a research fellow and Dr Heather Burke Archaeology Lecturer.]

Burra CFS & Burra SES will receive $500 each from a cheque for $2,574 presented to emergency services involved in the salvage operations when a B-double loaded with pineapples overturned near Burra on 31 January. The cheque came from Robinvale Transport Group who owned the load. Crews worked throughout the night retrieving and repacking the load so that only three palettes out of 46 were lost.

Issue 640, 24 March 2004, page 2

National Archives of Australia will hold a workshop in Burra on Tuesday 30 March. It provides an opportunity to find out about the records the Archives keeps and is offered free of charge.

The Uniting Church Kids Camp Out at West beach Caravan Park recently was attended by 16 children and leaders from Burra Uniting Church.

Goyder YAC has received funding to stage events for National Youth Week. They will arrange:

A Youth Forum called ‘SPEAK UP!’

A Dance Party in the Burra Town Hall with entertainment provided by SAFM.

The forum will be an opportunity to canvass what services are lacking for youth in the district and what needs to be done and will form the basis for lobbying local government and other agencies on behalf of the district’s youth.

Merino Field Days last week were very successful and drew a large number of visitors to the town, including a large group from WA.

Barbara Frances was given a farewell from Burra last week. She is moving to Ardrossan.

Marriage. At Quorn last Saturday

Jenni-Lee Leslie, formerly of Wesfarmers, Burra, married Bob Case. They are currently living at Alice Springs.

Haydn Lines married Poppy Barrington-Case.

Issue 640, 24 March 2004, page 3

Burra Probus held its AGM recently. Outgoing President Bob Gebhardt reported on 2003-04.

The club had organised some interesting visits:

Cadell & Morgan

Banrock Station & Waikerie

Spencer Creek Resort, Flinders Ranges

Picnic at Elizabeth

They had also had a number of interesting speakers. The new President is Mearle Mitchell.

St Catherine’s Anglican Church at Hallett was formally closed last Sunday. It had been unused for several years. About 50 people attended the final service. The church was opened and consecrated in 1957 by the late Bishop of Adelaide the Rt Rev. Dr T.T. Reed and dedicated to St Catherine of Sienna. [See Burra Record 11 June 1957, page 7and 17 Sep. 1957, page 1.] The unusual shape of the building won awards. Sunday’s service was conducted by the Bishop of Willochra Rt Rev. Garry Weatherill, assisted by Geraldine Smedley of Burra. Mary Shattock played the organ. Having been sold, the building was deconsecrated and secularised. Jan Tiver read the Declaration of Secularisation. [2photos]

St Catherine’s as advertised for sale 2003-04. Former St Catherine’s photographed in April 2011.

Issue 640, 24 March 2004, page 5

Burra RSL held its AGM recently. President Len Simpson reported on a successful year, with good attendances at Anzac Day and Remembrance Day. Five Honour Boards were restored after a grant of $3,600 from the Department of Veterans’ Affairs. Secretary Ben Kotz was thanked for organising successful collections for the Anzac Legacy Appeal and Poppy Day. Brian Riggs was thanked as Treasurer.

Issue 640, 24 March 2004, page 6

Goyder Council has secured funding from Planning SA ‘Places for People Program’ to review the Master Planning Option for Market Square and Best Place. The rest of this article is full of wonderful planner’s jargon, of which one paragraph will suffice:

‘There is now an increased awareness within the Council and the communities of Goyder of the need for an integrated approach to Market Square and best Place to reinforce links between the performance of the town and its tourism potential, historic character and coherence and vitality of the public realm.’

Issue 640, 24 March 2004, page 15

Advt. Dee Lloyd & Vanessa Reed are opening a Re-Cycled Clothing Shop located in the former Saltbush shop. Tuesday 30 March.

Issue 641, 31 March 2004, page 1

Burra North Railway Bridge. Transport SA has applied to the State Development Assessment Commission to demolish the railway bridge over the highway at Burra North along with part of the embankment. Goyder Council supports the removal. Numerous accidents have been recorded there over the years. The railway line has not been used since 1991. The last passenger train was a special Bluebird railcar used for a school trip from Hallett and Mt Bryan to a function in Burra. [Photo]

Paxton Square Chapel. Paul Wilson has the job of re-roofing the Booking Office in Paxton Square, which was formerly the Bible Christian Chapel. The work includes removing the hessian ceiling. Removal of the iron revealed the original shingle roof c. 1850. [Photo]

Meals on Wheels. The Governor, Marjorie Jackson-Nelson entertained more than 600 members of Meals on Wheels at Government House grounds on Sunday 28 March, to mark the 50th anniversary of the service. Attending from Burra were: Betty Thamm, Marg Dunstall, Shana Nourse, Celine Stockman and Jan Tiver.

Issue 641, 31 March 2004, page 2

Letter. Roger cross writes acknowledging the humour of recent galah recipes, but also recalling the experience of China in 1958 when Mao Tse-Tung ordered the entire population to kill birds on 15 January on the grounds that they ate the harvest. The result was a vast upsurge in plant pests and disastrously reduced agricultural production.

Burra Swimming Club wound up the 2003-04 season on Friday night. The club had 32 members, of whom nine were competitive members. The club had attended two carnivals without snaring any trophies, but participants had learned much about competitive swimming.

Issue 641, 31 March 2004, page 3

Mongolata Gold has moved into new premises at 1 Commercial Street. It has a bigger space to display its range of malachite, crystals and minerals, as well as gemstone jewellery. It has added solid pine furniture and other items, including doors painted by artist Jim Dunstan [photo] and pottery by Ronda [sic?] Dunstan. Kevin and Barb are also continuing to offer mine tours and cemetery walks.

Dee Lloyd & Vanessa Read have opened ‘Something Different’ in the former Saltbush Shop. It offers recycled clothing, handbags, shoes, jewellery etc. [Photo]

Issue 642, 7 April 2004, page 1

The Kingston Street Bridge is to be strengthened. The Council has appointed a contractor to begin work on the 1879 bridge. Concrete work will begin on 19 April and is due to be completed by 17 May. The steel work will follow. The creek is to be drained between the weir and the causeway downstream. Pumping has already begun. The bike track has been closed for the duration of the work and the Senior Citizens’ Garden will also be closed. It is expected the bridge itself will only have to be closed for one day, when the steel beams are placed beneath it. There will then be a detour via Ayers, George and Thames Streets. [Photo]

BCS. Part of the old stone wall on the boundary of the school is currently being repaired.

YAC is pleased with the response to the events that were organised for National Youth Week.

About 30 students attended the Speak Up Forum and 130 attended the Dance Party. Goyder Council matched the $1,300 from the Office of Youth, to enable the events to be held.

Issue 642, 7 April 2004, page 2

Letter from (Red) Danny O’Brien, objecting to the fact that the students who were taught music privately outside the school were excluded from a music concert held for BCS students at the Community Sports Complex on 29 March. Only students being taught privately at the school could participate. This he believed was unfair discrimination.

Letter. Don Lloyd writes objecting to the loss of another piece of the town’s heritage in the removal of the railway bridge. Why not raise it a metre instead of removing it?

Burra Golf Club. Reva Cullen recently took out all the summer golf trophies.

Issue 643, 14 April 2004, page 1

Bowls. Masters Games

Easter Saturday Men’s Fours Jamestown 108 defeated Burra 88

Easter Sunday Cosmopolitan Fours Two Burra teams played out for the title.

Mokota Conservation Park

A controlled burn of 30 ha was trialled to investigate how best to control/reduce pest plants and increase the health and vigour of native grasses in the 455 ha park. Dense ground cover had built up since the park was acquired in 1999, suppressing native grass regrowth and encouraging pest species. Mokota is unusual among the state’s Conservation Parks because it is purely grassland. The dominant species is iron grass (Lomandra multiflora) and it also has two nationally endangered species; the small scurf pea (Cullen parvum) and trailing hopbush (Dodonea procumbens).

Issue 644, 21 April 2004, page 1

Fire. A truck that was refuelling caught fire on Cactus Farm just south of Burra on Thursday. The fire spread rapidly southeast, destroying a haystack, before blowing across paddocks and into Princess Royal, where it ran for several kilometres before being stopped. James Reilly was taken to Adelaide for treatment to his burns and his father Matt Reilly suffered burns to his hands from ripping burning clothing from James. Burra Police, MFS and CFS along with units from Baldina, Mt Bryan, Booborowie, Farrell Flat, Spalding and Clare attended. [Photo]

Kingston St Bridge. Preparatory work has begun for the strengthening of the bridge, with access to the site being organised.

BBH Football. The A Grade team started the year with a win on Saturday, when they defeated North Clare 9.10 to 7.7. This is the team’s first win since defeating Eudunda at the start of the 2002 season.

Birth. To Jodie & Nick Pearce on 26 March, a son, Ashton Thomas.

Birth. To Jeffrey Price & Nicole Hussey on 3 April, a son, Jasper Ryan.

Obituary. Eric McKenna died on 3 April. He was an art and antique dealer who started in the second hand business in Burra, with a shop in what is now known as the Pharaoh’s Tomb and Burra Antique Centre in 1955*. Later he moved to Adelaide, where he continued to deal in art and antiques.

[I would not place great reliance on this date. Topsfield’s Butcher shop was in that building and was still operating when Topsfield’s sold their business to F. & J. McLean in 1972. Check on the possibility of the small shop immediately north of the butcher’s. There is an advertisement for a sale for McKenna in November 1955, which may indicate when he left.]

Issue 644, 21 April 2004, page 2

Scott & Petra Donaldson were farewelled from Burra recently. They have shifted to Victoria, where Scott will join his father in business.

Marriage. Auburn 25 April

Sueann Devries will marry Luke Scobie. Sueann teaches at BCS. [Her name has previously been recorded as Sue-Ann DeVries or De Vries.]

Letter. Barbara Rayner of Hallett writes re galah recipes. She recalls many years ago that her father used to shoot ducks and even the occasional bush turkey that ended up on their table. Failing that, he sometimes returned with a bag of galahs that the children then had to pluck – a very difficult process. She has since been told that they should have skinned the birds, but that advice came too late. The birds were stewed with onions and herbs and were then regarded as a treat and were not tough.

Issue 644, 21 April 2004, page 3

John Maidment recently located a large echidna in the toilet of the Bazaar building. It seems to have become trapped there. It was subsequently released by National Parks and Wildlife officers in a more suitable environment. [Photo]

Goyder Council honoured two retiring Councillors at a special presentation at Burra Hotel on 20 April. Dennis Keller served on the Robertstown DC 1977-97 before becoming the first Chairman of the Regional Council of Goyder, 1997-2004. Graham Kellock served on Burra Burra DC 1985-97 before becoming Deputy Chairman of the Regional Council of Goyder 1997-2004. [Photo]

Issue 644, 21 April 2004, page 11

Notice. The Regional Council of Goyder. Peter John Niemz has been declared elected to the vacancy of Councillor of Robertstown Ward.

Issue 645, 28 April 2004, page 1

The Anzac Dawn Service was well attended on a chilly morning. Fr Laurie Quinn was in charge.

Burra Picnic Race Club

Life Member, John Oates writes of the committee’s desire to have one last meeting in 2005. Dwindling numbers of committee members makes it likely that would be the last meeting – and even that is dependent on being able to obtain public liability insurance at a reasonable cost.

AGL is considering a major expansion of its Hallett power plant. It has lodged a development application that would more than double the generating capacity of the gas fired peaking power plant. This reflects the view that demand for peaking power generating capacity will continue to grow. Development plans and consultations would take to the end of 2005 and actual building, if work goes ahead, would not be completed before late 2007 or early 2008.

Issue 645, 28 April 2004, page 2

Sandy Taylor writes to thank Burra for being so welcoming and supportive of a single mother with three children. She is about to move on.

Burra Senior citizens celebrated Anzac Day at their April meeting with many stories of the war. Included in their number were Ben Kotz, Jack Oates and Bill Hughes, who were enlisted WWII soldiers. Laurel Neill and Aileen Kelly recalled knitting socks for the Defence Forces Comfort Fund during WWII.

Cameron Paul is the recently appointed Livestock salesperson for Landmark in Burra. He replaces Scott Donaldson and comes to Burra from Melrose. [Photo]

Issue 645, 28 April 2004, Supplement

A3 folded to make four pages: Visitor’s Guide to Burra Antique Fair.

Issue 646, 5 May 2004, page 1

Princess Royal Feedlot

The owner of Princess Royal Station, Simon Rowe, says there will be no increased traffic along Ayers Street in Burra as a result of the proposed feedlot on the property. Plans for the lot have been put out for public consultation by Goyder Council. Trucks will use the Old Adelaide Road entrance. Some local residents of Ayers Street have started a petition asking for a load limit on Ayers Street. Jenny Carter says that heavy commercial traffic to and from Princess Royal has been increasing for some months. The application before Council does not make clear what route the feedlot trucks would take.

Roger Cross, who owns two properties on Ayers Street, has lodged an objection to heavy traffic such as B-doubles using Ayers Street, saying that their vibrations would damage old cottages along the street with earth foundations and also the miners’ dugouts. There would also be dangers for children, pedestrians and cars passing trucks on the narrow road. Des Woolley, another resident of the street, says it is too narrow and too lightly built for the mass of vehicles the proposal would generate – added to which, he fears that much of the traffic would be nocturnal.

Constable Anthony Baldino is the new police officer at the Burra station. He transferred recently from Pt Augusta with his wife and 2-year-old daughter.

Annie’s Lane Clare Valley Tourism Awards

Gaslight Collectables & Old Books won the Associated Tourism Business Award.

Stephanie Crowley won an award for courtesy.

Issue 646, 5 May 2004, page 2

Elaine & Alan Ogden became Australian citizens at a ceremony at the Goyder Council offices on 1 April.

The Ulysses Motorcycle Club visited Burra over the weekend.

The Equestrian Federation of Australia put on a three day school at the showgrounds over the weekend.

June & Don Norris have celebrated their Golden Wedding.

Eudunda Quilters have an exhibition at present in the Burra Regional Art Gallery.

Issue 646, 5 May 2004, page 3

Burra’s 13th Antique Fair drew crowds at the weekend. About 1,200 went through the doors over the two days.

Burra Liberal Party Branch had a cocktail party at the Burra Golf Club on Friday last. The guest speaker was Vicki Chapman, the Member for Bragg.

Burra Community Development Program Inc. (BCDP) was established in June 2000 following a special meeting of Main Street, as a new committee to manage a Working Towns Project, to prepare a report for the Goyder Council with recommendations for a management structure for the Burra Town Hall. Council handed the management of the hall to the BCDP in October 2001. At the November 2003 AGM there was insufficient interest to fill the vacant committee positions. At present the BCDP and its sub-committees are in abeyance. If the committee cannot fill its positions the BCDP will fold and the Town Hall and its Telecentre will close its doors to the community. The hard work has been done. Much renovation has been accomplished at the hall and monies have been raised. A public meeting at the Town Hall on 13 May at 6.30 p.m. will decide the future of the BCDP.

Issue 647, 12 May 2004, page 1

Burra Hospital Auxiliary has donated to the hospital a monitor/defibrillator valued at more than $13,000 and two electric beds. The Bon Accord Hotel has donated a further $500 towards another electric bed. During the year there have been donations for two more electric beds worth $4,156. Holder Home has now been completed and will open on 23 May.

Office bearers for 2004-05 are: President, Celine Stockman; Vice President, Pauline Venning; Secretary, Avis Webster; Treasurer, Murray Tiver and Assistant Treasurer, Jill Lunn.

Issue 647, 12 May 2004, page 2

Paul Smedley and his wife Lone live in Skive, Jutland (part of Denmark). Paul is now an apprentice pastry cook. [Photo of Paul, Lone and children Mathilde and Mikkel.]

Red Cross 45th Northern Zone Conference was held in Peterborough. A Ten Year Service badge was presented to Elva Broad of Burra. Fay Jones of Burra received a Thirty Year Service Bar.

Goyder Council has commenced a review of master planning options for Market Square and Best Place. There will be consultation with the community as a precursor to detailed design and ultimate capital works. Repairs, replacement and maintenance over the past twenty years have slowly changed the character of Market Square and Best Place. Market Square is now a mixture of different paving materials, landscaping, public lighting and other street furniture. One aim is to win back public space from bitumen in Market Square. Consultants Greg Davis and Edith Mayer of Adelaide firm Hames Sharley have been engaged.

Issue 647, 12 May 2004, page 3

Redbanks Reserve. Some BMX extremists have dug up part of the park to make a track. The area concerned contains fossils, but nothing was taken – only disturbed. The cost of restoration is estimated at $10,000 to $15,000.

Issue 647, 12 May 2004, Supplement

Eight page Mega Health News, Issue 5 – 2004. [Over the counter health supplements & alternative medicines.]

Issue 648, 19 May 2004, page 1

Burra Community Development Committee had a crisis meeting last Thursday night to recruit members needed to keep the Town Hall open, with its Telecentre. Nineteen people turned up and this suggests that the management of the hall is assured. The Internet Centre’s future is less certain, as it would need significant volunteer support.

Theft. Six cars were interfered with at Burra North yesterday morning; two had damage to their ignitions and a Holden HQ Kingswood was stolen, but later abandoned near the passport gate at the Burra Mine.

Andrew Glen of the Burra Visitor centre has initiated a new driving trail through the Lower Mid North Region. The Heartland Trail encourages visitors to visit Gawler, Kapunda, Eudunda, Burra, Mintaro, Auburn and Two Wells. It allows also for side visits to Freeling, Robertstown, Point Pass, Farrell Flat, Balaklava and Mallala.

Copies of the brochure are available from Burra Visitor Centre.

Issue 648, 19 May 2004, page 2

Paxton Square and the Caravan Park recently had 108 walkers for eight nights – members of the Australian Retired Persons Association.

BCS teachers Tatiana Anesbury and Carolyn Allen have won a $5,220 science grant for the school.

Alison Donhardt has graduated with a Masters degree in Palliative Care.

Rostrum Voice of Youth competitors spoke at BCS on Thursday evening. Five juniors spoke for six minutes and one senior spoke for eight minutes on their chosen topic. Then all five had fifteen minutes to prepare their short notice speeches from three given topics. From the group Chelsea Evans and Katie Thomas will compete in the semi-finals in Adelaide on 30 May.

Issue 649, 26 May 2004, page 1

Holder Home at Burra Hospital was officially opened on Sunday 23 May by Cr Laurie Sullivan, Chairman of the Regional Council of Goyder. The home is named after Sir Frederick Holder, first Speaker in the first Federal Parliament in 1901. The cost of the conversion of the building was more than $400,000. Tours of inspection followed the opening. [2 photos]

Goyder Council

Council will seek further submissions from the community before deciding on whether to reduce the number of Councillors from the current 13 and to dispense with wards.

Work on the Kingston St Bridge is progressing well.

The wind-damaged lighting tower at Burra Oval has yet to be replaced.

Andrew Glen of Burra Visitor Centre and the BRTBA President Sue Ryan reported to Council on the Centre’s achievements since the start of 2003.

Council has offered $37,000 yearly towards the running of Burra Visitor Centre.

Fire. An unattended camp fire got away at World’s End Gorge at the weekend, but was soon controlled by CFS units.

Burra Show Society will host a night of entertainment at Burra Town Hall on 5 June as a fundraiser. Special guests will be Ian List – a bush balladeer, Paul O’Bryan and his band, with visiting artists and local talent.

Admission $5 or $2.50 for children under 16.

Issue 649, 26 May 2004, page 2

Market Square Proposal

Plans for changes to the square displayed on Saturday morning offered three alternatives:

Leave it as it is.

Return to a design where cars run right past the shops.

A design with a double row of parking around the curve of the shops, with the north bound lane removed and the south bound lane converted to a two-way flow.

Option three seemed to get more approval than the other two.

An extract from the Burra Record of 16 June 1909 that was printed alongside this article revealed that the 1909 proposal for a central triangular garden with a rotunda was disapproved of by a large section of ratepayers.

Vandalism at the public toilets in Market Street and in the barbecue area caused about $200 damage.

Issue 649, 26 May 2004, page 3

Colin Endean & Anna Szava started planting an olive grove in 1998 at the southern end of Burra. They are now producing a small amount of organically grown olive oil under the brand name C & A. They set up a tasting table outside Beaut Fruit last Friday. They also had Kalamata table olives, in both oil and brine.

Bimbowrie Station has been bought by the SA Government for $2.3 million as a National Park. It is located near the SA-NSW border and comprises 730 square kilometres. Heritage buildings on it include the Field Centre used by Sir Douglas Mawson in his Geological Survey of the Olary Ranges. The station has a number of interesting Geological features. It lies some 30 km north of Olary on the southern edge of the Strzelecki Desert.

Issue 649, 26 May 2004, page 4

Burra Red Cross trading table at the Antique Fair made more than $450.

Issue 649, 26 May 2004, page 5

BBH Social Club organised a ‘Tour de Burra’ that attracted eight teams of participants. In this version of the Great Barrow Push teams involved had to answer questions and collect a set of items to fill their barrow, among other tasks.

Issue 650, 2 June 2004, page 1

Two ‘Big Morning Teas’ were held last week in Burra to raise money for cancer research. Lorna Sutton raised $250 and the other was at the Uniting Church Hall.

The Railway Bridge over the highway at Burra North was removed on 27 May. Roger Kennedy of Clare sent his 30 tonne crane over for the job. In the near future the concrete surrounds will be removed and the embankments will then be sloped back to open up the whole area and improve visibility. [Photo]

BRTBA held its AGM on 25 May. The executive was re-elected: President, Sue Ryan; Vice President, Brenton Greenslade; Secretary, Dee Greenslade and Treasurer, Glynne Ryan. Members voted to continue to manage the Burra Visitor Centre for the period 2005-08. As well as managing the Visitor Centre, sub-committees also ran Jazz in the Monster Mine, Jailhouse Rock and the Antique fair. Planning has begun for the inaugural Wheal Burra Burra Festival of Arts & Culture on 13-14 November.
